2021-07-03T22:14:26.text: Kan ik bij jou blijven pitten misschien?

Safety.body: Don't travel to this country, as there are armed battles going on!!!

About.body: One of the poorest countries in Europe, and therefore maybe one of the most underrated. Even though the roads are not in the best condition, you might like the amazing nature, the awesome beaches and the Albanese hospitality.

FoodDrink.body:
• It is best to go to various food stalls along the way, in small establishments as we know them in Third World countries and in the local markets. There is one important difference, however. Everything has a fixed price, bargaining is only done on luxury goods, not on foodstuffs.
  • There are plenty of restaurants, especially in the vicinity of beautiful panoramas along the way. The menu is usually quite simple (sometimes the choice is even limited to one menu that everyone is served, very cheap). The quality is variable, but usually acceptable. In the south of Albania, the cuisine is mainly Greek. There are also many pizzas and pastas available. Pilaf (rice with sauce) is a much consumed dish. However, you shouldn't go to Albania for culinary delights. Along the way you will also come across plenty of shops where you can buy some food and drinking water.
  • (Jurriaan Rot, 2009) I did not get sick from the tap water in the north and north-east, but I was only there for about four days. It does not seem wise to drink tap water everywhere. There are lovely cool streams in the mountains; if you sit high enough, that water is perfectly drinkable (note if there is a village and / or cattle above it).

People.body:
• Despite the sometimes bitter poverty, a friendly and lively people where hospitality is of paramount importance. Albanians are jovial, friendly, helpful and have plenty of time, especially in the countryside outside the bigger cities.
  • Young children are often waving exuberantly along the road. Boys on their rickety bike often ride in front of you and do all kinds of revolutions on the bike, (to impress?), Then suddenly brake with a wide swipe and then look curiously at you. Sometimes they want to compete with you who can go the fastest, you on your - in their eyes: impressive and flashy - bicycle with 21 gears or they on their rickety cart.
  • Albania is a country with a mixed population ranging from Muslims to Christians and Orthodox. Albanians are not very religious.
  • Where many tourists come, it has already been discovered that they spend a lot of money by Albanian standards. In the museum cities of Gjirokaster and Berat they even try to rip off all the tourists. Firm action sometimes helps. The condition is that you respect the average prices that are used elsewhere in the country.
  • Tip: learn some Albanian expressions and they will no longer regard you as a tourist but as a guest!
  • Up in the mountains and everywhere where no tourists come yet, people can be trusted, although it is important not to show off your wealth here either. They even make it a point of honor to invite you to spend the night and provide you with plenty of food. Do respect the rules of conduct.

-MGIX3atbML2oqNQ0TP8.description: This route goes from Montenegro to the capital and 2 uNesco heritage's. It will bring you to Greece eventually. It's quite a hilly ride, but also very beautiful.
-MGIX3atbML2oqNQ0TP8.title: Montenegro to Greece

Safety.body_traffic:
• Loaded donkeys, donkey carts and horse and cart are still fully part of the traffic, although this is already a rarity in the cities. Many Albanians own a smoky and rattling car and everyone should know that. Loudly honking, they skim over the continuous asphalt roads. Also in the cities you constantly hear horns and you almost suffocate in the smelly exhausts of disrupted engines.
  • Where the roads are asphalted, which are most connecting roads between the cities, people drive as fast as the car or road surface allows. Because speed limits of 80 km / h or 40 km / h (cities) are only adhered to when police are in the area.
  • In stark contrast to this are the roads that run through the mountains. Here you will only encounter 2 or 3 vehicles per day. The mountain roads all look alike, although the map suggests otherwise. Only the people on the spot can tell you with certainty whether you are on the right track.

-MGIOIleGTqojO9isrQD.description: This UNESCO heritage around lake Ohrid offers some ancient natural life, as well as medieval buildings.
-MGIOIleGTqojO9isrQD.description_first: This UNESCO heritage around lake Ohrid offers some ancient natural life, as well as medieval buildings.
-MGIOIleGTqojO9isrQD.title: Ohrid region

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Campsites are practically non-existent. There seems to be one near Sarande. White gasoline for gas fires is very difficult to find. Simple piercing cartridges for camping gas fires can be found everywhere.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
You can spend the night in good hotels in Albania for about 10 euros per person and the reception was always excellent. A place for the bicycles was always arranged without any complaints.
In the big cities there are sometimes smaller private hotels near the big international hotels; they are atmospheric, you are treated kindly, led to an excellent room, and a place for your bicycle is cleared.

Transport.body_airplane: Taking the bicycle with you differs per company. Always wise to inquire about the conditions when booking. An option is to fly to Corfu and then cross by ferry to Sarande. The crossing takes about 45 minutes and costs 25 euros. Of course you can also take the boat from Corfu to the Greek mainland and then cycle into Albania, which is quite adventurous. Another option is to fly to Ohrid in Macedonia. Until now, this is only possible in the summer. Ohrid airport is only 15 kilometers from the Albanian border.
Transport.body_boat:
Several times a week boats sail to Albania from the Italian airports of Ancona, Bari, Brindisi and even Trieste. Please note that meals on board of these companies are not included in the price. There are also regular ferry services from Corfu, just off the coast. If you buy a boat ticket in Albania, you have to pay it in cash. More information about boats can be found at http://www.cemar.it/ferries/1_ferries.html

There are also ferry services between the different port cities, but these do not sail very often and are mainly focused on freight transport.
Transport.body_bus: Because buses are always packed, it is very difficult to get a bicycle with you. The preferred means of transport is a minivan. It is slightly more expensive than a regular bus, but still cheap. If he has space, the driver will gladly take your bike.
Transport.body_train: There is no international train connection with Albania. You can take your bike on the various train routes after some insistence. Your bicycle will then be placed on the front of the locomotive and monitored by the conductor. There is no place to park a bicycle in the trains themselves. Keep in mind that the train runs bizarrely slowly and stops very often. An experience!

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Albania without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: A former Portuguese colony, and a country with a history that is more about war than peace. For a long time this place was difficult for people to enter, but with the new president this rough diamond opens its doors, where you can find a unique hospitality and some stunning sights.

66336938-b0bb-478e-9ef1-a1cf40b68a82.description: The name of the shop is Clawana and run by Igor. He has race and mountain bikes, and fixed my tourbike. I had problems with the hydraulic Maguira brakes. He fixed one brake, and replaced the other with mechanical. He only charged money for the new parts, but I gave him a little extra. Nice guy and professional. Fixed my bike the same day. You can contact him on +244923525446.
66336938-b0bb-478e-9ef1-a1cf40b68a82.title: Clawana

Border.body: From the exclave Cabinda to the main land or otherwise, you can take a small airplane. The bicycle has to be shipped. There is no other option to this, other than crossing DRC. There is information on how to do that on iOverlander, but feel free to contact me (Bas Idsinga) on WhatsApp to ask me anything.

1723a3ec-52ed-4ebf-8ebc-667181ac9162.comment: I had a good experience with getting this visa!

d6d5403f-ddc5-44fd-bed5-db9205e1ac96.description: Getting the e-visa is by far the easiest option, however, you might need to fake some documents. If they approve your application, they email the document in less than 24 hours. On the website they ask for a few documents to upload. One of the documents is a return ticket, but as a cycler you might not be able to provide it. You can create a fake ticket on http://returnflights.net/, and for me (Bas Idsinga) this worked. Also, you need a letter of invitation, but you might not have it either. People in the West African WhatsApp group can help you with this. You pay the visa at the border, bring 120 USD in cash. Extensions can be obtained in Luanda, Benguela and Lubango. 1 month extension costs around 12.000 Kwanza (20 USD).

FoodDrink.body: The Angolese kitchen is quite nice. Fish can be found almost anymore. A very delicious meal is bitoque, which contains rice, fries, egg and steak. On the road you can find bread, fruit and vegetables and cookies.

-MGOXMAljS_yV8whOWm7.description: This route starts in Soyo, where the small airport is located to fly over DRC, and goes through Luanda and eventually all the way to the main border crossing with Namibia at Oshikango.
-MGOXMAljS_yV8whOWm7.title: North to South

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities, especially Luanda.

-MGOoYXB7xpKRzriFl39.description: With Tundavala and Serra da Leba as absolute highlights of the country, these are must visit places. Look down over a dazzling road on a mountain pass, or see how a mountain suddenly drops about 800 m.
-MGOoYXB7xpKRzriFl39.description_first: With Tundavala and Serra da Leba as absolute highlights of the country, these are must visit places. Look down over a dazzling road on a mountain pass, or see how a mountain suddenly drops about 800 m.
-MGOoYXB7xpKRzriFl39.title: Lubango region

-MGOod6vRAkt57Sqds7H.description: North of Luanda is shipwreck beach, where about 40 ships are rusting away in the salty ocean. South of Luanda is the divine moon landscape, or basically eroding colorful cliffs.
-MGOod6vRAkt57Sqds7H.description_first: North of Luanda is shipwreck beach, where about 40 ships are rusting away in the salty ocean. South of Luanda is the divine moon landscape, or basically eroding colorful cliffs.
-MGOod6vRAkt57Sqds7H.title: Luanda region

-MGOoiv1FbwrOZfdfEA1.description: Around Sumbe you can cycle a big circle through beautiful landscapes including the waterfall do Binga and some huge bold granite rocks.
-MGOoiv1FbwrOZfdfEA1.description_first: Around Sumbe you can cycle a big circle through beautiful landscapes including the waterfall do Binga and some huge bold granite rocks.
-MGOoiv1FbwrOZfdfEA1.title: Sumbe region

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts. Luanda has a few nice Warmshower hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Most cities have accomodation. Room with fan should be around 5.000 AOA, with AC a bit more.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, there are quite some good spots to do. But make sure you are informed well about the landmines that might still be spread.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa. Getting the e-visa is quite easy, although you may need to fake some documents (like the return ticket and letter of invitation).


Source: Wikipedia.

Some nationalities can enter Antigua and Barbuda without a visa for up to 30 or 180 days.

Visa policy of Antigua and Barbuda

About.body: Argentina is a well known destination by a vast majority of long distance cyclists. For many cyclists, this is either the end or the beginning of a world trip, as Patagonia is also called "Fin Del Mundo" a.k.a. "The end of the world". With plenty of good food, friendly people, amazing landscapes (and unfortunately also headwind), it's hard to not fall in love with Argentina.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
  • Petrol at the pump is clean, it will not clog the burner.
  • "Benzina blanca" can be found at paint stores. The name "benzina blanca" is not recognized everywhere in Argentina. 'Solvante' (or something like that) is a well-known term, but I don't know whether it is real petroleum jelly.
Markets
  • Depending on the area.
Supermarkers
  • In larger centers
  • Good choice
  • Argentina produces some tasty cheeses (rather expensive) and fantastic wines: you can find really good bottles from 30 pesos
Neighborhood stores
  • All the essential provisions
  • Fresh vegetables / fruit often limited in stock
  • Often fresh bread
  • In the North often 'difficult' opening hours. From 9 a.m. to about 1 p.m. and then open again from 6 p.m. or even 7 p.m. until 9 p.m.
Street markers
  • Rather in the north
Recommended
  • Humitas: fresh, warm corn snack
  • Lomito: steak sandwich
  • Hamburguesas: wafer-thin hamburger with an egg and some vegetables
Restaurants
  • Argentines like to eat well
  • Restaurants open at 9 pm and only fill up from 10 pm
  • With an emphasis on meat ("parrilla"), but also vegetarians usually get their money's worth. In large cities there is often a vegetarian restaurant. The vegetarian restaurant in San Juan is a must.
  • Pizza and pasta are available
  • Quite cheap
  • In the north many restaurants are unheated, sometimes a pot of glowing coals is shoved under your table, but in the cold season you should dress warmly (hat!) at the restaurant
Fast Snack
  • Many in larger cities
  • Hamburguesa, lomito
  • Pizza: cheese is the main ingredient
Drinkable water
  • Reliable mountain / spring water in the lake area
  • Often bottled water because of the taste of the tap water
  • Be careful with polluted river water in mining areas
  • Water filter not necessary if you regularly venture into residential areas
Wine
  • Bodega visit around San Rafael, Mendoza, La Rioja and Cafayate: sometimes a reservation is required
  • Mostly free, often interesting tours
  • Tasting session usually with entry-level wines
Meat
  • Almost always on the grill, "parrilla"
  • Fried with the fat on it, which provides the flavor
  • Lamb tastes different in every region
  • Delicious goat meat ("chivito") in the area around Bariloche
No meat
  • Soy products are good for vegetarians.
  • Soy burgers (Milanesas de soya) are in the freezer at almost every supermarket.
  • Dried soy chunks (Carne de soya) (ideal to take away) are available at health food stores in the larger towns.

Health.body:
Mandatory Vaccinations
No ;)

Availability hospitals / doctors
  • General hospitals only in larger centers, very good healthcare
  • In small villages there is usually a centro de salud
  • The knowledge in hospitals is up to date
  • Quite a few north americans go on "Hospital holidays" in buenos aires because of the low fees
  • Because hospitals often work with north american partners, advanced treatments / drugs can be more expensive than in europe

Other.body:
Roads
  • Most main roads have only two lanes and a narrow hard shoulder. Gradients of more than 8% are very exceptional on asphalt roads.
  • Gravel roads ("ripio") are usually passable but dusty in heavy traffic.
  • Regularly long strips of corrugated roads.
  • Smaller, less-used routes are rough, with large pits and jagged stones.
  • spicy incline percentages.
  • Road works or "improvement works" are extra difficult, with long strips of loose gravel.
Density of infrastructure
  • looking at the map twice a day is usually sufficient.
  • unless you really want to go off-road, a general road map is enough, on which a distinction is made between asphalted and unpaved roads.
  • there are not many alternative routes.
  • On the basis of the map you can estimate how busy the road will be: you can expect some traffic between two large cities (+ 300,000 inhabitants). Perhaps you can map out a long route in such a way that you mainly visit smaller cities.
Best period to cycle
Seasons
you will find different climate types in the country.
  • South: best from November to March.
  • North (east) and: best from March to November.
  • First snow in Bariloche: May.
  • In the whole area that parallels the Andes north of San Rafael, there is little chance of precipitation.
Tourist High Season
  • December to February for Patagonia, our July to September for the northwest (Salta and Jujuy).
  • Domestic holiday periods: January, Easter, July.
Prevailing wind directions
  • Patagonia: mainly from the west. This can sometimes improve considerably during the day. Make sure you have some leeway in your planning.
  • day and night (often less at night): a factor to take into account!
  • North-west: depending on weather conditions and relief, the wind often picks up as the day goes on.
Average temperature
depending on the region, altitude and climate type.

Spare parts
  • All imports are expensive because of the high import taxes.
  • 26 ”tires are most common.
  • The quality of the inner tubes varies.
  • Schwalbe is barely available.
  • Shimano parts are common, in larger cities spare parts are generally available.
  • In some regions (Bariloche, Mendoza, ...) cycling is on the rise, you will find repairers with an extensive range of spare parts.
  • The quality of the services varies.
Tips
  • Have a stick that sticks out half a meter on the left side of your bike and hang a red flag or ribbon on it.
  • On the way to El Chalten or El Calafate you better cycle on a piece of pampas plains along the road, when a strong headwind is blowing from the Andes. As indicated earlier, car and truck traffic hardly take into account the dire circumstances in which a cyclist finds itself.
  • It is nice to bring an inflatable globe.
  • Showing your feet to someone is considered a humiliation.
  • People don't like to answer NO to questions, so if you ask for directions, people will often answer YES.

People.body: Interested and open population. Good knowledge of their own country, even though they usually haven't traveled it themselves. You can also have good conversations about politics (and the past). Communication with the local people is in Spanish. People sometimes speak English around the metropolis, but knowledge is limited in the countryside.

Safety.body: Argentina is a safe country. In Buenos Aires, take your precautions as in any unknown metropolis. Some areas are for tourists and very unsafe.
Safety.body_traffic:
• Argentina is a mixture of new, fast and old, unreliable vehicles. There are relatively many casualties in traffic
  • cycling in and around Buenos Aires is not recommended due to the heavy traffic
  • the connecting roads between (really) large centers are just too busy for relaxed cycling.
  • when driving in and out of a slightly larger city it is always very busy
  • away from civilization it is usually very quiet, most people take the bus to cover greater distances.
  • drivers usually also give ample space
  • bus drivers are the most "professional": they often leave no more than half a meter in between
  • lorries and buses usually pull over, but if an oncoming vehicle approaches, you have to pay extra attention because not all drivers know where the brakes are. Sometimes we drove into the verge as a precaution, which is also appreciated by the drivers of (heavy) trucks.

67fd25d6-43fc-4ebf-885d-5582248c9c54.description: The capital of Argentina, which has more than a 100 km of bicycle paths.
67fd25d6-43fc-4ebf-885d-5582248c9c54.title: Buenos Aires

a78b421f-ffba-4b51-8eaf-96e31b70f75a.description: A small town surrounded by colorfull mountains named "Quebrada de las Conchas".
a78b421f-ffba-4b51-8eaf-96e31b70f75a.title: Cafayate - Quebrada de las Conchas

e1d29df6-7929-4992-8714-d8c68b660dd6.description: This is not a single point, but an incredibly large area in the Southern end of Argentina. This very open and isolated piece of land does have dramatic sceneries. You better hope that you got tailwind in this place.
e1d29df6-7929-4992-8714-d8c68b660dd6.title: Patagonia

e510f821-f693-41f6-bbc4-e6acae72ac6f.description: A few impressive rock formations inside the National Park Talampaya.
e510f821-f693-41f6-bbc4-e6acae72ac6f.title: El Totem de Talampaya

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
Couchsurfing and Warmshowers exists in Argentina, but mostly in cities. There are a few other phenomena around. 

Estancia's / Finca's / Hacienda's
Even if the hacienda is not furnished for tourism, you can usually go here for water and a camping pitch. After the crisis  (2008), many estancias passed into foreign hands and are no longer inhabited permanently, you cannot adjust your planning accordingly.

Casas Particulares
  • in almost every small village
  • usually good contact, warm atmosphere
  • boiler of the shower is fired with wood
  • you usually cook yourself
  • 5-12 euros / room
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Bringing a tent increases the travel comfort: you cannot always estimate whether you will find a place to sleep in the next village. In some areas you cycle from one village to the other for a day. Unless you are very limited in time and area and you are well informed about the climate, you will need a warm sleeping bag. Except in the lake area around Bariloche and in a few tourist centers, there is little equipped camping facilities. In the larger towns there is usually a Camping Municipal. Most people know where to find the next campsite. In terms of distance, that can be a day of cycling. In Catamarca, for example, many of these campsites are unattended.
If you do get stranded somewhere where there is no sleeping accommodation, you can often go to the police station. The policemen often like that very much, then they experience something again, the photos of a previous cyclist are soon looked up from a drawer.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Youth hostels will cost around 10 euro.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
• In the pampa you can pitch your tent anywhere, often the land is cordoned off with barbed wire.
  • Often there is no water and no shelter; a dry river bed is ideal.
  • Be careful with thorns.
  • In some areas the land is lined with barbed wire along the road.
  • It is often more convenient (water, shelter) to ask in a village / hamlet where you can pitch your tent.

Transport.body_airplane: Return flights to Buenos Aires are the cheapest. Watch out for bicycle transport. The rules are different for every company. For example, at Iberia you can carry 32 kg of luggage, but the bicycle is included if you return with a stopover, Keep in mind that the souvenirs you buy tax-free at the airport must be brought in your hand luggage. You cannot buy wine at the airport, you have to pack it with your luggage in advance.
Transport.body_boat: Freight boats regularly depart from Europe and moor in Buenos Aires three weeks later. Not a cheap option, count on at least 150 US $ per day.
Transport.body_bus:
• The bus is the most obvious means of transport for really long distances. Buy your ticket, if you can, preferably one day in advance. Count on a week to get out of Ushuaia during peak season. Mention that you are bringing a bicycle when you purchase your ticket
  • You pay extra, also give a tip to the person who loads and unloads the luggage.
  • In principle, you can always take your bicycle with you, but modern biplanes have relatively little luggage space
  • remove the front wheel, even if they say beforehand that it is not necessary. A bicycle with a front wheel is often just a bit too big for the luggage compartment.
  • sometimes you have to partially pack the bike.
  • try to load your bike first (upright against the wall) or last (lying flat on the rest of the luggage)
  • help with loading, so you know that your bike will not end up under a pile of suitcases
  • sometimes your bicycle is transported separately by truck
  • with regional buses your bicycle is sometimes transported on the roof.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Argentina without a visa. The transitions from neighboring countries run smoothly. You can get in and out as often as you want. Visas are valid for 3 months. Then you have to get out of the country and back in again. When you come in, you have to fill in a form declaring the goods you have with you. You must keep this record and hand it over when you leave the country

Visa policy of Argentina
  Argentina
  Entry possible with ID card or Passport
  Visa-free
  Visa required
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
A regular meal in people's homes usually consists of meat, bread, tomato, cheese, watermelon and lots and lots of vodka. And there is a lot of fruit, especially in August and September.

Stalls on the street
There is not much for sale in villages, but a lot can be obtained. In this country you do not need large stocks, you can always go to people to eat. You will automatically be invited.

Restaurants
There are some restaurants along the major roads. I do not know whether that is expensive because I did not have to pay. The quality is good and it is safe.
There is a lot of fruit and vegetables, so vegetarian dishes will not be a problem

Drinkable water
Samuel drank the tap water, but he does in every country. So he does not know whether it is safe for everyone. The spring water from the fountains along the way is reliable and delicious.

Other.body:
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
Armenia is a mountainous country so in the summer it can be warm in the valleys but cool in the mountains. You can actually cycle well from june to september. Cold and snow are to be expected in other seasons.

Spare parts
There is hardly any cycling so take enough parts with you. It will also be difficult to find a bicycle shop in Yerevan.

Bicycle repairers
There are (almost) no bicycle repairers, but they know how to find a repairer, welder or some other technical man who can fix something.

People.body:
Communication with the local people
  • The population speaks Armenian and Russian and a few young people speak some English, especially in Yerevan. Only with English you can go a bit. Try to learn some Russian, it can be very useful
  • It is a Christian country. You can cycle in a shirt and shorts without any problems. People are not used to cyclists at all, it is still a strange phenomenon in this country (2006). There is a bit of cycling in Yerevan.
Hospitality people
  • Samuel finds the population extremely hospitable and also very generous.
  • If you arrive in a village at the end of the day and ask for a camping pitch, you are assured of meal and accommodation. I only had to pitch my tent twice in this country and for the rest I always ate and slept in people's homes. You also get a lot, a lot of fruit (grapes, watermelon, etc.)
  • Blanche (May 2014) "I would be reluctant to accept food and the like. The people are indeed generous but also very poor. They are often self-sufficient and you do not want to eat someone's winter stock. Make sure to bring enough food of your own."

Safety.body:
• Samuel (2006): "I cycled through it alone and never felt unsafe. The people are extremely helpful and caring. Just watch out for drunk drivers on the road."
  • Samuel (2006): "Minbuza does not recommend traveling in Ngoro-Karabakh. I have been there for a day and many Armenians also go on holiday. The area itself is not unsafe at all, but you should avoid the border areas with Azerbaijan It is said that there is shooting, but I do not know if that is the case. "
  • In Armenia you have a lot of problems with dogs. Be on the lookout for aggressive dogs everywhere, you will see them everywhere. But a rock or a spray of water usually helps.
  • Apart from the dogs, Samuel has not had any unpleasant experiences and has not heard this from other travelers.
  • Blanche (May 2014) "We also felt safe. There is hardly any traffic, the dogs dim when you raise your voice or get off and people leave you alone while camping"

38cbdc9c-b578-4c0f-b5b3-349ce8011316.description: A 9th-century Armenian Apostolic monastery located on a plateau.
38cbdc9c-b578-4c0f-b5b3-349ce8011316.title: Tatev monastery

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: • Samuel (2006) has seen few campsites in 2006 and wonders if they are there.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
• You don't need hotels outside of Yerevan, you can go to people everywhere. Do not hesitate to just ask, they really all think it is great to have cyclists at home. In Yerevan, there is a relatively affordable backpacker homestay close to the Opera House.
  • Blanche 2014 - I have trouble with the above. Many people in Armenia are very poor, take care of your own sleeping place and food.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: • Blanche (2014): Wild camping is possible anywhere.

Visa.body:
Quite some nationalities can enter Armenia without a visa. Some other nationalities need to obtain a visa.


Source: Wikipedia.

Some nationalities (blue countries in the below map) can enter Aruba without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: The outback, also called the red center, is characterized by its endless desert plains where road trains demarcate the roads as their territory, but is very contrasted with the east coast. The Great Dividing Mountains are the gateway to the world's best-preserved rainforests, the Great Barrier Reef, bustling metropolitan areas and sun-drenched national parks bordering exotic bays. In short, Australia is the land of contrasts. In addition, the country has an enormous variety of wildlife. The hospitality of the people, not only inland but also along the coast, takes you to places you never dreamed of and gives you a reassuring feeling everywhere and at all times.

FoodDrink.body:
• In Australia the distances between places can be great. It is therefore important to consider before the start of the stage where food and drinks can be bought.
  • In the larger towns there is a very reasonable range of cheap restaurants and snack bars for various cuisines. The smaller places usually have to make do with only fish and chips.
  • In many towns there is a pub. Some pubs also serve food.
  • Supermarkets are available in all towns from about 1,000 inhabitants and are well sorted. In smaller towns there is often a General Store with a limited stock.
  • In the outback you are often dependent on roadhouses. The availability of food is often limited there.
  • In and around the cities you can drink water from the tap. However, it often contains chlorine, so that the water does not taste too good.
  • Drinking water (unbottled) is available at all roadhouses and petrol stations. Only occasionally is it refused. There are drinking water tanks in various parking places. The water supply of these tanks is not always certain. A few times you will find an empty tank and sometimes you will find maggots in the water.
Fuel
  • It is not easy to obtain Coleman gas cartridges in supermarkets or at petrol stations. Coleman gas cartridges can be found in specialty stores for outdoor sports. Camping-gaz, on the other hand, can be found almost everywhere. For those who cook with a coleman fire, it is advisable to bring an adapter with which you can adjust your fire, so that you can cook with both coleman and camping-gaz cartridges. This is because the threads of coleman and camping-gaz gas cartridges are different from each other.
Supermarkets
  • When planning your trip, keep in mind that food prices are considerably higher than for example in the Netherlands. In 2010 in the large supermarkets about 2.5 x the Dutch prices and in shops in small towns to almost 4x as much.
  • There are plenty of supermarkets in every major city. There will usually also be a supermarket in villages with more than 1000 inhabitants. In the smaller villages, on the other hand, there is sometimes a grocery store where you can only buy the basic necessities.
  • Also on caravan parcs there is usually a small shop where you can purchase the essentials. Please note: prices can rise here.
  • You can also stock up at road houses in the outback. Do not forget that you have to pay even more money here because of the transport that is done by road trains that you will undoubtedly pay for.

Health.body:
• Above Australia is the so-called hole in the ozone layer. This makes the UV rays stronger than normal. You can get skin cancer from these UV rays. It is therefore important to apply sunscreen every day. Factor 30 is recommended.
  • Because much of Australia has a very hot and dry climate, you run a high risk of drying out. In extremely hot weather it is necessary to drink a lot of water.
  • No vaccinations are required for Australia
  • Sand flies can make life pretty difficult for you. Provide a mosquito net with extra fine mesh. Especially in the tropical north, living without a mosquito net can be a nightmare.

Other.body:
Buying a bicycle
  • There are no second-hand bicycles for sale in bicycle shops. You can go to bikeexchange.com.au. Here, new and second-hand bicycles are offered by private individuals and shops.
  • In Perth (Western Australia) you can rent good bicycles at About Bike Hire. If required, they also supply front carriers, waterproof panniers, bottle cages, tools and repair items.
  • Touring bike brands that you mainly come across: Fuji Touring, Surly and Vivente.
Roads and traffic
  • The Highway National 1 that runs through and around Australia is well paved. The roads in the interior (the outback) are wider than on the coast because of the road trains that carry enormous loads. The roads along the coast are also much busier, especially in the east and southeast. The secondary roads are less busy but narrower and therefore sometimes dangerous, especially when motorhomes and caravans pass by.
  • Graval roads can be very different. Sometimes they are easy gravel roads, then miserable washboard roads where you always look for the best tracks to drive, but you can hardly find them. Dirt roads also occur. It is almost impossible to cycle on it and the only way to get through is to push your bike further.
  • The Stuart Highway runs through the interior of Australia and connects north and south. Only the Barkly Highway connects the interior with the east coast. Once you leave the highway you will end up on unpaved roads that run right through the desert. There are few or no facilities along the way.
  • Along the east and southeast coast you will find a denser road network where alternative routes can be made.
  • To the west, the Great Northern Highway runs from Darwin to Perth. An alternative route is the Gibb River Road, a dirt road covering a distance of more than 600 km between Kununurra and Derby.
  • South of Perth, on the other hand, there is a denser road network which is an alternative to the sparsely populated areas in the outback and along the west coast.
Best cycling season
  • Autumn and spring are the best cycling seasons. In summer (december to february) it is very hot and in the north it is also very humid. An exception to this rule is tasmania, where it is pleasant to stay in the summer.
  • The north of australia only has a dry and a wet season.
  • The average temperature throughout the year is 30 ° c.
  • The dry season runs from may to october.
  • The wet season runs from november to april.
  • The interior has a desert climate. Temperatures of more than 40 ° c in summer are not uncommon. The nights, on the other hand, can be cold and the temperature sometimes drops below freezing point. If you can't stand this heat, avoid this area in the months of june-july-august. From may to september there is hardly a drop of rainfall inland.
  • The south has a more moderate climate. Still, it can get quite hot during the summer months, especially around adelaide and melbourne. But don't be surprised by the changeable weather. When the warm wind turns from the north to the cold antarctic winds, the temperature can suddenly drop by more than 20 ° c. Four seasons in one day may well apply here. The best time to cycle here seems to me from october to march.
  • In july / august the south (sydney-melbourne) is doable. It is chilly in the morning, but during the day you can usually cycle with shorts and short sleeves. The disadvantage of this period is that it is dark early in the evening, around 5:30 pm.
 Parts and repair
  • Specialized bicycle shops, where parts that are also available in the netherlands are sold, there are in the larger towns from about 5,000 inhabitants. In australia, parts are mainly available for mountain bikes or racing bikes. For example, it can be difficult to find good tires for a bicycle with 28 inch rims.
  • Every place of any size has something: like toy shops, where bicycle parts are available and where they can refer you to someone who fixes bicycles. The range is limited and of mediocre quality.
  • In every hamlet, however, there is a garage where an emergency repair can be arranged.
  • You will find bicycle repairers in every major city. In the small towns or villages it is not always certain that there is a bicycle repair shop.
  • The most common wheel size in australia is 26 inches.
  • It is sometimes difficult to find 28inc wheels and / or tires. For this you can best go to the big cities.
  • Tires are also often of asian manufacture. The quality sometimes leaves something to be desired. It is also best to look for this in the big cities.
  • Other parts such as chain and sprockets, brake and gear cables, derailleurs, ... Are easy to find at any bicycle maker and often of good quality.

People.body: Because English is spoken everywhere, it is easy to communicate with the people. Hospitality is highly regarded. At camping sites or caravan parcs you rarely or never have to take the initiative to make contact with others. As a cyclist you immediately attract attention, and that raises many questions among locals. You are almost daily invited for a cup of coffee and a pleasant chat, dinner together, and cyclists are often invited to stay at their home. Not for a day or weekend, even for a period of a few weeks. Never hesitate to accept this invitation.

Safety.body:
A helmet is mandatory throughout Australia.

Australia is a safe country. Tom: "I have never had an unsafe feeling in Australia. Especially in the countryside I was not afraid that something would be stolen. Motorists with caravans and boats are unsafe. They often do not realize how big the colossus is. they peddle along ".
Safety.body_nature:
• Sand flies can make life pretty difficult for you. Provide a mosquito net with extra fine mesh. Especially in the tropical north, living without a mosquito net can be a nightmare.
  • Snakes can pop up anywhere, but are never a danger without provocation. 90 percent of snake bites occur on or under the ankle. So protection is the best guarantee against snake bites. It is best to wear boots above the ankle.
  • Australia has 2 types of crocodiles. Fresh and salt water crocodiles. Freshwater crocodiles (freshies) live in freshwater rivers, lakes and tributaries and are very shy. The saltwater crocodiles (salties) grow to 6 meters long and are a problem. They occur in fresh and salt water.
  • Wise with crocodiles:
  1. Keep your eyes open
  2. Do not feed them or disturb them
  3. Avoid areas where large crocodiles or their nests have been seen
  4. Do not stand on trunks in shallow water
  5. If you are going for a swim, find a shallow spot
  6. Swim in a group rather than alone
  7. Pay close attention to warning signs before camping
  • Australia also has poisonous and non-poisonous spiders. The most famous poisonous spiders are the Funnel web and the Red Back Spider. These are tiny spiders but have a deadly poison.
  1. Never leave your shoes outside, always take them with you in the tent
  2. Never feel with your hands on a tree trunk or under branches and leaves
  3. Always close your tent when you leave them
  4. Be careful while tearing down your tent
  5. Spiders can hide under the groundsheet.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
• Almost every self-respecting town has a caravan park. Most of them have unpowered sites. Often these sites have a unit price regardless of the number of people. In 2006, an off-season site cost between $ 18 and $ 25. Many caravan parks are well equipped; they often have barbecues, refrigerators, cooking facilities, washing machines, beautiful lawns, clean sanitary facilities, communal kitchen, barbecues, a shop, ... in short, luxury in abundance. Besides a camping pitch, many caravan parks rent out caravans and cabins. These can be very profitable from 4 people.
  • In addition to the caravan parks, there are special camping pitches in the national parks. Different rules apply to this per national park. For example, a permit is required for certain parks and for aborigone land. This permit is often for sale on site at the national park. For some parks, a permit must be arranged in advance. A permit must also be requested in advance for camping outside the designated areas. Wild camping is usually no problem at all.
  • Camping in national parks is less luxurious. Here you will find the peace that you do not always have on caravan parcs. Usually there is no running water and only a shelf with a hole in it as a toilet. The price you pay for this is negligible. Often you have to register yourself upon arrival.
  • Wild camping
  • Wild camping is ideal for spending the night undisturbed, especially in the outback and other remote areas. There is more than enough space to set up your tent somewhere. It is best to find a place a little further from the road where no one will notice you. Wild camping in national parks is prohibited
Sleeping.body_hostels:
• You can get hotels from travel guides or through tourist information and flyers at other hotels. In 2006, a bed in a backpacker's hostel dormitory cost around $ 20. Hostels are often more expensive in cities. Sometimes twice.
  • Pubs often have single rooms.
  • Motels

Transport.body_airplane: Every major city has its own airport (Darwin, Cairns, Brisbane, Sydney, Canberra, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth, Alice Springs and Hobart). All corners of Australia can therefore be reached by plane from another continent. Other cities can be reached via domestic flights.
Transport.body_boat: • By bike on the boat it is interesting to go cycling on one of the many islands. There are daily connections with the surrounding islands at regular intervals. In most cases you don't have to disassemble the bike
Transport.body_bus:
• Hitchhiking is prohibited in Australia. Although it is not exceptional that people with a camper want to take you with them. Riding a road train and the bicycle as luggage can also be a unique experience.
  • By bicycle on the bus is an easy way to bridge large distances. All you have to do is turn the handlebars parallel to the frame and take the pedals off.

About.body:
Hilltop peaks covered with forests, green, clean-shaven meadows underneath, high mountains with beautiful mountain passes in the west, houses with wooden roof structures that are perfectly kept in the stain and façades immaculately plastered in cheerful colors. Austria is a country that radiates wealth.

The Austrian landscape includes areas with high and low mountains, hills and plains. The difference in altitude and climate has produced a wide variety of flora and fauna. Austria is one of the most forested countries in Europe, 47% of the country is covered with forest. The bicycle has certainly been thought of and new routes and (separate) cycle paths are still being added. A country where you can stay safe and carefree.

Corona.body:
Appears to be strict but really isnt.
Accomodation can still be found via airbnb, couchsurfing and other platforms with private hosts

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
In principle, the shops may be open from monday to friday between 6:00 am and 7:30 pm, and on saturday until 5:00 pm. However, as a rule, most shops are open from 8 am-6pm with 1? Noon break and on saturday until 1:00 pm. The larger supermarkets are also open on sunday morning.

Restaurants
  • In the culinary field there are many possibilities in austria. Specialties from austrian cuisine include: tafelspitz, salzburger nockerln (a light dessert of beaten eggs, sugar, flour, butter and vanilla sugar), kärntner nudeln (the austrian variant of the italian ravioli. Dough bags filled with meat, mashed potatoes or cottage cheese), kaiserschmarrn (pieces of risen pancake with raisins. Served with icing sugar and apple sauce or cranberries), germknödel (steamed dough ball filled with plum jam, topped with butter or vanilla sauce and sprinkled with sugar and poppy seeds) or wiener schnitzel.
  • The choice is limited for the vegetarian.
  • South tyrol offers a beautiful combination of italian culinary tradition and german care in terms of service.
Drinkable water
Tap water is drinkable everywhere. In the mountains it is wonderfully soft, perfect for making delicious tea, in the lower areas, however, it is quite hard: boiling water immediately results in a white-coated pan.

Health.body:
Availability hospitals / doctors
  • Closed pharmacies have a sign with the name of the nearest pharmacies on duty.
  • Information about the doctor on duty at the local police or gendarmerie can be found in the phone book.
  • All mountain villages have their own mountain rescue service. Emergency numbers: rescue / emergency doctor: 144; medical center: 141; mountain rescue service: 140.

Other.body:
Mapped cycle routes
  • Map with bicycle routes in Austria
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
  • The climate has a transitional character: from the temperate, atlantic influenced west and northwest respectively to the more continental east. In the west the precipitation is considerably higher than in the east and in the high areas higher than in the low plains.
  • May to october are the best months for cycling. Spring is a particularly good time. Even in summer it can still be very cold on the mountain passes. Minor mountain passes, such as the beautiful timmelsjoch, can remain closed until late spring, only the important passes such as the brenner are kept open all year round.
Tourist high season
  • Harry: I was cycling through the east of the country in july and august expecting crowded campsites. That was not so bad, I was even the only one on a number. It is busy at the more touristy places such as the attersee and a city like salzburg.
Spare parts
There are plenty of options to have your bicycle repaired in the villages.

People.body: Generally really friendly and helpful, you can even get by with english in the countryside

Safety.body: Austria a safe country to cycle at.
Safety.body_traffic:
The roads are of excellent quality almost everywhere: smooth and smooth asphalt. In the mountains you are mainly dependent on the main roads, outside there are plenty of opportunities to find small roads. The main roads in the mountain are therefore quite busy.

There are cycle paths or strips along many main roads. It is annoying that the one time they are on the left and a little further on suddenly on the right side of the road: regular crossing is therefore necessary. Cycle routes with separate cycle paths run along the larger rivers and in other places. In the cities, the German system is used: You cycle on part of the footpath and use common traffic lights.

-MHjVUOqt9ToWjdfndEu.description: Take a break from cycling and do some hikes. There a thousands of beautiful hikes all over the country. Enjoy the breathtaking view from the top (Gipfelkreuz) it's definetly worth it
-MHjVUOqt9ToWjdfndEu.description_first: Take a break from cycling and do some hikes. There a thousands of beautiful hikes all over the country. Enjoy the breathtaking view from the top (Gipfelkreuz) it's definetly worth it
-MHjVUOqt9ToWjdfndEu.title: Hiking

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Campsites are a short distance from each other, especially along the Danube. It is usually not necessary to reserve campsites in advance.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
• Austria has many guest houses (Gasthaus) and hotels.
  • Many hotels along cycling routes are geared towards cyclists.
  • There are some youth hostels, http://www.oejhv.or.at/.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is prohibited and strictly controlled in the tourist areas. Outside these areas, for example north of the Danube, the controls are less strict and there are plenty of forests where you can spend a night. Make sure you are not seen, because it is forbidden there too.

Transport.body_airplane: There are international airports at Vienna, Innsbruck and Salzburg.
Transport.body_boat: Various (luxury) cruise ships sail from the Netherlands on the major rivers towards Austria. Who is going to try to bring their bicycle with you?
Transport.body_train: There are several international trains going towards Austria. You can take your bicycle on trains for 12 euro.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body:
Azerbaijan is an Islamic country, so you can take some reserve into account. Western clothing is also fine, you don't see headscarves much.
Many Azeris are curious about world cyclists. It is a phenomenon that they do not yet know. They don't understand much about it, but they do find it interesting. Sometimes they also drive next to you to have a chat or they give thumbs up. Due to the feud in Nagorno-Karabakh, the population around Nagorno-Karabakh is somewhat shy. But after a quiet introduction they are very hospitable and want to know everything about you. Guests always sleep in the show room and are really pampered.

FoodDrink.body:
Veerle: "Attention: Azerbaijani cuisine is the worst of the Silk Road! Main ingredients are sheep's leg fat and chickpeas. Very cheap. If you stay at people's homes, they will undoubtedly serve toasts with (a lot of) vodka ...". Vegetarians have a bad life here. The main ingredient in any meal is meat. On the road it is sometimes difficult to find food in the winter.

Tap water is not reliable. Water bottles are for sale in every village. In the large villages everything is available (seasonal vegetables, cans), but in the small villages the people are often self-sufficient.

Other.body:
Spare parts
The locals drive on 26 inch tires. However, there are not many cyclists.
We have not looked for workshops, count outside Baku but not on bicycle specialists. The people are very inventive, they always find a work around.
If you really cannot continue cycling, you can always get a lift from an Azeri or take one of the rattling (mini) buses.
Hi-tech spare parts may be found in Baku which has a very rich part. Otherwise send to post restante in Baku.
Never forget to bring your spoke tensioner and extra spokes!

973d7bb5-6f8a-404c-860d-35e61031c1c1.description: There are a few mud volcanoes that you can visit. It's not too spectacular, but it's something you might not see elsewhere too often.
973d7bb5-6f8a-404c-860d-35e61031c1c1.title: Mud volcanoes

Sleeping.body_hostels: There are very few hotels outside of tourist attractions.

Visa.body:
The visa policy of Azerbaijan differs quite a lot per nationality.

Visa policy of Azerbaijan for ordinary passport holders
  Republic of Azerbaijan
  Visa free
  Visa issued upon arrival by air. Also eligible for ASAN electronic visa.
  Eligible for ASAN electronic visa. Visa on arrival under special conditions.
  Eligible for ASAN electronic visa.
  Visa obtained in person required prior to arrival.
  Admission refused
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
The Azores is a group of Islands almost halfway on the Atlantic Ocean between Europe and North America and it is an autonomous region of Portugal. It consists of 9 volcanic Islands: Sao Miguel, Santa Maria, Terceira, Graciosa, Sao Jorge, Pico, Faial, Flores and Corvo.

The capital is Ponta Delgada and is located on the main Island of Sao Miguel. There are enough campsites on Sao Miguel to pitch your tent and have a shower.

It is famous for it's hiking routes because it is hilly, it has very beautiful landscapes and diverse nature. For the trained cyclist it would be the perfect place to plan unique adventures. It can be very steep at some places, but if you don't mind to walk a little and make a good planning that does make it a challenging destination. There are lots of volcanic craters and lakes to be explored, from many places you can view the Altantic Ocean. 

It is easy to plan flights and ferry crossings between the islands and bringing your bicycle would be not a problem, although please keep in mind that storms could occur and disrupt your planning a little.

People.body: The locals on the Azores are very kind towards cyclists. It is funny that by occasion you might encounter the same people again by cycling around the islands. 1 occasion a guy bought a beer for me in the supermarket just because he wanted to talk with me.

Safety.body_criminality: The usual thinking of being more careful in some cities or touristy areas at night, but overall quite safe.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

Quite some nationalities can enter Bahamas without a visa.



Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
There are many simple eateries where you can only eat Bengali.

Drinkable water
Drinking water is only suitable for people with a strong stomach, it is better to purify the water beforehand. Mineral water is readily available.

Health.body: Traveling in Bangladesh requires good preparation for the necessary vaccinations and malaria prophylaxis.

Other.body:
Spare parts
In Dhaka you can buy parts and tires for mountain bikes. In addition, there are many smaller bicycle repair shops along most roads. Take everything that looks somewhat "Western" with you and learn to repair your bicycle yourself. There are more bicycle repairers in this country than good water sources.

People.body: The population is very curious and hospitable. They come around you in great numbers. In principle nothing happens and there are only positive experiences with it. Bangladesh is an Islamic country, so pay attention to what attracts you. Women should keep legs and upper arms covered. Ankles is seen as a very seductive object. A little English is spoken.

Safety.body: Traveling in Bangladesh requires good preparation for the necessary vaccinations and malaria prophylaxis. Marco: We have never been afraid of being robbed. The country feels very safe, but that is of course always subjective.
Safety.body_traffic: Bangladesh can be dangerous on the bike if you only use the main roads. The small roads are much safer.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no official campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Big cities have hotels, which are often dirty or rather very simple. In Dhaka you can arrange overnight stays throughout the country in so-called resthouses.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but expect many people around your tent in some cases.

Transport.body_boat: Busy, dirty, slow but you can always take your bike with you.
Transport.body_bus: Busy, dirty, slow but you can always take your bike with you.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Barbados without a visa.


Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
We had to feel our stock of petrol once. The first best fuel station was willing to fill our 0.6 liter fuel bottle for free.

Markets
There is a larger market in every city, where a wide variety of items are for sale. The market is often a walled site, sometimes also covered. It is easy to find different types of fruit and vegetables on these markets, but that is often difficult outside of markets.

Supermarkets
You will find a supermarket in every small village. Macaroni and spaghetti are always available there as well as accompanying sauce. Bread and (fruit) yogurt. For the rest, the supermarkets often have more alcoholic drinks than food. You should not be in these small supermarkets for vegetables and, for example, western toppings. Vegetables can be found on the market and western spreads such as pasta in better supermarkets in the larger cities.

Street markers
You don't see many stalls on the street. Sometimes mushrooms and some fruit are sold along the busier roads. There are many kiosks (not in small villages) where you can buy marches, snickers, twix, etc., this concentrate is usually lacking in the supermarkets.

Drinkable water
We always got our water from wells or pumps and this was always very drinkable, we never had an upset stomach after drinking this water. Sometimes there is no bucket in the wells, if that is the case, one has one in the nearest house.

Health.body: Wilbert (2010): When we cycled into Belarus from Lithuania it was mandatory to take out medical insurance with Belgosstrach, an insurance company of the government. It only costs a few euros. When registering our visas in Minsk we had to show the insurance papers, and it turned out that we had only received medical insurance for five days at the border, after which we had to take out new medical insurance to be insured for our entire stay. So check carefully whether the compulsory medical insurance applies at the border for the entire duration of your stay: this makes the registration of the visa easier.

Other.body:
Best period
We cycled almost continuously across the countryside, through agricultural areas. In the 11 days that we were in belarus, we have not seen anything that really resembled tourism. When we arrived at the belarusian - polish border, we saw a dutch car with a caravan. The only people who are sure were tourists. During the rest of our stay, we saw maybe 10 cars that had license plates from an eu country.

Spare parts
Almost every village or city has a large market where there is often a stall with some bicycle parts, but don't expect too much! In Kobryn I was able to buy a mountain bike tire 26 inch for 3 euros. Quality even very reasonable. Can find other parts very sporadically. Quality moderate to poor. Therefore, take spare bicycle parts with you when in doubt about a part on your bicycle.

Tips
There is still a considerable bureaucracy in Belarus. You are expected to report to the 'foreign police', a result of the former KGB. You must report within 48 hours of crossing the border. The process can take quite a few hours, especially if you try to complete this process independently without knowledge of the Russian language. All in all, I think Belarus is a country that you only get to know, by using a guide / translator. Only go out with knowledge of the Russian language, otherwise in a group. (These rules were relaxed in 2010: reporting to the 'aliens police' must be done within five days of entering the country)
Hans Metz: I cycled around Belarus for a month in 2009 and 2014, did not register anywhere and had no problems. I also regularly ran into someone who spoke English!

People.body:
The people are very nice, although they will not come to you any time soon. However, talking to them is a problem as there are hardly any people who speak English. A few speak some German. Indeed it is important to know some Russian, many white Russians immediately start a chat with you when they see you with your bike. That makes it fun again and you get to know the country and the people a little better.

Belarusians are hospitable and friendly, it is just not that they come to you and invite you, as happens a lot in a country like Turkey. However, if you go to them and ask for water, for example, many will go to great lengths to help you. With the help of a translator / guide it is better to enjoy the hospitality. Intentions are better communicated by the translator and you learn a lot more about the country. People are also very interested in life in Western Europe, or the Netherlands. We have been invited several times, so it does happen now and then. It was noticeable that the Belarusians really want to know how we think about their country.

Safety.body:
We cycled through Belarus for ten days and never felt unsafe for a moment. We have always camped wild, because there are simply no campsites. Several times we camped on the banks of lakes or rivers where nearby fishermen were busy all night, stealing or bothering you didn't even seem to occur to them. As a precaution, someone always stayed with the bikes when, for example, we went to buy something in a supermarket, but we increasingly got the idea that this was not necessary for anything. In 2008 we cycle through the south of Belarus with 4 people, 1 of which is a guide / translator, from farm to farm. At night we stayed in the bedroom or living room of a Belarusian family. We, too, have never experienced a feeling of insecurity.

That is the advantage of a dictatorship! Safety.
Safety.body_traffic:
Density of the road network
There are many roads in the country, there is also an alternative for every route you want to cycle.

Traffic danger
You often cycle on roads where cars rush past you at high speeds. However, motorists pull aside well and often honk as a sign that they are driving behind you.
Especially the roads in central belarus were sometimes very quiet with about 1 car per half hour.

Presence of (detached) cycling paths
In cities we sometimes encountered something that could be a cycle path, but usually it was at least used as a footpath. You can actually cycle anywhere, from the sidewalk to the highway.
We once encountered a cycle path outside the built-up area, but that was overgrown :-)

Road signs
The villages and towns are always indicated in cyrillic, so it's important to learn this!
The signage was good, we never got lost on the regular main roads. Small villages off the main roads are only signposted at the exit.
It often happens that cities and villages have a ring road. If you are not aware of that, you sometimes unintentionally drive around a city or dopr, when you actually wanted to go through it.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
Sleeping in private homes has always been my favorite. This is also possible in Belarus. Reserve in advance.
Scattered across the country you have so-called 'agro-ucadbi'; sleep with the farmer. Ask for them because they are not indicated by signs or the like.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Campsites are not really around.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
We have not seen any campsites throughout the country. We have always camped wild. That went very well. Finding camping spots was easy and it doesn't occur to people to bother you. It was often possible to camp on the shores of beautiful lakes and rivers.

Wild camping is allowed everywhere except in the National Parks. We have never had a problem with it during the month that we cycled around it. Sometimes it is difficult to find a place because of swamp. In case you are looking forward to a shower after a while in the wild, it is important to know that the few hotels in the smaller towns (north-east for example) are often still of the old school and do not have a shower.

Transport.body_train:
With the elektrietska (slow train) the bicycle is always allowed, just put it in the hallway between two doors. With the express trains, this is only allowed if you can pack the bike. If you are unable to do so, you must have the bicycle sent to its destination via the baggage department, the bicycle will then be transported by a freight train and you can pick it up at the destination at the baggage department.
Hans Metz (2017): the express trains are indeed always a bit difficult to board. I keep looking friendly, supposedly don't understand anything, turn my handlebars a quarter turn and take the pedals off. Then I already throw in a bag. Always succeeded. In the back of each wagon is an informal smoking area, great place for the bicycle. (This also applies to Ukraine and Russia).

Visa.body:
The visa policy of Belarus differs quite a lot for the different nationalities.

Visa policy of Belarus

About.body: Belgium is divided in the Dutch speaking part in the North (Flamish), and the French speaking part in the South (Wallonia). Belgium is famous for their chocolate and their delicious strong beers. The country is mostly flat and therefore easy to cycle. Attractive in Flanders are the many canals and old railway routes along which and over which it is often good and quiet cycling; in addition, the (few remaining) rural areas. In Wallonia, the slopes in the densely forested Ardennes are steeper and longer than many expect, which has already given many novice holiday cyclists the necessary frustrations. A bicycle with at least 18 gears is not a luxury there.

FoodDrink.body:
The Belgium beers like Leffe, Duvel, La Chouffe are very tasty, but can also give you a major hangover. There are plenty of other different beers, and each of them seems to have its own character.

Chocolate and waffles are two other typical Belgium specialities.

Supermarkets
The supermarkets are often located a bit outside the built-up area along a large exit road.

Street markets
In some regions where mainly fruit is grown (eg Limburg Hesbaye) you can come across stalls with delicious cherries, strawberries and the like in the summer.
Another kind of well-known stalls are the frietkoten. These are often only open in the evening and not every weekday. Occasionally (especially in one place where the weekly market takes place) there are also burger stands. Don't forget to look around the market itself for a tasty snack / lunch.

Restaurant
There are plenty.

Water
You can drink all tap water.

Other.body:
Alternative Routes
  • Map with cycling routes in Belgium
Best period to cycle
The climate is almost the same as in the Netherlands, in Flanders perhaps a degree warmer. In the Ardennes, depending on the altitude, it is a bit cooler and rain showers can be heavier. In the winter there is significantly more frequent and longer snow in the Ardennes.

Road signs
Signposting is good on slightly larger roads. Many residential areas and all kinds of other roads lead to a dead end in the field or against canals or highways. Cycling a bit on spec often leads to very small circles that always lead to the main road.

People.body:
Flanders
The Flemish are by nature a bit more modest than the Dutch, but don't be misled, hospitality can also be found in Flanders.
  • As in the rest of Western Europe, the atmosphere in the cities is somewhat more closed: this is more of a problem in dangerous neighborhoods than in safer neighborhoods. In rural areas, people are usually friendlier or at least more cordial and more interested in travelers.
  • Flemish people are often quite proud of their environment, showing some interest in the local environment often opens doors. (Be surprised: before you know it you will be on the church tower.)
  • Speaking French in Flanders is not done: unfortunately you are sometimes judged on this as a tourist. In the vicinity of the language border, it is always useful to have a look at the street name signs so that you know which language to use.
  • Large groups of immigrants sometimes live in the big cities. Although respect for cyclists in traffic is often lacking in this group, they do have a very hospitable attitude. The older generations in particular invite people more often to drink or eat tea with them.
Brussels
  • Brussels is a mixed bag of cultures. 
  • Try to address people in their native language: this is often difficult, but it is certainly not wrong to address someone with "Good day, bonjour, can you tell me where ...", the person addressed will answer in the easiest way for him. language.
Walonia
  • Walloons have a warmer French culture, where hospitality is important. However, this hospitality has largely disappeared in some cities (former coal areas), unemployment and poverty make the people more distant, but still very much present in the countryside.
  • In some regions the idea prevails that Flemish people are richer, this sometimes results in prices that suddenly become a bit higher or, for example, sell a street map while there is also a free version. This effect is less of an issue with the Dutch.
  • As in Flanders, it is strongly inadvisable to speak the other national language in Wallonia, try to make contact in French as much as possible. Experience has shown that, if the Dutch then make contact in French and the interlocutor notices that he or she is dealing with a Dutch person, he or she will sometimes want to answer in Dutch, or at least what Dutch words call for clarify story (eg vous pouvez mettre votre fiets ici). However, do not abuse this, but compliment your conversation partner on his or her Dutch.

QuickFacts.climate: Sea climate, not very cold winters, summerdays can be hot in July and August.

Safety.body:
Belgium is a safe country to cycle, but always lock your bicycle and keep your bags safe.Walloons have a warmer French culture, where hospitality is important. However, this hospitality has largely disappeared in some cities (former coal areas), unemployment and poverty make people more distant, but still very much present in the countryside.
In some regions the idea prevails that Flemish people are richer, this sometimes results in prices that suddenly become a bit higher or, for example, sell a street map while there is also a free version. This effect is less of an issue with the Dutch.
Belgium is no more dangerous than the other surrounding countries. In the cities there are pickpockets here and there, but robberies with violence remain very rare. In and around Brussels there are neighborhoods where it is less safe, but there too the number of incidents remains limited.
Safety.body_criminality:
Student cities such as Ghent and Leuven are notorious for the high number of bicycle thefts, although most thefts are limited to opening a combination lock on an old bicycle. Stronger locks are enough to keep drunk students away from your bike. Unfortunately, at times there are also gangs at work that are after more expensive bicycles. It is therefore recommended to always attach your bicycle to "the world" with a sturdy lock.
If your bicycle is stolen, it is best to report it to the local police, however it makes sense to know that most police areas have too much work to actively look for stolen bicycles. With a bit of luck, your bike will be found when clearing a bicycle shed, but that chance is limited, certainly in the case of a holiday bike. (Most Belgians assume that they are not looking for stolen bicycles)
The Belgian police do not have the equipment to read anti-theft chips in locks, but use a local system in which the bicycles are engraved. This is mainly a deterrent because the engraving usually disappears quickly under a sticker. The engraving code starts with the owner's date of birth followed by a serial number. In case of resale, you can in principle report that the bicycle has changed owner.
Safety.body_traffic:
The roads conditions can vary, but are mostly good enough to cycle.There are many regional roads in Belgium without any bicycle facilities. Sometimes it concerns narrow, busy roads where the driving is very fast. It is better to avoid these roads. In contrast to the Netherlands, there is a lot of ribbon development in Flanders along slightly larger roads. The result is that those who do not have a detailed map are almost dependent on these roads and, while cycling, get the impression that the built-up areas of Antwerp, Brussels and Hasselt have completely grown together. In Wallonia, this problem is less acute, although more and more houses are being built even around the High Fens, which deprive the traveler of the once beautiful view in many places.
JPV: "Avoid all N-roads that go to Brussels in the immediate vicinity of Brussels. For example, the road between Ninove and Brussels is impossible for cyclists.

3e26fa1b-f9ec-4d6e-ab87-538e81ceb26b.description: This is not a single point, but a large natural Parc in the Southeast of Belgium. There are a few small rivers here, like the Ourthe, which you can follow and will guide you through some stunning landscapes.
3e26fa1b-f9ec-4d6e-ab87-538e81ceb26b.title: Ardennes

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Both Couchsurfin and Warmshowers are well established platforms in Belgium. There is also a local platform called Vrienden op de Fiets (Friend on bicycle), but for this platform you need to pay about 10 euros per night to the host, but you'll have a more private and well maintained sleeping place.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Belgians are generally not avid traveling campers. In both Flanders and Wallonia, many campsites are only intended for mobile homes. Usually, however, you can go there with your hiking tent.
A complete overview of all campsites for a specific region or for the whole of Belgium does not exist. Internet sites that provide overviews are often very incomplete. Tourist offices only provide information about the area they cover. Not all campsites are indicated on maps either.
Reservations are not recommended: cyclists reported that they were standing at the reception of a half-empty campsite, and were fobbed off with "we are completely full". There is probably a place for a few cyclists. You occasionally have to negotiate the number of tents that will fit in one place.
Wild camping is not allowed. In the Ardennes, if you are discovered by the police, you will at least be sent away.
Leon: "I have a tip for those who go cycling in the Ardennes during the summer holidays and then camp at campsites. Most campsites have a hiking field, which in itself is nothing wrong with, except that during the summer holidays, the Belgian growing up The disadvantage of this is that even good earplugs are sometimes not good enough. So the tip is to ask if you are allowed to stand in a different place than the hiking field. For your night's rest, a place among Dutch people with children is often better. go to bed on time. "

Transport.body_airplane: Brussels Airport is the main airport of the country.
Transport.body_boat: There is a large ferry connection with the U.K., at the Harbour of Dunkirk. From Zeebrugge it is possible to take ferries to Hull in England and Rosyth in Scotland. See http://www.seabridges.com.
Transport.body_bus:
One of the cheapest ways of traveling is by Flixbus, which also allows you to bring your bicycle. You should book in advance. Flixbus operates in many European countries, connecting all big cities.

De Lijn, the public transport company of Flanders, only allows bicycles on the Coastal Tram (tram from Knokke to De Panne along the Belgian coast). For this you can purchase a "Bicycle Ticket". There are experiments here and there with buses fitted with a bicycle carrier, but for the time being these are local and temporary options.
Transport.body_train:
It is possible to travel by train, but it is complicated in relation to the distance. In the Netherlands you have to buy an international ticket and you have to pay for the bicycle for both countries.
The bicycles can be taken on the train for a fee. More information can be found on the website of the NMBS (the NMBS forbids linking to the website without explicit permission). Keep in mind that places are sometimes limited. Certainly in the high season it is sometimes worthwhile to make a reservation, as youth movements in groups also take the train by bicycle. On intercity and interregio trains there is often a complete carriage for bicycles and wheelchairs, on local trains there is a small space (often in the locomotive that can accommodate four bicycles).
You always pay for the ride per person and a fixed price per bicycle (€ 5 per bicycle / tandem for a single journey, € 8 per bicycle / tandem for a whole day, anno 2012).
The conductor is sometimes helpful and sometimes not, unfortunately no line can be drawn here. Being kind always helps in the right direction.
Folding bicycles can almost always be taken along free of charge, although there are restrictions in terms of dimensions according to the letter of the regulations.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

Only a few countries can enter Belize without a visa.


  Belize

About.body: A small, but long country. Pass through it in one day, or explore the inner depths more inland. The country offers an interesting history of their Voodoo religion. The people are very friendly, but also very poor. You can expect some begging.

-MGMzsPL55JRFgURjx2i.title: Learning about Benin’s Voodoo and slave trade

39d39a0b-df60-4945-97dd-c8b78c79c983.description: Getting the evisa is very easy, but you must have a credit card.

Local food: Wagasi cheese, Acaraje
Local drink: Sodabi

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.

-MGMyFzy5feJ36dUNhkb.description: A Voodoo drenched city that was once the capital of a powerful kingdom. Visit one of the many palaces, the fetish market, a Voodoo basilica, a Voodoo priest or the underground village.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Most cities have accommodation. Room with fan should be around 5.000 CFA, with AC a bit more. Expect bucket showers.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

About.body: Bhutan is a small Buddhist kingdom in the Eastern Himalayas that has been cut off from the outside world for centuries. The population is largely of Tibetan origin and the language is related to classical Tibetan.

FoodDrink.body:
• Hygiene in the tourist restaurants is usually quite good. Local restaurants in remote villages and in the larger towns in the east are very simple and less hygienic.
  • Bhutan has a wide variety of fruits and vegetables. Mangoes, oranges, bananas, etc. Bhutanese cuisine is not very spicy. The basis is rice, barley or potatoes. Home-grown vegetables are onions, cabbage, carrots, mushrooms and green asparagus. Western bhutan hotels offer wetter dishes. The meat comes from India by truck.

People.body: Bhutans are friendly and hospitable. They also seem a bit introverted.

Safety.body: Bhutan is extremely safe.

FoodDrink.body:
Markets
In the larger cities, such as uyuni, potosi, sucre, la paz and also coroico and copacabana, you can get good quality vegetables on the market, usually of good quality. Bread is also usually available here. Varieties of fruits and vegetables and the price also depends on where you are, the closer to the valleys the cheaper.
