Enjoy your own sandwich with cheese (round, salty cheeses; feta-like taste), with avocado (palta) and tomato.
Very little is for sale in the shops outside the larger cities. Everything is sold on the market, but the quality is not good there either.

Supermarkets
Rinnert and Astrid: "In big cities, at least in la paz, we have found health food stores that also sell" soy chunks ". Ideal for on the go as a meat substitute: they don't go bad."

Restaurants
There are cheap restaurants in all towns and cities. They are often located at bus stops and markets. However, the meals are not big, simple and one-sided.
In potosi, sucre and la paz you will find several vegetarian restaurants.
The slightly better restaurants in the cities are also not expensive. In the highlands of bolivia you can travel around with little money.

Drink
There is no potable tap water. It is best to boil the water yourself first. A typical drink is jugo: a fruit drink, often with milk and sugar.

Health.body:
Common Illnesses
  • Altitude sickness: Cycling at high altitudes means that you have to take altitude sickness into account. You better take it easy, even if you are in such good shape. It is also better not to start your bike tour in the highlands. Many tourists who land in La Paz suffer from the altitude without cycling. Drinking coca tea or chewing coca leaves can help with altitude sickness. It seems that eating garlic-rich the days before you hit the altitude also helps. In any case, take sufficient rest (days).
  • Rinnert and Astrid: "The intestinal parasite we presumably had was probably gardia. This is because other cyclists recognized the symptoms: intestinal discomfort (diarrhea), fatigue," egg burping "problems. We have at the pharmacy, without a prescription. When we got back from our trip we asked our doctor for a check-up to make sure we were not carrying anything and our "hobby work" with the readily available anti-parasite drugs had been sufficient (we On the spot also looked up info on the internet) Not everyone will be charmed by this method, on the other hand, there was a man at a hostel whose daughter was supposed to be a doctor. He wrote my symptoms (in Spanish as well as possible) to her and then got I got a note about what I should take. We got the strong impression that my intestinal complaints had come across as an upset stomach. So it remains to choose from several evils. "
  • Rinnert and Astrid: "90% of the cyclists we encountered had a problem with their intestines. That is part of Bolivia, unfortunately. Presumably from the water or shaking hands. We brought a jar of soap for your hands, to "wash" without needing water. "
Useful things in the travel pharmacy
  • Rinnert and Astrid: "We wanted to go to the jungle, from Caranavi towards Rurrenabaque (Reyes). In La Paz we could get malaria tablets in the pharmacy. However, they were not in a strip, came from a large container. to be on the safe side informed at the hospital in Coroico and Caranavi It seems that yellow fever deserves more attention, occurs more and / or poses a danger Regarding malaria we got the impression that it is not necessary to take anything preventively or in Rurrenabaque itself further information. "
Availability of hospitals / doctors
  • Lizy: "The one-off use of health care in Bolivia has been particularly good for me. In Uyuni (10,000 inhabitants) there are two hospitals, of which the 'chic' one: Caja Nacional de Salud (for Bolivians with health insurance and tourists) has ultrasound and X-ray equipment, blood tests are carried out with sterile, single-use needles. The price for a consultation with a specialist, use of ultrasound equipment, blood and urine tests is about 90 Bolivianos (9 euros, price level 2006). "
Hazards
  • Watch out for dehydration in the jungle: bring enough drinkable water.
  • Rinnert and Astrid: "We went from San Pedro de Atacama into Bolivia, via the lagoons (including Laguna Verde), via Salar de Uyuni to Uyuni. Take enough food here. It is sometimes difficult to get something at the hostels , because you are not part of the target group (the 4x4, who by the way often bring their own food) There are a few villages, but it is wise to bring enough (we had taken into account 8 days, which worked out fine). this area we managed to get 1x2 days of water. Refill your empty bottles at every opportunity you see. "

Other.body:
Best period to cycle
The climate depends on the altitude and the time of the year. In La Paz (3600 meters above sea level) the maximum temperature throughout the whole year is on average about 20 degrees, in the jungle around 30. The driest time is around July, the wettest in November until March. In their winter, keep an eye out for the low night temperatures at high altitudes.

Spare parts
  • There are bicycle repairers almost everywhere, although according to some it is better to speak of "bicycle runners". So repair your bike yourself.
  • Simple parts can be bought on the market in major cities. Everything is cheap, but import quality products are expensive.
  • Jochem: "For the more advanced parts, check the" most dangerous road in the world "companies in La Paz that organize tours to it. I even decorated spd pedals there with my sister. Who knows what they do. all have more ..! "
Tips
  • Bolivia has the highest ski slope in the world: From La Paz you can go to the Chacaltaya slope at 5200 m. From a sharp bend in the autopista from the center you can find an alternative tricky, hard to find way to the ski slope under an arch . From 4800 m there is no longer a path and you have to carry the bike over boulders and cross the piste at the last. The normal road from El Alto is a good dirt road.
  • Make sure you have a properly working and adjusted compass if you want to go up the Salar.

Safety.body_traffic:
State of the roads
  • There is only 2000 km of paved road and that is good. The rest consists of gravel, dust and mud.
  • The cochabamba-villa de independencia-coroico route is unpaved and often bad and steep. Descending is therefore also slow. You climb and descend to river level and then climb again. Sometimes bridges are missing or being built, so it is fording the river. Sometimes you can see in the morning where you end up in the evening, 10 km as the crow flies, but after a lot of work the clock shows 30-40 km. Absolutely beautiful!
  • Quite a lot of trucks travel by road from caranavi to rurrenabaque. In the dry season, the road can be dry and very dusty, with a high risk of dust clouds.
  • Astrid and rinnert (2007): "The route caranavi - guanay - chuma - sorata is partly about bad road." at guanay we were advised to take a boat to maipiri because of the quality of the road. We knew from other cyclists that the part from maipiri to consata was largely bad due to steepness and large boulders on the road. We were unlucky that it was going to rain and that the parts that were smooth (without too big stones) and not so steep became so muddy that the wheels could no longer turn, within 2 km. We decided to take a taxi. All the more so the risk is that you can bridge so little distance that you will not find a suitable place to stay overnight (perhaps at the gold mining settlements). "
  • Giantus (2008): "The road between uyuni and potosí is being paved. The work should be ready in about 3 years (2011). In june 2008, workers were busy everywhere along the route. Some parts are therefore very sandy. , other parts that are almost ready for asphalting already feel almost like paved road "
  • Yolanda (2011): "The road between uyuni and potosí is now almost ready and 90% paved. There are a few small 'desvios' where they still have to build a bridge, but otherwise wonderful new asphalt!"
Traffic density / danger
Drivers take little account of cyclists: (hardly) anyone else cycles on gravel roads. They are nice and quiet.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
• Robertjan: "Sometimes you can go to private individuals, especially when there are no hotels. Just asking if there is a hotel nearby works best."
  • Rinnert and Astrid: "On the route Caranavi - Sorata there were sometimes hostelries in the villages. Once both were closed, but the locals thought along and we were allowed to spread our mats in an" eatery ". Other times there was a room somewhere, presumably also used by drivers who need an overnight stay. Very simple with a toilet "compartido" = shared, read shared with the whole village. You don't want to be in that toilet. In fact there is almost always something to arrange, especially in these areas with such small villages. "
Sleeping.body_hostels: • There are simple, cheap hotels in all small towns in the highlands. They are also cheap in the big cities, except for the expensive center of La Paz.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
• Wild camping is possible everywhere, however, the Altiplano is not much fun because of the low temperatures at night (between -15 and -20 degrees Celsius).
  • When camping on the Salar de Uyuni (or other Salars): The only place to get your pegs in the 'ground' is exactly in the seam / ripple of the hexagonal surfaces that make up the Salar. A self-supporting dome or geodesic is therefore more convenient than, for example, a tunnel, because those domes or geodesics are also stable without pegs.
  • Rinnert and Astrid: "In the area between Cochabamba and Coroico, it was sometimes difficult to find a suitable and especially invisible wild camping spot in the area between Cochabamba and Coroico, sometimes also at night. people still walk. For example, we had one unexpected "visitor" and he was probably also shocked by the "ufo" that stood on his walking path. His surprise still rings in our ears "descansar aca?" = sleeping / resting here? "

Transport.body_airplane: Several airlines fly to La Paz and Santa Cruz. Taking the bicycle with you differs per company. Always wise to inquire about the conditions when booking. Internal flights are cheap, and you can often take your bike along (sometimes you don't even have to pack it).
Transport.body_bus:
The bus is very cheap. Your bike usually goes on top of the bus. Make sure they tie it up properly without putting too much luggage on it. The bicycle costs about 10 to 20% of the ticket if on top or up to 80% if at the bottom of the cargo hold. Be on time and make it clear that the bicycle must also be taken along. It is best if you put the bicycle in the hold yourself.
With night buses on the Altiplano you have to make sure that the bus really has heating (which works), at least take your sleeping bag with you on the bus. In addition, of course also water and food in case it all takes a little longer than planned.
Transport.body_train: Trains run from Calama (Chile) or Villazon (Argentina) to Uyuni and from Corumbá (Brazil) to Santa Cruz. For the line Villazon - Uyuni. Taking the bike with you on the train is no problem: it goes into a guarded baggage car. Some trains only run once a day and also in the middle of the night.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Bolivia without a visa.

Visa policy of Bolivia
  Bolivia
  Visa-free (Passport and ID card entry)
  Visa-free (Passport entry)
  Must obtain visa prior to landing for free, or upon arrival for a fee (Special rules China and Iran)
  Special authorization required before visa can be granted
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Bosnia and Herzegovina is bordered by Serbia to the east, Montenegro to the southeast, and Croatia to the north and southwest. It is not entirely landlocked; to the south it has a narrow coast on the Adriatic Sea, which is about 20 kilometres (12 miles) long and surrounds the town of Neum. The inland Bosnia region has a moderate continental climate, with hot summers and cold, snowy winters. In the central and eastern interior of the country the geography is mountainous, in the northwest moderately hilly, and in the northeast predominantly flatland. The smaller southern region, Herzegovina, has a Mediterranean climate and mostly mountainous topography. Bosnia and Herzegovina is created when the former Yugoslavia broke up (since April 5, 1992). The capital is Sarajevo.

There is not (yet) much cycling in Bosnia and Herzegovina. There are no cycle paths and the country consists largely of hilly landscape with deep green valleys and steep mountain roads. Most roads are quiet and therefore very easy to cycle. Unpaved mountain paths are a challenge for those who want to cycle off-road. For those who like climbing, the country is very suitable anyway. The road from Sarajevo to Zenica / Travnik and on to Banja Luka is busy and narrow in some places and therefore less pleasant to cycle, in others (the transition between Muslim and Serbian zones) almost deserted.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
We have regularly seen gas shot tanks in supermarkets and hardware stores.

Supermarkets
In most areas, there are plenty of shops for shopping. The somewhat larger towns have large modern supermarkets.
The drugstore chain 'dm' has a limited range of organic products. The dm shops can be found in the larger cities.

Restaurants
Restaurants are cheaper than in the netherlands. Typical dishes are cevapcici (sausages) and stews.
There are kebab shops everywhere where börek is sold. Seasoned minced meat in one kind of puff pastry. There is also a variant that is filled with cheese or spinach, but this is not available everywhere. Yogurt is often drunk with it.
Vegetarian food in restaurants is no problem. The concept of vegetarian is well known. However, there is not much variation, it remains with the baked cheese slice and various omelets that are almost always on the menu.

Drinkable water
Tap water is usually drinkable, sometimes it is chlorinated. Along the way you can find springs that produce wonderfully cool water.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Seasons (dry / wet)
Spring and autumn are the best cycling season. In the winter it can get quite cold and in the summer quite warm, depending on where you are, it can cool down pleasantly in the evening.

Tourist high season
The real high season (if it actually exists in bosnia) only starts around the third week of july. Before that it is quieter.

Average temperature
We cycled at the end of august in a heat wave with temperatures up to 40 ° c. In the evening it cools down nicely, to about 15 ° c.

Spare parts
Bicycle repairers can mainly be found in the larger towns. The tire size is usually 26 "inch, but 28" can also be found. The combination with French valves then only presents a problem. Near the campsite in Illidza (Sarajevo) is one of the few bicycle shops with modern equipment and nice and helpful employees, you can also go here for trips (accompanied or not) through the mountains around Sarajevo.

People.body: The population can generally be described as hospitable and outspoken. In addition to their own language, there are people who speak German, English or even French.

Safety.body: There are still many landmines. All roads and verges are free of landmines. In case of wild camping you should always inquire or check (for example, is it an area that the population avoids) whether there are mines. Look here for overview maps. In principle there are no areas that should be avoided.
Safety.body_traffic:
There are many good asphalt roads. Some smaller roads are unpaved (called macadam) and can be good to difficult to pass. Unfortunately, asking motorists does not make much sense, they say it is bad anyway.

Traffic pressure / danger
  • You can cycle everywhere. However, cycling in the vicinity of sarajevo and mostar is not very pleasant due to the traffic on the road.
  • Through roads almost never have emergency lanes. Some drivers stay behind you when an oncoming vehicle approaches, but the majority don't.
Presence of (detached) cycling paths
  • Bicycle paths are a still unknown phenomenon in bosnia.
Signage
  • Signage is reasonable on main roads. The small and quiet roads are poorly or not signposted. However, a good map is essential and even better in combination with gps. In some places in the serbian part the signage is only in the cyrillic script.
  • Small roads are not or hardly indicated. Asking the population is difficult due to the language, but they also always want to send you over the main road. For example, you want to cycle the small road on the other side of the river instead of the busy main road. And try to make that clear.
  • We have the impression that the roads between serbian and bosnian areas in particular are dilapidated and poorly marked. Before the war these may have been more through roads, but now they are hardly used and maintained.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are few campsites. Some campsites are only open for a few months. Other campsites are again only intended for caravans, although this is not always clear. Campsites can be found in Blagaj (near Mostar), Ilidza (near Sarajevo), Busovaca, Vitez (under Zenica), Jajce, Ripac (near Bihac), Bosanska Krupa (summer 2009). With some effort it is possible to set up your tent in the private garden. Rural women are reluctant and often need the consent of their husbands. Be direct yet polite by specifically indicating the place where you want to pitch your tent.
Closer to the city, people can be very reticent.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
• Simple hotels cost approximately 15 to 30 euros per night for a room (2009).
  • The cities often have a hotel. Usually simple but good. Parking the bike in a good place is no problem. A few hotels that stand out in terms of friendliness (also because English or German is spoken well).
  • Saturday evening is a party night, every hotel takes part in this, so count on a lot of noise.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is not without risks due to the presence of landmines.

Transport.body_train:
Although not officially, buses take bicycles with them, but only if there is room for them. That chance is considerably smaller on the weekend. Take your time: if one bus doesn't take you, the next might work.
On weekends - and especially in summer - it is always busier than during the week and you have less chance of being taken by bike.
Sometimes you pay for each piece of luggage that is transported at the bottom of the bus. Then take as many bicycle bags as possible above the bus.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Bosnia and Herzegovina without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Botswana is a very good safari country, vast, sparsely populated and many game parks (Okavango, Chobe, Central Kalahari, ...). But the heat, the drought, and in some places the dangerous animals make it a trivial cycling country. But maybe this is exactly the challenge!

FoodDrink.body:
Drinkable water
  • Water from the tap is better to avoid.
  • The beer is not expensive and of excellent quality. Brewery a. De coq has many varieties, including bock beers and beer of 12%.

Health.body: The biggest problem in Botswana is AIDS. It is estimated that about 23.5% of the adult population is infected, the highest in the world. The risk of contamination via contaminated needles is small, and the hospitals are well equipped and of a high standard. Condoms (if you have such plans) are widely available (at street stalls, petrol stations, ...), and are also made available free of charge in toilets in almost all public buildings.

Other.body:
Best period
  • The dry season runs from april to october, and this is without a doubt the best cycling season. The weather will be dry and clear for 6 months, with a temperature between 20 and 30 degrees during the day and a temperature at night that can sometimes cool down to freezing point. The big advantage of this season for the camper is that all small dangerous animals (snakes, scorpions, ...) hibernate.
  • The rainy season lasts from november to march. It is then warmer (30 ° to 35 °)
  • In the north botswana has a subtropical climate, in the south a semi-arid desert climate.
  • Winters can be cold with freezing temperatures typical of desert areas.
  • Dry winds sometimes cause sand storms from the kalahari desert. The country sometimes falls prey to long periods of drought.
  • The tourist high season is situated around the holiday periods of the botswanese and south african schools. Schools have holidays from august 9 to september 9, from december 9 to january 21 and from april 9 to may 9.

Average temperature
  • In the winter months (june-august) the daytime temperature rises to 25 °, at night it can cool down to around 5.
  • In the summer months (december-february) it will be 35 to 40 °, and it will remain warm at night. Then the heat storms also develop in the afternoon.
Spare parts
Gaborone has 1 bicycle repairman worthy of that name. He has many qualitative parts in stock and will be able to help you with repairs. You can find it across the bp gas station, at the station mall, not far from gaborone's central bus station. (note from admin: please add marker to the map if you know where this is).

People.body:
Setswana (translated: language of the Tswana people ") and English are the 2 official languages. Most people can speak English, only sporadically you will find someone who can only speak Setswana. Learn a few words of Setswana, and many doors will open for you. 
  • Dumela Ma / Ra (Good day to a woman / man), 
  • Kea Leboga (Thank you)
  • Ee (Yes), 
  • Nnyaa (no)

Safety.body:
Although "safety" is always very relative, you can call Botswana a very safe country. The people are very sympathetic, aggression is not at all in their culture. The police still walk around unarmed, prisoners walk untouched across the street to the hospital and back here in Gaborone.
In addition to the western court system for serious offenses, each village has its "Kgotla", a kind of people's court for minor offenses where the village elders sit. The respect for this last court is great, and petty crime is low.
Safety.body_corruption: Corruption is also very uncommon. Never try to tip a customs officer or officer. According to the annually published CPI (Corruption Perceptions Index), Botswana is the least corrupt country in Africa.
Safety.body_traffic:
• The main roads are in relatively good condition but are heavily used. (With the exception of the Nata-kasane route). The maximum speed is 120 km / h. There is no room for cyclists on these roads, cycling is strongly discouraged.
  • The smaller roads are much less busy, but are not always paved. Much of the road network in Botswana consists of these "Gravel" roads.
  • Signage is hardly available. Provide a good map, a compass and possibly a GPS.

Transport.body_airplane:
• Most routes from Europe go via Johannesburg in South Africa. From Jo-burg you can fly to Gaborone (350km), Kasane (1200km) and Maun (900km).
  • All airports in Botswana are small and uncluttered. The advantage is that they are all located close to the city. The center of Gaborone is 10 km from the SSK (Sir Seretse Khama) airport, Kasane at 5 km. You can arrive there, find a quiet place to mount your bike and leave while cycling.
  • A taxi between SSK and the center of Gaborone costs about 70 Pula.
Transport.body_boat: From Zambia you can cross the Chobe River by ferry and arrive at the border post of Kazungula (near Kasane).
Transport.body_bus: Small vans are used for local and local transport, and you cannot take bicycles there. Larger buses do run between the major cities (Francistown, Gaborone, Maun, ...), so taking your bike with you is no problem here.

Visa.body:
There are quite a lot of countries that can enter Botswana for 90 days without a visa.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Drinkable water
  • There are restaurants in every village. Jurgen and Anke: "We had a great meal there, always for little money."
  • The food is often prepared with a lot of hygiene: staff wear gloves, paper caps and sometimes even mouth masks.
  • Drinking water from bottles is readily available everywhere.
  • Wendy and Marten: "We cycled in the south and drank tap water everywhere. We were often offered cooled water in restaurants or at people's homes, with ice cubes! We never got sick. It tastes good in the big cities. sometimes to chlorine. "

Health.body: • Wendy and Marten (2006-2007): "We have received a (free) dengue shot in the country, against infection from a mosquito that causes a lot of joint pain and headaches."

Other.body:
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
  • In the south, temperatures range from 15 degrees in winter (june to august) to over 30 degrees in summer.
  • In the amazon you can go all year round outside the rainy season. Roads then become impassable. Jurgen and anke (2005): "We were there just after the rainy season and even then some roads were still very bad."
  • In the rest of the country it is humid and hot during the summer (above 30 degrees) and dry and warm in the winter (around 25 degrees).
Spare parts
  • Inner and outer tires (26 ”) are available in the larger places. 28 ”is difficult to find.
  • Most bike shops only do basic repairs.

People.body: The people are friendly and very helpful. They are always ready to show the way and help with any other questions. They also look with amazement at those active cycling people, especially because it is so hot. The population mainly speaks Portuguese but with Spanish you come quite far as well.

Safety.body:
• Jurgen and Anke (2005): "We thought Brazil was the most unsafe country where we cycled. In terms of feeling and stories, although nothing happened to us. We would not recommend cycling alone.
  • Wendy and Marten (2006-2007): "The stories that the country is unsafe are endorsed by the population. However, we have not noticed anything, the south is even a pleasant area for cycling. Some roads are very dangerous (on the BR 101 NOT cycling) but with some searching there are many quiet roads. "
Safety.body_nature: • In the Amazon you come across many barking dogs that do not bite.
Safety.body_traffic: In the North East of Brazil, many roads are well paved and often with a wide hard shoulder that is usually good for cycling. But you will also find many gravel and dirt roads. Especially the latter are difficult to ride. Fat tires are therefore useful, but also a map on which the off-road roads are indicated. (primary roads, secondary roads, gravel roads, ..)

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
• With a hammock you can possibly sleep in people's homes. Hang out your hammock under a lean-to
  • Wendy and Marten: "In the southern provinces (near Rio de Janeiro and more south) we were occasionally invited to people's homes. The hospitality is very different from Asia. People are (scared) by stories about robbery and manslaughter. "
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
• There are no campsites in the Amazon.
  • www.campingclube.com.br/
  • Aaldrik and Sonya: "You can ask at any petrol station if you can camp. This will rarely, if ever, be refused. The advantage is that you have access to a toilet, water and often a shower. And it is free. Also. there is often 24-hour security, which benefits your night's sleep. "
  • Aaldrik and Sonya: "There are many campsites on the coast, but they are often in a poor condition and are shockingly expensive (up to 20 euros for a tent and two people). someone puts up your tent and that you share the shower and toilet with the occupant of the house. "
Sleeping.body_hostels: • Aaldrik and Sonya: "Hotels are very expensive (count on 30 to 40 euros for two people) and if you find a cheaper place to stay, then the quality is also appropriate."
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Jurgen and Anke: "There is room for wild camping, but for safety reasons this does we don't recommend it."

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Brazil without visa for up to 90 days (see this Wikipedia page for exceptions of duration of stay).


Visa policy of Brazil
  Brazil
  Entry with identity cards possible
  Visa exemption
  Visa must be obtained in advance

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Bulgaria has a lot to offer cyclists: The Danube Valley, a beautiful mountain region (south), sun and a friendly population. There are two middle mountain ridges running from east to west. The most northerly is the Balkan Mountains and consists largely of limestone with many caves and subterranean rivers. The Danube flows north of the Balkan Mountains, the border river with Romania. In the plain of the Danube and Balkan Mountains, there are gently undulating wheat fields and fields of sunflowers. The southern mountain region is formed by three densely forested mountain regions, the Rila, Pirin and Rhodope mountains. The latter mountain range is thinner forested towards the east. You will still find numerous monasteries, sometimes still in use. Sofia does not appeal to many cyclists: large gloomy buildings and few terraces. Plovdiv, the second largest city in size, has a beautiful old town. The Black Sea coast is frequented by tourists. (Source: Cycling in Europe, ENFB)

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
  • There is nowhere for sale butane gas, but unleaded petrol.
  • Benzene is also very difficult to find (or maybe not at all).
Supermarkets
  • The food is better and more varied in quality than in romania.
  • What can be bought in food and drink depends on the season. The country shops generally have a limited number of vegetables and fruits. You have more choice at markets and in greengrocers in larger cities. In the villages you sometimes have to look for vegetables, but there is always something for sale.
  •  The corn white bread that is baked in the morning is delicious. However, breakfast is usually not a fun activity in bulgaria. Bad bread. So a nice picnic is also not possible.
  • Jam, biscuits, (sheep) cheese, preserves and sweet pastries are for sale everywhere. You have to put in more effort for dairy products, chocolate, lemonade, baby products (diapers, milk powder) and film rolls.
Restaurants
  • Along the way you can find eateries where the food is not expensive.
  • In sofia you can eat extensively for little.
Drinkable water
  • Drinking water is not a problem, there are wells and taps everywhere. The water tastes fine.
  • Water: in the mountains you will find springs almost everywhere. Buying water is therefore not necessary.

Other.body:
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
April, may, june and september are the best cycling months, when you avoid the greatest heat of the summer and the cold of the winter. In the summer it is wonderful cycling in the mountain area: now and then a cloud and not too hot. In the evening it can cool down considerably. It can get very hot in the valleys.

Spare parts
Bring spare parts. And certainly brake pads. If no bicycle repairer can be found, look for help in a garage (or a lock smit!) where they're happy to help a cyclist. Well-inflated tires are less likely to puncture. Taking a spare tire with you is no luxury given the road surface. Buy it when you arrive there. In cities with more than 50.000 people, you probably can find a bike shop.

People.body:
The population is very nice and hospitable. They just don't understand cycling and always send you to the main road towards the Black Sea. The population uses the Cyrillic script. So it is useful to learn the Cyrillic alphabet (see http://www.omniglot.com/writing/bulgarian.htm). Hardly anyone knows foreign languages, with the exception of young people, who often speak English. The people are generally very patient and are willing to explain it again with hands and feet. If you speak some Russian words, this is an advantage. Keep in mind that yes and no kinks have the opposite meaning.

When they invite you in the house you take off your shoes at the front door. You walk on socks or (guest) flip flops.

Safety.body: Bulgaria is a safe country for lonely cyclists. Take normal precautions. Bulgarians themselves complain about increasing theft, burglary and pickpocketing.
Safety.body_criminality: There are a few dangerous routes, such as on the E80 / E85 near the Turkish border, where cars and trucks are sometimes robbed and robbed. Also some campsites and motels seem to be a popular victim of robbery, which are better to avoid (note from admin: please verify this information and which places are we talking about?).
Safety.body_nature: Sometimes you come across annoying dogs on small roads.
Safety.body_traffic:
The roads are generally pretty quiet, with little car traffic. Bulgarian drivers generally behave correctly: they drive calmly and do not keep honking. Sofia is an exception as the traffic is dangerous for cyclists. Trucks and taxis take you into account, others don't. Wear highly visible clothing.

The E-roads are usually well paved but busy and formally even prohibited for cyclists (inquire on the spot!). Sometimes, however, there is no alternative available. In that case, the police will not make a fuss about it.
The inland roads are of varying quality, sometimes frequently repaired asphalt, cobblestones or gravel, but quiet and usually reasonably easy to cycle. Note that not all shortcuts are on the maps. In the mountains you can encounter quite steep roads with gradients of over 15%.
Watch out for the deep, poorly visible pits on the sides of the roads.
Paules Dukker and Ilona Berkhof took the road from Smolyan via Mugla to Borino. The road to Mugla was ascending but very beautiful. Beyond Mugla the road turned out to be no longer in use (various landslides and all bridges no longer functional).

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You are quickly invited to people's homes. Blanche (2007): "It is best to stay overnight with private individuals; best price / quality ratio. In 2007 we paid an average of 30 leva / 15 euros for two for a room with often a private bathroom. You can also ask the locals for a spot and they will almost always take you to a nice place to sleep by car, moped or donkey! "
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
• The number of campsites in Bulgaria is declining sharply. Only a few remain along the coast, most of which have been replaced by expensive resorts.
  • Inland campsites can be found within cycling distance, but they are not always easy to find. There are large and luxurious campsites, but also small, simple ones. Unfortunately, the sanitary facilities often leave something to be desired, sometimes even dirty. The costs are low.
  • An overview of campsites can be obtained from the tourist office.
  • Most camping sites have wooden houses that you can rent.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are plenty of hotels, people want to help you on your way. There are about 50 youth hostels.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Wild camping is officially prohibited and not recommended because of wild dogs and malicious people. Rather, get permission from a landowner to stand in their property and they will be happy to provide any help you need.

Paules Dukker and Ilona Berkhof (2009) had no problems with wild camping. Usually we have pitched our tent in the woods or along a deserted road. Dorenda and Maciek (2017) have also had no problems with wild camping anywhere.

Transport.body_airplane: Taking the bicycle with you differs per company. Always wise to inquire about the conditions when booking. Tip: There are various low budget flights to Thessaloniki in Greece (especially cheap offers from Germany) from which it is 1 or 2 days by bike to the Bulgarian border.
Transport.body_boat:
You can come from Turkey with a passenger boat.

Regular boat services sail along the Danube and along the coast to larger towns, you can bring your bike.
Transport.body_bus: Buses run frequently and are not expensive. However, there are hardly any large buses with which your bicycle can travel. Another problem is the lack of timetables. To be on the safe side, always ask the following: "Moga li da vzemam kolelo?" Can I bring the bicycle (Kolelo = bicycle).
Transport.body_train:
By train to Sofia: from Western Europe via Italy or Hungary to Belgrade. From Belgrade night train to Sofia.

It's very easy to take your bike on the train in Bulgaria, although you may have to take the panniers off to lift it up the steps into the rear carriage. When you buy your ticket, you need to buy a ticket for the bike too at a cost of 2 Lev. The trains on which bicycles are allowed are very slow!. https://www.bdz.bg/en/a/transportation-of-bicycles

Visa.body:
Bulgaria is not yet part of the Schengen area, but are members of EU. However, they have a visa policy that is based on the Schengen policy.

Schengen Area visa lists.
  Schengen Area
  Other EU member states outside the Schengen Area but bound by the same visa policy and legally obliged to join the Area when they meet the criteria, and special territories of Schengen member states (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Member of the EU with independent visa policy (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Visa-free access to the Schengen states for short stays, usually 90 days in any 180-day period (EU 2018/1806 Annex II)
  Visa required to enter the Schengen states, and to transit some Schengen states in some circumstances (EU 2018/1806 Annex I)
  Visa required to transit any Schengen state (EC 810/2009 Annex IV)
  Travel documents not accepted
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Food
  • There are plenty of places to eat, the quality of which varies widely. Dinner is often prepared and stored in large bowls in the afternoon. Cold limp fries are normal and no one complains about them. Make sure you have sufficient food supplies on the way.
  • Petrol is available for cooking, they measure half a liter for you neatly. The quality is usually not good, it still contains lead.
  • In Ouagadougou you can get everything, there is even a hypermodern supermarket that sells wholemeal bread, among other things!

Drink
  • Along the way there are many pumps with good water, installed by means of development funds. Make sure you have sufficient water supplies along the way.
  • Avoid pits as much as possible because of the risk of contamination. Bringing a water filter is highly recommended.
  • In the cities and some villages, in addition to bottles, water is sold in plastic bags. Only the printed, sealed ones contain good quality water.
  • Children with handcart and cool box sell frozen bisap, a kind of red lemonade made from hibiscus, nice for a change!

Health.body:
• Healthcare is at a low level. In case of major problems, it is better to move to neighboring Ghana.
  • Malaria occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis and the like are available on site.
  • Yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.
  • Vaccinations against DTP and hepatitis A are recommended
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.

People.body: In the province the people are very cordial and hospitable, but generally slightly more reserved than in neighboring Mali. The official language is French with several local languages in addition.

Safety.body: Burkina Faso is a poor but relatively safe country.
Safety.body_criminality: Like almost everywhere, it is important to look after your belongings in the cities. Especially in the capital Ougadougou and especially when the biennial film festival 'Fespaco' is organized (end of February and beginning of March of the odd years). In addition to many tourists, this also attracts a lot of scum to the city.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: In the villages you will always find something for you, ask for the "Chef de village" if necessary.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In many places there are hotels, which vary in quality.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible, not dangerous either, but you will get a lot of attention in the vicinity of the villages. Make sure you have a well-ventilated tent as the ground is heated by the sun during the day and can make your tent uncomfortably hot at night.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Burundi.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Cambodia is a poor country, but you can still go here as a cyclist. People are helpful and you can eat and find a place to stay overnight.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
If you use a burner, there is enough fuel to be found, the question is whether it is clean. However, the prices are so low that you cannot cook for it yourself.

Supermarkets
Soft drinks and beer are available everywhere.

Street markets
Cambodia is one of the few countries where you can get ice (frozen water) in the middle of nowhere. A relic from the time of the french. Every morning there are small "Ice factories" where a load of frozen water is transported every morning to cool boxes in restaurants.

Restaurants
Provided you are not too picky, you can eat well and cheaply in any decent village. Cambodians like it spicy like the thai. There is a difference: in cambodia you get the (hot) spices served on a separate dish. As a vegetarian, there are often only one or two choices left.

Health.body: Cambodia is notorious for diseases such as malaria, TBS and dengue fever. Inquire well before your trip about the health measures you can take. There are small clinics in the interior, but they can offer you little more than a painkiller and a plaster. In addition, there are not many doctors in the interior. Previously, everyone with a little education was murdered by the Khmer Rouge and many doctors were also covered. The situation is only slowly improving.

Other.body:
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
The monsoons prevail from may to october: wet and hot.
It can still rain heavily in november, although it is cooler than the months before.

Tourist high season
Most tourists come to the country in december and january, because it is then “cool” and dry.

Average temperature
December and january are the most suitable months for cycling because it is "Cool" and dry. When it comes to cool, you should think of maximum temperatures of around 30 degrees.
February, march and april are the hottest months with temperatures between 35 and 40 degrees.

Spare parts
You can hardly buy spare parts. So bring everything yourself. You can fix and inflate tires (especially French valves) everywhere, but do not expect any more advanced technology. People want to help and sit everywhere, but they cannot provide service to a bicycle (see what they ride themselves). Most villages have a workshop where they can (try to) repair your bicycle. Consider, for example, moped business.

Safety.body: Mines remain a major problem. You are only safe on the main roads and in inhabited areas. Outside the inhabited areas it is wise to stay on the main road. Don't just cycle up a quiet road.
Safety.body_criminality: Phnom Penh and Siem Reap are notorious for robberies. Keep your belongings with you, and make sure you get back to your sleeping place on time.
Safety.body_traffic:
The quality of the roads varies from tight asphalt to dusty dirt roads that in the rainy season turn into mud puddles where you sink deep into. Cambodia is increasingly successful in making roads more passable with help from abroad.

Traffic is crazy, but only Pnohm Penh is really busy, but if you go with the flow it is very doable. The speeds are generally low and there is enough space for making mistakes. The fellow road users anticipate that and also expect you to anticipate their mistakes. If you do that, it will be fine.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: The population is happy to offer you shelter. It is best to inquire at a restaurant. Men can also go to temples.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no official campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In the south, the distance from hotel to hotel is rarely more than approx. 100 km; you often cycle past a hotel. You will also find hotels in smaller towns. It is more difficult to find a place to sleep in the north and the east. When you go down the "main road" (relative concept in Cambodia) there are few or no hotels. The distance between hotels can then quickly be 2 days cycling (200 km).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is allowed. Of course you have to be very careful with landmines. Outside the infamous areas, however, it is very good to wildcamp. People are curious but they quickly leave you alone compared with other parts of Asia. There is always a place to be found in the jungle. You do have to watch out for many different insects (red ants!) That like to crawl into your things. You can spend the night on flonders on which lumberjacks used to sleep. They are about a meter from the ground and you can sleep well on them. Of course with a mosquito net.

Transport.body_boat: From Thailand you can enter the country at Shihanoukville.
Transport.body_bus: There are not many buses, often only in the morning. Many buses run on the better roads. If you want to keep your bike intact, you don't want to transport it there. Buses are very cheap. In the luxurious Angkor Express double decker buses from Phnom Penh to Siem Reap V.V and from Phnom Penh to Sihanouk V.V. can cycle along. There are even mopeds on the bus.
Transport.body_train: The train is even cheaper than the bus, but very slow.

Visa.body: You can simply get a visa at the border. At the border of Laos / Cambodia you are obliged to undergo a health check, of course for a fee. You also pay a little more for your visa

About.body: Cameroon is not a country for inexperienced and luxury travelers. However, if you looking to experience the real africa, in which you meet friendly locals and experience struggles along the way, it might be a good destination. The west, north and south have completely different characters, both in terms of population, landscape and nature.

FoodDrink.body:
In all cities and many villages there are food stalls where you can get a reasonable to good meal. It usually consists of fish, chicken or bush meat (south) with cassava or plane tree.

Restaurants
In the cities there are circuits (small restaurants) with a similar offer to the stalls described above and sometimes also western food. Most of the better restaurants have this too. In the real restaurants, the food always seemed fine. With the cheaper ones I have had my doubts about the quality several times. Once, mowing even crawled out of my fish. Nevertheless, I have not been ill and not even had diarrhea!

Drinkable water
Officially you cannot drink the tap water. But according to some expats it can be done locally. Some better hotels filter themselves. Sometimes there is a village pump where you can get drinkable water. Bottled water is available almost everywhere, even in small villages. Only in the south it is more difficult.

Health.body:
• Yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs all year round.

Other.body:
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
The dry season happens during November to March. I thought december and january was a good time to visit cameroon. Had some rain in the west and south. This mainly occurred in the evening and at night and caused hardly any nuisance. The positive effect of these showers was that the roads were less dusty.

Tourist high season
The foreigners who come there are usually there for (voluntary) work, study or family visit.

Spare parts
Although there is a fair amount of cycling in the north, derailleur bikes are rare. I have the impression that there is a lot available in the big cities and the north. Finding what you need can sometimes be difficult.

People.body: The population consists of approximately 200 ethnic groups, each with their own language. The official languages are English (two provinces) and French. In the English-speaking provinces you can work well with both English and French. However, knowledge of English is limited in the French-speaking provinces. Here and there you can also use German, Spanish and Arabic (north). The population is usually very friendly and interested without being troublesome or intrusive.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Although the travel guides regularly mention campements and possibilities for camping at hotels or auberges, there are no experiences that it is indeed possible to camp.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels and Auberges can be found in almost every city and at transfer points for the bust. There are also occasional auberges in small towns. Where yes and no is often unpredictable. The quantity is such that you can consider leaving the tent at home. In general auberges are cheaper than hotels, this is also noticeable in the facilities, although the price / quality ratio can vary greatly. It is usually assumed that you want air conditioning (if available), the price of a room with a fan can sometimes be considerably lower.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible here and there, but depending on the requirements you set and probably not easy. Especially in the north, the bush is often burned to get rid of the dry grasses. Putting the tent up somewhere in the dry season is therefore not recommended. Many stranded travelers standing along the road light a fire in the roadside where they lie down to sleep. You could also do this as a cyclist.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Cameroon.

Source: Wikipedia.

6e16d12b-91ac-48c2-b1c3-bb40594fffa3.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

FoodDrink.body:
• You can eat and drink well, even for vegetarians. There is more than enough choice in the supermarkets as well as in the restaurants and eateries. The food is affordable (slightly cheaper than the Netherlands). A must is Mr Mike's, where you can eat for $ 10, plus you get healthy food and the service is very friendly. You can also always buy food at gas stations.
  • Try the subway in the cities: for a real sandwich.
  • In the Okanagan Valley it is fruit season around mid-September.
  • Nova Scotia is for fishing enthusiasts.

Health.body:
Take out good health insurance in advance: the Canadian health insurance fund does not cover health insurance for foreigners. 

Bicycle helmets and good lighting are mandatory in British Colombia, at least on the highway and is certainly recommended. On the busier highways, extra protection such as reflective bags or vests does not hurt.

Other.body:
Spare parts
  • In the larger cities there are bicycle shops, especially mountain bikes. Not much to be found along the way, but Canadians are very helpful.
  • There are several well-stocked bicycle shops in Toronto for both mountain and racing bikes. The salespeople are very helpful.
  • Buying a bicycle is cheaper in Canada.
  • Good experiences with Cyclepath.
  • Bike shops in Kelowna, Penticton, Princeton. At the KVR you have a problem with a breakdown, often remote.
  • Pieter: "In British Colombia there are also bicycle shops in most of the smaller villages. Also ask at a more general sports / outdoor shop."
Tips
  • Those who go to Nova Scotia and are short on time should go to Cape Breton first. The Cabot Trail is fantastic.
  • Anyone who leaves Canada by plane should take into account that his petrol burner must be left behind. So send home by boat.
  • Bas: "I just got my gas burner on the plane from Halifax, but maybe that's a bit different at the larger airports."

People.body: The population is very friendly, very helpful and easy to contact, especially around the campfire at the campsite. There is a lot of appreciation for the cyclist. Cyclists are a special feature in remote places, which in turn leads to nice contacts. The language of instruction is English. French is also spoken in some places.

Safety.body: Canada is ideal for the nature lover, where cycling on the major roads should be taken for granted.
Safety.body_traffic:
• The quality of the roads is reasonable to good, on the hard shoulder a little less. Cyclists are a common sight on major roads.
  • There are busy highways on Vancouver Island and around the cities. Toronto, in particular, is notorious. Cyclists are not always taken into account. 
  • It is quiet on the back roads in the Rocky Mountains, for example.
  • It is fairly quiet from mid-June to mid-July, half of them are campers.
  • The emergency lane - if available - must be used by cyclists; These strips are wide. Due to the limited speed on the roads, cycling on the emergency lanes is not annoying.
  • Pieter N .: "On some routes the motorways are very busy and the driving is very fast (officially max. 110 km / h, in practice faster). Not always pleasant. In the less densely populated areas the motorways are correspondingly quieter to almost completely extinct. "

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Every village has a campsite or something similar. It is pricey on your own, but it is quite normal to share a place together. So make a tour around the campsite before you install yourself. Costs can vary considerably. There is enough space at the campsites. There are special camping pitches for cyclists between the campers. There are plenty of campsites from simple to luxurious and large, but a lot of nature. The distances between the campsites are quite considerable. At the campsites you will often find a picnic set (table + bench) and fire pit.

At a ranger station you can request an overview of 'dispersed campgrounds'. These are free camping spots in nature; a lawn with a fire ring. Sometimes on a stream or river. In some cases with a picnic table and / or a pit toilet.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Motels offer a great option for an overnight stay in the city.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is also possible and doable. Be aware of bears. Always follow the directions of the rangers. Never leave food in your tent. Also no cans of beer, because bears love beer and can smell it through the can. Furthermore, toothpaste for bears is a delicacy. At campsites you have bear boxes where you can safely store food and other items that attract bears. Pepper spray and a bear bell can be helpful.

Transport.body_airplane: Several airlines fly to different cities in Canada. Taking the bicycle with you differs per company and is subject to change. Always wise to inquire about the conditions when booking.

Visa.body:
There are only a few nationalities that don't need a visa, however, they do need an Electronic Travel Authorization. All other countries do need a visa.

  Canada
  Countries with visa-free access to Canada
(eTA required when arriving by air, except for United States nationals)
  Electronic Travel Authorization or visa required
(eTA only available for citizens who have held a Canadian visa in the last 10 years or who hold a valid United States non-immigrant visa when arriving by air)
  Visa required for entry to Canada

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Do you want to cook yourself: the distances between the villages are not great and there is a possibility to stock up on something everywhere.

Restaurants
With the sea all around, it is not surprising that it is mainly fish that is served. The cuisine mainly resembles the portuguese. So often a combination of fish, salad, vegetables, potatoes (fries) and rice. There are plenty of restaurants, but pay attention to the meal times. Most of them have a european design and the quality is generally good. Hot meals start at 5 euro (info 2007). You can also order sandwiches in the afternoon. For the vegetarian it will not be too difficult to find something. There are bean dishes without meat.

Drinkable water
It is not recommended to drink tap water. Bottled water is available everywhere.

Health.body:
It is dry, so drink, drink, drink a lot !!!

Mandatory vaccinations
  • If you come from a yellow fever area, a vaccination is mandatory.
  • A dtp vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against hepatitis a is recommended.
  • Sometimes a cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs from september to november.

Other.body:
Best bike period
  • In september and october it is rainy season with heavy showers and flooding.
  • There is always wind, especially in january.
  • Just before the rainy season it is hot, the rest of the year it is fine cycling and very dry with midday temperatures of about 25-27 degrees.
Spare parts
You see few bicycles and there is little for sale when it comes to spare equipment. Bring your own is the motto.

People.body:
The population is descended from Portuguese and African slaves. One can be characterized as nice and swinging, but somewhat intrusive in the tourist environment. As a cyclist you are spontaneously encouraged. There are no stone throwers. Cape Verde is a Catholic country, there are no regulations regarding clothing. The population themselves dress very loosely.

Portuguese is the official language with a number of Creole dialects on the right. With Spanish you can manage reasonably well and in tourist spheres you can come along with some French or English.

Safety.body: It is certainly safe during the day. In the capital Praia it is not recommended to walk on the street in the evening.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are hotels and guesthouses everywhere. From about 15 Euro you have a simple and clean accommodation. There is usually a solution for the bicycle.

Visa.body: You need a visa.  On arrival at the airport on site it is also possible it costs 25 Euro. (info 2007, please update if you have more recent information).

About.body:
Chile is a beautiful country, perhaps the most beautiful in South America, especially in the lake area, the Paso Agua Negra and the oases in the north. The south is recommended for everyone, the dirt roads to Illapel are a bit more adventurous, but the Paso Agua Negra is especially for experienced cyclists. There are many cyclists who cycle from the lake area to Tierra del Fuego.

The itinerant cyclist, following the adventurous gravel road (Ruta 7, Carretera Austral) from Chaiten to Villa O'Higgins, will notice few historical areas of traditions and culture in the Region X and Region XI regions of Chilean Patagonia. He / She is mainly dependent on the many nature reserves or national parks along the route. On the stretch from Chaiten to Cochrane, the dense rainforests of Pumalin and Queulat National Parks, glacial scenery of Rio Simpson Nature Reserve and wooded mountain scenery in Cerro Castillo Nature Reserve are the attractions of the region. There are plenty of walking and hiking routes in the national parks. In the vicinity of Puyuhuapi there are facilities to take a break from the adventurous journey by using the thermal baths, Termas de Puyuhuapi. Between Cerro Castillo and Cochrane, travelers imagine themselves in a different world, which is mainly determined by the untouched nature and wetlands along the meandering Rio Ibanez and Rio Murta rivers. The last part of the Carretera Austral shows a fairly inaccessible fjord landscape near Puerto Yungay (Tortel district). This piece can be regarded as one of the last wildernesses of Patagonia, where man has not yet intervened. The last part of the gravel road ends in Villa O'Higgins, where the cyclist can make the crossing to Argentina via a ferry. For many cyclists it is a challenge to complete the approx. 20 kilometer long mountain bike route from Candelario Mansilla (Chile) to the lake Lago del Desierto (Argentina) in five hours. The cyclist braves many steep slopes and will make a lot of crossing over the pools in the dense forest, before reaching Argentina.

The tourist attractions of the Region XII region in the very south of Chile are located in the walking & hiking paradise of the world, Torres del Paine. This world-famous park is a worthy end to a journey of discovery through Patagonia. The attraction of the famous Torres del Paine peaks makes many tourists decide to take the nine-kilometer hike so that they can immortalize themselves with the vertical granite towers.

The return trip to the civilized world of Patagonia can be made with a ship from shipping company Navimag. The cruise from Puerto Natales to Puerto Montt, 1500 kilometers away, takes four days and heads north along the Chilean fjords, narrow sea passages (Patagonia Channels) and glaciers. If the sailing schedule and weather conditions permit, you can visit the glacier Amalia. From the boat you have a view of the barren mountain landscapes along the Chilean south coast for days. The low-hanging clouds can obstruct the beautiful view of the Patagonian ice fields.

In the lake district of Patagonia you can find historical areas with traditions and culture of Mapuchu Indians and Jesuits. European influences and the Christian faith have mainly left their traces on the island of Chiloe and in the major cities of the region IX. Several colorful wooden churches are located in the center of picturesque fishing villages and towns. However, the attractions of the Lake District are the many volcanoes and national parks (P.N. Villarrica, P.N. Nahuel Huapi and P.N. Vicente P. Rosales).

The Atacama Desert is very dominant in the north of Chile (Region I and II). In the desert you will find deserted ghost towns near the mining areas. Impressive natural phenomena such as dune formation, moon landscape, volcano tops, vast salt plains and geothermal activities can be found especially at San Pedro de Atacama. In the mountain valleys near the coastal town of Arica, the giant figures drawn on the mainly bare mountain flanks (petroglyphs) and ancient storage sites of the Incas are nice historical sights.

The remote mountain villages are located on the plateau (Altiplano). The remote mountain roads through the national parks show the diversity of flora and fauna. National park P.N. Lauca is recommended for cyclists who cycle from Bolivia to Arica and want to enjoy the many volcano peaks (+ 5000 m) and lakes. In the vicinity of the national park, many houses in mountain villages are deserted. The residents (shepherds) only return during religious festivals.

FoodDrink.body:
Drinking water
In general, the tap water is perfectly drinkable, in the cities it has a strong chlorine taste and in Northern Chile drinking is not recommended (not only because of the chlorine, the water simply tastes dirty).

Restaurants
In the south along the Pan Americana and in the lake district are good restaurants (as in Western Europe).

Shops
Even in the smallest villages there are shops selling food and drinks. However, these are generally more expensive than larger supermarkets and the quality is less; often snacks with a lot of chocolate. 

In the desert in the north, the distances between villages are a lot longer, are a lot longer than in the south, but still doable without having to carry too much food. Hardly any people live in the north on the high mountain passes, so bring plenty of food. Please note that on Paso Agua Negra you cannot buy food in Juntas (customs office only).

Burners
It is difficult to obtain fuel for a methanol burner. Camping gaz is also hard to come by. For a gasoline burner you can often buy so-called bencina blanca at a ferreteria or paint shop, benzene actually.

Health.body:
Mandatory vaccinations
No compulsory vaccinations.

Useful vaccinations for cyclists
Nowadays a good vaccination against rabies (rabies) is available, it consists of three vaccinations.

Other.body:
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
  • For the part south of santiago you better go in the summer (our winter). Long pants, a sweater and certainly good rain gear are still necessary
  • In the north it can be very hot in summer (our winter).
  • On the high plains (altiplano), one must take into account rapidly changing weather conditions in the summer months (december to march). Weather change is often accompanied by heavy rain and thunderstorms, strong gusts of wind and falling temperatures. These weather phenomena mainly occur in the late afternoon. The weather is often stable in the early morning.

Tourist high season
January / february is high season, december and march are less busy.

Prevailing wind directions
The wind comes from the sea, turns north above puerto montt and south below puerto montt. Cycling from north to south seems to be the most attractive. The wind always blows hard in the far south.

Average temperature
Varies by region.

Spare parts
In the larger cities and tourist places (such as pucon) good material is available, both parts (up to deore xt) and tools. Beyond that, if there are bicycle shops at all, the range is limited / often unsuitable for touring bikes.

The most common tire size is 26 inches, this tire size is not difficult to come by (everyone rides mountain bikes). You see a lot of racing bikes in big cities. Here it should be possible to get other tire sizes, but perhaps without a profile.

In santiago, all bicycle shops are located in (calle) san diego 800 and higher. Further south (carretera austral) you will find good bicycle repairers in coihayque and punta arenas. There is little or nothing in between.

People.body: It is very useful if you speak Spanish. People are friendly and helpful.

Safety.body: Chile is a safe country. Only in and around Santiago and Valparaiso are less safe neighborhoods, beyond that the country looks safe, but even Santiago seems to be a safe city by South American standards. In general it is not a problem to cycle alone, cycling is accepted as a means of transport as well as a sport. Both men and women get on their racing bike or mountain bike in tight cycling clothing.
Safety.body_nature:
Joost and Maud (2006): "Street dogs are absolutely no problem and guard dogs are usually behind fencing. Sometimes the latter is not the case and in certain areas we have had 'dog sticks' at hand (afterwards everything turned out better, better technology is to stop when a dog chases you and make sure that the bicycle is between you and the dog. Often the challenge for the dog is gone and after a short walk next to the bicycle you can continue cycling). Dazer also helps.

In the north, drought can be a problem (no water).
Safety.body_traffic:
• There is a lot of freight traffic on the Pan-Americana, which is no fun.
  • Buses and taxis are particularly dangerous for cyclists. Buses in particular often run under great time pressure, the drivers are often overtired by working days that are too long.
  • Along many asphalted main roads is an asphalted hard shoulder, with a width of 60cm to 2m, on which it is pleasant to cycle without having to look in your mirror all the time. Watch out for glass and other junk on this strip.
  • The Pan Americana is a good but busy asphalt road. Other asphalt roads are good too, but much quieter. Dirt roads are almost all accessible in bad weather, but often have a lot of washboard. There are also some parts of the route in the desert and the high mountains in the north where there is some loose sand. Only a few cars per day pass on this route.
  • Roads in the Central Valley are quite good, as well as around Santiago. There is a lot of gravel / washboard in Patagonia.
  • In southern Chile, the paved roads often consist of concrete slabs, but sometimes only in one direction, such as from Puerto Natales to Punta Arenas. There is mainly freight traffic and some tourist traffic.
  • You are not allowed to cycle on the highways near Santiago.
  • Dirt roads can be very hilly, but recommended due to little traffic.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
• There are a relatively large number of well-maintained campsites in the tourist areas. Keep in mind that many campsites are only open during the high season (December - March).
  • The nature parks sometimes have beautiful camping pitches (sometimes also free). In national parks, camping is only allowed where indicated.
  • There are hardly any campsites outside the tourist areas.
  • In 2006/2007 the price of campsites is around 8000 pesos, just over 10 euros. They are often mainly aimed at families. The larger official campsites can easily be found via the Turistel Camping guide (approx. 5000 pesos) which also has maps (no height / relief indication). You will often also find signs for other campsites along the route. They are often more pleasant for cyclists.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
In most of the larger towns there are plenty of affordable hostels / youth hostels / Residentiales / hotels. Parking bicycles is rarely a problem.

Hospedajes are cheap overnight accommodations with private individuals: bed + breakfast. They are located in the lake district around Osorno and towns along the Pan-Americana.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible everywhere and sometimes even necessary in the sparsely populated north. The population is usually not difficult about it and when you ask for permission to camp wild on someone's land, you are not easily refused. This is of course more difficult around urban areas and also less sensible in connection with safety.

Transport.body_airplane:
Several airlines fly to Chile. Taking the bicycle with you differs per company. Always wise to inquire about the conditions when booking. Also pay attention if you continue with a domestic flight from abroad. Even if your baggage appears to be tagged through, you must first "clear" it yourself at the airport where you enter the country (Santiago).

Domestic transport by plane is doable. The extra costs for the bicycle are limited.
Transport.body_boat:
From Argentina you can risk the crossing at Lago del Desierto to Candelario Mansilla in Chile. You must complete the walking or cycling tour within 5 to 6 hours, otherwise you will miss the ferry in the late afternoon. Anyone who does not make it can go to one of the refugios of the argentine or chilean army. The shelters are located resp. on the north side of Lago del Desierto in Argentina and south side of Lago Villa O'Higgins, Candelario Mansilla in Chile. In the summer season there is a ferry service once or twice a week.

You can bring the bike. Keep in mind that the ships often sail according to a timetable and only visit a place once every few days.
Transport.body_bus:
Modern coaches are used for a large part of domestic transport. Usually it is no problem at all to take your bike with you, although you sometimes have to pay for it. In principle, everything can be reached by buses. If you go further south (south of Chiloe and Puerto Montt) it is no longer possible to cover the entire distance by road. You then have to divert to Argentina, fly or try to get a boat.

Chilean buses are generally cheap and good. You almost always have to pay for taking your bicycle on the bus, a quarter to the same amount as your bus ticket. The greater the distance traveled, the relatively cheaper the bicycle. Bicycle is usually paid for by the driver. Try to buy a bicycle ticket at the counter, that will not often work, but if you succeed, you will probably be cheaper than the driver.

In "single-deckers", the bicycle often fits entirely in the luggage compartment. Avoid double-deckers because they have a lot less luggage space. If you can already go on that, it is with loose wheels.

Jozef: "Sometimes you have to pay extra to take your bicycle with you. Pullman takes the cake and asks 5000 Pesos per bicycle (about 8 Euro) per long distance journey, a large amount compared to the regular bus ticket. To my knowledge also the only company with fixed rates for taking the bicycle with you, with other companies it is often possible to negotiate about the price (which is rolled up on the spot). "
Transport.body_train: Chile does not have an extensive network. Bicycle can be taken along for free, but it causes quite a few problems.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Chile without a visa.


Source: Wikipedia.

Other.body:
Best bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
In general, the best time for cycling is spring and fall. The north of china has a continental climate, with dry and cold winters from november to april. In the summer, hot and humid, the temperature can reach over 30 degrees. Central china, with the yangtse river as its vein, is hotter and more humid. Winters are short there. 

The south is warm to hot and humid (32-36 degrees) all year round, with a slight dip between january and march, when it is cool and relatively dry. The rainy season here is roughly between april and september, with short heavy showers in the late afternoon.

The west has an extremely continental climate with dry and very hot summers and icy winters. Best time is may / june and september / october.

Kashgar: in the mountains there is already snow in autumn and it can freeze. During the day it can get warm.

Canton: august and september are very suitable. There were only a few showers, but they only last an hour.

Tourist high season
In the week of october 1 (national holiday) and for the celebration of chinese new year, many chinese people go on holiday.

Spare parts
The mountain bike is on the rise, but the quality leaves something to be desired. In large cities you can therefore find larger bicycle shops with parts from well-known brands such as shimano, but usually of poor quality. Therefore, take all parts (especially the pinion customer) with you.

Tires are mainly available in 26 inch, sometimes 27 inch. 28 inch tires are limited available, so you have to bring a spare, because many tires will break.

Bicycle repairers are skilled but do not always have suitable equipment. 

Kashgar: There are several bicycle repairers in kashgar, be sure to check the market! In kashgar there are a number of outdoor sports stores and the well-known giant store, where they have complete bicycles, but also shimano parts and bicycle bags.

Canton: There are workshops all along the way.

Yunnan: There is almost nothing to be found in Zhongdian. In Lijiang there is a Giantshop with enough stuff of reasonable quality that will help you in case of problems. In the Minzhu Lu you will also find smaller bicycle shops with a limited number of low-quality items.

People.body: In the remote areas of China, the Chinese welcome foreign cyclists with open arms. They are hospitable and invite you to have a cup of tea with them. In these areas you can arrange a place to sleep for a fee and experience traditional, close-knit family life.

Safety.body_traffic:
Types of roads
There is a strict hierarchy in roads:
  • 高速公路 (gao su gong lu): highway.
Highways mean smooth and new asphalt. In mountain regions (most of China) they cut through the landscape and are a combination of long viaducts and tunnels. This means that the slopes are usually gentle.
Motorways are usually not accessible to cyclists. Sometimes yes: it is possible to cycle on the stretch of highway from 景洪 (jinhong) to 磨憨 (mohan) near the border with Laos. Even though there are big red signs stating that cyclists are not allowed, just look at what the local population does: if they take to the road on foot, by bicycle or by motorcycle, it is in any case allowed to cycle there.
You can also cycle on highways where cyclists are certainly not allowed, nobody will stop you. Although this is at your own risk.
Motorways do not always have a hard lane, especially in mountain areas. Sometimes there are many dozen kilometers between two exits.
Motorways are always toll roads.
Today there are highways in large parts of China. This is good news for cyclists: it relieves other roads. Often there is an “old” road next to the highway. Sometimes there is little traffic on that old road, but this is not guaranteed: if the old road is not a toll road, it is sometimes busier than on the highway itself. After all, the toll is often very expensive. In addition, smaller types and open trucks are no more allowed on the highway than cyclists.
Highways are usually marked on maps with thick yellow strips with two red lines on the outside and a red line in the middle.
  • 快速 路 (kuai su lu): expressway
It is actually a small highway with no central reservation. The same remarks as for motorways also apply here.
On cards usually thick yellow strips with no red line in the middle. Not all maps show this type of road separately, usually this type of road is marked as a motorway (高速公路).
  • 国 道 (guo dao): national road.
These are roads of many 1000s kilometers long that cross the country.
They are easily accessible for cyclists.
The quality varies from completely destroyed by heavy trucks to excellent.
The traffic varies from quiet to hellish. Often these roads are used for local transport by small, open trucks (which are not allowed on the highway). They often transport gravel or other building materials. The road then becomes very dusty.
Usually these are not toll roads, but sometimes they are.
国 道 follow the landscape and do not often have long tunnels or bridges.
These are the roads most long-distance cyclists follow. Often for 100s or even 1000s km. It is easy to follow them without getting lost.
It is possible to traverse the country north-south or east-west along these roads.
国 道 always have kilometer markers with the distance to the end of the road.
国 道 always have a three-digit number, sometimes preceded by the letter G. On maps, these roads are usually represented by a red strip or line.
  • 省道 (sheng dao): provincial road.
These roads run within a province (省). They are similar to the 国 道, but shorter (100s km instead of 1000s)
省道 always have kilometer markers with the distance to the end of the road.
On maps, these roads are usually represented by a green strip or line.
  • 县 道 (xian dao): xian way
These roads run within a xian (arrondissement). They are not always indicated separately on cards: then they simply fall under the category “other”.
  • Others
There are many other minor roads. The quality of these roads varies from excellent smooth asphalt to hard-to-ride dust and stone chunks. And often, during rain, ankle-deep mud.
These smaller roads are also well indicated on maps with a sufficiently small scale. It is necessary to have such a map in order to follow these roads properly. Even with a good map, they are often difficult to follow (due to many exits and intersections that are not properly on the map). A good knowledge of Chinese is recommended in order not to get lost.

Toll
Toll never applies to cyclists. Just cycle past the toll booths: there is usually a lane for cyclists on the right-hand side. There is never really any discussion. If a toll is nevertheless charged, refuse to pay. If there was any discussion: when approaching a toll gate, there is always a sign indicating (with drawings) what each type of vehicle must pay. Bicycles are never listed here.

State of the roads
The main roads between major cities or industrial areas are well paved. These main roads can be traced well on the map, and certainly on the detailed Chinese maps. To avoid them you often have to choose an illogical route.

The quality of B roads differs per province. In the richer provinces in the east these B-roads are still asphalted, in the less fortunate provinces they are gravel roads, clay pebbles on a hard surface. In the valleys, on small roads along rivers and on the high plains, the roads get worse. The road surface then consists of hardened sand full of potholes.
In the Karakoram the roads are very good and asphalted.
Road works: sometimes roads are interrupted for 10 kilometers due to road works. The result of road works is a very difficult to cycle and dusty road. A highway under construction can be a good alternative to a small mud road. Please note that bridges have already been built and the tunnels are open.

Density of the road network
In the metropolitan areas with metropolitan cities such as Hong Kong, Zhengzhou, Beijing, Shanghai and Tianjin, the density of the road network is highest.
