These areas are often provided with 3 or more ring roads and the highways cross the cities. In the suburbs it can be very busy with commuting. In the other large metropolises (Xi'an, Kunming, Chengdu) there are many motorways with a few ring roads. The density of the road network in these cities diminishes quite rapidly as one is more than 15 kilometers away from the city center.

Traffic density / danger
Traffic rules are not actually applied. The cyclist will have to be careful, especially in the big city. On the country roads, Chinese car and truck traffic takes much more account of slow-moving traffic. Foreign tourists should be aware that Chinese car and truck traffic does not automatically give way to cyclists, scooters or pedestrians. This also applies to turning traffic at intersections, entrances and exits, roundabouts or pedestrian crossings. The Chinese drivers of cars and trucks only take slow-moving traffic and pedestrians into account at the very last moment and they place their vehicle in front of the passed vehicle at the last minute, because they no longer have to take into account vehicles behind. They have no insurance and legal liability for what happens behind their vehicle. Keep in mind that every participant in traffic respects each other.
Sticking out your hand with your fingers spread as a stop sign in the direction of the other road user (s) usually works, the other stops. You can use this if you have right of way or if it is very busy to cross. Pay attention to whether the other person responds to it.

It is very busy around the big cities, also with scooters and cyclists. You often come across rotten trucks, ramshackle buses and crackling mopeds that all spit out a lot of smelly exhaust fumes.

In China, the highways (= toll roads, expressways in English) are prohibited for light motorized traffic, pedestrians and cyclists. This is clearly indicated on the traffic information signs at the entrances (toll gates) of the motorways.

Presence of (separate) cycle paths
In the vicinity of the major and tourist cities there are separate carriageways along busy national motorways, which are intended for light motorized traffic, pedestrians and cyclists. Chinese car and truck traffic make use of this during overtaking campaigns.
In the center of large cities, there are also separate lanes along the busy city roads, which are intended for light motorized traffic, pedestrians and cyclists. In the big cities, low gates prevent car and truck traffic from using these separate lanes.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Especially in areas where the Han Chinese live, people are not likely to invite you to stay overnight. But if there is really nothing in a village, they will still find a solution and a bed is made available at someone's home.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are hardly any campsites in China. Camping is compulsory from Sost to Kashgar (Karakoram).
Sleeping.body_hostels:
Many truck drivers use guesthouses in mountainous areas. These overnight accommodations are located near mountain passes and you can recognize them when a truck is at the door. Prices for a basic room vary between 20 and 50 yuan.

Cheap guesthouses [旅社 (lu she) - 旅馆 (lu guan) - 旅店 (lu dian)]. The guesthouses have simple sleeping places that you can share with several guests. You share the use of the shower and toilet with several guests. Many Chinese use these types of cheap accommodations, which you can find everywhere. In the remote areas it is useful to look for this type of accommodation. The locals often know where to go.

Tourist places sometimes have hotels or guesthouses of a foreign owner. More atmospheric than the standard Chinese hotel and a conversation is also possible. Nice for a change.

Ivo: "We only stayed in hotels. Prices ranged from € 3.- (old and dirty) to € 25, - (5 stars). The bicycle can usually be in the room or at the reception. Every village has a hotel . "

All hotels register the passport details and visa in the database and require a deposit for the key. Passport and visa are scanned. Breakfast is not always included in the price. Single travelers do not pay the full price for a standard double room and often receive a discount. Some hotels offer rooms with wired internet connections.

Gerben (2011). Keep in mind that not all hotels are allowed to accommodate foreigners. Sometimes you have to pass two or more hotels before they accept you anywhere. In addition, we visited the police three times in the evening in three weeks to see and copy our passports and visas. A fourth time we were even expelled from the city by the police (really!) With the argument that there were no hotels for foreigners. I think they could not deal with individually traveling cyclists, but good. The result was no different.

Lonely-Push-Biker (2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013): The local government authorizes certain overnight accommodations to allow foreigners to stay overnight. These accommodations meet a certain rating. In all other cases you will need to get the cooperation of the police. If the hotel or guesthouse does not have a proper registration system, you will have to register at the police station. The benevolence of the police cannot be predicted. In my case I have always been able to arrange a place to sleep with the cooperation of the police.

Atie: "You can spend the night cheaply in Yunnan. A safe place is always sought for the bicycle or was taken in the room."

According to Whiskey (2008); For people who want to visit Tibet, the Saiman Hotel in Kashgar is the place to be. This is the hotel where most of the Tibet cyclists stay. Handy for exchanging information and so on.

Blanche (2013): "As you get deeper into Qinghai province, Tibetan region, you will no longer be asked for a passport at the hotel"
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping seems to be allowed. However, it is often difficult to find a place. In most parts of China, especially the eastern part, it is almost impossible to camp as every patch of land is used for agriculture. The people are curious, so you get regular visitors. However, they are not intrusive. Camping is no problem in the sparsely populated west. Water is scarce in the area between Kashgar and the Axai Chin plateau.

Transport.body_airplane:
Several airlines fly to Hong Kong, Shanghai and Beijing. Ask in advance about the conditions for bicycle transport. For a domestic flight there is a surcharge of approximately 20 RMB per kg of excess baggage. The weight of the bicycle is included in the determination of the total luggage weight. Maximum allowed baggage weight is 20 kg (incl. Bicycle) for a domestic flight (economy class). Checking in the bike can take a long time. The staff often do not know which procedures apply for transporting the bicycle. The bicycle must be packed in a box or bicycle cover. Test beforehand whether the bicycle passes the X-ray machine at the excess baggage department. Ask for the cooperation of the staff.

Hainan airlines:
With Hainan, taking a bicycle with you is free within the baggage allowance. Beyond that, there is a hefty surcharge of 20 eur / kg.
The bicycle must be packed in a box.
Some travel agencies can obtain better conditions at Hainan that are very interesting for cyclists: free or cheap date change, departure from an airport other than arrival, 30 kg baggage allowance.
Transport.body_boat: You and your bike can easily travel from Hong Kong to Guangzhou and from Wuzhou to Hong Kong.
Transport.body_bus:
The same applies to the bus as to the train. The bicycle goes on top of the bus. This often causes damage to the bicycle. You have to find a place and material to fasten the bike yourself. Sometimes you have to pay a lot.

The luxury coaches can place the bicycle at the bottom of the cargo hold. Ask / negotiate with the bus driver and then buy your ticket.

Place your bicycle yourself in the cargo hold or on the roof of the bus and dismantle certain bicycle parts if necessary. Reserve extra time for this, the Chinese are punctual and do not understand that a bicycle has sensitive parts.
Transport.body_train:
It is not that easy to get a ticket for the train. It often takes a long wait or even coming back the next day. It is advisable to enlist the help of other Chinese, so that things will go a bit faster. Bicycles must be sent forward. It is well arranged, but you have to know how and where. It goes as follows: First you buy your own ticket, for long journeys best 2 days in advance. This will take you to the luggage transport department, so do not take enough time for this right before departure. There you will find people who want to help you with baggage handling. They can pack professionally and fill in the necessary forms, they only speak Chinese. With the correct officer you fill in the necessary documents such as name, train number, final destination, etc. The amount you pay is partly for transport and partly for insurance against loss (this insurance is often more expensive than the transport itself and not mandatory). It can be useful to have a plastic card with you with a photo of the bike and yourself plus all the necessary information, preferably with an impressive stamp.

On some routes it is difficult to get the bicycle on a slow train. It depends on which railway company you are traveling with. First ask if you can bring the bicycle.

The-lonely-push-biker took his bike on the train from Dali (formerly Xiaguan) to Kunming and from Qimen to Jingdezhen. He made it clear to the train crew that his bicycle was entering the train packed in a bicycle cover. Firm insistence and language barrier were factors that helped him.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter China. The Chinese register passport and visa data in their database when booking hotel stays. They use the visa to translate the data from the passport.

Source: Wikipedia.

Since July 2013, a new rule applies. Tourists only receive one month when applying in the Netherlands and can then only apply for a visa extension of one month once. However, we managed to get three months. That took a lot of work. We had drawn up a full report of the entire route (along major sights / cities) for 2.5 months including hotel bookings through a website that we could cancel immediately. To our surprise, we got three months! And you can think about the route once on the spot ;-) Never tell that you are going to cycle and do not mention that you are going to travel in the former Tibetan area in Qinghai and Sichuan. The areas near the border of Kyrgyzstan are also sensitive. Along the way we were approached a few times by undercovers who asked what we were going to do. We said a bit of cycling or to Chengdu and that was the end of it.

Issuing a multiple entry is only possible under certain conditions. Make sure you have a permanent address of family, friends or business relations and state this with the application.

It is important that you do not indicate that you are going to sensitive areas such as Tibet or Qinghai. If this is the case, the application will be handled with a critical eye. It is important to be able to submit a detailed itinerary. In the travel schedule you indicate per day where you are traveling to, how you travel through the country and where you will spend the night. Print this out and add it as attachments to the application form. Tell them that you cycle and that it is not possible to book all hotel nights due to weather conditions, bicycle breakdown, natural disasters or illness. Indicate that interim reservations is pointless, because as a cyclist you will end up in remote areas, where they can hardly speak English. Record the most important things such as airline tickets and hotel stays on arrival and departure.

About.body:
Colombia is a very bicycle-friendly country. Just like with us you see large groups of trimming Colombians on racing bikes on Saturday and Sunday. In terms of bicycle and clothing, they do not collect from the Dutch image. There will always be a few who will drive past you to have a chat.

 
On Sundays, the inner cities are closed off for a number of hours and made available for cycling, skating, walking and dancing. This is used in large numbers.

In the cities there are bicycle shops with ditto workshops. You can have your bike repaired anywhere. In smaller towns this is often done impromptu, in the big cases in the big cities even professionally as in the Netherlands.

The roads are good, but some routes are busy with freight traffic. However, not as terribly busy as suggested in some weblogs. Good to do.

The country is mountainous in many places, point that out. Sometimes the distances are long. In the more populated areas you will often pass stalls where people serve the most delicious fruit juices with a big smile.

Every few days you will see a cycling American or Canadian crossing the continent from north to south or vice versa.

FoodDrink.body: Meals in restaurants are usually tasty and inexpensive. Tap water is not reliable, but water is available everywhere. Tap water is drunk everywhere without purifying, this is not sensible but has not caused any problems.

Other.body:
Best bike period
January and February are very hot and dry in the northern lowlands.
Average temperature. Temperatures mainly depend on the altitude. In the plain in the north, 40c is no exception.

Spare parts
There are well-equipped bicycle shops with ditto workshops in the cities. You can have your bike repaired anywhere. In smaller towns this is often done impromptu, in the big cities bike repairers are of good quality. Many parts are for sale in Bogota, Medellin and other major cities.

People.body: Most people are surprised that you are cycling through this country on your own and almost everyone will warn you of the many dangers. Colombia has a bad reputation, but in reality it is probably safer than most American countries (including North America). Few people speak English, so you will need a little Spanish for a conversation.

Safety.body:
Colombia is just as a safe country as other South American countries. You hear a lot of bad stories from other travelers about robberies. Colombia is just as safe as any other South American country, only the people are even more hospitable here than elsewhere. And more curious! In Cartagena you can feel free to drink rum and coke (or something else of course) until late at night on the local plazas and nothing will happen to you.

The idea of insecurity is still in the mind of many Colombians. When questioned, it usually turned out to be based on occurrences of around 2005 or earlier. The ex-president Uribe is widely praised for his achievements in promoting security. Incidentally, he scores significantly less on social items. However, in a number of suburbs of the big cities you see the same insecurity that you find in such cities elsewhere in the world.

“We have been sleeping peacefully for 4 years now” said a jugo (fruit juice) seller somewhere in the countryside. You do see a lot of police and soldiers (in terms of uniform and armament they look almost the same) on the street. Usually they are bored and they are very willing to show you the way or to chat with you. Once we meet a whole platoon of police officers who were "on action". They explained this to us in a friendly and cheerful manner. Two days later we read in the newspaper that there had been 2 clashes with the Farc in that area and that several tons of marijuana had been stolen.
Safety.body_criminality:
Martin: "I was interviewed in Cali for the news because I had already cycled 2500 km without being robbed, kidnapped or murdered. That such a thing was possible had to be in the news. However, several robberies and even a murder happened around me. I got rolled into Bogota. The hotel in Bogota where I stayed the night before my arrival was armed robbed and the guests were robbed of all belongings. I myself was a day behind schedule because of the TV recording! In short, know what you do when you goes to Colombia. "

Wilbert: "When I had a lift to Bogota, the co-driver held a gun in his hand when entering the city to be able to shoot immediately in case of danger. I was advised not to drive to the dangerous center of the city and well before that. For fear of many hotels the door was not opened and they had no room for a stranger on a bicycle. Fortunately I could find a hotel room in the center. The streets were deserted and the atmosphere was very unsafe, but once inside a restaurant it was pleasantly busy. "
Safety.body_traffic:
There is a lot of freight traffic on the main roads. And sometimes little space for the cyclist, no hard shoulder, but often a gutter where you can ride crookedly. Therefore, rather look for local roads, but they are sometimes in bad condition.

In Bogotá and in other larger and sometimes smaller cities, 'ciclovias' are often indicated here and there with a yellow bicycle sign. But they can sometimes end abruptly, be used as parking space for cars or walkers get in the way.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are few or no campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There is sleeping accommodation in almost every town, varying from hotel to guest house. Aaldrik and Sonya: "There are also often small hotels at petrol stations. You can usually rent a good spacious double room for 5 to 15 euros. For this you get clean sheets, your own shower and toilet and usually cable TV! Colombia has to be the easiest land for finding a place to sleep. "
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Aaldrik and Sonya: "In the mountains or the nature reserves you can safely camp (wild). You ask a farmer if you can pitch your tent and that is never a problem. We spent the night at a school's playground and were invited to delicious colombian coffee! "

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Colombia without a visa and can stay for 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

Most nationalities need a visa for Congo DR. Getting this visa, appears to be quite difficult, and even if you have obtained it, they might not let you in as they don't approve all visas at the border. The 2 Swiss guys from Cape2Cape.org have been able to get the visa and enter the country. 

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Also known as Congo Brazzaville, this country hosts gorilla’s inside the wild jungle landscapes.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Most cities have accommodation. Room with fan should be around 10.000 CFA, with AC a bit more. Expect bucket showers.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

-MGOlZAvzZvjsZpfKeCS.title: Bike touring in Gabon and Congo

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa for entering the Republic of Congo.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
For every place where tap water is guaranteed to be drinkable, this is indicated at the beginning of the place. There is generally enough drinking water (bottles) and bread available in the villages. You will see many shops on the way. From simple fruit stalls to mega supermarkets. Furthermore, there are usually restaurants (Sodas) but it is sometimes unclear when they are open or not. The food is generally good. Soft drinks, beer and mineral water are available everywhere.

Good bike food: A simple casado (rice, beans, vegetables, meat and fried banana). 

In San José you have the vegetarian restaurant chain Vishnu.

Cooking fuel 
Gasoline is available everywhere (super 95). Screw mounted gas cans possible only in San Jose. "

Markets
Supermarkets Small supermarkets are of some size in every town. In larger places also real supers such as Walmart.
Stalls on the street So-called Sodas can almost always be found, sometimes in the form of stalls on the street, but more often a very simple restaurant / snack bar. Open from (early) breakfast and usually close again around 6pm.

Restaurants 
Often pizza or steaks with fries. Restaurants have European prices and rarely an interesting menu.

Drinkable water 
We drank water from the tap everywhere, even if it was not explicitly stated that it is drinking water.

Other.body:
Tips
Bart: "From San Jose to the Caribbean, transport is necessary because it is not possible to cycle through a nature park (Parque Nacional Braulio Carillo). Furthermore, cycling along the Pan American Highway is also not recommended."

Bert: We cycled mostly on quiet b roads to the east to Siquirres. after that it is still 50 km. to Puerto Limon along a busy 2 lane road. Freight traffic does take cyclists into account. from Puerto the road is quiet again (towards Panama)

Best time to cycle
The best time to travel is from December to March, the dry season with temperatures around 25 - 30 degrees. But this is also Costa Rica's high season. The prices are higher and it is more difficult to make a reservation. 

The rainy season runs approximately from June to October. Then there can be a shower every day, usually in the afternoon. The rest of the day, however, is usually sunny and pleasant, so that it is also good travel in Costa Rica. During the day, the temperature generally also remains above 20 degrees, in the evening it can be a bit cooler. In the mountains it can cool down considerably in the evening.

April also turned out to be a good month; the busy season is coming to an end and it is easy to find a place to sleep everywhere without a reservation. It often rained on the east coast, but only in the morning. The west side is still in the dry period.

Spare parts
There are many mountain bikes around, as well as racing bikes. There are plenty of workshops. 28 inch tires are available.

People.body:
The population is originally Spanish. Making contact is easy. They love to party. The people are generally unobtrusive but not very friendly either. Cyclists are a common street scene. The standard bicycle for the Costa Rican (especially in rural areas) is a mountain bike. Traffic (especially in San Jose) is generally quite anti-social. We drove around San Jose in a rental car for 2 days and it was occasionally quite assertive.

The official language is Spanish. Most of the Tico's are mestizos, people with mixed Indian white blood. The indigenous population often still speaks Indian languages, such as Bribri and Guaymi, but they are only a very small part of the population. On the Caribbean coast, the majority of the inhabitants are of black descent, mostly former slaves from Costa Rica and the countries in the area. In the capital and in the tourist hotels reasonable English is spoken, in the interior the knowledge of English is a lot less. It is therefore advisable to learn a few words of Spanish to facilitate contact with the local population.
With English you can go pretty well in most places.

Safety.body: Overall, the security seems very good. There are certain neighborhoods in San Jose and Puerto Limon that are said to be less safe.
Safety.body_traffic: There is a lot of traffic on major thoroughfares and around San José with buses and American trucks. With the arrival of the asphalt, the roads have become much busier. Cars, trucks and buses do take cyclists into account. Traffic in the Central Lowlands is generally very quiet and cyclists are taken into account. In the Caribbean this is a lot less; lorry drivers in particular are downright anti-social.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites as we know them. You can camp for a few dollars at various guesthouses.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
Most places of any size have a hotel or guesthouse. From about 7 dollars for a bed in a guesthouse. Can be a bit more expensive in tourist areas (coast). At various guesthouses you can also camp for a few dollars. Place for the bike has never been a problem.

Safe bicycle storage is not always possible, especially in San Jose, with the cheaper accommodation options (especially if they are on the first and / or second floor and only accessible via a narrow staircase).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is allowed in designated places, including in the national parks.

Transport.body_bus: In the regular buses, bicycles can be taken along cheaply in the luggage compartment at the bottom. Bicycles can travel on the long-distance buses but sometimes require persuasion and the need to cross handlebars due to limited cargo space and a rope to tie down the bicycles.

Visa.body:
Quite a lot of nationalities may enter Costa Rica without a visa.


Visa policy of Costa Rica
  Costa Rica
  Visa not required
  Restricted visa
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Cycling in Ivory Coast can be pleasant, especially after you’ve when you come from Liberia or Guinea. The country has a large coastline with a lot of relaxing places. For a big part, the jungle has been replaced by many plantations.

-MGMm75F1XAbZcn00kjE.title: A thousand plantations in Ivory Coast

cd923d1c-94c4-46b9-87e1-80c656aa7209.description: We don't have experience with obtaining the e-visa of Cote d'Ivoire. Please update this description if you have recent experience with it.

FoodDrink.body:
Food in Ivory Coast is cheap and delicious. "Aloco" is sold on the street. This is banana in palm oil with spiced and steamed onions. Grilled fish tastes good with this. Other famous dishes are:
  • Foutou or Attieke: Pasta made from boiled cassava jam
  • Kedjenou: Chicken dish with vegetables and a mild sauce
On the road you'll find plenty of small open restaurants where they sell omelette on bread, often quite spicy for about 800 CFA. Palm wine and beer are famous drinks.

Health.body: Yellow fever vaccination is mandatory. It is strongly recommended to take preventive measures against malaria.

Other.body:
Best cycling time
The best cycling time is from the middle of November to the beginning of May. The climate is tropical, there is a lot of rain, especially in the south. From December, the harmatan rises, which can cause a lot of dust.

People.body:
The people are friendly and often invite you to their homes or let you stay in schools. 

The official language is French. However, it is not spoken by everyone (often outside the cities). There are several local languages such as Mande, Malinké, Darn, Senoufo, Agni and Dioula.

-MGMkFoSV3pmRy9Jdr6V.description: This route goes from Liberia border to the Ghana border, following the coast untill Abidjan, and then heading North.
-MGMkFoSV3pmRy9Jdr6V.title: West to East

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.
Safety.body_corruption: Bas (2019): "I have not experienced any corruption at border crossings, police checks and embassies or other places."
Safety.body_criminality: Bas: "I haven't experienced criminality, but I'm pretty sure it's around. However, while staying at a Warmshowers host in Abidjan, we regularly went out on the streets, even in the dark. Just be careful and don't look afraid. In the smaller villages there is no criminality, but people like to drink, so try to make some friends who can help you if needed."
Safety.body_nature: There aren't so many wild animals left, especially around places where people live. Mosquitos are your worst enemy. There is nothing to be afraid of when it comes to nature, only some fierce rain can happen occasionally.
Safety.body_traffic: The roads are not in best condition, but overall the cars take good caution of cyclists. Sometimes you get scared by big trucks passing by recklessly.

-MGMkjZXeU0Tl_Adw1pf.description: Watch the stilt dancing or visit the La Cascade – a waterfall. The area appears to be a good hiking place. The roads are rather muddy.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Most cities have accommodation. Room with fan should be around 5.000 CFA, with AC a bit more. Expect bucket showers.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

Visa.body:
Only a few African countries can access Cote d'Ivoire without a visa. All other nationalities need to have a visa. 
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Croatia is part of the former Yugoslavia. Reason why you should cycle to this country: Croatia is a country with a lot of variety: the arid interior, the green coastline with beautiful sea views, the easy connection to the islands and also a lot of culture. The kitchen also offers a lot of goodies. Roadworthiness of the country: The quality of the roads (along the coast) is very good. However, the terrain is quite hilly, which means that there is a lot of climbing.

FoodDrink.body:
General
Delicious bread is available everywhere, as well as fine cheese, meat products, vegetables and fruit. Beer, wine, coffee and liqueurs are also recommended . 

Croatia has been under the rule of several countries during its long history (Venice, Austria, Hungary ...). This has had a major impact on Croatian cuisine and there is a wide variety of dishes. You will find fish and meat dishes, pizzas, pastas, goulash.

Cooking fuel
It is very difficult to get camping gas. Petra: "We only found prick tanks once. Larger, refillable tanks were not available at all, we heard from other campers. This was not a disaster, by the way, eating out often turned out to be cheaper than cooking yourself."

Markets 
In the cities (including in Sibenik, Rijeka and Split) in the morning excellent markets, a good range of bread, vegetables and fruit and also a lot of meat and fish (although it is more difficult to take it with you on the bike in the summer).

Supermarkets
Shops are fairly easy to find. Sometimes you can also find a thing or two in a gas station. In tourist areas (along the coast) there are shops everywhere, but much less inland.

Stalls on the street 
In June we saw quite a lot of stalls selling some fruit and vegetables from our own vegetable garden. Limited range (potatoes, tomatoes and cherries in June) but good.

Restaurants
There are plenty of dining options on the coast road. Campsites often also have a restaurant with a limited menu.

Vegetarian dishes
are hardly available. Some fish, and sometimes a vegetarian pizza. Salads are usually not like that.

Drinkable water
no problem. The tap water is drinkable and usually tasty. In many places there are fountains with wonderfully cool drinking water.

Other.body:
Beste bike period
Seasons (dry / wet)
generally very nice weather in the summer, but the only day it can be bright sun, and the next day gray and gray. The best cycling season is spring (May-June) or autumn (September-October). You then have good weather and not the worst heat and tourist crowds of the summer. In spring (March-April) very wet and in winter there is often a very icy hard bora (wind).

Tourist high season
July, August and the first half of September. It is always high season in Dubrovnik.

Prevailing wind directions
Along the coast, the wind can blow quite hard and you have to watch out for gusts.

Average temperature
23 ° in summer

Spare parts
In Istria, on the islands and along the coast 26 "tires and mountain bike parts are available everywhere, although you will have to search and inquire. In the north In Croatia, cycling is much more common (including the local population), although those bikes are often old, but do have 28" tires. Only in the larger cities such as Varazdin, Sisak and in Osijek (see this bike shop) you will be able to find a real bicycle repairer.

People.body:
The locals are generally friendly. On the coast, the population is geared towards tourism, in the interior you can taste undiluted hospitality. 

The population speaks Croatian. Knowledge of English / German is certainly not a problem on the coast, on the coast people often speak a bit of Italian as well. In the interior it will be more difficult to find someone who speaks English or German.

Safety.body: Croatia is a safe country to be at. Watch out for landmines. If you are going camping freely or with a farmer, ask the locals if it is safe. There may also be mines in uninhabited houses with war damage. Almost all landmines have been mapped: there are now warning signs along the roads. All roadsides are safe!
Safety.body_traffic:
In the summer months, it is very busy along the coast! The main roads on the islands can also be very busy, especially on weekends.

There are not that many roads. There is the coast road and a number of inland connections. There are also few roads on the islands.

The condition of the roads is moderate to good and is getting better and better. The stretch between Jablanac and Novi Vinodolski along the coast has been moderate for years. Just like the main road on Hvar from Sucuraj to Jelsa.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are many campsites in Croatia, along the coast road you will find campsites every few kilometers, although they can sometimes be very large (up to 2000 people) and also quite noisy due to the traffic. It is sometimes better to drive into a village and look for a campsite close to the water. These are much quieter and also on a smaller scale. There are hardly any campsites on the mainland. You can often camp with farmers.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Can be found all over the tourist sites but are quite pricey. Private rooms are decent and cheaper. Inland accommodation options are scarce, except in the large cities or in the vicinity of nature parks.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Not allowed, but asking a farmer if you can stay on his land shouldn't be a problem.

Transport.body_bus:
The most used public transport is the bus. Buses take bicycles for an additional fee, but only if they have space. Consult in advance about the price for the bicycle and do not bet on one horse: if one bus does not take you, make sure that you still have a choice of other buses.

At the weekend - and especially in the summer - it is always busier than during the week and you have less chance of being taken by bike.
Sometimes you pay for each piece of luggage that is transported at the bottom of the bus. Then take as many panniers above the bus as possible.
Transport.body_train:
Nowadays you can reach Zagreb by train with a bicycle. Within Croatia, bicycles are not officially allowed on local trains, but you can often arrange something with the conductor. In intercities, the bicycle is allowed once or twice a day. It differs per line at what time the bicycle is allowed. If you have a tight schedule, choose well in advance. On the Split-Zagreb it is also possible to take the train with your bicycle in the evening.

For shorter train journeys in Croatia (between smaller train stations) it is best if you board the last train wagon with your bike. You then pay the conductor for a card for the extra baggage (approx. EU 1.7 per 50 km). If you want to travel by train between larger stations, it is best to transport your bicycle as cargo. You can arrange this at the sales desk (info Croatian traffic office).

Visa.body:
Croatia is not yet part of the Schengen area, but are members of EU. However, they have a visa policy that is based on the Schengen policy.

Schengen Area visa lists.
  Schengen Area
  Other EU member states outside the Schengen Area but bound by the same visa policy and legally obliged to join the Area when they meet the criteria, and special territories of Schengen member states (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Member of the EU with independent visa policy (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Visa-free access to the Schengen states for short stays, usually 90 days in any 180-day period (EU 2018/1806 Annex II)
  Visa required to enter the Schengen states, and to transit some Schengen states in some circumstances (EU 2018/1806 Annex I)
  Visa required to transit any Schengen state (EC 810/2009 Annex IV)
  Travel documents not accepted
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Cuba is one of top destinations for cyclists, according to some magazines. Nature is overwhelming, with for example the mogotes around Viñales in the west. In the east you will find the green landscapes and jungle clad mountains. There is hardly any traffic, while the roads are well maintained everywhere. You can also easily find your way with the cycling Lonely Planet. The people are very friendly and always willing to chat if you speak some Spanish. And you can eat delicious things. Time to ask yourself why you haven't traveled to this cycling paradise yet.

aded771f-5a60-4d89-b8cc-b8a8145d7e2f.description:
This is not the website for the visa, but for the Tourist Card. 

We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

FoodDrink.body:
Paladars
We have always eaten in the casas. We always got a very extensive breakfast with lots of fresh fruit and fresh fruit juice. During the day we had little need for food. We have hardly seen any markets, but a few stalls along the road. Outside the cities it is difficult to get food and drink. It is best to bring enough water and some food with you when you leave.

You can enjoy good food at private individuals (paladar, or with an overnight stay in a casa particular). This is in contrast to state restaurants, where there are not much more than beans, rice, fried chicken on the menu. Breakfast costs 2-3 pesos convertible; dinner 7 peso convertible.

It is not always easy for vegetarians. They can of course ask for a meat-free meal at a casa particular or paladar, although it can become monotonous (it will just be the meal but without meat): lots of rice, beans, green beans, cucumber, mango, banana, oranges, papaya (seasonal).

Shops / supermarkets
Food is sometimes difficult to get. So make sure you always have stock with you. There are not many shops, and often there is not much for sale. Exceptions are the tiendas panamericanas, where you can buy convertibles (Cuban) cola and orange, fruit juice, biscuits, rice, pasta, and sometimes cream crackers with pesos. Shops where you can pay with peso MN usually sell cheap alcohol (1 liter of 'firewater' for 3-4 peso MN), refresco's (can of cola 10 peso MN), sandwiches, rice and local cigars etc.

Stalls
Along the way, people sell tasty juices, fruits (bananas, mangos, and pineapples), and sometimes cakes and small nutritious pizzas. Very cheap, but you have to pay with the MN peso.

Drinkable water
The quality of water varies a lot. It is best to check on the spot. The local population does not purify the water, they often get it from wells. It is important to bring a lot of drink. Bottles of drinking water are available at tiendas panamericanas. Costs 1 peso convertible per 1.5 liters. You need a lot of water, so this will be very expensive. Disinfection pills or a water filter is therefore worthwhile, also for environmental reasons.

Tips
Special recommendations for cyclists and easy to obtain are the pizzas de queso (from 3 to 5 peso), nice and crispy, often baked on coal in a metal mold. Ask for a pizzeria or pizza de queso in almost any town and people will send you there. This is usually a private house with a sign. Are only open at certain hours, + - between 10 and 12 AM, in cities also in the evening between 5 and + - 8 pm.

Fruit is also heavenly for the cyclist; June is the time of the mangoes, along the road there are people with buckets to sell. We tasted quite a few of the thirty varieties, ranging from the size of a pear to pineapple, pineapple, guanabana, zapota (especially the juice), bananas, ...

Health.body:
We have not been vaccinated. We have also had no health problems, even after drinking tap water. For the rest, we have no experience with medical care.

Tom (2003): "The soft drinks you buy at roadside stalls are not made from bottled water. Nevertheless, we did not get sick."

Health care in Cuba has a very high standard. We ourselves have no experience with hospitals, but if you can afford it, you can undoubtedly go to clinics or doctors.

Other.body:
Special sights
We thought Trinidad and Vinales were worth it. You can make various excursions from these towns. Also worthwhile was la cueva de los peces, on the road between Playa Giron and Play Larga = lake connected to the sea.

For those who like to hike on foot, we can recommend a day trip to El Yunque (the anvil) in the east. To the top of the table mountain through the jungle. You can take a guide. Info in the Lonely Planet.

Wim and Corrie (2011): "We traveled through Cuba with a sit-down tandem. Liked the west very beautiful. Have also driven from Cienfuegos to Santa Clara, Remedios, Sancti Spiritus and Trindad. Very favorable distances (start early with cycling) and you will pass many nice places. We did not want to go to the commercial beaches. We therefore had a few wonderful days in La Boca (just outside Trinidad), from there also made a boat trip to an island with Iguanas. Very nice and special. Furthermore, enjoy some snorkeling, unlimited drinks on the boat and a relaxing day."

Wim and Corrie (2011): "In Viñales, Vladimir and Gladys (casa owners) arranged a farmer with horses for us to ride through the tabas fields. Very nice to do for a few hours. Especially viewing and discussing the entire process with these people is very instructive and pure. Quite different from visiting a tobacco factory. Which in itself is also nice, by the way."

Existing routes
Wim and Corrie (2011) We have used the English booklet Bicycling Cuba by Willy and Barbara Smith. It contains many cycling routes, described in great detail and provided with maps. All sorts of great tips, short routes, but also what to bring, a piece of history, etc. are not missing. VERY meaningful little book in our view.

Best bike period
Seasons
Normally from December to April. We cycled from the end of October to the middle of November and had practically no rain. The heat was bearable.

November to March is a good time to travel to cuba. Temperature is around 30 degrees. The wet months are the end of April to July. Admittedly no rain all days. Relatively much North-East and East wind.

Tom (2003): "We traveled around in May and June, but it was very hot (34 degrees every day). It was still doable, but for people who like it a bit cooler, winter is recommended. In Cuba it never gets warmer than 40 degrees, but due to the high humidity every day felt like the hottest day of the year. We only had 1 day of rain during the day, generally it rains in the evening (thunderstorms). "

We went east in June in 2004, which is normally not the best season. Yet we have not had much rain. The plants were also more in bloom, which is very nice. It was very hot, getting up early and starting was the message.

Blanche en Douwe (2008): "We were there in July and August, the hottest months of the year. If you start cycling early, it is doable. We were on our bikes before 7 am every day and had a siesta in the afternoon after a shower. By the way, the light is beautiful for photographing and filming early in the morning." 

Wim and Corrie (2011): "We cycled in March and April. Even then it was quickly hot. When you get up often about 26 degrees. We got on at 6.45 am and tried to get off the bike around 12 noon and 12:30 pm. Drink enough and eat on time !! Also make sure you have enough drink with you. There is not always something available everywhere !! Finally, it might also be good not to think "100km = 4 hours cycling". This does not work with these temperatures and if you want to see and do something on the road. Perhaps superfluous information for experienced cyclists, but as beginners we made this mistake the first few days."

Wind direction
It is important to cycle from east to west, that way you always cycle with the wind. In the west you can e.G. First take the bus to trinidad and from there cycle west to vinales and return by bus to havana.

Spare parts
We had spare parts with us. We did not meet any bicycle repairers on the way. We have not had any bad luck, not even a single flat tire.
Spare parts are hardly available. There are 28 inch tires for sale, but strangely enough they often just don't fit around our rims. 

It is advisable to bring your own spare inner tube and tire and spokes, depending on the quality of the parts on your bike. The helpfulness is great, you will probably be able to get a lift, even if it is illegal.

Tips
It is forbidden to bring a GPS to Cuba. This was even stated in the new folder about import duties from Customs at Varadero airport. Bringing one with you is therefore at your own risk, there is a chance that you have lost your expensive device. By the way, it is not difficult to navigate in Cuba, there are not that many roads. Even the cities are easy.

Astrid: "Contrary to the information in travel guides and the country information of Vlieg & Fiets, your European mobile phone does work in Cuba, as long as you have network coverage (in the big cities). So bring it with you." Blanche: The GPS is officially prohibited. There have been cases of customs confiscating the GPS !! We wisely left the GPS at home. A GPS is also not really necessary.

Ati and Marise: "Cuba is a country in desperation because of the political situation, which, unfortunately, makes it special to visit it. Nobody knows what it will look like after Fidel Castro, but I hope better for the Cuban."

Ati and Marise: "In terms of nature, Cuba is not very special in the part where we have been, but that is of course very personal and depending on what you have already seen. The area around Vinales is very green, also good for a walk. You also seem to be able to dive well and enjoy the beach. Yes, and Havana is a must. "

Wim and Corrie (2011). We made a day trip from La Boca (Trinidad) with a catamaran to an island with a number of iguanas on it. Had a wonderful day. Boat is regularly stopped for swimming and snorkeling (everything on the boat), lunch on the island with the iguanas where you can also relax on sun beds for a while. In addition, the whole day of drinking is included.

People.body:
The people are very hospitable. It is recommended to sleep with the people themselves in casas particulares. They are very helpful and arrange reservations for the next destination if desired.

The language of instruction is Spanish. Few people speak English, so basic knowledge of Spanish is useful. The people are unusually friendly, helpful and unobtrusive.

The population is poor and of course you are the rich westerner who has a lot of dollars with them that they like to get a piece of. Especially in Havana and Santiago you come across vendors offering you cigars or a woman every five minutes. Outside of these cities, Cubans are more sincere to chat. People react enthusiastically to the bicycles and are now used to the foreigners coming to their country to sweat on a bicycle.

Safety.body:
Cuba is a safe country. It is a dictatorship with an extensive police force. Each village is divided into zones controlled by the party. However, as a tourist you will notice very little of this well-functioning device. The only thing that really struck us was that you were asked to show your passport for registration at a casa within 1 minute. A number of times we have seen registration checked by government officials. 

To be on the safe side, take your bike inside the house. Usually, however, the casa owner will arrange all these things for you.

Jonas (2007): "We did not succeed in discussing politics freely. Everyone then says that it is a fantastic system, that Fidel is the great leader and that nothing will change when he dies. I'm not sure what their real opinion is on this case."

Jonas (2007): "Apparently since 2005 it has been forbidden for 'normal' Cubans to speak to tourists. This is to prevent hassle about cigars, etc. This of course makes contact more difficult, although it is not the case. that everyone shies away from that. "

Wim and Corrie (2011): "We have heard this rule, but have heard nothing about it. Every Cuban we spoke to was more than happy to start a nice conversation. Politics is hardly, if at all, negotiable. We were also treated very respectfully. Never even 1 Cuban bothered us. For example, if we indicated that we were not interested in something, they immediately walked away. Even in tourist resorts in Havana."
Safety.body_traffic:
With the exception of Havana and Santiago, the roads are not busy. You can even cycle quietly on the motorway. A car passes by once every five minutes.

Motorists take the cyclist into account. The many honking is well meant.
Cubans also cycle a lot themselves and occasionally someone cycles with you to have a chat. You also regularly see "horse and cart" and ox wagons.

Blanche (2008): "We cycle through East and West Cuba. We used the lonely planet cycling guide and drove a bit more. East Cuba is a bit rougher and more deserted and perhaps the best if you have to choose between east and west given the time. On the way there was a bridge about to collapse between Marea del Portillo and Niquero. The river below is deep and wide is difficult to bridge. (!) "

Tom (2003): "We cycled on small and large main roads, without being bothered by the traffic (in the sense of bad driving behavior or crowds). However, those few vehicles that pass by often broke out an enormous black smoke. . "

The main roads are generally passable. The most beautiful roads are often of poor quality. Often the asphalt is so hard to find that off road is more appropriate as a term. Doable if your bike is set up for this. There are no cycle paths. You are allowed to cycle on the highway.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
We have only stayed in casas particulares. We have only seen a campsite in Vinales. As a tourist you cannot go to all hotels. Some hotels or bungalows are only accessible to Cubans. The casas are highly recommended, around 20 € per night. The food in the casas is also better than in the hotels.

The casas particulares are by far preferable to the hotels. You will receive a more friendly welcome and you will get to know Cuban life better than in hotels. If they have a license for it, you can also eat there, otherwise they will send you to a paladar, a private restaurant if you wish. The food in a casa is usually much better than in a hotel. The money you spend also ends up more directly with people. As far as we know, the official casas particulares pay a fixed annual amount to the state, and this is quite high. They could use some income. $ 20 is an average price (2004).

Sleeping and eating at private homes is fantastic! Via the “casas particulares” (note the blue door stickers) you enter the world of a Cuban family, including cordiality, local secrets, the problems of the land and, very importantly, a good bed and a plate full of warm and healthy food . Including dinner and breakfast it costs 20 to 30 pesos convertible for two people. Villages seem to have fewer options and Cuba must have a permit to offer a casa particular (a lot of control).

Illegal casas particulares are more exciting as the owner takes a huge risk. The fine is inhumanly high. Prices and service are at the same high level. Tom (2003): "We had a lot of trouble drawing up a route where we could spend the night in a hotel or a casa particular every night (distances ranged from 70 kilometers to 100 kilometers). Accommodations must sleep (eg motel Bitiri in Mayari). An overnight stay in a casa particular is always recommended above a hotel, because the quality and service of this is ten times better. Bicycles can be safely stored everywhere, but at hotels you have to leave and then pay a dollar to the guard Hotels cost between $ 20 and $ 25 for a double room, a room at a casa particular costs between $ 15 and $ 20 and a cottage at a campismo popular about $ 12.50. In all three cases, breakfast is not included. "

Specific addresses
  • Our starting address in Havana at Rafael is highly recommended. He is very helpful and will reserve the following stages for you. We were also allowed to leave our bicycle boxes with him. Hereby the email address: virtudes624@yahoo.es
  • Great new casa (02-2016) at Liuba Gonzales in Santa Marta (district of Varad.), Just 1 km before the main access bridge to Varadero. From the Intern. Varadero airport was just 24km by bike. Luggage (bicycle packing, etc.) could stay here for free and without any problems for 7 weeks. Large living room, bedroom and bathroom and 2 terraces for 20 Cuc / night. Extensive breakfast (5 Cuc) and delicious dinner (10 Cuc), Liuba knows something about it !!! Was a great start to a pleasant cycling trip!
  • CASA LIUBA - Mail: liubajp@nauta.cu // Address: Calle B no.17b, betw. Av. 1ra & Av. Indepencia - SANTA MARTA / VARADERO - Tel: 45 610 247 and mobil: 01 - 52 737 595
  • Very good casa in SANTA LUCIA, 40 km west. v Vinales, rightly recommended to me by other cyclists (03-2016).
  • CASA CUSY: José Ramon Trujillo no.86 La Loma, Santa Lucia mail: cusi75@nauta.cu // tel: 00 53 5419 0481
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
You will not find real camping sites for tents like in Europe in Cuba. Sometimes you can camp in the garden with local families. Please note: The so-called campismos are definitely not campsites, but areas where you can rent a bungalow or cabin; sometimes only intended for Cubans, sometimes foreigners are also allowed to use it. Peter de Rijk (2008): "I doubt whether you would be allowed to pitch a tent on such a campismo, the rules are very strict."

Tom (2003): "We didn't bring a tent with us, but I rarely saw good (wild) camping opportunities along the way and I don't think campsites exist at all. We did spend the night at so-called campismo popular, but this has nothing to do with a campsite. In a campismo popular it is possible to rent a house for a low amount. "

Transport.body_airplane:
You can fly to Havana, Varadero and Holguin in the east. Many charters go to Varadero and you can possibly book a cheap last minute.

In Havana we immediately unpacked our bikes at the airport and cycled to the center. In Varadero we can take the Thomas Cook bus for 20 $ and are dropped off at the Dos Mares hotel. For the return, we paid $ 25 for a taxi (a regular passenger car, bicycles inside with the seats flat).
Transport.body_bus: The famous tourist bus Viazul offers very good quality. It is better, faster, more comfortable (and we also think safer for the bicycles) than the train. Bus timetables can be found at www.viazul.com. Those who want certainty can already reserve a seat from another country (and even if you do not yet have certainty for the bicycle, you will still have a better chance than someone who did not book). We did not do this because we like to keep our travel schedule free and it was still low season. In July and August, it seems that six to eight cyclists are willing to join. turning the steering wheel). The staff are sometimes used to load bicycles, but the best thing to do is to crawl into the luggage compartment yourself. Always try to secure the bikes to the iron bars in the middle with carrier straps. You can also connect them with a bicycle lock, but we believe it is safe (each piece of luggage is labeled with a card, of which you have the corresponding number with you and there is a baggage manager at the stops).

Visa.body:
Quite some nationalities need a Tourist Card to visit Cuba, which is different than the Cuban visa. The tourist card is often confused with the visa. On Easytouristcard.com you can get the tourist card online.


Source: Wikipedia.

Some nationalities (blue countries in the below map) can enter Sint Maarten without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Markets
There are plenty of shops and markets to buy your own food.

Restaurants
Eating out is not a problem. Vegetarian food is not a problem. There are plenty of vegetarian mezes. The main course was twice a large bowl of spagetti with a simple sauce at a larger hotel / restaurant. But at the small agri and eco tourism guesthouses we have always had a very good vegetarian meal.

Drinkable water
Tap water is generally not reliable. Every house in Cyprus has 1 or more large water tanks on the roof. If the water comes from here, it is not recommended to drink it. Sometimes there are two taps, one of which is the drinking water tap. Always check with the landlord. Bottled water is readily available.

Health.body: In case you need a doctor, it is best to present your problem in a pharmacy, they can tell you where to go best. There are folk clinics but also private clinics.

Other.body:
Routes
Existing cycling routes
The Greek Tourist Office is busy promoting the Troodos Cycle route. This is a somewhat strange cycle route: 80% wide two-lane asphalt roads where you hardly see a car and furthermore some unpaved parts, of which the quality is sometimes good and sometimes bad. So: for the mountain biker too little unpaved, for the racing cyclist not to do through the unpaved part, for the holiday cyclist too wide roads and for the untrained cyclist too much climbing. Because here too, progress is unstoppable: entire mountains are being excavated for an asphalt road that is much too wide.

Nice routes
  • The Troodos Mountains are very worthwhile. Lots of climbing on the way there but manageable.
  • Polis and surroundings: not so touristy with mainly backpackers, fairly relaxed with beautiful quiet beaches, ideal for camping. You run the risk of being visited by herds of goats.
  • Nicosia is the last shared city, it is somewhat reminiscent of Berlin. The border with Turkey is cordoned off with sandbags and you see UN soldiers everywhere. Tourists can visit the Turkish side for several days (maximum 90).
  • Agia Napa is a terribly busy tourist town and has only hotels and guesthouses where mass tourism resides. Best to avoid. There is also a youth hostel. It is a ghost town outside the tourist season.
  • Pafos is very touristy but has very beautiful archaeological sites.
  • Karpaz (North East of the Turkish part) has many quiet roads, especially the old coastal roads are nice for cycling and parallel to the mountain ridge the roads are fairly flat. If you want to go from the north coast to the south coast, you will have to deal with rising and falling, but also beautiful views.
  • Turkish part: A nice road leads Girne to Karsiyaka. However, you can only get there by highway. And when you have climbed halfway up the castle, you will be sent back by Turkish soldiers at an army base; the last two km to the castle are prohibited for cyclists. Solution: arrange a lift. But the 3 meter wide, beautifully paved road is worth it, it goes (almost) over the peaks of the Pentadaktylos Range.
Best period
Seasons (dry / wet)
Best time: March, April and May. Not too busy and nature at its best. In September it is still quite warm and the temperature is pleasant in October as well.

Spare parts
Cyprus is too small to cycle there for long. If your bike is in order beforehand, it shouldn't cause any problems. So only take the essentials with you.

Because the quality of the B-roads in Northern Cyprus is not always great, it is advisable to bring spare inner tubes and repair equipment, the chance of a flat tire is high.

People.body: In tourist areas, people are a bit indifferent, but not unkind. Inland, the population is completely different, warm and helpful. During harvest time, people spontaneously offer you fresh fruit. The most commonly used languages are Greek, Turkish and English

Safety.body:
Cyprus is a safe country for cycling, even as a woman alone. The island has a Greek and a Turkish part, the Turkish part is not internationally recognized. Sometimes hostilities flare up again, as in 1996 when some fatal border incidents took place. You hardly notice that. Be careful with taking pictures. Usually there are prohibition signs, but that is not always clear. Along the border, UN soldiers patrol the Greek side and you will see many Turkish military posts on the other side, keeping a close eye on you but not bothering you.

Several days from the Greek part to the Turkish part is no problem. You will receive a separate piece of paper with stamps, which you must show when you return. Only a limited number of border crossings are open.
Safety.body_traffic:
Greek and Turkish part follow the English system: drive on the left. The main roads are easy to cycle with the exception of the dual carriageway from Lefkosia to the east, towards Ercan airport. Busy (freight) traffic and bad verge with a risk of flat tires. The back roads are quiet but not always of good quality (cracks and holes). On the north coast, a new road is under construction, from Kaplica to Yenierenköy (May 2010). Motorists are taking cyclists into account as much as possible.

The roads in the city are busy. Especially the capital of Nicosia is a disaster. If you cycle from the South-West (Kato Deftera) to the center, look for the (dry) river. Along this is a good cycle path with every now and then trivial crossings. Unfortunately, the last stretch to the center is not finished yet. The Turkish part of Nicosia is a lot quieter.

We have seen separate cycle paths, especially in the east of the Greek part (Agia Napa). But this touristic part is not interesting for cycling. And the bike paths are laid out pretty trivially: posts, curbs and suddenly stop.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are campsites near Pafos, Polis and Coral Bay. Wild camping is allowed if you have permission from the owner.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
There are 5 youth hostels all over the island. The atmosphere is like in a guesthouse, with larger and smaller dormitories and cooking facilities.

There are many guest houses, the distances in between are not great. Cooking facilities are often available. Along the coast, accommodation in the tourist season is certainly difficult to find later in the day. In North Cyprus, smaller hotels can generally be found along the coast, here and there an English bed and breakfast and rooms.

Visa.body:
Cyprus is not yet part of the Schengen area, but are members of EU. However, they have a visa policy that is based on the Schengen policy.

Schengen Area visa lists.
  Schengen Area
  Other EU member states outside the Schengen Area but bound by the same visa policy and legally obliged to join the Area when they meet the criteria, and special territories of Schengen member states (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Member of the EU with independent visa policy (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Visa-free access to the Schengen states for short stays, usually 90 days in any 180-day period (EU 2018/1806 Annex II)
  Visa required to enter the Schengen states, and to transit some Schengen states in some circumstances (EU 2018/1806 Annex I)
  Visa required to transit any Schengen state (EC 810/2009 Annex IV)
  Travel documents not accepted
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Czech Republic is a pleasant country to cycle at. The population density is quite low, the nature is beautiful, the roads are in good condition and the people are very friendly. Regularly you will spot wild deers. There are a lot of beautiful castels around, which you regularly pass by by accident.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
Hard to find.

Markets and supermarkets
Food can be bought in many places, even on top of hills. Sometimes shops are closed at noon (from 12:00 to 1:00 pm). Smaller local shops are often open early in the morning, also on saturdays and sundays, but may close as early as 11:00 or 12:00. The larger supermarkets are usually open every day of the week from 7 am to 7 am.

Stalls on the street
There are stalls where you can buy something warm.

Restaurants
There is a lot of choice in the cities. In Prague: quite expensive. Between the cities: here and there are small restaurants that offer a dish of the day.

Drinkable water
No problem. Water is widely available. The water in hotels is good, but there is an aftertaste. There is also plenty of mineral water for sale.

Other.body:
Best period to cycle
The weather varies greatly, from very nice weather to downright bad weather. Summers are the best time of year for cycling in the Czech Republic. From November it starts to get noticeably colder and in January and February a lot of snow can easily fall. Road cleaning is only done on the main roads.

Spare parts
There are some, but they are hard to find. Almost all cities and towns have a bicycle shop. Nowadays modern parts (Shimano) are also sold there. The Czech industry is also moving forward and sells compatible parts of comparable quality. The prices of these are a lot lower. The bike shops are often run by avid cyclists, who will certainly help you with repairs. You can often use their tools.

People.body: The local population is generally friendly. In the cities, knowledge of English and German is not a problem, in the smaller villages it is more difficult to find someone who speaks some English or German. The alphabet is the same as with us, place names on the map are easy to read.

Safety.body: Czech Republic is a safe country to cycle in. You won't been bothered by the car and truck drivers, they are quite courteous. There is a helmet requirement for cyclists up to 18 years old.
Safety.body_corruption: If there is corruption, you probably won't notice anything from it ;)
Safety.body_criminality: Be cautios in the big cities.
Safety.body_traffic: The condition of the roads is certainly not bad. The drivers are fairly courteous. In terms of crowds, it is certainly not too bad as you can cycle on secondary roads quite a lot.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are many campsites in the Czech Republic, in the tourist areas they are a lot busier than elsewhere.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are are quite some youth hostels available in most cities. Guesthouses can be found everywhere, you can recognize them under the name 'sobe' and they are certainly not expensive. Hotels and guesthouses can be found in both small and large towns for a very reasonable price. In areas where a lot of winter sports are practiced, you can often leave your bike in the ski storage room. You will then receive a separate key for that.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Not allowed, but if you had to ask if you can stand on a farmer's land, we don't think this would cause a problem.

Bas (2020): "Once I was doing wild camping on a large grassfield from a farmer, and in the morning he spotted me and became quite angry. Having asked beforehand would probably have solved the issue. Other days I camped wild in the nature without problems from locals. Just make sure to clean up after yourself."

FoodDrink.body:
Denmark is quite expensive. Meat and alcoholic drinks are often the most expensive groceries. You will find many stalls along the road with produce from your own land, here you can often put together a good meal that is cheaper than the supermarket.

A grocery store cannot be found everywhere in small villages. Many gas stations also sell food.

Other.body:
Best period to cycle
Seasons (dry / wet)
It is sometimes said that it is special when it is not raining. That is perhaps a bit exaggerated: we have heard stories of cyclists who had beautiful weather. In any case, rain falls more than average elsewhere in europe. The best cycling period is may, june and early july. After that, the chance of rain is greater.

Governing wind directions
Pay attention to which direction you are cycling. In connection with the sometimes strong wind it can be nice to determine your direction of travel. The wind often comes from the (north) west.

People.body: The people are friendly and helpful. Friendly people, very helpful. There is a lot of cycling. They speak Danish. As a foreigner, you can usually use English: almost all people younger than 40 years speak excellent English. Older people often have better German.

Safety.body: Denmark is a safe country. Just be careful in big cities, as always.
Safety.body_criminality: At smaller campsites you can safely leave your bags on the bike.
Safety.body_traffic: There are many good cycle paths, where you can cross the country without a car. On some roads there is a narrow strip next to the road, but then it is noticeable that the Danes drive much more slowly and really take cyclists into account. Avoid the E-roads, they are the busiest.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Denmark has many luxury campsites. You will often find cooking areas with hobs, communal areas with play facilities, washing machines and sometimes a sauna. The campsites are well spread across the country. Official campsites in Denmark require a Camping Card International (or
a Scadinavian Campcard). But many campsites also accept your passport as proof of identity.

Bert (2007): "Campsites in Denmark are quite pricey, but there is a covered cooking area with gas stoves everywhere. Furthermore, the picnic tables are not missing. Also under a shelter for when it rains."

Wimbas: A three star campsite in 2014 with a covered cooking area and good facilities was about € 14 per night for cyclist with tent.

The Danish Cyclists' Union (see organizations) publishes an overview of camping addresses for farmers and landowners.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Youth hostels are suitable for cyclists of all ages: they are luxurious but expensive. Reservations are recommended in high season. Hotels are only available in the larger towns.

Transport.body_boat: All inhabited islands are connected by ferry services on which the bicycle can be taken. The Danish Tourist Board publishes information brochures about ferry services in Denmark.
Transport.body_bus: Many villages can be reached by bus. Some long distance buses also take bicycles if there is room.
Transport.body_train:
Trains run to Copenhagen via Hamburg where the bicycle is allowed. Inquire at the Deutsches Bundesbahn and the Danish Tourist Office. You can also take your bicycle on the train from Malmö (Sweden).

It is also possible to bring a bicycle on the local train. See the journey planner of the Danish railways: www.rejseplanen.dk. Check: "Cykelmedtagning er nødvendig". Bicycle places must be reserved in advance.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

70510d9c-c18f-4815-afc7-99b2adf52013.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

Visa.body: Most nationalities need a visa for entering Djibouti.

Almost all nationalities can enter Dominica without a visa, ranging from 21 days up to 6 months.

  Dominica
  Freedom of movement
  Visa-free entry for 6 months
  Visa-free entry for 3 months or 90 days
  Visa-free entry for 21 days, for Cuba 28 days
  Visa required

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: The Dominican Republic is a beautiful country with a nice variety of dry landscapes with thorn bushes and tree-like cacti and more tropical mountain and hilly landscapes with meadows and palm and banana trees. High in the mountains there were still some cloud forests with a lot of precipitation.

FoodDrink.body:
Food is available in every village except on the Pedernales-Puerto Escondido road.

Drinkable water
You can drink tap water, although this is not recommended. In Santa Domingo it's better to buy water because there is a lot of chlorine in the water and it's not tasty. Bottled water is inexpensive and available in many places.

Other.body:
Best period to cycle
Seasons (dry / wet)
December / January: maximum temperature usually just above 30 degrees. Usually dry and sunny weather. It often had rain in the evening and at night. And of course there was rain in the mountains in a piece of cloud forest. During July-December there is a risk of hurricanes. Wind direction are usually (north) -easterly.

People.body: The people are friendly, there are many people who call and wave Americano or Gringo to you. People call out to you but are never pushy. Occasionally you will also be asked for money (especially children). Spanish is the main language, few people speak English. Many people like it when you take pictures of them.

Safety.body: DR is an easy and safe country that is large enough for a bicycle ride of several weeks.

Sleeping.body_hostels: There are hotels in most cities and towns. The hotels were expensive for their quality. 70 Peso for a very primitive hotel with no running water in a wooden house to 550 peso for a hotel where hot water supply was not working and the light could only go on in the bathroom. In places with more bathers such as Santa Barbara and Punta Cana, the hotels were not more expensive but much more luxurious.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Dominican Republic without a visa for up to 90 days.

  Dominican Republic
  Countries with visa-free access to Dominican Republic
  Visa required for entry to the Dominican Republic
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body: Much more than rice, egg, potato and casava is not available in the smaller towns.

Other.body:
Spare parts
Basic bike shops are in most places. In Quito and Cuenca there are also high tech stores that e.g. also have v-brakes and the like. 28 "wheels are not found.

People.body: The Indigenes in the Andes are quite timid. Coastal residents are less pleasant to deal with.

Safety.body_traffic: Buses, in particular, drive dangerously. For the rest, people drive fast but still quite careful with regard to cyclists. Wearing a helmet is certainly recommended on the PanAm highway.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Camping with the locals is possible.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There is a hotel in almost every town.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: You can camp in the national parks.

Transport.body_bus: Taking a bicycle on the bus is no problem at all. Buses run frequently and everywhere. There is a good chance that your bike will end up on top of the roof (roof rack) and a scratch cannot be ruled out completely, but every effort is made to make it go well. Costs around $ 2.

Visa.body:
Quite a lot of nationalities can enter Ecuador without a visa.


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Cycling in Egypt is different from a lot of other countries. Here you get escorted by the police on many roads. This is mostly because they want you to be safe, unfortunately.

Corona.body:
Corona tests are quite expensive. Ranging from 80-150$. Entering from an airport is the cheapest option when it comes to the tests. Entering via boat is possible in Port Suez, Hurghada. Their might be more ports available. 
Also the ferry from Akaba, Jordan, to Dahb is going.

Otherwise there are very few restrictions when traveling.

FoodDrink.body:
There is not always that much to eat in the oases. There are hardly any cafeterias in the western desert, where there is less traffic. 

Restaurants
Eating out is cheap, especially in dahab and there are good restaurants to be found. Follow the lonely planet and you are usually in the right place.

Drinkable water
John: "We used tap water. In dahab it didn't taste good and we bought bottles. There are shops in all the villages. Unfortunately there are local prices and tourist prices. Adding amounts is rounded up very broadly."
Take enough water with you in the desert (6 to 8 liters).

Health.body:
Mandatory vaccinations
A yellow fever vaccination is mandatory if you come from a yellow fever area.

Useful vaccinations for cyclists
  • Vaccinations against dtp and hepatitis a are recommended
  • Sufficient (pet) bottles on your bike seems obvious to me.
  • A water bag for wild camping is also handy and yet easy.
  • If you have delicate skin (or don't want to look old at a young age) you should protect your skin from the sun. Not just with suntan lotion, but with thin cotton or linen clothing. Long sleeves, long legs, most desert dwellers never wear their swimming trunks. A cap or hat is also nice, even cotton gloves can offer a solution against extreme sun radiation.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
July and August: unsuitable, midday temperatures rise above 40 ° C, but the advantage is that it's dry. The best period to cycle is from November to March.

Jan and Janny: "In the desert the temperature drops to freezing at night in February. During the day there is a pleasant spring temperature."

Wind
Helen: "Egypt is notorious for its wind, and the direction varies quite a lot. We had a headwind as we drove from North to South along the East side of Sinai, and so hoped for tailwind on the west side, which didn't happen and we got headwind again."

People.body:
The population is hospitable and easy to talk to. As a Westerner, you are hardly left alone for a moment in Cairo and Luxor etc. Elsewhere it is relaxed. Egypt is an Islamic country. 

John: "You absolutely have to adjust clothing. Cover as much skin as possible. You are ashamed of the airplane tourists who don't care about anything. In the tourist towns on the Red Sea you can walk on the street in shorts and sleeves, the locals do the same."

Safety.body_nature: When camping, never pitch your tent in a wadi (dry river bed). If it rains a hundred kilometers away, there is a chance that a water / mud tide will wash away your tent. Take into account very cold nights, especially in february. "
Safety.body_traffic:
Freek: "The first part from Cairo to the Suez Canal is very busy. You probably are not allowed to cycle in the tunnel under the Suez Canal; if you are allowed, it is advisable not to do it. Not too wide road and very a lot of freight traffic, which does not always run smoothly. The part from the Suez Canal to the south is also still busy. All the traffic runs along the coast. Many places are not on the way, so take that into account !!! Very inspiring is the environment in my opinion neither. " The route through the western desert processes several dozen vehicles per day.

We did the route along the west side of the Sinai by bus. This is not very suitable for cyclists because the traffic is busier with, among other things, a lot of tankers that transport water.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: John: "We visited campsites in Basata (25 km north of Nuweiba; beautiful and comfortable), Sharm el Sheik and Luxor. You can also pitch your tent on the roof of simple hotels for a few euros. the desert and on our gravel routes we could camp freely without any problems. "
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are very cheap hotels in the Nile Valley and in oases.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: The desert is one big campsite, where you don't even need a tent. You can also sleep at the cafeteria, where there is water, tea and occasionally food.

Visa.body:
The visa policy of Egypt differs quite a lot, see image below. Quite a lot of nationalities can obtain a visa on arrival.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Stalls on the street
Many pupuserias, the fast food of El Salvador. Tortilla with filling of your choice.

Restaurants
In simple comedores you have a good and inexpensive meal in the morning and afternoon. The restaurants a la carte are slightly more expensive, but still cheap. Always with rice and tortillas.

Drinkable water
You can buy water in 500ml bags almost everywhere, very cheap and quite handy.
