People.body: The Salvadoreños are very hospitable and helpful. They feel honored that you want to visit their country. They also seem very eager to tell about their area. They don't come across as intrusive.

Safety.body: El Salvador is known for its murder rate, but as a bicycle tourist you don't have to worry about that. They are gangs who deal with each other. It is best, as for any region, to check what neighborhoods to avoid after sunset. There are many security guards everywhere on the street and at the tourist attractions. But I have not seen any incidents.
Safety.body_traffic: Outside large cities, there is little crowds. Traffic is mostly bicycle-friendly, with a good distance in between. Primary roads are very good. There is some dirt and things that are not very tire-friendly on the emergency lane along the highway. There are some boulders on unpaved roads, but most roads do have a layer of asphalt, so that a good route can always be mapped out.

Visa.body:
Quite a numerous amount of nationalities can enter El Salvador without a visa.


  El Salvador
  Visa-free access to El Salvador
  May not enter on Canada/Schengen/US visa
Source: Wikipedia.

There are a few countries who don't need a visa, but most do. During Bas Idsinga's trip he heard rumours that it was almost impossible to get this visa. It seems that they don't want tourists.

Source: Wikipedia.

Most nationalities need a visa to enter Eritrea. 

Visa policy of Eritrea
  Eritrea
  Visa not required
  Visa on arrival
  Visa required
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
You can buy the well-known tanks for campingaz in tallinn at matkasport, about 5 km from the center in a shopping center along exit road 4 next to a large server supermarket. Rakser sport, karga 20, in haapsulu also has campingaz.

Supermarkets
Almost every village has a shop. There is a wide choice of food. Supermarkets can also be found in the larger cities. In every village shop, no matter how small, you can pay easily and super fast with a credit card. You can also drink coffee and tea in various village shops. They usually have cakes there too.

Drinkable water
Water from the tap is better to avoid. The beer is not expensive and of excellent quality. Brewery A. de Coq has many types of beer, including bock beers and beer of 12%.

Health.body: Estonia consists largely of non-cultivated area. There are many forests. There are many stabbing animals in the woods. If you leave the road for a while for your sanitary needs, an attack of hornets, mosquitoes and other small scum immediately follows.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The best time to go to Estonia is late spring and summer. Winters are cold and autumn is humid.

People.body:
The people seem to be a bit distant at first, but if you approach them and ask something, they will be happy to help. The young generation is much more open. Of course, people in the countryside are also curious about this strange cyclist, because tourists usually linger in the coastal region and the cities. In the countryside you will also be able to enjoy the authentic life as it has been for decades.

Bert: "The residents like to party: in the summer months they go out with large groups. They first play a kind of game without limits on a campsite and then the barbecue starts. Can be noisy, but if you can't beat them!!! I have been invited several times ".

Safety.body_traffic: In general, the roads are quiet to very quiet, with the exception of the motorways (where cycling is allowed). An exception to this is June 23 (Midsummer). All Estonia's cars are then on the road. And drunken riders seem to be no exception

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: In the countryside there are so-called tourist farms where you can spend the night (bed & breakfast formula). Look out for small signposts marked "külalistemaja" or "puhkemaja" (meaning "guesthouse") or "turismitalu" (guest farm).
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: New campsites are emerging everywhere. Managers of holiday homes also offer their lawn as a parking space. The sanitary facilities of the campsites are remarkably good: a nice hot shower, toilet paper in the toilets and sometimes a sauna and a fully equipped kitchen. Several campsites are beautifully situated in nature. Prices are between 3 and 10 euros for a cyclist and a small tent.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
The international YH guide only mentions a few youth hostels in the Baltic States. The respective organizations are affiliated with the Finnish youth hostel center. However, there are plenty of alternative inns. These have a more extensive network and the operators speak at least one foreign language (English or German).

You will find hotels in all possible price ranges. Budget hotels are scarce and very sober.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
There are information boards with a large map at various places in the country. Camping spots are indicated on it, but when you come close, nothing is indicated. Usually these are picnic / bbq places near a lake. There is a difference between campsites and campsites. The campsites are the places as described above with only a wooden dixie as sanitary facilities, washing must then be done in the lake (if there is one). Often there is also wood to make a fire. You can find info about free camping places in Estonia in the RMK phone app -  or they have an online map, too. The map is the most precise map for Estonia you can find with small forest paths marked in it.

With the exception of the national parks, it is officially allowed to camp freely, and that is often done. There are many good places to be found.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

640869e2-06af-425d-9bdf-7da9a5c3c833.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

FoodDrink.body:
The national food is injera: a teff sour pancake. The injera is often served with some (s) which are placed on top of the injera. One thing that is almost always served is Shiro. The wats are generally quite spicy, so that the sour taste of the injera is suppressed.

Another common meal is tibs, which are small pieces of roast meat served on an injera.

Restaurants
Restaurants are widely available throughout the country. They can often be recognized by a sign depicting the meals served. In smaller places they are difficult to recognize and will have to be informed about them.

Pasta is also often available. This too is served on an injera. Instead of injera, you can often opt for (fairly sticky) bread. There are many other dishes, such as firfir and cutlet. However, these are mainly found in the larger towns. Western meals can also be found there. Considering the many possibilities to eat very cheaply in a restaurant, cooking utensils are not necessary, unless you do not like the Ethiopian food.

Drinkable water
A jerry can (can be purchased in Arba Minch or Konso), water filter and water bags are indispensable as water is scarce and usually has to be collected from the pump yourself.

There is no water on the way from one village to the next, so you must be able to bring water with you for at least one day of cycling. We took about 10 liters per day for the two of us and that was almost always used up at the end of the bike ride.

Health.body:
Common diseases
Malaria occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis and the like are available on site.

Vaccinations
  • Yellow fever vaccination is recommended and sometimes mandatory.
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
Useful
Given the complete lack of medical facilities, we took a broad spectrum antibiotic (ciproxin) and an anti-amoebic treatment (Fasigyn) with us. We did not need them, by the way.

Other.body:
Best bike period
During the rainy seasons (march to may and october to december in the south, and june to october in central ethiopia) the roads are impassable due to mud and rivers.

Parts and repair
Boulders and potholes require a sturdy bike. Count on at least one flat tire a day: the acacia thorns are like metal. Strong tweezers are useful for pulling the thorns out of your tire.

There are bicycle shops in large cities. However, don't expect a large selection and / or high quality.

Due to all the bumping on the roads, bolts and screws become loose in the long run, including those of the Ortlieb bags. It is important to fix it regularly. Lost one ortlieb bolt m5 x 10 with flat head from one of the suspension hooks. Despite visiting dozens of shops, garages and bicycle dealers in different cities, only two m5 bolts were found, both were far too long and had recessed heads.

People.body:
There are quite a few different population groups in Ethiopia. The most important are: Oromo, Amhara, Tigre, Sidamo, Shankella and Somali. Sixty percent of the population is Christian. The people, children in particular, can be quite pushy and annoying. Persistent begging for money and gifts can seriously damage your resilience.

People who work in shops, hotels and restaurants and the like are very helpful. Owners of hotels and restaurants keep all too curious people at a distance, and bicycles are also guarded. A restaurateur even called in the police to secure the bike. In this way, hotels and restaurants are true refuges.

Much of the Ethiopian population believes that white people hand out money. To avoid not noticing them, you are called out very loudly: YOU YOU YOU, FARANJI FARANJI FARANJI, MONEY MONEY MONEY !!!!! Especially when climbing on unpaved roads, which you often find in Ethiopia, almost continuously children walk behind you with a lot of screaming. In Ethiopia, as a cyclist, it's difficult to get rest.

If it turns out that you don't give anything, children often want to throw stones at you. Not very loud, but still hit and very annoying. This behavior gets worse when it gets / is dark, even older youngsters start throwing stones. Children also sometimes want to pull your bike so that you come to a stop.

Safety.body: In Ethiopia you have to deal with children throwing stones. Very annoying. If you want to avoid this, you could take a direct bus to Arba Minch. (For further information see under Transport) The disadvantage is that you immediately skip half the country! South of Addis the experiences with stone throwing children are a lot less than north of Addis. It often helps to step down, beckon an adult and ask to come along (possibly after offering a cigarette, very unhealthy, but you do make friends with it). No adult around? Stay standing for a while, some of the children will stand around you and thus prevent the rest from continuing to throw. And remember: most of them go wrong. By just squeezing your brakes or getting off, many children run away. The border areas with Sudan, Eritrea and Somalia are unsafe with the exception of the main road from Gondar to Matema in the northwest.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A tent is only necessary / usable in the sparsely populated parts in the south, or on the sporadically present campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In many places, including the smaller ones, a hotel is available.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Ethiopia.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
The Faroe Islands formally belong to Denmark. The landscape is bare, eaten bare by the sheep, but the steep cliff coasts full of birds, the fjords and the tranquility make it an indescribably beautiful destination.

If you ever get the chance then go for these incredible capricious shaped islands of which a lot are connected by bridges and the roads are very good. Climate can be harsh and winds can blow extremely hard, but if you like a challenge you won't be disappointed.

If you are going by ferry to Iceland from Danmark, the ferry also calls in at the capital Torshavn. If you have your bicycles with you, you have the chance of doing a half day cycling tour over the main island.

Other.body:
Routes
Driving around is difficult. Because of the many fjords, most roads end up dead and you are forced to cycle back the same way. It is beautiful almost everywhere.

The main roads on the central island of Streymoy are very busy (especially during the morning and evening rush hours) and the cars drive quite fast. From Torshavn to the northwest it is better not to take the very busy road nr 50. A good, quiet and beautiful alternative is the old pass road No. 10. You can cycle on the relatively flat island of Sandoy (the ferry leaves from Gamlaraett, south of Torshavn).

Best time to cycle
Undoubtedly the best cycling period in summer: June, July and August. It hardly gets dark then. The average maximum temperatures in summer are around 12 degrees and it is the driest time of the year. However, the weather is also very changeable in summer. Any time it doesn't rain is included.

Spare parts
Bicycle repairers will undoubtedly be found in the capital Torshaven.

Tips
Harry: “I visited the Faroe Islands on my way to Iceland. The ferry service sails in between to Bergen (Norway), returns after three days and then continues. However, the islands are so beautiful in my opinion that a longer stay is definitely recommended. Do not just cycle there, also step now and then and walk towards the beautiful cliffs, indescribably beautiful. ”

People.body: Everyone speaks Danish and Faroese (which is a bit like Icelandic). The young people usually also speak good English. The people are a bit shy, but very friendly.

Safety.body_traffic:
The quality of the asphalt is amazing, up to the last house there is beautiful asphalt. There are tunnels on many routes; so make sure you have good lighting. There are two types of tunnels: "normal" tunnels through the mountains and "sub-sea tunnels" from one island to another.

The regular tunnels are quite different from each other: one or two lanes, illuminated or unlit. The length varies from 200 meters to more than 3 km. Exciting, but not completely harmless.

There are also two sub-sea tunnels: to the island of Vagar (5 km) and to the island of Bordoy (6 km). I have not tried them, but I assume that you have to descend and climb considerably in these tunnels. You can also take the bus through such a tunnel. You can bring the bike.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are about 10 camping areas. Free camping is not allowed, but if you ask in a village if you can stand somewhere, you may succeed.

Transport.body_airplane: Copenhagen maintains a flight connection with the islands.
Transport.body_boat:
Smyril Line sails twice a week from Denmark to Torshavn in the summer. Once a week the boat sails on to Iceland. On the way out or back to or from Iceland, a stopover of 3 days in the Faroe Islands is possible without additional payment.

Ferries operate between some islands.
Transport.body_bus: All villages on the islands can be reached by bus and the road to it is paved. The bicycle is allowed on the bus.

About.body: Appropriately nicknamed 'The land of the thousand lakes', Finland is truly a gem in the Nordics with its exquisite nature, varied wildlife, and picturesque landscapes. Many cycling paths, the hospitality of the local people, and a huge number of places waiting to be explored provide for unique cycling opportunities for bike touring or bike packing all year round (do not forget that winters can get quite rough).

227eb524-8413-4750-9c51-fdc1be56e080.description:
Pyörä-Nurmi is Finland's largest private sports store located in Rauma. The shop's got a wide selection of gear for different sports, including cycling and bicycle maintenance. Pyörä-Nurmi's been reviewed highly by customers.

For more information, visit the website: Pyörä-Nurmi
227eb524-8413-4750-9c51-fdc1be56e080.title: Pyörä-Nurmi

2e439793-f873-401e-a432-d7d48432c2b6.description:
Bicycle shop and service Antin Pyörä - Electric bicycle specialist shop, but they service other types of bicycles.

For more information, visit the website: Antin Pyörä.
2e439793-f873-401e-a432-d7d48432c2b6.title: Antin Pyörä Oy

36bd0a36-00a7-4da9-a214-daf605467d02.description:
Among other things (car parts etc.), Motonet's got a fine selection of bicycle gear. If your bike breaks down in the area and you want to fix it yourself, you might find what you need in this shop.

For more information, visit the website: Motonet
36bd0a36-00a7-4da9-a214-daf605467d02.title: Motonet

8e0158ba-24d7-4b09-bd8c-5c29088175cd.description:
Carfield is a bicycle rental shop. It offers a wide range of bicycles, and its bicycles can be found at over 20 rental points all over the Turku Archipelago.

For more information, visit the official website: https://www.carfield.fi/
8e0158ba-24d7-4b09-bd8c-5c29088175cd.title: Carfield Pyörävuokraamo

9b3ddae5-ff28-483a-b9b3-d1292b68c77b.description:
Carfield is a bicycle rental shop. It offers a wide range of bicycles, and its bicycles can be found at over 20 rental points all over the Turku Archipelago.

For more information, visit the website: Carfield.
9b3ddae5-ff28-483a-b9b3-d1292b68c77b.title: Carfield Pyörävuokraamo

e9b0882d-8133-4cdb-aa8a-fca877fb0c5e.description:
StyleRide is a shop for cruisers and custom bicycles, but they also have city bikes, frames, parts, and parts for older bicycles. 


For more information, visit the official website: StyleRide.
e9b0882d-8133-4cdb-aa8a-fca877fb0c5e.title: StyleRide

f0dd4df5-d6fa-4499-89bf-e8a4f52e8fef.description:
Among other things (car parts etc.), Motonet's got a fine selection of bicycle gear. If your bike breaks down in the area and you want to fix it yourself, you might find what you need in this shop.

For more information, visit the website: Motonet.
f0dd4df5-d6fa-4499-89bf-e8a4f52e8fef.title: Motonet

f1563d93-c02f-4236-96a6-e8d38e6576fa.description:
Suomisen Pyörä is situated in the centre of Rauma. They sell new bikes and do maintenance and service. You might not need a booking for small fixes such as a flat tyre, but you need to call in first regarding bigger repairs.  The company's got great reviews online.

For more information, visit the website: Suomisen Pyörä
f1563d93-c02f-4236-96a6-e8d38e6576fa.title: Suomisen Pyörä

Corona.body:
Residents of the following countries can travel to Finland for leisure: the Vatican, Australia, Singapore, Thailand, New Zealand and South Korea. There is no mandatory testing or quarantine for residents from the above-mentioned countries on arrival in Finland.

Only essential travel (not leisure) is possible from China and Hong Kong, and Macao Special Administrative Regions.

All travellers arriving in Finland from corona risk countries are tested for the Coronavirus. (Latest update on 25 February 2021)

For more information about the current Coronavirus situation, visit the website and this website.

FoodDrink.body:
In Finland, everyone is allowed to pick wild berries and mushrooms almost anywhere. The best season is from mid-July until late September. Just make sure that you follow the straightforward but crucial rules for pickers and safety.

There are various dishes to try while visiting Finland such as Karjalanpiirakka (Karelian pasty - rice pie), Leipajuusto (Finnish squeaky cheese), Salmiakki (salty liquorice), Poronkäristys (sauteed reindeer), Kalakeitto (Fish soup), Hernekeitto (split pea soup), Salmiakki Koskenkorva (Pre-mixed liqueur), Lakka (Liqueur produced with Cloudberry) and many other dishes and drinks.

For more information about berry and mushroom picking, visit the website www.nationalparks.fi 

Cooking fuel
The "camping gaz prick cans" (at the do it yourself, tool department) are available in the very large supermarkets.

Health.body:
The biggest problem are the many mosquitoes - we ourselves had anti-mosquito milk, a gel from Care Plus based on 30% Deet - in Lapland we bought an extra (effective) product, namely Johnson OFF! "Tervantuoksu" o. OFF is available everywhere in various forms (spray, gel, marker, liquid, aerosol, candle). Etono (20 mg) can be bought at pharmacies and helps against itching. Brewer's yeast should help but didn't.

One person is "tastier" for the mosquitoes than another. Type of forest matters whether you have a lot or little trouble. Hornets can also be very annoying.

People.body: It might not be an easy task to strike up a conversation with Finns at first, but once you manage to get to know them, you will find out that they are just a polite and straightforward bunch who are extremely friendly and willing to help you out.

QuickFacts.climate:
The Finnish climate is relatively colder than in many other countries, and the weather varies a lot in different seasons. 
Nice and mild summers with the average temperatures around 20°C in the south, and 15°C in the north.
Winters tend to be cold and you should be prepared for snowfalls and daytime temperatures that could easily go down to -20°C in Southern Finland, and -30°C in the Northern Finland, although the average temperature is around 0°C. (In the northernmost part of Finland, the sun does not rise at all for several weeks in the winter, and does not set at all in early summer).
QuickFacts.language:
Finnish, Swedish - Official languages. 
Saami languages - Languages of the indigenous population of Finland.
QuickFacts.religion: Most Finns are Christians. The largest community in Finland is the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland (Suomen evankelis-luterilainen kirkko) - about 70% of the population.
QuickFacts.sim_card: Telia, Elisa, DNA, and other small companies.

Safety.body:
Finland is one of the safest countries globally and has one of the world's most effective and trusted police forces.

For more information, visit the website.
Safety.body_corruption:
Finland ranked 3rd out of 180 countries with a score of 85/100 in the Corruption Perceptions Index done by Transparency International.

For more information, visit the website.
Safety.body_criminality:
Petty crimes such as pickpocketing do occur in crowded areas and during the summer tourist season.

Bicycle theft is the most common type of theft. However, after a long period of increase, the number of bicycle thefts has declined. (Finland 2020 Crime & Safety Report).

For more information, visit the website.
Safety.body_nature:
Finland's got a lot to offer. Diverse nature, with its islands, lakes, as well as Lapland covered in autumn colours, wildlife and much more.

Although, there are a few things to be prepared for, such as infuriating mosquitos during the summer months, especially in Lapland or encountering wildlife.

For more information, visit the website:  and this website
Safety.body_traffic:
Relatively well-organized, and there are numerous official bicycle roads to get around. Although, the more remote place you go to, the fewer bicycle roads you get.

For more information, visit the website.

01d89b55-ded6-48f0-a226-39555287998d.description:
The outdoor swimming centre, Samppalinnan maauimala, is situated almost on a riverbank of Aura, a river which runs through the city.

For more information, visit the website: Samppalinnan.
01d89b55-ded6-48f0-a226-39555287998d.title: Outdoor swimming facility

1914777f-318b-4388-8dfd-1d8d2e99f04d.description:
Kustavin Savipaja Oy is a family-run business with pottery located in the Archipelago. They also run a café and serve traditional and delicious Finnish dishes such as Munkki, Finnish doughnuts with cardamon, or salmon soup which are a must-try while in Finland. 

For more information, visit the website: Kustavin Savijapa.
1914777f-318b-4388-8dfd-1d8d2e99f04d.title: Kustavi Handicraft Village

3e3dbcd5-1430-4508-a825-e58348ee3f24.description:
Kuparivuori is a lovely spot overlooking Naantali and some great views to offer. While in Naatali, do not forget to visit the Old Town with its wooden houses, cafes, narrow streets, and nearby harbour. 

For more information, visit the websites: Kuparivuori info, Old Town, and Visit Naantali.
3e3dbcd5-1430-4508-a825-e58348ee3f24.title: Kopparberget (Kuparivuori)

3fede3f9-2203-4e84-b040-2c9dd1f0561b.description:
Sammallahdenmäki is a bronze age burial site that is also listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Probably not one of the must-see sights, but definitely worth a visit.

For more information, visit the website: Sammallahdenmäki
3fede3f9-2203-4e84-b040-2c9dd1f0561b.title: Sammallahdenmäki

7365e448-334d-4327-8743-767f7529fc20.description:
Ispoisten uimaranta (Ispoisten beach) is a public and free beach and a great place to end a long day of riding with a quick dip or a bit of swimming over the summer. There are also other facilities nearby - changing room, toilet, sauna, kiosk, playground. 


For more information, visit the websites: Ispoisten uimaranta, and Turun Avantouimarien
7365e448-334d-4327-8743-767f7529fc20.title: Beach

7e5e68dc-c64e-49c7-ba27-f23fe061511c.description:
Nagu Marina is located in Nagu village centre. The local attractions include shops, restaurants and cafés, hotels, art, beach, and events.

You can visit Nagu while cycling around the Turku Archipelago, where it is part of the longer route and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: Nagu Hamn, FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, Cycling around the Archipelago and Info page.
7e5e68dc-c64e-49c7-ba27-f23fe061511c.title: Nagu Marina (Nagu Hamn)

84179b23-ff7f-45c5-bac4-7658346c57fd.description:
A more 700-year-old landmark in the heart of Turku is worth paying a visit to when cycling through this picturesque city in the south of Finland. 

For more information about the city, visit the  websites: Visit Turku, and Kiss my Turku.
84179b23-ff7f-45c5-bac4-7658346c57fd.title: Turku Cathedral

8ce0f291-de51-4689-93c8-4a111e29cc02.description:
Iniö municipality's got more than 1000 small islands out of which only 10 are inhabited all year round, and the main attraction is its nature. 

Visit Iniö while cycling around the Turku Archipelago, where it is part of the longer route and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, and Info page.
8ce0f291-de51-4689-93c8-4a111e29cc02.title: Iniö

9ccc5c7c-0463-48c4-931f-751ffa89e957.description:
Hikes in the forest or strolls on a beach are already a couple of reasons why to visit Korpo while cycling around the Turku Archipelago, where it is part of the longer route and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit websites: Korpo, FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, and Info page.
9ccc5c7c-0463-48c4-931f-751ffa89e957.title: Korpo

a09e680b-047a-4294-a0b0-c3bb7f88c3d1.description:
Travelling to Kylmäpihlaja island to see the lighthouse will surely do for a fine experience. Several facilities can be found on the island, such as the lighthouse hotel, a restaurant, saunas, outdoor hot tub and more.

The hotel, restaurant, and beach cafe are open from 4 - 29.8.2021 and on weekends 3 - 5.9. and 10-12.9.2021.

Make sure to check the opening tours, COVID regulations, and waterbuses to the island before travelling. 

For more information, visit the website: Kylmäpihlaja Lighthouse and Waterbuses timetables.
a09e680b-047a-4294-a0b0-c3bb7f88c3d1.title: Kylmäpihlaja Lighthouse

a3f0fdb2-abd2-4d54-abaa-1db5b07f3e9f.description:
A steep hill leads to Karhuvuoren ilmavalvontatorni which is a highly recommended scenic spot on the Aaslaluoto island. 
You can visit the observation tower while cycling around the Turku Archipelago, where it is part of the short route and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: FinFerrries,  Archipelago Trail, and Info Page.
a3f0fdb2-abd2-4d54-abaa-1db5b07f3e9f.title: Bear Mountain Observation Tower

aad62692-57b1-41cf-b873-d2a9ad8ac67e.description:
Själö is a tiny island known for its history (used to be a leper hospital and a mental asylum), as well as nature and church. At the moment, the island hosts the Archipelago Research Institute, which is a part of the University of Turku. 

You can visit Själö while cycling around the Turku Archipelago, where it is part of the longer route and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, Cycling around the Archipelago, Själö info, and Info page.
aad62692-57b1-41cf-b873-d2a9ad8ac67e.title: Själö (Seili)

bdc37e31-33dd-4b5b-8260-13ae4bf7d782.description:
Uhlu quarry is a body of almost crystal clear water and a great site to visit.

Although you should not swim in the quarry under no circumstances due to safety reasons and the fact that it might also be illegal.
bdc37e31-33dd-4b5b-8260-13ae4bf7d782.title: Uhlu quarry

c1502751-be6b-4c03-8fc4-103ee5611a1b.description:
Castle from the 13th century houses a museum and exhibitions (permanent and changing).

For more information, visit the website: Turku castle.
c1502751-be6b-4c03-8fc4-103ee5611a1b.title: Castle

d8b2cffb-339f-48b3-992e-962e562f1089.description:
Old Rauma is a remarkable collection of more than 600 wooden houses such as churches, houses, and halls. It is also listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

For more information, visit the website: Vanha Rauma
d8b2cffb-339f-48b3-992e-962e562f1089.title: Old Rauma

d9292787-e207-4746-8de9-9adaf10baf8f.description:
Livonsaaren yhteisökylä is an experimental area for rural resettlement and a sustainable lifestyle (ecovillage). You can even sign-up as a volunteer if you fulfil certain requirements.

If you would like to visit the place, make sure to contact responsible people beforehand to see whether you would be allowed to come and if someone would have time to meet you.

For more information, visit the website: Livonsaaren yhteisökylä, and Info page.
d9292787-e207-4746-8de9-9adaf10baf8f.title: Livonsaaren yhteisökylä (Livonsaari Community Village)

de5f4d23-5805-4745-8da2-687a7c3ec6a9.description:
The village is a theme park that is normally open year-round and offers accommodation, restaurants, and different attractions. (safaris, meet the Santa, cross the arctic circle in the village and more).

Make sure to check the opening hours and Coronavirus update.

For more information, visit the website: Santa Claus Village
de5f4d23-5805-4745-8da2-687a7c3ec6a9.title: Santa Claus Village

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are few campsites and they are often far apart. Almost every Finnish campsite (“leirintäalue”) is located on the water (river, lake or sea). They are well equipped for itinerant cyclists with washing facilities, hot water, free hot showers, covered cooking and dining area, toilets, sauna (usually included in the price), a fire pit, children's playground, ...

They offer log cabins, comparable to hikers' cabins, for rent (useful in rainy weather) and you can purchase a Scandinavian camping card (6 euros), which gives you a discount on various campsites. Some campsites do close in mid or late August.

Campsites always have good showers, always a kitchen, often a sauna (sometimes free). Campfire every night and this is a good place to socialize. Camping costs between 15-20 euros per night (fixed amount + per person an amount). Camping card gives a discount of approximately 2 euros at a time and costs 7 euros. Is a good investment.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is allowed anywhere. Many pests in the woods (mosquitoes, flies, hornets). Uimarantas are ideal (wild) camping pitches. Often a toilet and a table. Very precise and informative maps for Finland - https://retkikartta.fi/?lang=en . Switch layers and zoom in to see free camping places.

Transport.body_airplane:
Finavia operates 21 airports in Finland (but there are 27 in total) out of which Helsinki-Vantaa, Oulu, and Rovaniemi are the most frequented. Domestic flights are operated by Finnair, Norwegian, and SAS.

For more information, visit the website: finavia.fi
Transport.body_boat:
Finland's got boat services in many towns along the coast as well as at lakeside places. Moreover, there are options for sightseeing tours and ferries. There are several lines that can take you in and out of Finland to Sweden, Estonia, Germany, the Åland Islands, and even Russia.

For more information, visit the website Visitfinland.com.
Transport.body_bus:
Coach route network in Finland extends far and wide, covering around 90 per cent of public roads.

If you need to continue with your bike further than a train can take you, coaches will help you reach your final destination. (Sitting on a bus in Finland is an experience in itself with the scenic surroundings you get to experience on smaller roads). 

For more information: Matkahuolto, Expressbus, Onnibus

Before you buy a ticket, make sure that bicycles are allowed on a coach to your destination!
Transport.body_train:
Trains in Finland are operated by VR Group (a government-owned railway company). You are allowed to take bicycles on certain trains. Be aware that trains do not run all across the country. The network ends in Kolari (long-distance trains). Trains are generally on time, comfortable, and have power outlets, and free Wi-Fi.

For more information, visit the website.

Before you buy a ticket, make sure that bicycles are allowed aboard a train to your destination!

Visa.body:
People from the EU and several other countries don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit Finland.

The visa is valid for 90 days (no more than 3 months within a 6 months period) and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries. In some cases, there is a possibility for an extension. 

For more information, you can also visit this www.infofinland.fi.

About.body: France offers a variety of possibilities: sights, curiosities and cultural and folkloric events, beautiful landscapes spread between the sea and European high mountains as well as a variety of food, top wines, liqueurs and other drinks.

FoodDrink.body:
• Many villages do have a boulangerie, where you can enjoy the French baguette, croissants and many more. In Northern France, however, they are sown more thinly than you think.
  • Note that in France cola or beer is often more expensive than wine. For cheap drinks, you have to behave like a bon vivant in France, and drink a glass of wine with a meal.
Cooking fuel
Gas cans from Campingaz are easy to find.

Markets and Supermarkets
There is a wide variety of foodstuffs in France. The local markets are tempted to stock up on fruit, vegetables, cheese and spreads. You can also find all the necessities in large supermarkets (Le Clercq, Carrefour.) That are announced kilometers in advance. Leave the Dutch cheese on the racks for 1 time and enjoy the artisan French cheeses of the region, the ham (jambon), the liver pate, the salamis, the seasonal fruit and seasonal vegetables. This in combination with a baguette (French elongated bread) with or without a French wine is the ideal picnic during your holiday.

Restaurants
A good alternative to the “à la carte” meal in the restaurant is the “menu du jour” that the local bar offers you. Check out what the cook will be serving that day via the sign or ask the waitress directly. You often get a starter or salad, a main course and a dessert or cheese with a carafe of wine and bread at will for barely 10 to 12 €. For a smooth service, it is best to present yourselves around 12 noon but not after 1 pm.

Water
Just like with us, the tap water is drinkable. A useful advice: have your drinking cup refilled with ice-cold water at the cafe or restaurant where you had a coffee. Since the warm summer of 2003, the Horeca owners were kindly requested to offer this refreshment free of charge.

Health.body: France is well supplied with the 'Pharmacies', even the smaller towns have such a provision. Hospitals can be found in the larger towns. There is also a list of a doctor, dentist and the like at every campsite.

People.body:
Communication with the local people
  • French is spoken in France. Few French speak a second language, such as English. The French are very happy when you speak French.
  • In the south of France I got the idea that they speak more and better English there than in Northern France. It is true that the French appreciate it very much if you try to speak their language.
  • In various regions, the local population speaks a strong dialect. In some regions this is a light variant of French, but in other areas it seems unintelligible French. Especially in the south of France and on the Breton coast, there may be people who occasionally speak a variant of French. But everyone in France is supposed to be able to speak French.
Hospitality
  • Opinions about French hospitality and communication differ widely. Some argue that even if you speak French, the arrogant attitude of the French remains. Others have noticed little of the arrogance. The truth is somewhere in between. It seemed to us that the Parisians are a bit jerky while the French in the villages are a bit more relaxed.
  • The reaction to holiday cyclists is usually neutral, but sometimes a bit strange. Sometimes people don't understand why you go cycling (especially with all that stuff!) When a car goes faster.
  • (Paul 2012) I had some nice experiences with French myself, they are very warm people who like to take the time for something. This is also reflected in the small shops and cafes where the locals come. I myself have not noticed anything of the French arrogance. In general, the French love that you cycle in their country, they think you are crazy, but they are sympathetic to the idea.

Safety.body: France is a safe country. Only in the very large cities do you have to pay more attention to your bike, but that is just like in any other country.
Safety.body_traffic: The quality of the roads is generally good. The roads to and from large cities are of course busier. The French are very cyclist-friendly and ride around you or brake if there is no room to swerve. Make sure you stand out.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
• Camping seems like a great option for a low budget overnight stay. As in hotels, you have a variety ranging from nature campsites (Air Naturelle) or from small campsites (usually Municipals) to the large commercial caravan villages, usually planned around the tourist sites or coastlines. Prices therefore also depend on the type of campsite. The camping rates are clearly announced at the entrance and often so low that wild camping is not an option. In case of emergency, you can always knock on the door of a remote farm and ask to pitch your tent on its domain. There are fewer campsites in the north of the country than in the center and south, where almost every village has a campsite,
  • For an overview of all more than 10,000 campsites, including the farm campsites, there is the FFCC guide (google). It is best to only take the maps and the text parts of this thick book with you from the departments where you will be cycling.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
• You really come across plenty of affordable hotels. You see them even more than campsites.
  • Logis de France has a free booklet with approximately 3000 overnight addresses at independent hotels affiliated with this chain. The booklet contains clear maps and hotel descriptions and is updated every year. It is available at the hotels themselves. Even if you are alone and want to book a night, that is no problem. An overnight stay for 1 person costs approximately € 40 (prices 2007). More information at http://www.logisdefrance.com.
  • Since 2003, Michelin has also published the "Atmospheric Overnachten" guide with a selection of special guesthouses and charming small hotels where you can get a room for € 80 or less per night. Individuals
  • Chambres d'hotes is the French version of Bed & Breakfast. The Gites de France are one of the most famous "labels" for a minimal quality of the Chambres D'Hotes. See http://www.gites-de-france.fr.
  • The Trotter Chambres d'hôtes in France contains the 1500 best Trotter addresses for affordable yet characterful guest rooms in rural France. A very thorough selection, based on years of experience.

Transport.body_airplane: Is possible, also to Corsica
Transport.body_boat:
• From or to Italy. You can find information at http://www.cemar.it/ferries/1_ferries.html or at http://www.seabridges.com.
  • Corsica, for example, has boat connections between Sardinia (Sta Teresa) and Bonifacio.
  • Information about ferry connections across the canal can be found at http://www.seabridges.com
Transport.body_bus: The bus is often not a problem, because the bicycle simply fits in the cargo hold of the regular bus. However, it can take a particularly long time.
Transport.body_train:
• Possibility to take the bicycle with you on the TGV, not disassembled: the places can be reserved and you have to pay. If one is obliged to travel over Paris, one has to change station: this is certainly doable by bicycle. Without reservation, the bicycle must be taken in a transport bag
  • Bicycles CANNOT be taken on many through trains.
  • In Thalys and TGV, the bicycle can be taken in a bicycle transport bag. (see next paragraph)
  • You can also take your bike on the night train to Basel, ten kilometers from the French border
  • Several night trains run from Lille (Lille) to places in the South of France, such as Nice.
  • There are even TGVs where you can take the bike with you without taking it apart or packing it. The bicycle is then hung on the hook in the wagon. However, it is necessary to book in advance.
  • Unfortunately, there is no longer a bicycle train to Avignon.
Bicycle in the TGV and Thalys
When booking a TGV ticket, you will be informed of the possibility to take your bicycle with you if you have it disassembled in a special bag. That bag must be 90x120cm or less. Most bicycles fit exactly in that bag, and the experience is that disassembling your bicycle before departure and reassembling it at your final destination takes about 20 minutes. SNCF gives the impression that your bicycle fits in the luggage rack in the front of every wagon. In practice, this turns out to be disappointing. The racks are retrofitted with an extra grid so that a bicycle no longer fits in the rack and you are forced to place your bicycle in front of the luggage rack. Not everyone is friendly with the obstacle, so it is advisable to walk to the luggage rack at stops to prevent people from destroying your bike.
Another potential problem is transferring in Paris. For example, the metro between Gare du Nord and Montmarte (line 4) is not equipped with escalators. Expect a long and tiring climb through narrow metro tunnels and over steep stairs.
Bicycle transport bags are available from Vaudé, AGU, and Rose, among others. Prices start at around 70 euros and go up to 350 euros for a hard plastic case. Bags can also regularly be found second-hand on well-known auction websites.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

The visa policy of French Guiana (and other French overseas territories) differs quite a lot per nationality.

Visa policy of Overseas France
Visa-free access to:
  All territories, unlimited period
  All territories, up to 3 months
  All territories; most up to 3 months, one up to 15 days on organized trips
  All territories; some up to 3 months, some up to 15 days
  Most territories, up to 3 months
  Some territories, up to 3 months
  Some territories, up to 15 days on organized trips
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: There are more national parks than big cities in this country. There is a nice transition from the busy capital to the quiet South. The country is flat to hilly, with good roads.

-MGOeIg7i6YcrRc7Il7p.title: Making animal friends and enemies in Gabon

-MGObCEccQY63dAioVGS.description: Quite an easy place to get the visa with friendly officials who speak English quite well. Bring 2 passport photos, passport copy and hotel booking. You can pick up the visa the next day.

-MGObTa0zEz8IWDWhVQk.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

Onroad: Omeltte+bread / Spaghetti (±1100CFA) 
Local food: Rice, fufu
Local drink: Palm wine

-MGOcjxAzzWyVoT6N1v2.description: I landed in Libreville, and then headed to Congo Republic via the road closest to the coast (still far away from the coast).
-MGOcjxAzzWyVoT6N1v2.title: Libreville to Congo

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.

-MGOd9O9alDQuDcer8pA.description: Here you can spot elephants and gorillas in between an amazing area.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Most cities have accommodation. Room with fan should be around 5.000 CFA, with AC a bit more. Expect bucket showers.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but in the North there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first. In the South there are more opportunities.

-MGOeYbJwjzSwgEtuFQo.title: Bike touring in Gabon and Congo

About.body: Surrounded almost entirely by Senegal, The Gambia more or less is the same, except that they speak English. As it is divided by a river into North and South, you can either cycle through it in one day, or follow the river to explore the inner depths of the country.

FoodDrink.body:
The Gambian cuisine can be very delicious. They like to eat rice, casave and domoda, with a local juice from baobab trees. They eat together from a big plate and if you're at the right place, the meals are very tasty.

Most villages have shops with a limited supply of fresh bread and some standard canned products. Lodge camps and hotels usually also serve meals.

Restaurants
Hugo: "You eat with the locals. Rice with fish or meat, together from one pan. Costs 25 dal. Vegetarian food is better available than with meat. Fine cuisine."
George: There are plenty of places to eat. Make sure you have enough food supplies yourself.

Drinkable water
Tap water is usually unreliable. There are many pumps with good water along the way. Avoid pits as much as possible because of the risk of contamination. Water is also available in bottles, but not everywhere. Depending on the season and destination, make sure you have sufficient supplies, for example in water bags. Bringing a filter with you can help in some situations.

Health.body:
• Malaria is the number one enemy of the nation, it occurs all year round. LCR advice: before a trip to The Gambia, always visit a travel advice and vaccination office or a specialized travel medicine doctor, especially for a short last-minute trip.
  • Malaria drugs and vaccinations are urgently advised for The Gambia.
  • Yellow fever, DTP and hepatitis A vaccinations are recommended.
  • In the dry period there are few mosquitoes and directly along the coast and the river up to Tendaba, because of the salty water, there are fewer mosquitoes by default.
  • In many lodges and small hotels, mosquito nets are already fitted as standard, sometimes you have to hang one yourself. Also bring your own cord and some screw hooks.
  • There are not many dogs and you hardly notice the timid nature.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In January and February it is the dry season and there is a high risk of sand storms (harmatan). March and April are also dry but warm with an arid landscape.

It is rainy season in May, June and July when it is very hot with high humidity. Nature then flourishes. The best time to cycle is from October to February. Nature is very beautiful, especially in October and November.

Spare parts
Tire size 26 inch is standard. The people are very helpful, also with regard to a lift, but the possibilities for repair are limited. So take enough spare material with you.

In an emergency, you might think of going to western (bicycle) rental companies on the coast (Serekuna), you might be able to pick out western parts here. Otherwise, in case of extreme emergency in Dakar (Senegal), you can go to Bomtey Sport, Rue Petavin (in the center of Dakar). This may be the only bicycle dealer with Western parts in all of West Africa.

People.body:
The people are friendly and peaceful, but know that a white person is "rich", so people want to become your friend. They are very hospitable, like to make contact and tell a lot about their culture. Shaking hands is a must. Cyclists are an attraction and command respect.

Ninety percent of the population is Muslim and the vast majority of the rest is Christian. Appropriate clothing is not necessary, but women should not be defiantly dressed.

-MGJPuC0VrY5cnXnVa_y.description: This is the easiest route from North to South Gambia, only a few kilometers long and as close to the coast as possible.
-MGJPuC0VrY5cnXnVa_y.title: North to South

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.The Gambia is a relatively safe but poor country. Like everywhere else you have to look after your belongings in the cities.
Safety.body_corruption: The Gambia has large billboards to prevent corruption, in which they tell you to call a number if you experience something like corruption.
Safety.body_criminality: Bas (2019): "I haven't experienced any criminality. To cross the river, I even had to leave my bike in the crowd with a single lady from the police, and while I was gone for 5 minutes to get the ticket for the ferry, the bike and all attachments were still there."
Safety.body_nature: Wild camping can be dangerous because of presence of hyenas.
Safety.body_traffic: The traffic is typical African style, wild and unorganized. However, cars seem to take cyclers into account quite well.

-MGJOmxUkmjVZB96g8yO.description: Serekunda is quite a popular destination for tourists, so you will find many Western style bars and restaurants. There are plenty of things to do around Serekunda, such as visiting the Atlantic Coast Resorts, Bijilo Forest Park, Abuko Nature Reserve or the Makasutu Culture Forest.
-MGJOmxUkmjVZB96g8yO.description_first: Serekunda is quite a popular destination for tourists, so you will find many Western style bars and restaurants. There are plenty of things to do around Serekunda, such as visiting the Atlantic Coast Resorts, Bijilo Forest Park, Abuko Nature Reserve or the Makasutu Culture Forest.
-MGJOmxUkmjVZB96g8yO.title: Serekunda

-MGJOxlq5bJe5xTmCdc-.description: The African Stonehenge, only smaller stones, but much more locations. It’s the largest concentration of stone circles in the world. In Senegal, the main sites are in Sine Ngayène (location) and Wanar (location).
-MGJOxlq5bJe5xTmCdc-.description_first: The African Stonehenge, only smaller stones, but much more locations. It’s the largest concentration of stone circles in the world. In Senegal, the main sites are in Sine Ngayène (https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=19/13.69546/-15.53557) and Wanar (https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=18/13.7685837/-15.5181782).
-MGJOxlq5bJe5xTmCdc-.title: Senegambia stone circles

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You can often stay with natives, volunteers or development workers. The villages are close to each other. To stay overnight you go to the oldest of a compound (village) and ask for a place to stay overnight. You will then be given a place to sleep, food, washing facilities. Costs nothing, but of course you will not leave without giving 100 to 150 Dalasi. Bicycle is next to your bed.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are hotels in many large towns. The quality varies greatly. Luxury in the tourist areas on the coast to very simple inland, sometimes noisy. Think about 10.000 CFA for the cheapest price.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible but you do get a lot of attention. Wild camping can be dangerous because of presence of hyenas.

Transport.body_boat:
From Barra there is a ferry across the wide mouth of the Gambia River to Banjul. A slow and packed boat will bring you to the other side. There is another ferry service across the Gambia between Soma and Farafenni, important for the (freight) traffic between North and South Senegal.

All the way in the southeast under Kartung you have to take a boat over the river that serves as the border with Senegal. No more than a small paddle boat or authentic hollowed-out tree trunk. The border on the Gambian side will be closed at 7 pm in the evening. There is no border office on the Senegal side. Furthermore, in places with, for example, a lodge camp on the water, such as at Tendaba, you can have a fisherman put you across the river.

Visa.body:
Citizens of the following countries (dark green) can visit The Gambia wihtout a visa for 28 days. You'll receive an entry stamp at the border. 


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Georgia is a raw and beautiful country, with a lot of different landscapes, a lot of historical buildings like holy monasteries. Georgia even makes good wines and has a small ski area.

37d2733b-54f6-4225-8ebf-e64e658756ee.description: Currently the e-visa portal is closed due to the pandemic. They will open the portal if traveling is allowed again. Please update this description if you see it's open again.

FoodDrink.body:
Eating and drinking in Georgia is really fantastic. The basis is bread (khachapuri) often filled with cheese, meat or mushrooms. People also eat chinkhali, dough filled with seasoned minced meat and cooked in broth. There are many vegetables available in restaurants. The local drink is "cha-cha", which is even stronger than vodka. 

Supra is an ancient eating and drinking ritual in the Caucasus. A Tamada is assigned to it. He will give a sermon for 10 minutes and until then you are not allowed to drink. After this follows the Gaumarjos (cheers) and then you have to drink your glass of wine in one go. When the ritual ends, usually after 4 liters of wine, a toast is made to the deceased.

Supermarkets
In the mountains, the shops are less well sorted, but there is enough.

Restaurants
Eating out is cheap. In the big cities there are also Turkish restaurants.

Drinkable water
Gudy and John: "We filtered water in the cities, but in the mountains there are springs, complete with bubbles."

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Spring and fall are best. The passes can still be closed in the spring.

Spare parts
There is no cycling in Georgia, so there are no bicycle shops anywhere. Bring enough spare material with you.

Safety.body: You might find stories about Georgia being unsafe, but this seems something from the past. Nowadays, Georgia is a wonderful country to cycle through, with very friendly people.
Safety.body_nature: In the region on the border of Azerbijan the Azerbaijanis (semi-nomads) live. These people are in possession of very large false dogs that run free. These dogs are used to scare away the wolves. You also regularly see fake dogs on a chain.
Safety.body_traffic: The highways are very reasonable, to super tight. For example between Gori and Tblisi. Thanks to the French. The other roads are bad to exceptionally bad. (Worse than in Albania or Morocco, comparably bad as in Ukraine.) The latter type requires a lot of technical skill from the cyclist. An average speed of 15 km / h - on flat terrain - is then already high. The effort is rewarded with exuberant nature.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: If you ask people if you can camp, they warn about "banditi" and often you are invited to their home. Just respond to that! Be prepared for a lot of food and alcohol.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
The big cities do have some nice hostels where a lot of backpackers stay as well.

There are also plenty of reasonable hotels in villages and towns. Sometimes there is only an intourist hotel from the Soviet era. Here it is often a large rubbish bin with only a few renovated rooms, which is still nothing. These hotels are also often too expensive.

Transport.body_bus:
In Georgia, they have marschutka's, which is like a combination of a bus and a taxi. There are no time tables, and you can get in and out when you want. They do drive specific routes, so you just have to ask for the right line. 

It's no problem to take your bike on a . Inexperienced drivers take the bike for free, others can charge a surcharge (+ 100%). But even then, it remains an inexpensive way to make miles quickly. A very dangerous alternative - they, and otherwise the other road users, drive like crazy.
Transport.body_train: No problem. Can join for free.

Visa.body:
94 countries can enter Georgia visa free. Your passport must be valid for 6 months. 

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Germany is a good cycling country, something for everyone. Asphalt or unpaved (gravel, sand, mud); flat, hilly or mountains. Nice people, good facilities, friendly traffic. Also suitable for cycling with children.

FoodDrink.body:
Food and drink is easily available everywhere. In the south you can eat well and cheaply in the "Biergartens". Prices comparable to nearby countries or slightly cheaper. The south is cheaper than the north and east.

Most bakers have "Stehcafé". You can get a cup of coffee with the banquet. You can buy sandwiches for a very low price at most butchers in the south. A euro or less for a sandwich with a thick slice of warm meat is no exception.

Other.body:
Routes
There is a map with bicycle routes in Germany made by an official organization.

Spare parts
In the country of Ortlieb and Schwalbe, you can expect to find anything you need. However, they are not available in every location. For example, a 20 inch inner tube is difficult to obtain (for recumbent bicycle).

People.body: The population is friendly and helpful, always willing to help you, even when looking for a nice route (but be careful, because they also easily send you to a cycle path along a busy road). A cyclist often has an advantage. The Germans also cycle a lot themselves.

QuickFacts.language:
-Official Language: German
-Most people speak English (School subject for everyone)
-Some people learn Spanish or French in school aswell

Safety.body: Germany is a safe cycling country.
Safety.body_corruption: Germany might be the last country where you'll find corruption.
Safety.body_criminality: Be cautios in big cities.
Safety.body_nature: Nothing to worry about.
Safety.body_traffic: Germany is a safe cycling country. Traffic rules are adhered to. Motorists are sympathetic towards cyclists, especially where there are no cycle paths. Officially they must keep a distance of 1 meter. Stay sharp. Connecting roads are sometimes busy, but it is generally easy to avoid busy roads. There are hardly any cars on "Nebenstrassen", sandy paths and bicycle routes. You will meet many other (older) cyclists on "easy" cycling routes.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: For an overnight stay at the farm, see http://www.heuhotelferien.de. You can also join the network of cycling friends in Germany: http://www.dachgeber.de. The deal is that in principle you also open your own house and / or garden to other cyclists free of charge.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are campsites almost everywhere. In the former GDR and Northern Germany, however, they are dungeonized. Most campsites are very large and noisy, with many caravans etc. usually there is a small field for hikers. Reasonable to do in the spring and autumn, outside the holiday periods and weekends. Most are closed between 12:00 PM and 3:00 PM (sometimes 5:00 PM). There is often a camp shop and a café or restaurant. Costs camping: approx. € 5 to € 10.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are youth hostels in various places. During the week they can be quite packed with school groups. The accommodation is good: sometimes there are even single rooms, the rooms have a private bathroom, and the breakfast is usually classy. The prices are cheap compared to other accommodations (hotel / guesthouse). On average you pay between 15 and 20 euros for an overnight stay. On the downside, breakfast is served quite late, so if you want to get out early again, not an ideal option. Another disadvantage may be that if you stay in a youth hostel for the first time, you have to pay a supplement to become a member of the youth hostel organization. It is advisable to make a reservation. See also http://www.jugendherberge.de.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Illegal to camp with a tent in unprivate places, but sleeping outside under a tarp or in a sleeping bag is a legal grey area

Transport.body_train:
The bicycle can be taken on most intercity trains, but not on the fast ICE. Reservation is strongly recommended. A bicycle ticket costs 9 Euro. The bicycle can usually easily travel with regional trains. A clear pictogram on the train indicates where the bicycle can be loaded.

The price for bicycle transport in the regional train differs per region. In various regions, such as in Southeast Bavaria, the transport of bicycles is still free, in others you have lost about 4.50 euros. During holidays and public holidays, you should take into account that many people take a bicycle on the train.

During the weekend you can travel unlimited by train with a cheap "Schönes Wochende" ticket (maximum five people per ticket). The restriction is that only regional trains may be (RB, RE, S) and the ticket is valid for one day, so on Saturday or Sunday.

Visa.body:
Quite a lot of nationalities need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information on www.schengenvisainfo.com. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Ghana offers a great range of activities for cyclers, whether you cycle in the Islamic North or the Christian South, people live in harmony and like to give you a glimpse of their life.

-MGMnIG9L6VjD8vdwQDZ.description:
It takes 4 days to get your visa here. There are a few documents required:
  • Copy of passport
  • Copy of previous visas in passport
  • 2x passport photos
  • 2 filled out copies of form given at the office
  • Explanation letter about your travel in Ghana
Be patient with the unhelpful lady. If you apply for a multi month visa, you don’t always get it as soon as you pass the border. They also ask for a Ivory Coast resident card, which you probably don’t have. Instead, you have to write an explanation letter.
-MGMnIG9L6VjD8vdwQDZ.description_first:
It takes 4 days to get your visa here. There are a few documents required, check the iOverlander app. Be patient with the unhelpful lady. If you apply for a multi month visa, you don’t always get it as soon as you pass the border. They also ask for a Ivory Coast resident card, which you don’t have. Instead, write an explanation letter.

1 month, CFA 40.000
3 months, CFA 60.000
6 months, CFA 90.000
12 months, CFA 150.000

-MGMnWWZRc5vLGpd4bIO.description: No experience yet, please fill in this information when you obtained this visa to help other cyclists.

FoodDrink.body:
Eating on the road at the stalls does not usually cause any problems, although the quality is often poor. For a small amount you can buy rice with sauce and an egg or meat, sometimes some lettuce or vegetables. Very nutritious dishes such as fufu and kenke are also made from cassava. This is served with a spicy sauce and is filling.

Restaurants
Typical dishes are fufu (mashed yam), banku (corn dough), koko (millet porridge), kenkey (fermented corn flour), fried yam, corn on the cob, fruit, coconuts, donuts, pieces of meat or chicken and frozen yogurt.

Drinkable water
  • Tap water is not reliable. There are many pumps with good water along the way. Avoid pits as much as possible because of the risk of contamination.
  • Bottled water is available but expensive.
  • Drinking water is sold in (printed and sealed) plastic bags.
  • Water available in unprinted, buttoned bags often contains tap or pump water and sometimes even well water! So be careful.
  • You can buy soft drinks at small stalls along the way.
  • It is useful to bring a water filter.
  • You have to take water with you on long distances (especially in the north).

Health.body:
Common diseases
Due to the heat it is wise to drink a lot and start cycling early.

Mandatory vaccinations
  • Yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.
  • A DTP and Hepatitis A vaccination is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs all year round, keep this in mind. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis and the like are available on site.
  • Healthcare is at a low level.

Other.body:
Spare parts
Cycling is done in Ghana and there are small workshops on the way, but don't count on them having modern Shimano parts. 26 inch tires are available. It is certainly advisable to bring enough spare material and tools with you. The people are very helpful and curious along the way.

People.body: Like most African countries, Ghanian people are friendly and offer a great hospitality.

-MGMrnmjvEHEOqLsOWyM.description: This route goes from Cote d'Ivoire border to Togo border, but doesn't follow the coast line as it is more in the middle of the country. It passes Mole National Park and the Volta Region.
-MGMrnmjvEHEOqLsOWyM.title: West to East

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.
Safety.body_corruption: You should be able to cross Ghana without experiencing corruption.
Safety.body_criminality: Be cautios in big cities.
Safety.body_nature:
There are some wild animals around in Ghana, but you don't see close to places where people are.

Bas (2019): "Locals brought me to a pond where they challenged a crocodile, which I was glad I didn't see all by myself. In a national park I saw elephants and some other animals. On the road, however, I didn't spot any dangerous animal, except for a dead snake."
Safety.body_traffic:
The roads are of fair to good quality. The unpaved ones are also often easy to ride. The road from Ho to Hohoe is steep and follows a very bad road. Cycling is almost impossible in some parts. The route to Mole national park is also not good. However, these are the biggest exceptions.
Are you looking for the small roads, then count on a lot of sand roads, sometimes mullet or washboard.

-MGMr7ZHmu5tFatMDxd0.description: Next to the stately mountains, a village with traditional tata houses – small mud castels – is still doing business the old way.
-MGMr7ZHmu5tFatMDxd0.description_first: Next to the stately mountains, a village with traditional tata houses – small mud castels – is still doing business the old way.
-MGMr7ZHmu5tFatMDxd0.title: Mole National Park

-MGMrGRYx-oMbV0L0rnG.description: Find refreshment under the rumbling Wli waterfall and explore the mountainous region around the Volta reservoir. It’s a beautiful area with plenty of awesome bike routes.
-MGMrGRYx-oMbV0L0rnG.description_first: Find refreshment under the rumbling Wli waterfall and explore the mountainous region around the Volta reservoir. It’s a beautiful area with plenty of awesome bike routes.
-MGMrGRYx-oMbV0L0rnG.title: Volta Region

-MGMrPsbbcKmbB8P4kTi.description: Explore the vibrant and historical coastline by visiting Accra, Cape Coast and Busua.
-MGMrPsbbcKmbB8P4kTi.description_first: Explore the vibrant and historical coastline by visiting Accra, Cape Coast and Busua.
-MGMrPsbbcKmbB8P4kTi.title: Coastline

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Campings are not widely around, you find them mostly at the entrance of a National Park which you can visit to watch animals.

Formal camping is the way to go through Ghana by bicycle. It's a great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you where you can put up your tent, often in a school, or with the chief.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Most cities have accommodation. Room with fan should be around 20 Cedi, with AC a bit more. Expect bucket showers.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

Visa.body:
Most African nationalities can obtain a visa on arrival, and a few African countries don't need a visa. All other nationalities mut get a visa. 
  Ghana
  Visa exempt
  Visa on arrival
  Visa required
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Food and drink is available everywhere, except in the somewhat sparsely populated areas. There is usually no shop in the smaller villages. In the slightly greener, you always have a shop to do some shopping.

Bread in Greece has the disadvantage that it is not very nutritious and that you cannot keep it for more than a day. If the baker has it, try to go for multigrain (8 or even 9 grains): slightly more expensive but tastier. In small villages it is often difficult to get bread, because baking is only done for the population. The baker only visits there once a week. So pay attention to the bakery car.

Health.body:
No additional vaccinations required.

You have to watch out for stray dogs. Dogs on a leash don't really exist here. The legs that spin happily on the pedals are unresistible for most dogs,… Even shouting firmly can scare them away. If this fails, a “Dazer” is highly recommended, works very well (except for the 1% deaf dogs, ..) Keep in mind that it can get very hot in the summer.

People.body: The Greeks are not really shy, but they will not really speak to you spontaneously. Although the younger generation generally speaks a word of English (sometimes German), you have to make do with sign language from time to time if your Greek is a bit rusty.

Safety.body_criminality: Crime does not occur in the smaller villages, in larger cities it naturally exists as everywhere.

Transport.body_boat: The boat is highly recommended for transport in Greece itself. It is a great feeling to combine a number of islands with the help of the boat connections. These are numerous and inexpensive. Watch out for departure times: it is perfectly possible that occasionally a connection is lost with respect to the folder, always check the correct departure times.
Transport.body_bus: The bicycle can usually also be taken on the bus. These run faster and more frequently than the train. It depends on the bus driver whether the bicycle is allowed. Doesj: "Our experience is that we had to pay a baggage surcharge on the buses where they easily took it. When we had to negotiate a lot and make theater, we didn't have to pay anything."
Transport.body_train:
You can take your bicycle with you on regional trains. In many cases, the bicycle has to be stored in a separate luggage compartment. Martin: My experience is that you are not allowed to take the bicycle with you on the train between Thessaloniki and Athens.

In the Athens metro, it is allowed to bring a bicycle (free of charge) (situation 2012) in the rear wagon and outside the morning rush hour. This is an easy way to cycle from the airport to the city center without having to cycle on busy (motor) roads.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

Some nationalities can enter Grenada without a visa.


Source: Wikipedia.

Health.body:
Common diseases 
stomach / intestinal complaints, parasites, advice buy water or filter it, vegetables and fruit with peel should be treated with disinfectant drops, (we bought a bottle in mexico, we don't know if it is for sale here).

Mandatory vaccinations 
Yellow fever is mandatory if you come from a yellow fever area. We also recommend DTP and hepatisis A and antimalarials. Typhoid fever is also recommended for a stay longer than 3 months. Check with your vaccination agency.

Useful vaccinations for cyclists 
High risk of rabies or rabies.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The climate of Guatemala has a wet season (May-November) and a dry season (December-April). Although Guatemala is located in the tropical climate zone and has predominantly warm and sunny weather, the local weather conditions can deviate considerably, mainly due to the large differences in altitude. In Quetzaltenango (2200 meters altitude) night frost is not uncommon in the months of October - December, while a few dozen kilometers to the south the temperature rarely falls below 15 degrees Celsius. Because Guatemala is quite far west of the Caribbean, hurricanes hardly occur.

People.body: The hospitality of the people varies per region, but if you ask them to camp at their places they are likely to accept. It could be helpful if you speak at least a little Spanish.

Safety.body: Be careful in El Salvador, then you should be fine.
Safety.body_criminality:
As always, use common sense. 

Karin: "We have never felt unsafe for a moment. We have not been to the capital. In larger cities we take a hotel / hostel, in the countryside we look for the safety of a family or village at night to pitch the tent there. Wild camping may be possible, but it is advised to be in before dark."

Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping may be possible, but it is advised to be in before dark.

Visa.body:
Quite a numerous amount of nationalities can enter Guatamala without a visa.

  Guatemala
  Visa-free access to Guatemala
  May not enter on Canada/Schengen/US visa
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Guinea, also known as Guinea-Conakry, to avoid any confusion with one of the other three Guinea name carriers. I have to be honest with you, I crossed the coastline of the country in a high tempo due to circumstances, so I don’t know all ins and outs, but let this give you a small direction.

-MGJ_k-dqu2I2TGL8ClV.description: Getting this visa is quite easy and possible to get it in one day. You only need passport photos.
-MGJ_k-dqu2I2TGL8ClV.description_first:
- 1 month, single entry, CFA 30.000
- 2 months, multiple entry, CFA 60.000

-MGJ_wCB4Po_uJglneGF.description: We have no experience with getting this visa yet. Please update the information if you have obtained the visa at this embassy.

e06d3fe2-8f27-4ab7-88e3-ac716e383d09.description: Note from Cycle Planet: We have no experience in getting this visa. Please update this information if you have recent experience.

FoodDrink.body:
In Guinea people eat rice with a sauce almost 3 times a day. This is the cheapest food. A piece of meat already makes it twice as expensive, but of course still cheap. There are 2 types of coffee. Nescafé, the instant coffee and Caffee Noir. This coffee is consumed from very small bowls and is very strong.

You'll find plenty of bars where you can get egg with bread for about 7.000 GNF. A local dish is "fou fou" and a local drink is made from ginger.

Health.body:
• Yellow fever, DTP and hepatitis A vaccinations are recommended and sometimes mandatory.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed (stamp).
  • Malaria occurs throughout the country all year round.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Guinea is one of the wettest countries in West Africa, especially the coastal region. The best cycling time is from the middle of November to the beginning of May. From December onwards, the harmatan rises, which can cause a lot of dust.

Spare parts
The local bicycle repairers often destroy more of a western bicycle than it does whole. Tires can be properly fixed, but this takes quite some time.

-MGJb555modqFc814tWe.description: This route goes from Guinea-Bissau to Sierra Leone, following the road as close as possible to the coast. The route doesn't go through Conackry, but passes it very near.
-MGJb555modqFc814tWe.title: From Guinea-Bissau border to Sierra Leone border

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.

-MGJbu5qZRLldiTo63pA.description: There are plenty of things to do in the capital, from listening to live music, to watch acrobatics or relaxing on the beach.
-MGJbu5qZRLldiTo63pA.description_first: There are plenty of things to do in the capital, from listening to live music, to watch acrobatics or relaxing on the beach.
-MGJbu5qZRLldiTo63pA.title: Conakry

-MGJc0eJBj6R3qHJUGAh.description: Reach the amazing landscape of Fouta Djalon via Mamou. It’s a great place for hiking, while the highlight is a beautiful waterfall.
-MGJc0eJBj6R3qHJUGAh.description_first: Reach the amazing landscape of Fouta Djalon via Mamou. It’s a great place for hiking, while the highlight is a beautiful waterfall.
-MGJc0eJBj6R3qHJUGAh.title: Fouta Djalon

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites, but there is plenty of space for the tent. In some areas, however, it is difficult to find a camping place due to the burning of forests, which is happening there on a large scale. You can of course put your tent on a burnt piece, but then all the camping equipment will be covered by the black ash. Camping in villages is almost always possible if you ask the "chef du village".
Sleeping.body_hostels: Guinea is a country that is not geared towards tourism, the hotels that exist lack any luxury. The exception is Conakry, where staying overnight in one of the luxury hotels costs a fortune. But overall, some villages have accomodation. Think about 200.000 to 300.000 GNF for the cheapest price, so probably it’s more.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

Visa.body:
A visa is required for most countries, see image below.

  Guinea
  Visa exempt
  Visa on arrival (Disputed; see below)
  eVisa / Visa required
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Guinea-Bissau, not to be misunderstood with its neighbor Guinea(-Conakry). Some people call it the cashew republic, not strange seen the fact that in the right time of the trees are full with the colorful cashew fruits and streets are filled with bags of cashew. In Guinea-Bissau you see a lot of green surrounding.

-MGJZ-YGVf5U7nQQEGES.title: Learning the language of the rain season

-MGJVmCci57AF8ITwJMe.description: One of the easiest places to obtain a visa. In about 5 minutes you walk out of the embassy with a fresh visa in your hand. You only need a passport and cash to get this visa.

FoodDrink.body:
Onroad: Egg with bread (±700 CFA) 
Local food: Rice,Fufu, soup
Local drink: Palm wine

-MGJXyA7MfoCE4uI9KPl.description: This route goes from Senegal to Guinea, following the road as close as possible to the coast, and visiting the capital Bissau in order to apply for the next visa.
