-MGJXyA7MfoCE4uI9KPl.title: From Senegal border to Guinea border

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.

-MGJXBxLczxo65872fse.description: It’s not the most exciting city to visit, but at least you’ll be able to charge your wallet, your own body and your supplies. And if you do want to chill, you best go to Ilha de Rubane, Ilha de Bubaque, Quinhamel or Bolama, all to be reached from Bissau.
-MGJXBxLczxo65872fse.description_first: It’s not the most exciting city to visit, but at least you’ll be able to charge your wallet, your own body and your supplies. And if you do want to chill, you best go to Ilha de Rubane, Ilha de Bubaque, Quinhamel or Bolama, all to be reached from Bissau.
-MGJXBxLczxo65872fse.title: Bissau

-MGJXNMd9K6NJWpjjtSH.description: Rent a kayak or a mountain bike (or use your own :)) and explore the many islands. It’s also a great place to rest.
-MGJXNMd9K6NJWpjjtSH.description_first: Rent a kayak or a mountain bike (or use your own :)) and explore the many islands. It’s also a great place to rest.
-MGJXNMd9K6NJWpjjtSH.title: Ilha de Bubaque

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Some places have accomodation, but it’s expensive. Think about 10.000 CFA for the cheapest price.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first. In a range of 30 km from the border to Senegal, there might be some land mines, so try to go pat this range.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa for entering Guinea-Bissau. Getting the visa in Senegal, Ziguinchor is very easy!

  Guinea-Bissau
  Visa exempt
  Visa on arrival / eVisa
Source: Wikipedia.

Some nationalities can enter Guyana without a visa for up to 90 days.

Visa policy of Guyana
  Guyana
  Visa-free access
  Visa on arrival
  No visa-free transit
Source: Wikipedia.

People.body: All day long (except in the cities where you are left alone) people shout Blanc or Mon Blanc to you. This usually sounds like an order to listen to the people and comes across as much less friendly than in the Dominican Republic. Most people don't like taking pictures or they want money for it. Often people ask for money.

Visa.body:
Almost all nationalities can enter Haiti without a visa for up to 90 days.

Visa policy of Haiti
  Haiti
  Visa free
  Visa required

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Beautiful country in the heart of Central America. Honduras is full of mountains, you will just find a couple of valleys but the country is mostly hilly. Open roads in Honduras are mostly safe all along the country. Cycle touring is not commonly done by Hondurans but they are mostly warm people, highest crime rate is mostly on the two biggest cities Tegucigalpa and San Pedro Sula and only on specific areas of this two cities. This two big cities are not cycling friendly because of road infrastructure but the rest of the country is just fine for traveling. Not recommended traveling by night, by day pretty much anywhere is ok.

Corona.body: You need a prior negative covid test before entering Honduras. The current situation about corona is not stable because of neglected health system even though face masks are obligatory on indoors all over the country.

FoodDrink.body: You can find nice food all around the country. Close the the north and south coast the food changes, mostly seafood, you can find great seafood specially in the south coast. In the rest of the country you can find any type of restaurants with great food. If you ask you will find the cheapest places to eat. The most common food in Honduras is called Baleada, you can find them anywhere, its a wheat tortilla with beans and cream and cheese. For the rest of the country you will find anytype of common food, Honduras has no exotic or weird flavors in its gastronomy so dont worry, you can try everything all around the country. You can find the national beers anywhere, the most known are Salvavida and Imperial, also plenty of imported beers, specially in big and medium sized cities.

People.body: Mostly warm people specially on the countryside and small towns. In big cities people are more distrustful but this is because of high crime rate in certain areas.

QuickFacts.climate: Warm most months of the year, tropical climate, not extreme high temperatures but it can get warm and very humid specially on summer in the south and the north coast. The rest of the country is made up of mountains so the climate gets less hot on this places.

Safety.body_corruption: You may find sometimes corrupt border agents but there should not be any major issue with them, policemen will mostly help you as a foreign traveler if you need any help. Honduras is known for high corruption by government officials but there should not be any issue with travelers, its corruption is mostly related with bad managing of state funds.
Safety.body_criminality: High criminality in certain specific places in Tegucigalpa and San Pedro Sula, the rest of the country specially in small towns and open roads is just fine. You should always ask to the locals in the place town or neighborhood where you are. This will give you a reference to which places you should not go.
Safety.body_nature: Beautiful national Parks like La Tigra, Parque Nacional Cerro Azul Meambar, Pico Bonito, Celaque, Yojoa Lake, Parque Nacional Jeannete Kawas. Wildlife is not commonly seen in Honduras except for National Parks which are protected areas.
Safety.body_traffic: Big cities like San Pedro Sula and Tegucigalpa are not recommended for cycling, you should only pass through this places, there is not much to do for tourists in this two places. The rest of the country is ok, not much bike infrastructure but in small towns and cities traffic is fine

02f4bf4d-b222-49ac-97ea-9511508f82b1.description: Here you can find the ferry to go to Roatan or Utila, the caribbean islands of Honduras
02f4bf4d-b222-49ac-97ea-9511508f82b1.title: Ferry Dock

0e1c1071-74d0-4660-95d6-7572d27590b2.description: Roatan is the biggest island in Honduras. Its a caribbean paradise in which you can find plenty to do. Its a tourist friendly place. You can find cheap and expensive food and accomodation. Its more expensive than Utila but you have much more to do around the island.
0e1c1071-74d0-4660-95d6-7572d27590b2.title: Roatan island, great nightlife, diving and food

12d18d54-da44-41ad-99b9-4980b9a77490.description: Nice place to chill and also try rafting on the beautiful cangrejal river. In the hotels around here you can find touring services to Pico Bonito National Park.
12d18d54-da44-41ad-99b9-4980b9a77490.title: Cangrejal River, rafting and Pico Bonito National Park

1da721a0-0e22-4cff-be3f-a73840833298.description: Here you can find nice seafood and hotels, this is one of the most touristic cities in Honduras. You can book boat tours to visit Jeannete Kawas National Park and can also travel by bike to Lancetilla Botanical Garden. Also you can find diving services in Tela Marine.
1da721a0-0e22-4cff-be3f-a73840833298.title: Tela (Coastal City)

1e9ba93f-0279-4bb3-beed-ca675aa099cf.description: You can find beautiful scenery in this colonial like city, also museums and plenty of options for food
1e9ba93f-0279-4bb3-beed-ca675aa099cf.title: Comayagua, colonial capital of Honduras

30f6e169-4182-4fda-8e64-98de5237fdc9.description: You can find archaeological parks around the town of Copan Ruinas, this are one of the most beautiful Mayan Ruins in Central America. Also plenty of museums in town also about the mayan civilization.
30f6e169-4182-4fda-8e64-98de5237fdc9.title: Copan Mayan Ruins

4b191b2c-a80f-43a8-9383-3591d351491c.description: Good island for travelers, cheap living and great caribbean experience. You can cross by ferry from La Ceiba. Most backpacker friendly place in Honduras. This island is known to be one of the best places for diving in all of the caribbean. Multiple diving schools around here.
4b191b2c-a80f-43a8-9383-3591d351491c.title: Utila Island, diving and sea activities

653f6299-ee66-4a9a-825b-dacae65fc1eb.description: This is one of the most cultural cities in Nicaragua. Its known to be a backpacker friendly place. Here you can also find one of the ferrys to cross to the island of Ometepe
653f6299-ee66-4a9a-825b-dacae65fc1eb.title: Granada (City with ferry dock)

bd149905-4004-4fe9-9a81-96c8cb0c701c.description: Beautiful coastal city with great hotels, here you can find tour services to Pico Bonito National Park and also the dock where you find the ferry for the Bay Islands.
bd149905-4004-4fe9-9a81-96c8cb0c701c.title: La Ceiba (City)

e08d6c61-29b8-49ca-8cd1-d9586003bbab.description: Beautiful small island from volcanic origin. Nice place to chill, crossing by boat is super cheap.
e08d6c61-29b8-49ca-8cd1-d9586003bbab.title: Amapala Island

f8cd79dd-7d1c-4594-928f-a4a9c7d6664e.description: You can find nice hotels to stay around this area and kayak to the biggest natural lake in Honduras, Yojoa Lake. You should also try the fried fish, its one of the best in the country.
f8cd79dd-7d1c-4594-928f-a4a9c7d6664e.title: Yojoa Lake and Kayak trips

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Mostly only on national parks
Sleeping.body_hostels: You can find hostels mostly in backpacker friendly places like La Ceiba, Utila, Roatan. Hotels you can find in any major city and most small cities too.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Not recommended unless you are on a national park

Transport.body_airplane: You can find three major airports in the cities of Tegucigalpa, San Pedro Sula and La Ceiba. Also medium sized airport mostly for national flights in Roatan.
Transport.body_boat: You can find ferrys to travel to the three major caribbean islands Roatan, Utila and Guanaja. You will find this ferrys in the city of La Ceiba in the north coast. If you want to visit the pacific island Amapala you can find small cheap boats that take you to the island in short time.
Transport.body_bus: You can get to any place by bus, you can find buses pretty much anwhere in open roads, these buses are mostly safe. Public transportation inside big cities is not recomended because of robbery, if you need to move inside a big city better find a private taxi service, you should ask in any hotel. Public transportation in small towns is safe.
Transport.body_train: None

Visa.body:
Most american and european countries do not need a visa for Honduras. Honduras mostly asks for visas from Asian and African countries. You can find which countries need a visa here.

  Honduras
  Visa-free access to Honduras
  May not enter on Canada/Schengen/US visa
Source: Wikipedia.

Corona.body: The border is closed for all foreign travelers. Perhaps if you come by bicycle, there are routes that don't have checkpoints and you can still enter.

FoodDrink.body:
There are plenty of dining options. However, the food is rather varied, but good and very cheap.

Cooking fuel
Campinggaz available in Budapest: Outdoor shop at Vaci Ut, near metro station M3 Lehel Ter.

Supermarkets
Supermarkets are sufficiently available.
Even the smallest villages have their groceries.

Drinkable water
The tap water is reliable.

People.body: The population is hospitable, quite helpful and friendly.

Safety.body_traffic: It is very busy around Budapest. Roads are sometimes good, but sometimes bad with many deep big holes in asphalt.

-MGCJvJsXY1XGvGEJev9.description: Budapest is the Paris of the East and has plenty of interesting sights to discover. It's even a good combination to take your bicycle with you and you can go anywhere. Even though it's busy in the center, cycling is quite doable. Visit the St. Stephen Basilica, the City Park, the parliament and the Royal house. For sunset you want to go up to the citadel on top of the hill. At 9 pm every evening there is an amazing fountain show at Margaret Island.
-MGCJvJsXY1XGvGEJev9.description_first: Budapest is the Paris of the East and has plenty of interesting sights to discover. It's even a good combination to take your bicycle with you and you can go anywhere. Even though it's busy in the center, cycling is quite doable. Visit the St. Stephen Basilica, the City Park, the parliament and the Royal house. For sunset you want to go up to the citadel on top of the hill. At 9 pm every evening there is an amazing fountain show at Margaret Island.
-MGCJvJsXY1XGvGEJev9.title: Budapest

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Many campsites are only open from June. Campsites are sober, but cheap. Sometimes they are about 120 km apart
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hostels in Budapest can be incredibly cheap, with 4 euro as the bottom price (not sure what you get). In other cities, the prices are higher.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: It is not legal, but at some places it is tolerated. It's only a bit difficult around Lake Balaton.

Transport.body_train: The train is the preferred means of transport for taking the bicycle. You can travel cheaply by train. The bicycle can often be taken along, even if there is no baggage car, just at the end of the last wagon, or at the beginning of the first wagon. You have to pay extra for the bicycle. The advice is to stay with your bike or take all luggage with you to your compartment: there will be stolen.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body:
When God finished creating the earth, he had some leftovers. Especially stone, fire, ice and water. He threw it in a corner, not realizing he had created Iceland.

For those who love rough nature and can take a beating when it comes to the weather, Iceland is the right destination. There is a wide spectrum of possibilities from lighter camping to camping bike rides on the bypass to more extreme expedition-like rides in the highlands where you have to be self-sufficient for many days. Different degrees are also possible, something for everyone. This makes Iceland a wonderful adventure destination. Several people often come for the second or third time.

Iceland does not only have snow and ice, although you could say that an average day would have all four seasons included. 

Cyclability of the country
  • The ring road that runs around the island is easy to cycle. And you regularly come across places to stock up on new stock. Only in the east you will encounter pieces without asphalt, but they are well paved.
  • The interior is a different story, sometimes the road is nothing more than a sandy tire track. Some parts cannot be cycled, you sink into the lava dust, then you are happy that you encounter a washboard, the trick is to cycle on the edge of the washboard to have a grip. Rivers without a bridge are more the rule than the exception and should be taken with caution. Get off, first try without a bicycle, then the bicycle downstream next to you, otherwise it will push you under water. There are no villages in the highlands where you can buy new supplies. Depending on the length of the tour, this requires additional planning.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
Camping gas is often sold by gas stations and can also be found at the campground in Reykjavik. Fuel for the trangia is readily available at most major petrol stations. It is called rautspritt there. It burns well. The only annoying thing is that it also has a lot of soot and covers your things with a greasy black layer that is difficult to remove.

Supermarkets
Apart from the southwest, iceland is sparsely populated, which means that you have to bring enough provisions yourself. At gas stations there is usually also a shop where you can buy everything. Because you can sometimes be attacked by bad weather, it is always wise to always have enough stock with you.

Willem: you really have to prepare well for a trip through the interior. In 2013 we had more than ten days of provisions for our trip through the interior. On spec is not an option because that limits your range enormously.

In the supermarkets you can also buy dried packs of spaghetti, couscous, noodle soups and conditions where you only need to add water, handy if you have to bring food for a few days. The camping segment of the population is clearly not forgotten. Sometimes a barbecue is available at campsites.

Restaurants
Eating out in iceland used to be really expensive. With the economic downturn that also hit iceland, eating out is now just as expensive / cheap as in the netherlands. Menus look a bit different than in the netherlands, with specialties such as puffin (puffin), whale meat and lamb. Furthermore, of course a lot of fresh fish on the menu, which even people who normally do not like fish can enjoy!

Drinkable water
Bottled water is available in shops, but it is not very convenient to bring water on longer trips. You might as well get water "From nature". A water filter is recommended in many places in iceland sheep who defecate everywhere, so you do not know whether the water in a river is clean. You can find water everywhere in iceland, only on the stretch south of nyidalur on the f26 there is an area that is dry, so bring water with you.

Health.body:
Hypothermia is a risk, it can occur more quickly than you might expect. The greatest risk is between 0 and 12 degrees Celsius, because people are often not well prepared. Cold & wet & wind can be quite annoying. Therefore an extra point of attention if you cross the interior where you are more dependent on yourself. Appropriate rain gear + warm clothing that can be layered is necessary. Leave cotton at home and bring quick-drying materials. Don't forget your mittens / gloves.

Crossing rivers can also be dangerous. Water can be dangerously cold. Never go through "white water". In case of strong currents, never go deeper than knee through the water, otherwise ask for a lift with 4x4. For example, special sandals that do not fall off your foot due to the strong current. First aid kit!

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The ideal time for cycling would be in the midsummer nights in June because maybe winter is over and you have almost 24/7 daylight. But also winter time seems to be very cool, challenging and you would definitely spot Aurora Borealis which gives the already stunning landscapes an extraordinary dimension.

The interior is in many cases closed until the middle or even the end of June. You can find an overview on visiticeland. Even then the weather can be very erratic. Depressing gray weather with low-hanging clouds, rarely pleasantly warm. While cycling it is still okay, but it is quickly cold at the tent.

Rutger: "In recent years I cycled about 3500 kilometers in Iceland. I liked it very well. It was a matter of riding between the showers. So when you wake up in the morning and it rains, just read a good book and only leave in the afternoon or possibly in the evening. "

Luddo: "Of the four weeks I had about 3 weeks of rain. I have never suffered so much while I have already cycled quite a bit in the high mountains."

Climate
Furthermore, it is again something to take into account. It can sometimes storm very hard (9 or more Beaufort). So stay informed. In Iceland they measure wind speed in m / s and not in Beaufort. Above 18m / s it is time to make sure you get to safety, tear down the tent and make sure you are safe and dry. At those wind speeds I have seen many tents tear and sometimes they are found miles away.

In such wind, long plastic pegs are useful to have a grip in lava sand. Large stones on top for extra weight also help.

Wind
The real bummer is the wind. By the way, it accounts for a large part of the cold. We cycled against the clock and predominantly had headwind, but we don't know if this is a constant and he can really keep going. Especially in the afternoon. So driving early in the morning or in the evening (at night) can be a solution.

Spare parts
Except in the larger towns, such as Reykjavik, Hella, Egilsladir and Akureyri, you are completely on your own. There is no bicycle shop between Selfoss in the south and Akureyri in the north. This is about 1000km via the ring road. In Selfoss, the bicycle repairer did not sell 28-inch wheels. These were for sale in Reykjavik.

Clothing
  • Rain gear is indispensable.
  • Warm clothes in layers. We always rode with long bib shorts and at least one fleece jersey, but usually more.
  • Warm gloves and a hat were also a necessity.
  • We wore shorts and a T-shirt for a few hours once (at the campsite in Egilsstadir).
  • I wore shorts for three hours in three weeks. Don't skimp on warm clothing. In August it was often around freezing on the high plateau towards the end of the evening.
  • Try to live to the rhythm of the weather: If the sun is shining more or less in the afternoon, prepare a hot meal on a nice picnic area with table on your burner. In the evening it may rain or it may be so cold that you don't feel like it anymore.

People.body: The population is very hospitable, open and tolerant. Making contacts is very easy. They are also very bicycle-friendly. The image of the gruff tough Icelander was completely shattered. You will be left alone, but if you have a question, you will be helped very friendly.

Safety.body: Iceland is one of the safest countries in the world
Safety.body_nature: Along the south coast you can sometimes be attacked by terns that are breeding. Tip: bicycle helmet, hood handy to prevent them from getting stuck in your hair.
Safety.body_traffic:
It is quite busy around Reykjavik, the Ring is getting busier (especially the south). Other than that, about 5-20 cars per hour.

The ring road is almost completely paved, the roads through the interior are rough slopes (stones, washboard) where a good mountain bike / trekking bike with wide tires is in place.

Don't be fooled by the daily distances. If you have a tailwind on an asphalt road you can reach more than 100km in a day. But certainly inland, many roads, including the ones that pass through, are an ordeal. Here you often cycle less than 10 km per hour. Even worse are the deserted tracks with miles of loose sand; walking is sometimes the only option. On parts of the old F910, which is located south of the F910, it is best to take 8 hours over 30 km (many rivers, stony, water plains). In the direction of Askja there is a stretch of 40km deep sand. For food planning, count on 50Km / day for normal highland roads and for very bad 25km / day. That way you build in margin when the weather or the road is against it.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Campings are present in most towns and useful for a nice warm shower. Spending the night with private individuals or on farms is quite possible. They are very nice people.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
The youth hostels are small and cozy. However, they are more than 100 km apart. In the late season, from September, the prices of guesthouses drop considerably and sleeping bag accommodation will cost you about 20 euros per night (2010).

Hotels or staying at the farm… everything is possible, but it is also a big bite out of the budget. In Guesthouses you can sometimes also go with your sleeping bag. Saves money again. About 4000 crowns p.p. for an overnight stay.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Free camping is allowed in Iceland, except in places where it is explicitly prohibited (such as in national parks). Sometimes it is necessary because there is no camping site nearby. Wild camping is easy in many places. It is a great feeling when you put your tent on a jeep track in the middle of the wide surroundings. Large lava blocks, a thick layer of loose sand (bring dune herring!) Or stretched meadows can sometimes spoil the food. In the interior, take an (Ortlieb) water bag with you.

Iceland has numerous campsites ranging from very simple (a toilet and sink) to very reasonably equipped (dryers). They are clean and safe.

Transport.body_airplane: The national airline is WOW air, and offers cheap flights to Reykjavik, and the bicycle can be taken as well. The airport is located 50 km from the capital, from which you can cycle or take a bus.
Transport.body_boat:
Make it a logistical adventure by going by ferry, perhaps include Faroer Islands on your way, and arrive in the eastcoast town of Seydisfjordur. 

Smyril-line sails twice a week from Denmark (Hirtshals) to the Faroe Islands and then on one of these crossings to Iceland (Seydisfjordur): http://www.smyril-line.com. You can therefore make the crossing in one go (about 48 hours) or in two times with a stopover of three days on the Faroer.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body:
When you think of India, you often think of overpopulation. Nevertheless - at least on the smaller roads - cycling in this country is very good and quiet, there is little traffic and still something to see everywhere.

There is an abundance of nature, beautiful beaches alternate with mountains overgrown by jungle. Not only in big cities, but also in all small towns you will find temples and you can see the culture and religion in the daily life of the people. The people in non-touristic places are very friendly and hospitable. It is also very easy to find food and accommodation.

FoodDrink.body:
All federal states have their own specialties. Almost in all states and restaurants they sell nan bread, chapati, lentils, raitha, curry dishes, egg dishes and especially rice! Of course you will find many vegetarian restaurants, but meat and fish is also readily available.

Stalls 
  • You can find stalls on the street very often, typical dishes are:
  • Bread dishes: chapati, parotha, naan, roti, ... In the south you sometimes find fresh rolls or packaged rolls. I asked for [warapaw] or [paw] (pronounced like that). Nice for breakfast for those who have less easy Indian breakfast. Or you eat chapati with bananas.
  • Typical dishes for the south: puri, dosa, idli (typical breakfast), "meals": rice with lentils, curry and papad (similar to dahl). You can sometimes ask for an omelette at the stalls that make puri or other things.
  • You will find tea houses on many main roads. The "chai" is a specialty here, but coffee is also available (at least in the south). Some also have cold drinks and meals.
  • In the south you will often find stalls with coconuts, more south also other fruits such as pineapple, ...

Markets and supermarkets
There is a good supply of both in cities of some significance.

Restaurants
In the cities there is often a large choice of restaurants, both vegetarian and non-vegetarian. In the tourist cities there is even more choice and more Western food available.

Drinkable water
In the villages there are wells or taps where you can refuel if you disinfect or filter the water.

Health.body: Mosquitos are your worst enemy, as they also contain malaria. Using DEET might help, or use medicines if you don't want to end up in a hospital in India. Bringing a desinfection gel with you might also be useful, to regularly wash your hands.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
January & February are fine, (10 to 20 degrees C). March quickly becomes uncomfortably warm and April and otherwise the rainy season is not suitable for cycling trips.

Spare parts
In India there are many bicycles that are used for short distances. However, there are hardly any bicycles with gears. So you cannot count on spare parts. Indian mountain bikes are sold, but are certainly an exception outside the big cities. If you have a problem with your modern Shimano assembled bike and you need to get spare parts, you will have to go to Delhi or Bombay.

Tips
Let India come over you and experience it. It helps if you take your time and are patient with the people. Try to talk to people as much as possible; a booklet with photos from your own life is a great means of communication. I sometimes gave a photo away to people with whom I had a good contact or who helped me.

People.body:
The local people are nice, interested, curious, willing, helpful. You often receive invitations to use or spend the night in people's homes. Moreover, people are very interested in how the bicycle works! 
The people in the south are hospitable, which often manifests itself in the provision of coffee, etc. Especially in smaller cities and the countryside you have a great sense of security, just as if stealing is not in their dictionary. Larger cities also feel safe, using common sense remains the message of course. I have more often than not put the bike in the room at night, many hotels have a porter, the bike is very safe here.

The people are very curious and like to get in touch. In the south, a little more English is spoken and signposts are also in English. The official language Hindi, which is spoken in the north, is hardly spoken in the south; each state has a different language with different dialects. Some cyclists have trouble with people's curiosity, especially the tinkering with the bike and the gears.

Religion is very visible in life in India; everywhere along the way you will find pilgrims, on their way to a place of pilgrimage. These are often very pleasant conversation partners.

Martin: "The population is nice but very curious. Waiting for the barriers, three rows of Indians will soon be around you. They are sitting on the (recumbent) bicycle, wanting to know everything about it (gear system sir? the bell rings). Stay relaxed. In India, people are everywhere. "

Safety.body:
Marc: "Stone throwing boys are actually recognizable in advance by their attitude. During these six weeks, if I remember correctly, it happened four times. If I have the opportunity I try to talk to them about it (they rarely understand it and they usually take off immediately when you turn around), but I think this is a job for the adults of the region (they often do this too, if there is one nearby)."

Lukas: “Indians always seem to be after your money, they are unable to have a conversation, in English, which does not ultimately lead to a request to buy something. The people, especially in the countryside, are incredibly curious: people always cycle with you and as soon as you stop the whole village literally comes running and then starts staring at you alone. Hardly anything is said then. In India you are never alone, it is nowhere quiet and everyone always wants something from you, this will start to get you upset very quickly (but it seems that it will pass after a few months). The population (or India as a whole) is so different that in the beginning you are completely annoyed but want to go back afterwards. ”
Safety.body_nature: In high heat it is good to cover your head to prevent heat stroke. Drinking a lot is important. In the high mountains (especially above 3000m) you can get altitude sickness. Increasing gradually is the best way to avoid this.
Safety.body_traffic:
The major roads are generally busy, although it is possible to cycle in the hard lanes. Smaller roads are often better than bigger ones, always more beautiful and in any case much less crowded.

The road network in India is often in a changeable state due to floods and weather conditions. It is therefore often worked on the roads with primitive means.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
You can easily approach someone to arrange a place to sleep. You do have to take into account the fact that you have no privacy and the house is full of people who all want to know who you are. And you have little time to sleep and can only leave late in the morning since you first have to have a very extensive breakfast.

Yvette about spending the night in temples: "You can often go here as a foreigner. This is cheap and very interesting. You will receive meals together with the people who also stay in this temple. food goes with the hands and very quickly everything is worked in. They often find it very nice to see that you also eat with your hands. They laugh a lot and look at you. During your stay you are also allowed in the temple to attend a ceremony. They will explain how it all goes and take you on a tour of the temple. "
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Not much present. Sometimes it is possible to spend the night in a tree house in national parks. This requires administrative hassle, often this has to be reserved in another city.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In almost every city you'll find a ho(s)tel. In the smaller cities, the supply is less and you have to adjust your standards in terms of hygiene. A good tip: when entering a city, ask the locals for a "lodge" or "lodging"; often they immediately direct you to the best place to sleep. You do not have to be afraid of "touts" in the non-touristy cities. You often find a hotel in front of the bus station.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: In general, this is not really recommended due to lack of privacy. The local population is very curious. In North India and the Himalayas, wild camping and / or camping on a farm is no problem.

Transport.body_bus: It's no problem to take the bicycle on the bus. This is possible, usually for an additional fee. On the roof of the bus, if possible you can help yourself to fasten it and make sure that the bike is securely fastened.
Transport.body_train: It's possible to take the bicycle on the train; The disadvantages of this are the cumbersome procedure for ticket sales. You can no longer see the bicycle because it is loaded into the freight wagon. Sometimes there are additional problems with loading (e.g. the bicycle is refused despite a valid ticket).

FoodDrink.body:
Food is very cheap, only imported food is very expensive. Fruits are good and cheap. There are shops everywhere, often every few kilometers. However, be careful with ice cream, salads, and the like. During Ramadan it is difficult to find food. Many shops are closed, the supermarkets are open. Only after sunset are there stalls where food is cooked. The first week after Ramadan it is still difficult to find food, because many shopkeepers are visiting relatives, so the shops are closed.

Sumatra
You can eat delicious food here. A vegetarian has a more difficult time. There is always tempeh and tofu to be found. In tourist places there are eateries with Western breakfasts and other meals. Central Sumatra and especially Padang has quite spicy dishes. Bread is increasingly available here, but it is tasteless.

Java, Bali and Lombok
You can buy bottled water almost everywhere. Food is good. Many small stalls and restaurants where you can eat well. Well pepper! Everything very cheap: a few euros for a meal.

Sumbawa Islands and Floris
Cor: "We encountered a lot of good quality food on these islands. There are also plenty of shops and markets for shopping.

Sulawesi
The food is rather monotonous (fish, rice and occasionally chicken meat). The biggest problem is the sometimes long distances between food and beverage outlets. Good precautions are important. Price (1997) varies from 1 Euro to 7 Euro.

Supermarkets
There are supermarkets in the vicinity of the major cities.

Stalls on the street
Warungs are the cheaper stalls, you will also find small pushcarts of everything. Those who want to eat something different (Java) can try roti bakar: baked bread usually with sweets and / or melted cheese

Restaurants
Java has a large choice of restaurants.

Drinkable water
Buy water preferably in bottles. These are available in 1½ - 2 liter plastic bottles for 40 - 60 cents You can also boil water in hotels. Along the way you can regularly get tea and cola and also boiled water (not always tasty but reliable). Sometimes you can buy fresh buffalo milk, just make sure it has cooked long enough.

Health.body:
• Malaria occurs in Indonesia. Whether you take prevention is up to every single soul, there are different opinions about it. 
  • Watch out for wounds from insect bites: can quickly become inflamed. There are leeches in Aceh.
  • There are very few dogs in most areas. In places where there are dogs, they are very shy. The chance that you will be bitten is very small, but because rabies is deadly, it is best to get vaccinated.
  • Sun cream is available in the slightly larger places, even if it is not always of the same quality as here.
  • There are many hospitals. Every slightly larger town has a hospital, but the infrastructure is not on a Western level. You may be confronted with communication problems.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Java
In Java you can cycle all year round, July and August is a very good period. Just before the rainy season (November / December) is suitable for cycling, even better a little earlier (October / November).

Sumatra
October is less suitable for cycling because of the rainy season: there is a lot of rain at the end of the afternoon. September is suitable, most tourists are gone by then, while the rainy season only starts a month later. It can be very hot. That means starting early, also because it is early light and gets dark early. In June the weather is excellent: warm, mostly dry and a lot of sun.

Bali, Lombok, Sumbawa Islands and Flores
The rainy season starts in October, before September is the best time to travel. September is ideal: no rain and not too hot.

Sulawesi
The dry season is suitable, which starts approximately in March. It can still rain now and then, but that is more pleasant than unpleasant. Get up early again because later in the day, from about 12 o'clock, it will be hot (30-35 degrees). It is also dry in July and August.

Spare parts
Better bring your own tools and important parts yourself. There is no lack of helpfulness. There are plenty of bicycle shops on Java. There are now many ATBs driving around. Only bring specific tools yourself (e.g. for replacing a hyperglide pinion).

There are bicycle shops with Shimano parts in Medan (Sumatra). 28 ”tires, on the other hand, are difficult to obtain. All non-high-tech stuff can be repaired well. Moped gear cables are available. It is better to bring your own cables. Hitchhiking is easy and they are happy to help you.

In Jakarta there are several good bike shops where you can find all material for derailleur bikes, including high-tech parts. Go to Roxy Mas Blok C in the area of Roxy Mas shopping center. This shopping center is located in the spacious area of the Monas tower. There are several bicycle shops in this street.

People.body:
The people are very hospitable, especially if you master a few words of Indonesian. They often offer you food and coffee. They keep asking you to stop to chat with you, even though they can't speak English at all. They are not meant to be intrusive, they are just curious. That can be difficult if you need a break. It can also be very pleasant and special because you get to know the population and their customs. Much heard is “Hello Mister, where are you from?”. They do not know the difference between Mister and Miss.

Answering “no” is inappropriate in Indonesian culture. So never ask a question to which both yes and no can be answered.

Safety.body: As a traveler through Indonesia you have a very safe feeling. There is little begging. No one will address you directly and ask for money. Most Indonesians are very concerned about your safety and the safety of your belongings. When you have a problem and go to the police, they will always take very good care of you. Don't be surprised that if you ask a police officer if there is a hotel, there is a police car that will escort you to your hotel and will even carry your luggage up to your hotel room.
Safety.body_criminality:
It can sometimes be restless on Timor. It is no harm to inform in advance how the situation is there. Indonesians are very concerned about the security image of their country. They will therefore always do their very best to guarantee your safety and that of your belongings.

There are no significant safety problems or risks, unlike in other countries. There are many police and military posts on the roads. The police are very helpful. As long as you stay outside the tourist areas, there is no begging or asking for money and you will not be cheated.
Safety.body_nature: Indonesia is regularly struck by natural disasters such as tsunami's, volcano eruptions or earthquakes. Do your homework and find contact details of your embassy.
Safety.body_traffic:
The larger main roads can be very busy. Usually the roads consist of a lane in each direction. There is no hard shoulder or shoulder, making it handy to have a rear-view mirror so that you can leave the road in good time in case of overtaking traffic behind you.

Not all roads are good. On the lesser road sections there are often potholes where the asphalt is missing. If these pits are in the shade, you should pay close attention, because they are not clearly visible

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You can stay overnight with private individuals. You must then ask the mayor (kepala desa) of the village, who will then refer you. Expect to be peeped through your window half the night.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
Guesthouses can be obtained from the Travel Survival Kit. They are very pleasant and sometimes you meet other cyclists. Tip: stay at the back: street noise already starts at 6:00 am. Overnight stays are very cheap: between 3 and 6 euros, slightly more expensive in tourist places.

Sumatra
At Lake Toba and Bukittingi you can find many beautiful guesthouses at unbelievably low prices. A great location to recover a bit. There are not always hotels within cycling distance of each other. You will then have to improvise by asking for a place to stay with the locals, at a gas station, police station or road restaurant. Usually you don't have to ask more than twice.

Usually they will indicate a safe place where you can park your bicycle. In the non-tourist areas people will not 'tinker' with your bicycle, if it does happen you can take your bicycle with you in the hotel room without any problems.

Bali and Lombok
There are plenty of nice places to spend the night. Always at short distances. Cheap and comfortable are: home-stays and pondoks (= Indonesian for boarding house). A few times for a maximum of 10 euros we had a nice house (plus breakfast) on the coast, where you walk straight into the sea. Bicycle safety: ok.

Sumbawa Islands and Floris
Cor van Weel advises to find out in advance where there are places to stay on these islands. He didn't always find them easy to find. In an emergency you can always stay overnight with private individuals

Sulawesi
You can sleep in hotels from 10 to 20 euros. in wisma or homestay 2.5 to 10 euros. In small towns it is dirt cheap. There are plenty of homestays or losmen in tourist areas, otherwise hardly. In cities or larger villages you have wismas, often very primitive or noisy. Occasionally there were more than 100 km between two overnight stays.

Java
The prices of mid-range hotels vary between 150,000 and 400,000 Rp (12-35 euros), losmen can be found from 50,000 (4 euros). Bargaining is possible in some places.

Transport.body_boat:
From Bali to Lombok there is a regular ferry (about 4 hours sailing). Bicycles can be brought along for a fee. Transport is also no problem between Sumbawa islands and Flores.

Ludwig: "The ferry from Java to Bali (half an hour) costs less than a euro, they did not charge anything for the bicycle 

Juul about Sulawesi: "Along the coast are many port cities and towns. The wooden ships sail very slowly, are poorly maintained, little comfort, poor hygiene and overcrowded (broken life-saving equipment). Steel (German) ships are also sailing, these seem to be much better."
Transport.body_bus:
Bicycles are carried on top of the roof rack of the bus. On some routes special (expensive) tourist buses run that also take your bike with you. Long distance buses in Sumatra are usually 'executive AC' and do not have the necessary space to take bicycles. Inform well if you still want to take your bike with you to avoid disappointment.

Ludwig: "In Java I took the bus very often, often in addition to a morning trip to bridge a busier road. Buses go from one major city to another, sometimes two cities further. I found it easiest to stop the bus along the road, the bike would go in the back."
Transport.body_train: There are always options for taking a bicycle with you on the train. Bicycle ticket is sometimes more expensive than a transport ticket. Try to bargain. There is no freight wagon and no place to take bicycles on local 'economic' trains. Because Indonesians are very helpful and do not want to disappoint you, they will still try to get your bike on the train. This can be accompanied by the necessary scratches.

About.body:
Iran is unique in many ways. The bad image that most Westeners have about the country, is far from true. If you like to see an untouched culture that is carried out by so many lovely Iranians, it's a paradise. The food is great, there are quite some beautiful places to visit (Isfahan, Persepolis).

One thing to bear in mind, is that there is not a single ATM in the country, and you can't get money from the bank, so you have to bring a lot of cash with you. Depending on your needs, a $1000,- would be a sufficient amount to cycle through Iran in 3-4 weeks and get the visa for your next country.

49bbc0e0-f767-455f-a8db-13add9156989.description: Easy place to obtain visa for Iran.

FoodDrink.body:
Stores
If you cook yourself, it is usually not a problem to buy your things, but you have to go to 4 or 5 shops before you have everything together. It's insanely cheap. A good change is making your own meal, for example in the shower of a hotel.

Iran has very good bread, in many shapes and sizes. You can find it even in the small villages. Pastry shops are well worth a visit.

Restaurants
If you follow the main route, eating and drinking is no problem: there are plenty of (road) restaurants. Elsewhere and where the distances between the cities are great, especially in the east, you will need to have sufficient supplies with you.

Vegetarians can have a hard time, as a lot of meat (kebab) is usually eaten together with rice. In cafeterias or sandwich shops you can buy all kinds of sandwiches and healthy snacks.

Except for roast meat, all food is reliable and often very tasty. In the big cities, pizzas and burgers are popular and good. Also, don't miss the breakfast of honey, whipped cream and bread. For meat lovers, 'dizi' is a tasty dish, look out for the tin cups.

Drinkable water
Bring enough water with you on the long journeys. Tap water is reliable in most places, but it is advisable to check. In the big cities it is chlorinated. Hotels and restaurants often have separate drinking water in the kitchen.

Tea stalls also have boiled water, it costs nothing and is safe. Pepsi is sold as a soft drink. The local soft drink is 'Zam Zam', the Iranian version of cola or Fanta.

Willy (2007): "Water can be found regularly and is pumped up 'plop-plop' with diesel pumps. It is good to drink but tastes like petrol, especially in the north."

Alcohol and related
Non-alcoholic beer is quite popular. E.g. the Istak brand has a whole range of fruit flavors. The taste of this beer has nothing to do with the taste of our beer.

If you want alcohol, you have to rely on someone who can buy it for you on the black market. In any case, there is plenty of it in Iran. Since alcohol is prohibited, some people make their own wine from their grapes at home. Worth a try!

Drugs
Drugs are ubiquitous in Iran, thanks to neighboring Afghanistan and other active trafficking routes such as Marivan. Quite a few people, even good family men, are addicted to opium, crack, crystal meth and other drugs. The reason is often and paradoxically a flight from a poverty-stricken existence and the lack of other entertainment. Fortunately, there are also many people who consciously try to keep away from these kinds of life-destroying drugs.

Health.body:
Common Illnesses
Malaria occurs from March to November, but that cannot be compared to the scale on which it occurs in Africa. Bilharzia occurs in still to weak flowing water.

Mandatory vaccinations
Vaccinations are not mandatory.

Useful vaccinations for cyclists
It is recommended to take measures against DTP, Hepatitis A and typhoid fever.

Availability of hospitals / doctors
Iran has a reasonably good healthcare system. Vaccinations are not mandatory. It is recommended to take measures against DTP, Hepatitus A, typhoid fever. Malaria occurs from March to November. Bilharzia occurs in still to weak flowing water.

Hazards
  • Greater dangers may include dehydration or lack of food. Make sure you have enough of that with you. The places are far apart in certain parts of the country, count on long day trips.
  • Motorcyclists can also be downright dangerous, especially when there are 2 men on the bike.
  • A helmet is advisable given the driving style of the average Iranian (= driving and not looking).

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Iran has a desert and a mountain climate. In the south there is a steppe climate. Usually it is dry and only along the Caspian Sea it is suptropic. The Iranian climate has large temperature differences in the different seasons.

The winters are cold and only at the Persian Gulf the temperature is then not too bad. In the mountainous areas, winters are harsh and in places extensive snowfall makes the roads impassable for months. For example, if you come from Turkey, make sure you are in Iran before December. When winter sets in, the northwest completely snows. Summers are very hot, temperatures above 40 degrees are no exception, actually impossible to cycle.

Best time is generally spring or autumn. September and October are still a bit on the warm side, especially if you cycle to Pakistan, the desert after Bam to Quetta is also very warm. The temperature is around 20ºC at the end of autumn, lower in the mountains. At the end of winter (March) it is just doable. There is often rain where it will be chilly. At night it freezes, but in the afternoon it is usually pleasant again. Wearing long pants is therefore never a problem. A little later in the spring is more pleasant: it is slightly warmer and the nature is greener.

Spare parts
There is hardly any cycling in Iran. Exceptions are the big cities. You can occasionally meet groups of recreational cyclists. Parts for your bike can be found there. Shimano LX / XT and the like in addition to Chinese and Tawaiian stuff. Under no circumstances Rohlof. In Tabriz it is best to go to the tourist info (near the entrance of the bazaar) they know the way to good bicycle shops.

Tires come in 26 ”or 27” or 28 ”(?) But the latter are often of dubious Chinese quality. In Shiraz there is someone who can weld gas (including aluminum). “People” know the way. Aluminum welding is also possible in Isfahan, they do well. Inquiry at hotel Naghse Jahan (Chahar Bachstr)

People.body:
Nowhere in the world do you encounter as much hospitality as a cyclist as in Iran. From tea by the side of the road to staying with a complete stranger. Although it sometimes demands a bit of your stamina after a whole day of cycling (Iranians don't dine until very late at night, they often want to know everything about you, take you to friends and family), accepting an invitation is one of the nicest and most fun. most educational experiences you can have in Iran. It is appreciated if you bring a little something yourself.

Taarof is a kind of politeness protocol that has permeated deeply into Iranian social relations. Almost everyone does it, and as a tourist you command respect if you master this game well. The bottom line is that you have to leave out directness and express your wishes or objections in an indirect way. When someone offers you something (whatever), it seems greedy to accept it right away. So always refuse first (up to several times). After all, sometimes the offer of the other party is not really meant. It's a game, you have to get a feel for this.

Women must wear a headscarf, a little bit of hair should be visible. Tight clothing is out of the question. The body must be covered, but the traditional chador is not necessary on the bike, but not bare legs. A headscarf and loose-fitting clothes are sufficient.

For men: Cycling in shorts and T-shirt is not a problem, IF you wear long pants in the big cities, small traditional villages (out of respect) or when visiting a mosque. Tight bib shorts are possible, but limit this to connecting roads or quiet roads where few people can take offense.

Safety.body:
Most of Iran is fairly safe, but like everywhere else, watch out in the major cities. It's better to avoid the East (border with Pakistan / Afghanistan)  as a cyclist. Go through there by bus.

Bernadette proves that traveling as a woman alone is possible. "I even think that as a woman solo is the best way to experience Iran. I have also been stopped many times by the police who asked for my passport. He would then write my name and passport number on a note. I thought it was out of boredom and to have a chat with me. I have never experienced it as intimidation. Once I was even treated to a handful of rose petals."
Safety.body_corruption: Bas (2015): "I haven't experienced any corruption, and would be amazed if anyone would"
Safety.body_criminality: In Kerman it can be dangerous because of bandits. Try to weigh the many stories you hear about this and estimate the real dangers.
Safety.body_traffic:
The greatest danger is traffic, which is often quite busy. A helmet is advisable given the driving style of the average Iranian (= driving and not looking). Motorcyclists can also be downright dangerous, especially when two men are on it.

Traffic around and in the cities is busy and people drive without observing any rules. Lanes are only for decoration, only at very important intersections red and green are respected, cyclists are quantité negligable. But it is kind of friendly chaos, they are not aggressive. The right side of the road is usually used by taxis to stop abruptly (at any time, at any place) and is therefore unpredictable. It is best to move forward and it is also safer if you take up the space of a car in the middle of the road, so that people cannot skim past you. Be very careful of cars that cut you off when turning. There is no priority! Alternatively you can drive on the footpath, but unfortunately this is very slow due to the irregularities and sewers and there are transverse gates everywhere to prevent motorcyclists from using the footpath.

Outside the cities it is not too busy, people ride politely and the few cyclists are respected. The whole north is an exception! Also on many local roads it is busy and dangerous, the road is narrow in contrast to the even busier main roads, making a choice sometimes difficult. It is possible to enforce respect, but an alternative is to cycle on the roadside, which is sometimes just as good as the road itself.

The roads are usually of very good quality, smooth asphalt. Iran is an organized country in this regard and can certainly be compared to countries such as Pakistan and India. In the mountains, too, people are very active in opening up areas by building new roads. That political motives lie at the basis here.

23f8c0c6-8002-4cff-988e-fd86fca08e38.description: One of the largest squares in the world.
23f8c0c6-8002-4cff-988e-fd86fca08e38.title: Naqsh-e Jahan Square

3a31df99-8f23-443f-8727-157fa075823d.description: The former capital of the Achaemenid Empire, and now left in ruins. This UNESCO World Herritage Site is definetly worth a visit. You can visit most parts for free, but there are some paid areas like the museum. There are also guides available.
3a31df99-8f23-443f-8727-157fa075823d.title: Persepolis

7900ddd1-0240-49cd-8429-eddcd302a2b8.description: This mosque contains one part with very colorful mosaic windows, and quite often the light shines through these windows and gives an amazing lightshow.
7900ddd1-0240-49cd-8429-eddcd302a2b8.title: Nasir al-Mulk Mosque (Pink mosque)

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Staying in people's homes is a very viable option in Iran. People are very hospitable and always willing to take in visitors. Usually a few folding mattresses are available for the guest(s). If you are invited to stay with someone, do not decline that invitation, there is nothing more behind it than for example in some other countries. Hospitality is an intrinsic quality of Iranian culture and you have not been to Iran until you have experienced it!
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: It seems there are not real campsites around in Iran.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Especially in the larger cities you usually have enough choice of hostels or hotels. The prices vary from a few euros for a place in a dormitory to more than 100 € in a good hotel in Tehran. If you just want a simple room with toilet and shower for yourself in a simple hotel, you pay an average of 15 € (after haggling!). Breakfast is not always included and costs about 2 € extra.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: In Iran you can pitch your tent in any park. Almost every place has at least one park (you) and 9 times out of 10 there are also toilets and running water.

Transport.body_bus:
Public transport is very cheap. For long distances (and therefore large buses) the bicycle can be taken on the bus. Often you have to pay extra for it, from 2 to 5 € depending on the distance. For shorter distances / local buses, taking the bike with you is difficult or impossible. Then a pick-up car is a good alternative, but much more expensive (+ -18 € per 100km). You can stop them on the way or approach them at bus stops.

Often taxis also offer their services. There are no large taxis, so the bicycle is placed in the back of the trunk (halfway) or on the roof (rather rare).

Visa.body:
Getting the Iranian visa can be quite complicated, but it's definetly possible. Make sure you don't have a stamp from Israel in your passport, because than you won't be able to get a visa for Iran.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Large parts of the country are very unsafe, the Kurdish part, which has self-government, is prosperous and relatively safe. Please check the latest travel advice before going to Iraq, as the information on this page may be incorrect!

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
In Erbil you will find a lot of (luxury) supermarkets, but outside it mainly smaller food shops.

Restaurants
You can generally eat well in the restaurants. You will especially find kebabs and relatives there.

Other.body:
Spare parts
In Erbil is a lot available, including modern Shimano parts and 28 "tires. In the other cities you will find mainly Chinese and Indian stuff.

People.body: In the cities you can often use English. You will regularly meet former refugees who returned to their native soil after the Second Gulf War with whom you can speak one of the European languages.

Safety.body: Iraq is not safe to cycle. Please update this description if you have more information.
Safety.body_traffic: Cycling in the big cities is strongly discouraged. Traffic is busy, full of freight traffic and the roads are often just too narrow for safe cycling. Beyond that you can find wonderfully quiet parts.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In the major cities of Kurdistan you will find a multitude of hotels, from basic to luxury. Zakho on the border, due to trade with Turkey, may have the highest hotel density in the country. You already have a neat room from about € 10.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is no problem.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Iraq. At the border you can receive a visa that is valid for 15 days.

Visa policy of Iraq
  Iraq
  Visa on arrival at any entry point
  Visa on arrival at Basra or Najaf airports
  Visa-free access to The Kurdistan Region (up to 30 days)
  Visa required
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
Campinggaz is not easily available, but it is available in larger places in outdoor shops and large supermarkets. Cooking on gasoline can be a good alternative.

Luc: "I cooked on a spirit burner. Finding methylated spirits was also very difficult. I was eventually able to buy it at the pharmacist / chemist for 4 times the price in the Netherlands. However, I had to identify me first and sign a statement !!! otherwise afraid that you apparently drink the poisonous methylated spirits illegally "

Supermarkers
Most small towns currently have a small Centra, Coop or Spar supermarket with a good range of fresh and non-perishable foodstuffs.

Gatha: "In the countryside it is even a matter of looking for bread. As soon as I saw a shop I bought a day's supply."

Restaurants
In large cities such as Dublin and Cork you have a wide choice of good affordable restaurants. There are no restaurants in the countryside, but you can sometimes go to the pub for a hot meal. However, the price / quality ratio of the hot meals is moderate. Most pubs don't serve much more than farmhouse fare like stew and Irish beans with mutton, for a price that is way too high. Moreover, it can take a very long time during the day before your meal is served.

Every self-respecting village has a pub, which you can usually start in the morning. They often serve delicious pastries, such as apple pie and cream or scones with jam and whipped cream. Full Irish Breakfast can also be ordered in the pubs. The price varies from about 6 to 9 euros.

Drinkable water
The tap water is drinkable.

Other.body:
Nice routes
  • The Ring of Kerry is not recommended: very touristy with many buses passing by. Sander and Inge (2006): "We do recommend the inland roads on this peninsula and that of Beara. These are very quiet in terms of traffic and they lead you over rugged passes and through a green, hilly landscape with many sheep and goats."
  • Since 2011, a separate cycle path has been constructed that runs from Achill Island via Malaranny and Newport to Westport (co Mayo). It is a great cycle path, but with obstacles (fences, posts, bridges, etc.) and it leads the cyclist over private areas. It is known by the name of Great Western Greenway. The most beautiful part of the route is from Achill-Island to Newport, because you have the best view of the beautiful coastline and the islands.
  • Along the west coast, the 2500 km Wild Atlantic Way tourist car route is very well signposted. The quiet parts of the route are mainly the regional roads that make a detour to keep following the coastline. This route is very suitable for cycling. If you deviate from the route for a moment, you can quickly reconnect to this tourist car route further on. Many bed and breakfast can be found along this route.
  • In the tourist areas, regional cycling routes have been set out, the Loops. The route varies between 20 and 50 km and always brings you back to the starting place. These cycling routes mainly take regional and local roads.
  • On the peninsula, the Slea Head Drive tourist car route is very beautiful for cycling. This route is part of the long tourist car route Wild Atlantic Way. Lots of pre-historic sites and stunning views of the islands.
  • The highest mountain pass in Ireland is Connor Pass to Dingle. The tough climb is 5 kilometers long and has an average gradient of 7 percent (+100 - 450 h.m). Near the top, the road is narrow and has only one carriageway, which must be shared with oncoming traffic. Reward is a dazzling view.
Best time to cycle
Seasons
June, July and August are the best cycling months. In other months it is colder and it rains more often. Ireland is not very popular with us for cycling tours because of the weather gods. We can be brief about the weather: it is very changeable and strong gusts of wind can be treacherous. Good rain clothing is therefore an absolute necessity.

Frank: "Sorry, I want to contradict the above points: April and May are the dry, sunny months and these are ideally suited for a cycling holiday. June, but especially July and August are the rainy months!"

Tourist high season
Please note: the high season ends at least in mid-October. In the tourist areas, restaurants, cafes (pubs), ferry services (eg to Valentia Island) or hotels may be closed from mid-October to March.

Wind
On the Irish peninsulas Dingle, Iveragh, Baerra the wind direction is mainly southwest to northwest and the wind can blow strong. Best cycling direction on the peninsulas is counterclockwise if you want to keep following the coastline from north to south. Wind gusts of more than 40 km per hour are no exceptions. The danger lies in the open plains and narrow roads.

Average temperature
Due to the warm Gulf Stream, the temperature differences are not very large.

People.body: In many ways you can compare Ireland to England. The population is friendly and helpful in finding the way. Many pubs host a music evening on Friday evenings with traditional Irish folk songs. That could be someone standing on top of a table and performing his singing talents. This is usually done by a local singer who provides some enthusiasm with his repertoire for an evening. Spontaneously, he receives such support that the mandatory closing time is sometimes forgotten.

Safety.body: Ireland is a safe country. Battle in Northern Ireland: In Northern Ireland you are regularly confronted with the consequences of 25 years of political battle between Catholics and Protestants: checkpoints, lockable streets in risk cities like Cookstown, graffiti in the big cities on this subject, sometimes separate shops for both parties , etc. Especially around the 12th of July (Protestant holiday) the tension rises and patrols become clearly visible in the street scene.
Safety.body_traffic: Irish drivers have a lot of respect for cyclists and only overtake when really possible. There are quite a few roads and roads in the coastal area, so that a navigation error will result in no more than 20 km of penalty kilometers.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: The local shops know where you can stay overnight with private individuals or where your tent is allowed.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are campsites within day distances along the coastline. Inland campsites are dungeonized. As a cyclist you often enjoy a reduced rate and you are a curiosity. You get a lot of interest from fellow campers; caravan owners especially like to peek from behind their curtains and watch all your movements.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Ireland has two chains of youth hostels. An Oige has about 40 youth hostels, according to the international standard of the IYHF. In addition, the Independent Holiday Hostels (IHH) has 125 hostels where you can go. Both are in the same price range and offer the same facilities. Several inns are affiliated with both chains.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is officially allowed if you approach the land owner. Very possible along the coast and in the national parks, elsewhere there are few good places to be found. Often you can pitch your tent in the garden of a hostel for a relatively low amount, and use the sanitary facilities and the kitchen (cozy and also handy in bad weather or many midges).

Transport.body_boat: Boats to Ireland depart from Great Britain from various ports. Information on some of these ferry services can be found at www.seabridges.com. Another option is to take the ferry from Roscoff, Le Havre or Cherbourg in France to Cork or Rosslare in Ireland. Sailing time approx. 14 hours. Reservations are desirable, because the available places have already been discussed long in advance. There are several options for combination tickets.
Transport.body_bus:
The situation is unclear on Intercity buses. If there is enough space available and your bicycle is well packed, it can usually be carried without too many problems. You pay a small surcharge for this. In practice, this means that your bike can only be used on the so-called highliners, and they are only used on the express services between the larger cities. Always make sure you have plenty of time to pack your bike a bit smaller. The Dublin - Belfast Express Coach runs 7 times a day, takes three hours and a bicycle ticket costs a quarter of a normal ticket. More information at www.buseireann.ie.

In the highliners, bicycles can be placed completely and unpackaged in the luggage compartment. The buses that leave from the airports are usually low buses. Drivers are not obliged to bring cyclists, but will not be difficult if there is enough space.
Transport.body_train: You can take your bicycle on the Intercity trains, but not from, in and to Northern Ireland (the popular train route Dublin-Belfast v.v. you therefore have to bridge in a different way). You have to load and unload your bike yourself. The bicycle can be taken along in the luggage compartment (if available) or simply in the carriage. Be courteous and put your bike out of the way at any stop. Price for the bicycle is a day ticket and independent of the distance. What applies to bicycles sometimes does not apply to tandems. There was no room for our tandem on the intercity from Galway to Dublin (Sept. 2012). Every effort was made to accommodate us and via Limerick and Limerick junction we traveled to Dublin. In Limerick, another train set was even used that the tandem could use.

Visa.body:
Ireland is not part of the Schengen area and have their own visa policy. There are quite some countries that need a visa for entering Ireland.


Visa policy of Ireland
  Ireland
  Common Travel Area
  Freedom of movement (EU/EEA/CH)
  Visa-free access to Ireland for 90 days
  Visa required to enter Ireland, transit without visa
  Visa required to enter Ireland and for transit through Ireland
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Restaurants
You can find good food everywhere, especially in Jerusalem and Eilat. There are also many shawarma restaurants.

Paul and Hennie: "Palestinian food was well recognizable to us because of the shawarma-like, if we may express ourselves that way. We found Jewish food more adventurous because we didn't actually know it. Vegetarian too!"

Drinkable water
The tap water is drinkable. Bottled drinking water is widely available.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Spring and autumn are the best periods. In summer it is quickly too hot, especially around the Dead Sea. Jerusalem is at 800 m, Dead Sea at minus 400. That gives considerable temperature differences.

Spare parts
28 inch tires are available. There are no serious bike shops.

Nice routes
  • Paul and Hennie cycled the following route: Jericho - Bethlehem - Jerusalem - Ramalla - Lod - Tel Aviv.
  • Martin: "I cycled in Israel and Jordan for three weeks. Both are very tough cycling countries: despite my derailleur gears, altitude differences of 1200 meters occur in one day. Temperature of 28 to 41 degrees. I weighed 13 kilos less when I got home."
  • Martin: "I sailed to Haifa via Cyprus on a passenger boat. According to the official rules this is not allowed. After insisting it turns out to be possible."

People.body:
Israelis in general are inhospitable and distant, Palestinians are curious and hospitable. The latter sometimes accost cyclists. Most Israelis never enter Palestinian territories. They advise against going there: it would be dangerous. Israelis distrust the Palestinians. Otherwise it is less.

Martin van Doornik (2007): "I cycled through Israel and Jordan for three weeks. The Jewish population has been very nice and very friendly to me. Only in the Arab areas, on the other hand, not: many children wanted me and my touch the bike. The police had to come in to send those rascals away."

Note from Cycle Planet: The above information speaks against each other. If you have more up to date information, please change the above text.

The Israelis speak Hebrew, the Palestinians Arabic. You can speak English with both ethnic groups.

Safety.body: The political situation can change from day to day, although the tension will not be the same everywhere. As a foreigner on a bicycle you are relatively safe. Both Israelis and Palestinians want to be your friend. The checkpoints around the Palestinian self-government areas are, of course, a source of conflict. You feel that when you cycle past it.
Safety.body_nature: Dogs can be tricky sometimes. In summer it can be quite hot, especially in desert areas. Drinking a lot is then a must.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Sometimes people invite you to spend the night in their house.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: You can (also) camp at kibbutzim.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In Israel it is not too difficult to find a cheap place to sleep. Just a matter of asking a few times. The prices of hotels can vary quite a bit. There are hardly any cheap guest houses in the Palestinian territories (Palestinians are probably not used to travelling).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Israel without a visa, others need to obtain a visa.

  Israel
  Countries with visa-free access to Israel
  Visa required for entry to Israel
  Confirmation from Israeli Foreign Ministry is required
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Those who want to cycle in beautiful landscapes and who do not despise culture and the coast will find all this in Italy. A short distance from each other you will find mountains, sea and beautiful cities. If you avoid the major roads, Italian traffic is doable. The art cities with squares, marble buildings, beautiful churches and typical Italian atmosphere are all worthwhile. The evening life can also be amazing; there is a wide range of concerts or events.

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkers
Supermarkets and other shops often hold a siesta for a very long time: sometimes from 1:00 pm to 5:00 pm.

Stalls on the street
Along the way you regularly come across fruit stalls in the villages.

Restaurants
Every village has a 'bar' where you can drink something and have breakfast. You can have an excellent lunch in most bars. After eleven, most bars have exchanged their sweet assortment for a collection of savory sandwiches that are excellent for lunch, and that are often even heated for you between the toasted sandwich plates if you wish. Furthermore: do as any Italian and stand still in a bar. Different prices apply for sitting down, you are often twice as expensive. Just stand at the bar and eat your coffee and your sandwich, or else sit outside on a wall ...

The food in restaurants is excellent and the pasta is very nutritious for cyclists. In short: Fantastico !! Restaurants are often closed in the afternoon after lunch. On the other hand, they are still open late into the night.

Sometimes they charge 1 euro p.p. when you sit down at a table. So if you only take a coffee for 1.50 euros, the coffee quickly becomes quite expensive. You do not pay this when you drink your coffee at the bar. In restaurants you pay 1 euro extra for use of the table anyway.

Drinkable water
Water can usually be drunk straight from the tap or the village fountain. But in the south and in Sicily here and there brackish water comes out of the tap. It is not for nothing that you see people everywhere along the side of the road pouring bottles from mountain water sources. Drinking water in Sardinia is often supplied with chlorine.

If there is no good pump in the area, you can try it in a restaurant or at a farm. Bottled water is widely available.

Other.body:
Nice routes
Many cycling routes have been laid out in the valleys of the Dolomites. The best known is the Reschenpass to Merano, Bolzano and Trento. But also from Bolzano to Bruneck and Lienz. Our experience: if the valley becomes flatter and wider, pay attention to bicycle signs, often there is a bicycle route, sometimes these routes are used as a cross-country route in winter. The quality varies.

The quiet cycling area of Oltrepo Pavese, in the south of Lombardy, is unknown but very worthwhile. You cycle in the hills between the vineyards and enjoy beautiful views. This area is also very popular with Italian cyclists.

For an overview of the bicycle network in Italy map with bicycle routes in Italia.

Best period to cycle
Spring is very good for cycling, summer can also be good when in the mountains or on the coast. Leave early on warm days. September is a wonderful month for cycling.

Spring (May - mid-June) is the most pleasant for cycling. The weather is fine, there are few rainy days. Summer is the best cycling time in the high mountains. In the lower regions, but also in the low mountain ranges, it can sometimes get pretty hot in the summer. The chance of rain in the summer is quite small. In Tuscany, on the other hand, it can rain a lot. If you want to cycle in Sardinia, avoid the hot summer months. Spring has a pleasant temperature.

Spare parts
There are plenty of bicycle repair shops in most places. However, if you are cycling in Sardinia, take enough spare parts with you. Bicycle shops are scarce there (still?). In southern Italy it is difficult to find modern bicycle repairers. So bring the right spare parts.

Tips
On beautiful Sundays, all city dwellers go out to the beach, lakes or mountains, where it is very busy and not pleasant to cycle. So it is easier to drive through Milan, for example, but it is better to postpone a trip along a lake or over a beautiful col.

Many museums and attractions are closed on Mondays, even in high season. A great cycling day ...

As soon as the sun has set, it becomes cozy in the villages / towns. Everyone comes out and sits around the village square. Young and old are together. It is still very quiet and the atmosphere is great.

People.body: The people are generally very friendly, but make contact themselves less quickly than in third world countries. Yet they are very helpful. Speaking Italian is of course an advantage, but you can also make do with Spanish. In southern Italy people hardly speak English. Communication is therefore very difficult when you do not speak Italian. That's a shame because people are very interested in you. You don't see many holiday cyclists there.

Safety.body: Italy is a safe country for tourists. The maffia won't bother you if you don't bother them. Just be cuatios in big cities. In hotels, always leave your bike in the room or safely stored. In the youth hostels, if no storage room is available, properly lock and remove your saddle.
Safety.body_criminality: In large cities, you can deposit your money and expensive items at the hotel reception.
Safety.body_traffic:
The main roads are busy, especially around large cities and along the coast. In the province of Naples very busy with aggressive road use. Tip: plan your cycling tour through Naples on a Sunday afternoon, then it will be nice and quiet on the street. It can be very quiet on inland roads and car traffic is prohibited in very small villages with narrow streets.

Drivers are sometimes not taken into account properly. This can be particularly risky on a descent. Italians are used to scooter traffic, so if you behave like that as a cyclist, it is not too bad.

Tunnels can be treacherous: no lighting, wet and with bumps, don't panic.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are many campsites on the coast (also in Sardinia) and on the lakes.
