Near Venice you will find hundreds of campsites in endless rows, each with its own stretch of beach so that free access to the sea is not possible. The quality is still good here. More to the south, endless rows can often be found along the coasts. The quality is usually less good than in the north, some do not open until the beginning of July, the big wave visitors come in August when the Italian is on holiday. Many of those beach campsites are closed again in mid-September.

Inland there are fewer campsites. Sometimes you have to cycle well over a day's distance before you encounter the next one (even in Tuscany). So if you want to camp inland, you have to plan well.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels can be found in most places (even smaller ones), so they are within cycling distance if you plan something. In general, Italy is not that cheap, although the smaller non-touristy places are affordable. Bargaining for room rates is possible in some places.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is possible, but you have to look carefully for a place. In the wooded mountains of La Silla you can easily camp wild.

Transport.body_boat: It is possible to bring your bicycle on the ferry services between the mainland and the islands.
Transport.body_bus: The bicycle can be taken on some buses (if there is room for it).
Transport.body_train: Most intercity trains and all high-speed trains are off-limits to the bicycle. On the regional trains it is possible to take the bicycle with you for a fee. The bicycle department is usually located in the front or rear carriage. In some regions (such as Basilicata, Naples) bicycle transport on regional trains is free. See also railbike.net

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

Some nationalities can enter Jaimaica without a visa for up to 30, 90 or 180 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
There are many dining options. The food is healthy and light. A meal costs € 6 to € 15, including Japanese green tea. Coffee, black tea and alcohol, on the other hand, are more expensive at € 2 per cup. (Note from Cycle Planet: This information might be outdated, please refresh and delete this note).

Peter: "All supermarkets and convenient stores sell O-bento (packed lunches), which are often prepared on site in kitchens. Prices vary between approx. Y 300 (€ 2) and, depending on the size and composition, Y 1000 (€ 6.5). They can be eaten hot or cold and all convenient stores and most supermarkets have microwaves to heat them up. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bento. Convenient stores also have kettles you can use for free so you can make instant noodle and noodle soup. You can eat well without a burner."

Stalls on the street
There are plenty of eateries available. You can usually eat very well and cheaply. You can often find eateries near the train station.

Drinkable water
You can drink tap water without any problems. There are soda machines all along the way.

Other.body:
Nice routes
  • Shimanami Kaido is a nice cycling route between Onomichi (Honshu) and Imabari (Shikoku). Enjoy the bicycle-friendly route over the many bridges and islands between Honshu and Shikoku. Wonderful views of the islands in the inland sea (Seto Inland Sea). A nice option is to start the cycle route to Shikoku from Fukuyama via Tomonoura to Onomichi, because there are beautiful temples and castles along the route.
  • Cycling or hiking in Japan's national parks. Follow the scenic routes (Scenic Byway Hokkaido) through national parks on the sparsely populated island of Hokkaido, but watch out for brown bears in the Shiretoko and Daisetzusan national parks.
  • Discover the traditional rural life of Japan or relive the ancient folk tales by cycling the separate cycle paths in the valley near Tono (island of Honshu) and visiting the historic buildings. Visit the local Tono tourist office at the train station beforehand.
  • Cycle along coast road 45 from Shiogama to Matsushima and enjoy the many beautiful islands in Matsushima Bay. Many Japanese consider the tourist town of Matsushima to be one of 'The three most scenic spots of Japan'. The town has beautiful temples and a rich history.
  • Norikura Skyline Road is the road across the plateau of Norikura and is located in the Chubusangaku National Park. Whoever cycles this road cycles on the roof of Japan and sees the many mountain peaks protruding only a few hundred meters above. The route is a nice run-up to the mountain village of Kamikochi, as the road is prohibited for car and truck traffic in high season. There is a shuttle service (taxis and buses) to transport the masses of tourists. The road is at an altitude of 2700 meters and can be approached from the town of Norikura (+ 1400 m) or the Hirayu mountain pass (+1700 m). Take into account a tough mountain stage, because overcoming 1,300 vertical meters in 17 km means a mountain from the outside category. The road to the plateau contains many hairpin bends in both directions, which are fortunately provided with mirrors. Always keep cycling on the left because of the taxis and buses!
Best time to cycle
Seasons
Realize that the North of Japan differs 2000 km from the South. Check the Japan Meteorological Agency website for weather forecast, tropical cyclones, tsunami, earthquakes & volcano activities.

Early May and October has a stable climate with ideal cycling temperatures in southern Japan (Kyushu, Shikoku and Honshu). In the first half of October in the South, many flowers and beautiful Japanese greenery. Second half colder but wonderful autumn colors. In the spring you can also enjoy all the beautiful blossoms. Temperature about 15-22ºC.

More Northern, May, June offers temperatures of about 25ºC. It's an ideal time: lots of butterflies and little wind. The rainy season starts in mid-June and it can drizzle for days.

The typhoon season starts in mid-August and lasts until about mid-October. Shipping traffic can be seriously disrupted by typhoons. It is therefore wise to have a few days leeway if you sail to the airport by boat during this period for the return flight.

September is the month of the typhoons. The temperature is thus between 30 and 35ºC. Humidity is high. During this period you see a lot of dragonflies.

Tourist high season
The first week of May, all of Japan has a holiday in the so-called Golden Week; then it is very busy on all roads, something to take into account during your route.

From 13 to 16 August it is Obon, a Buddhist event for which the Japanese return to their birthplace. Millions of Japanese make massive use of public transport in the period just before and after Obon, and travel by public transport is virtually impossible during this period without a timely reservation.

Wind
Favorable route on the coastal roads on Hokkaido Island is counterclockwise cycling as you often have the wind in your back!

Spare parts
There are plenty of bicycle shops, but in the smaller towns they only focus on the simple city bikes that Japanese people use (often without gear).

People.body:
Japanese are hospitable. They want to pay for you directly and want to give you the best and arrange everything for you. They do not give you conspicuous extra attention as a cyclist or foreigner, while you really stand out. Schoolchildren do this on the other hand. They are happy to show you the way, for which they copy maps with the way on it.

Just assume that outside university cities, nobody (really nobody) speaks English. Sometimes you can communicate in writing in English (English lessons in Japan focus exclusively on reading and writing skills because of the great difficulty Japanese have with English pronunciation).

Safety.body: Japan is generally safe. The population always treats you correctly and nicely. The Japanese work with all their might on road safety and safety in the big cities. There is not much crime. You will hardly find homeless people outside the big cities. During wild camping, keep in mind the bears in Daisetsuzan NP and Shiretoko NP on the island of Hokkaido. Poisonous snakes (pit vipers) are mainly found in the south of Japan.
Safety.body_traffic:
The maximum traffic speed is 50 or 60 km per hour on the national motorways, but car and truck traffic hardly adhere to it. Cycling on the motorways (expressways) is prohibited. These roads are well signposted from the regional and national motorways and are marked green on the traffic information signs. In large cities there is a bicycle ban on some motorways (fly-overs) to relieve the traffic in the city. Please note, prohibition signs for cyclists are clearly recognizable and the warning texts are also in English.

On the island of Honshu, the traffic on the national highways is present during the day, but does not pose a danger to the cyclist because of the many narrow cycle and pedestrian paths on the left or right side of the road. For your own safety, you cycle on the constructed paths, because the roads on the island have hardly any asphalt verge or hard shoulder and are narrow for large passing trucks! Take into account increasing irritations, because the cycle path ends or is on the other side of the road. In urban areas you will encounter many pedestrians and oncoming traffic on a bicycle, or stationary cars taking up part of the path. The low curbs or the many traffic lights prevent you from developing a good cycling pace in the big cities. Despite the traffic on the regional roads of the island of Honshu is considerably less, the advice is to cycle as much as possible on the paths laid out for cyclists and pedestrians. If a cycle path suddenly stops, look around you and do not lose the orientation point of the cycle route to be followed. The Japanese have thought about cycling along the national highways, because there are many tunnels and flyovers for cyclists and pedestrians.

On the other hand, the island of Hokkaido is bicycle-friendly, if you leave the urban areas. The paved roads are in good condition and often have well-paved shoulder strips. The coastal road 231 between Rumoi and Atsuta has many tunnels with a length of more than two kilometers. Do not give space to the car and freight traffic behind if oncoming traffic is approaching and make sure you are visible! There are refuges in the large tunnels where you can temporarily stop to allow traffic behind to pass.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are plenty of campsites. The northern island of Hokkaido has a relatively large number of campsites. Campsites are sometimes cheaper than European campsites, but do not have hot showers. Prices vary between 500 and 1000 yen (3.5 and 6.5 euros; 1 person and 1 tent).
Sleeping.body_hostels:
Youth hostels cost about € 25 per person per night including meal. Sometimes they are fine, but sometimes you find a chilly concrete colossus; you can get your own room.

Ryokans are something between a B&B and a hotel. They are traditional with the tatami, the sloefkes and the wonderful Japanese bath (Onsen).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Camping in the wild is very well possibly. In Hokkaido, there are still wild bears around. Wild camping is therefore not recommended on (parts of) this island. For other parts, a few of the best spots can be found at:
  • Lookout spots for tourists (often with toilet)
  • Old roads that have been replaced by brand new roads offer opportunities
  • Along rivers
  • Parks / playgrounds / sports fields (often with toilet)
  • Camping in the mountains: watch out for "landslides" when choosing a spot
  • Next to rice fields, in the evening after sunset no one comes (further plus point there is always water at hand)
  • Abandoned temples / shrines (in urban areas); Maintain respect for Buddhism, don't leave a mess!

Transport.body_airplane:
Tip: Always take a bicycle cover or a special bicycle bag to transport your bicycle. Many airlines hardly sell bicycle boxes outside their home base or only sell to their own customers. At Kansai International Airport (Osaka), you can buy a bicycle box (lxwxh = 177x23x102 cm).

Osaka-Kansai airport is bicycle unfriendly. The airport is located on an artificial island off the coast of Osaka. It is connected to the main land by a 5 km long bridge. You are not allowed to cycle to the airport on the highway (= toll road). You are not allowed to take your bicycle unpackaged on the train, bus, taxi or boat. The-lonely-push-biker cycled the national roads (25 and 26) from Shinosaka (Shinkansen station in Osaka) via Osaka Namba to KIX within three hours (approx. 40 km) and he only cycled in the overcrowded urban areas . He packed his bicycle in a bicycle cover and was allowed to transport the bicycle on the train from Rinku Town to Kansai International Airport. This was only allowed if it was properly packaged and the staff gave an agreement, otherwise he would not get through the entrance gates of the station!

The train station in Rinku Town is 7 km from KIX. From this station there are no more stops to the airport and towing the bicycle to the platform is only 100m incl. Escalator. If you step at other train stations (eg in Osaka), you can tow your packaged bicycle over a great distance and then pick up your luggage. Help from the staff cannot be taken for granted. Every day many Japanese and tourists pass the train stations in the big cities, making it difficult to get your bike on the overcrowded train. Travel to small stations outside the big cities and outside peak hours, the trains are less busy and there is always room for the bike.

Narita Airport is about 70 km from Tokyo. Cycling to Tokyo is very easy, because there are quiet cycle paths through rural areas over dikes (Jim 2008)

Ferry: "They do not sell bicycle boxes at Narita terminal 2, the only exception is Continental Airways, they only sell to their own customers. Tip in Narita village there are bicycle shops, which are 7 km from the airport. Here you can ask for boxes, but then you have something to drag. You can already pack the bike in the box in Narita village and from there by train to the airport (250 Yen)."

Nagoya is a practical airport if you want to visit Kyoto and the south.The Comfort hotel in the airport itself is ideal and inexpensive.
Transport.body_bus: There is simply no room for the bicycle on long-distance buses between Kyoto and Tokyo.
Transport.body_train:
Japan is overcrowded and so you better skip the endless kilometers of urbanization by train. A folding bicycle in a baby carrier is ideal for Japan. Before you leave, ask for a railway pass that you can no longer buy in Japan. It is quickly cheaper than buying tickets.

In Japan, they can be difficult about taking a non-foldable bicycle on public transport. The bicycle must be completely disassembled and put in a special bag.

The bicycle can be taken on the Shinkansen (bullet train) or local train at no extra cost. No extra costs, but uncertainty whether it will work. You have to take your bike apart and put it in a special bag. Get pedals and steer off. Pack your bike in a pannier or bike cover and find Shinkansen's rear train set. When commenting from station staff, the language barrier helps to get the bike along. Always indicate that you are bringing your bike packed and also show this to the staff. After approval you buy a normal train ticket and surcharge ticket (express service for Shinkansen). There is not much space in the Shinkansen, so travel outside rush hour (07: 00-10: 00 and 16: 00-19: 00). There is space to place the dismantled bicycle behind the last row of seats or the rear aisle of the last train set. Train layout is clearly indicated on the platform by Japanese Railways. Another option is to send the bicycle separately via the Shinkansen. JR offers this possibility. Make good agreements!

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkers
Every self-respecting village has a supermarket with biscuits, bread and drinks. You never really have long distances in Jordan.

Restaurants
The food is delicious: kebab, chicken sandwich, baklava, say the traditional Arabic dishes. All very tasty. Bread, water and soft drinks are available everywhere, sometimes at tourist prices (5x normal price), sometimes for free. Vegetarians don't have to complain either: stuffed eggplant, falaffel, etc.

Drinkable water
The tap water can be unreliable. You will find tea and strong coffee everywhere.

Health.body: If you come from a yellow fever area, yellow fever vaccination is mandatory. A DTP vaccination is recommended, as is protection against Hepatitis A.

Other.body:
To see and do
Note from Cycle Planet: If someone would like to add these bullet points as markers on the map, be our guest. In that case, you can also remove this note ;)
  • Wadi Rum (Beautiful !. You can cycle to the village (asphalt). Then it becomes loose sand and you have to take a jeep excursion. You can spend the night in the desert)
  • Petra (UNESCO World Heritage Site, one of the Seven Wonders of the World according to tourists)
  • King's Highway: beautiful cycle route, old Jordan trade route
  • Madaba: church of the beheading of St John
  • Jerash: ancient Roman city of Gerasa (After Rome, the best preserved archaeological site from the Roman period).
  • Castles of Shoubak and Kerak. History and strategic location.
  • Dana Nature Reserve for its different bio-geographic zones, variety in wildlife, geology and landscape.
  • Bethany: Baptism site (20 km north of the Dead Sea) along the Jordan / Israel border river. It is a place of pilgrimage for many religious movements within Christianity, as evidenced by the many different churches on the complex.
  • Dead Sea; experience it!
  • Madaba: visit the church "Shine of the beheading of John Baptist". You can climb the tower (free) with a nice view
Nice routes
Peter: "I cycled the King's Highway from Madaba via Karak and Petra to Aqaba and then via the Desert Highway to the Dead Sea, Ajlun and Jerash. There are no hotels on the way from Aqaba to the Dead Sea, so you have to rely on wild camping or the benevolence of the (few) local population. I thought the Desert Highway was a bit boring. The total route is very nice and interesting because of all the sights, the history, the Biblical places and the different nature reserves. Very fascinating to see what was and happened there thousands of years ago, in terms of civilization and historiography."

Best time to cycle
Seasons
The best times are spring and autumn: no precipitation, temperatures between 10 and 35 degrees. Spring: everything is then in bloom and it is not too hot. In the summer it is too hot, in the winter it is too cold.

Willy: "I had rain in February and snow in the higher regions, so bring warm clothes."

Wind
On the King's Highway, the predominant wind direction is a westerly wind (also visible in the direction in which the trees grow). In April 2009 this wind was quite strong for a few days.

Spare parts
26 and 28 inch tires are available. Inner tubes (26 inch) with Dunlop valve (DV) are hardly available in Jordan. On the other hand, the inner tubes (26 inch) with Auto Valve (AV) are for sale in small towns at bicycle and moped repair shops.

Bicycle and moped repair shops can be found in small towns. Inquire with the residents of the city. Bicycle shops can be found in Amman. There are hardly any bicycle shops outside the capital. Shops were found in Madaba that also sell bicycles. Otherwise, post a message on Cycling Jordan's Facebook page. They can provide you with more information.

Tips
  • Long legs and sleeves are recommended in connection with religion. Freek: "Women please wear covered clothing (long pants, long sleeves). Men can cycle / walk quietly in shorts. They are used to tourists. Women can also walk around less covered in tourist areas." Willy: "In the south around Wadi Rum it is advisable to dress long as a man, the Bedouin women feel uncomfortable otherwise." Peter (2014): "I had no problems cycling in shorts."
  • Jordan can be combined very well with a tour of Israel.
  • If you are using Amman airport for arrival / departure, use Madaba as your base instead of Amman. Amman and Madaba are about the same distance from the airport. The sights in Amman (especially amphitheater and citadel) can also be done in a day trip from Madaba. Amman is a large, cluttered city with chaotic, bicycle-unfriendly city traffic and (possibly) smog, while Madaba is much quieter and more bicycle-friendly.

People.body:
The population is generally hospitable, friendly and interested (adults).
Children can be annoying, they sit on your bike (bags), and sometimes throw stones. You are regularly (but less often than in Turkey and Syria) offered something to drink, for example in restaurants, shops or along the road by truck drivers.

Willy: "After saying Salaam Aleikum, the astonished teenagers no longer throw stones. In some villages they throw tomatoes, handy for dinner."

Safety.body:
You can cycle quietly and easily everywhere. Avoid the border with Iraq. Children sometimes throw stones at cyclists. 

Robin: "In Jordan the boys between 6 and 18 have a hobby that I do not appreciate; throwing stones, spitting, yelling, trying to pull things off your bike. From other I heard the same, they warn each other about difficult parts, especially on the Kings Highway."
Safety.body_nature:
Occasionally you may encounter a stray dog, but usually it does not bother you. Stray dogs are usually in the category "barking dogs don't bite", but it can still be a scare from time to time. Once a dog even tried to bite my bicycle bag. The dogs often walk near herds of sheep and / or goats. 

In the desert near Wadi Rum, watch out for dehydration, especially when the wind is blowing hard.
Safety.body_traffic:
Traffic is not too bad outside the big places. However, the exhaust fumes can be nasty and unpleasant. Only Amman is busy. But good to cycle via the roads. The cosmopolitan city of Amman is not a cycling city because of the many hills in the urban areas and the busy city traffic. Crossing the road can be tricky.

Dessert highway is wide. Not busy. Trucks visit you very generously. King's Highway: little traffic between Madaba and Wadi Musa (Petra). There is more traffic between Jerash and Amman, but a wide hard shoulder makes cycling easier. Dead Sea road: slightly more traffic, but on balance still fairly quiet and the lack of a wide hard shoulder on parts of the route.

8cb9e80c-da6c-47fc-aec8-f8f10c87907e.description: UNESCO world herritage site. Carved out of the rocks, this temple symbolizes a rich history.
8cb9e80c-da6c-47fc-aec8-f8f10c87907e.title: Petra

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: If you indicate that you are looking for a place to sleep, there is often someone who can arrange a place to sleep for you (with himself or family, etc. and whether or not for a (small) fee).
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are a few campsites around.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are cheap hotels every 100 km.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is doable. Officially it is not allowed, but in the desert, near the Jordan and near the Dead Sea there are many possibilities.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Jordan.


Source: Wikipedia.

f1b7482d-72f0-4b27-b011-1756b62d37f0.description:
It is necessary to have a travel visa for Kazakhstan unless you are from a country which is visa-exempt.

Citizens from a number of countries can enter Kazakhstan visa-free for up to 30 days including the US, Canada, all EU countries, Brazil, and Argentina. People from eight neighboring countries (Russia, Ukraine, Georgia, Armenia, Belarus, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, and Mongolia) can enter for up to 90 days without a visa.

FoodDrink.body:
Stalls on the street
There are regular stalls along the road where food is prepared.

Drinkable water
There is plenty of water from the mountains (only in the far south are mountains). A pump can often be found in villages.

Health.body: It may be wise to take preventive vaccinations against FSME. FSME is a nasty viral infection that is transmitted by ticks, just like Lyme disease.

Other.body:
Nice routes
The route over the Asy plateau is really beautiful. A good alternative for the route from Almaty to Kök-Pek / Kegen towards Kyrgyzstan. Take into account the extremely bad road down the plateau towards Kök-Pek (or on if you come from the other side).

Best time to cycle
Kazakhstan consists mainly of steppe, so very arid and dry, in the summer it can get very hot.

Spare parts
Make sure you have all your belongings with you. The people are often very resourceful.

People.body: The population is very friendly and wants to help you from all sides. Besides Kazakh (Turkish related language) everyone speaks Russian, another language such as English is spoken in Almaty every now and then. All designations are in Cyrillic.

Safety.body_traffic: The main roads are generally good, sometimes with some holes and potholes, especially in the cities. In the cities it is busy and the driving is fast. Outside the cities it is generally a lot quieter.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are few or no campsites in Kazakhstan.
Sleeping.body_hostels: For foreigners, most hotels are terribly expensive, the cheaper hotels are afterwards and the comfort offered is minimal.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is not a problem, sometimes people will point you to a suitable place (where, for example, drinking water is available).

Transport.body_bus: Buses are usually quite full, nowadays many East German buses drive around in Almaty.
Transport.body_train: You can bring a bicycle with you on the train, but it is done in a separate wagon on through trains. The baggage department is not the responsibility of the railways and you often have to negotiate firmly about the price (in dollars).

Visa.body:
Most Western countries can visit Kazakhstan visa free for 30 days. A few countries around Kazakhstan can visit 90 days without a visa. Other nationalities (grey) must apply for a visa.

Visa policy of Kazakhstan
  Kazakhstan
  Visa exempt (90 days)
  Visa exempt (30 days)
  Visa exempt (14 days)
  Visa required

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Kenya is a beautiful country located in East Africa and has it all, desserts, mountains, hills, tropical climate and one of the most amazing beaches!

Corona.body: You need a Negative PCR Covid Certificate issued withing 72 hours of travelling and will have to fill an online locator form to gain entry into Kenya.

142309ed-e3c3-4964-a9c1-56c45a69bc1c.description:
You need to apply for an EVisa. Visa on entry is no longer issued in Kenya. 
Be sure to use the government website provided to attain your visa, there are alot of fake websites out there conning people. 

East African Tourist Visa is also available, which allows you to travel to Kenya, Rwanda and Uganda with a single visa. The visa expires if you travel outside of one these countries.

FoodDrink.body:
Stick to Mineral or Filtered water. 
Choice of basic local food to 5* Hotels. Many options available including KFC. Food also depends on where in the country you are

Health.body:
• Malaria occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis and the like are available on site.
  • Yellow fever vaccination is mandatory for Kenya.
  • Vaccination against DTP (diphtheria, tetanus and polio) is recommended. Typhoid vaccination is also recommended in certain cases.
  • Both Nairobi and Mombasa have international hospitals, where the quality of medicine is on the same level as in Europe.

Other.body:
My name is Tanvir Singh Sabharwal and I am happy for you to contact me directly with any questions you may have and I will delighted to assist you! 
Happy Travels 
+254703696964

People.body: The people in Kenya are generally very friendly and speak English. They do assist travellers alot. It is very common to be invited to someone's house to stay with them. Hitchhiking is very popular especially with the truck drivers.

Safety.body: The capital Nairobi is also called "Nai-robbery", always watch out here. Try not to show off your electronic items especially at night and Make Sure you have your face mask on in Public Places
Safety.body_criminality: Criminal activity is on the rise, avoid being out at night if you are cycling/walking. Take a taxi/bolt/wasili/uber at night.
Safety.body_nature: Many major National parks where wildlife can be seen. You need to pay park entry fees and a vehicle to enter the parks. You can however cycle through a National Park called Hells Gate
Safety.body_traffic: Traffic usually gets really bad with alot of motorbike taxis pushing their way around, be extra careful of your surroundings.

577e8dae-48b0-4843-a74a-19cdcd263f2e.description:
Eldoret is a town located 2100m above main sea level. It is home to many world renown Kenyan athletes that train at this altitude.
Just nearby there is the Kerio Valley which is part of the famous Rift Valley located in a town called Iten, there are a few high altitude training centres there are well. 
Eldoret also has huge supermarkets, restaurants and supermarkets so it is a great place to stock up on rations and unwind.
577e8dae-48b0-4843-a74a-19cdcd263f2e.title: Things to Do and See

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Campsites all over the country
Sleeping.body_hostels: Check out hostelworld
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Not recommended

Transport.body_airplane: Multiple airlines come into Kenya. You can fly into major towns and cities across Kenya
Transport.body_boat: In Lake Victoria, Lake Naivasha, Lake Nakuru, Lake Turkana and Naivasha
Transport.body_bus: Multiple Buses going across the country and borders
Transport.body_train: SGR from Nairobi to Mombasa and commuter line within Nairobi to Nyanyuki

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa for entering Kenya.

Source: Wikipedia.

Some nationalities can enter Kosovo without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

Most nationalities need a visa to enter Kuwait.

Visa policy of Kuwait
  Kuwait
  Visa-free
  Visa on arrival or eVisa
  Visa required
Source: Wikipedia.

26841089-bd5b-44b7-a447-c827edaacf90.description: If you have to apply for the e-visa you might need a letter of invitation (LOI), which might be quite a hassle to obtain and can take up to 2 weeks. The e-visa has to be used within 90 days of the visa approval and the duration of your stay needs to be finished before these 90 days. It takes about one week to process the e-visa. Check out this guide for more information.

FoodDrink.body:
Off the main roads, it is wise to have food with you for at least a day. In yurts you can also buy bread from the people. There are many apricot trees along the road, so there is no shortage of fruit.

Stalls on the street
In villages there are all kinds of stalls where, for example, bread, pasta and bars are for sale, and where food is also prepared. There are also restaurants or canteens. The food in canteens is not great. In the restaurants, the food is usually quite reasonable.

Restaurants
Cafés serve Russian-style food, quite varied, and of course shaslicks, bread and tea in the south. 1 or 2E is enough per man.

Drinkable water
Tap water seems safe, except in Osh! Ask, pointing to the tap, 'ette vodda pietnaja?' (is this drinking water?). Bottled water is available everywhere. In the mountains all rivers are good to drink, the water comes straight from the high mountains. In addition, there are pumps in the villages, where there is pure water. Quite often, however, the pumps do not function.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The best months are June and September. In the spring there can still be snow on high passes. If it is not a through main route, there will be no clearing and passage is virtually impossible or in any case risky. In July and August it can be very hot in the lowlands (up to 40ºC), in the mountains, on the other hand, there is a mountain climate, where high in the mountains it can be especially cold at night.

Spare parts
Because there are hardly any bicycle shops, it is recommended that you bring your own gear with you as much as possible. The people are generally very resourceful. Take enough inner tubes and puncture-proof tires with you, the streets are full of glass!

There is a bicycle shop / repair shop in Osh. It is called X-store / Bikemaster and is located in the Osh Business and Training Center, Alieva Road no. 145, tel. 56633. Very enthusiastic, young people. Note from Cycle Planet: Please add this bike shop to the map when you find the exact location, and delete this bike shop description.

People.body:
The population is very friendly and curious. They all want to know where you come from and what you come here to do. Children all feel your tires. When you are invited by people, you will be received very hospitably and generously: usually you have to stay for dinner and even sleep is possible (also in the mountains in the so-called yurts = tents).

Note: the Kyrgyz do not appreciate being compared to the Chinese, they prefer to see a relationship with the Turks. The Kyrgyz and Uzbek languages ​​are related to Turkish, so many people understand Turkish, some have also studied it.

In addition to Kyrgyz or Uzbek, almost all adults also speak Russian, hardly any other language (not even in Bishkek). Young people speak much less Russian, but on the other hand - in the cities - often understand a word of English, although they are usually too shy to speak it due to a lack of practice. All inscriptions are in Cyrillic. So it is useful to learn the Cyrillic alphabet.

Safety.body: In general, Kyrgyzstan is a safe place to travel.
Safety.body_traffic:
Most roads are quiet. On the northern route along the Issyk-Kul lake it is quite busy and the driving is very fast, so watch out. At night there is hardly any lighting in the cities (also in Bishkek there is a lack of lighting here and there). It is therefore not advisable to cycle at night, it can be really pitch dark.

Mountain trails through the mountains are very rough and very tough, require a good condition and a lot of experience in rugged terrain. Especially in the south through the mountains, the roads are not paved but tamped. It is good to drive over.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: In Kyrgyzstan an extensive network of "sleeping in people's homes" is available. This is united in Community Based Tourism (CBT). We have regularly used this. Especially in Suusamyr it is very pleasant to stay. Usually there is a local coordinator. See also this website.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are few or no campsites in Kyrgyzstan. Camping is always possible at yurts or road cafes (for safety reasons this is more sensible), and often spontaneous invitation from private individuals and even meals etc. ask for money, give what you would pay at a cheap hotel ('reimburse costs').
Sleeping.body_hostels: In general, hotels for foreigners are quite pricey.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is allowed and is possible everywhere. Certainly in the mountains, there is always a spot on a river. In the busy valley along the Tsjoe it is difficult to find a place because the valley is narrow and there is a busy road, a railway line and a wide river.

Transport.body_bus: If there is space, the bicycle can sometimes be taken all the way in the back. Often you have to stand still for the entire ride.
Transport.body_train: A daily train runs from Almaty and Moscow. It is possible to bring a bicycle, although the price sometimes has to be negotiated firmly. On local trains, taking a bicycle with you can usually be done without problems as long as there is space in the compartment. Simply put the bike on the luggage racks.

Visa.body:
Quite a lot of nationalities can enter Kyrgyzstan without a visa, which means you can freely cross the border. Some nationalities need to apply for the e-visa.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Vegetarians can enjoy tasty salads and rice meals. There is not much for sale between the larger towns, sometimes only noodle soup. Then take enough water and food with you. There is always some glutinous rice for sale early in the morning, delicious on the go with fruit, etc.

Stalls on the street
There are regular stalls with water or (lukewarm) soft drinks and some biscuits, but not on all routes. There is nothing at all on the PakMong-LP route after the 1st 35km. Also bring your own in the mountains between LP and PhouKhoun.

Restaurants
Eating in sleeping places is not always so varied but always sufficient, also lots of fruit. Food is fairly reliable, use common sense. In larger towns they sell baguettes and good coffee.

Drinkable water
Tap water is not drinkable and often hardly available. Bottles of water (0.95 liters) are available everywhere. Don't throw the empty bottles away but give them to villagers, they like to reuse them.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Seasons (dry / wet)
Laos has 2 seasons. The rainy season from May to October and the dry season from November to April. November - January: Fairly cool and dry in the north. It can freeze at night in January. In the south (Vientiane and further south in the lowlands) it can be quite warm up to 35 and sometimes 40 degrees.

In February it can reach 30 degrees and sometimes a single shower.
Rain in February or March is exceptional. From April it gets very hot with temperatures above thirty degrees.

Spare parts
Furthermore, bicycle parts are difficult to obtain in Laos, including 28-inch tires. 26-inch tires are widely available.

People.body:
The population is friendly and hospitable. A little more commercial spirit would sometimes be welcome. As a cyclist you are a special attraction, in every village you will be greeted enthusiastically and followed by the children.

Bernadette: "The population is very friendly. When I entered a village, I kept getting the feeling that I was the first tourist ever. Kids ran with me, waving while they yelled "sabajdie!" at me. After a while they leave you alone and go their own way. Sometimes they are very shy, both children and the elderly. The minority groups in Muang Sing can sometimes be pushy. You achieve a lot with humor. Many are now learning English and would like to practice it. Surprisingly many elderly people also speak English or French. They often try to teach you Lao and are very patient in this. Appropriate attire desired i.e. no very shorts or dresses, no bare bellies and no public affection, always be patient and smile. Cycling shorts are accepted as long as you are on the bike because this is sport. Covering arms and legs completely in temples is appreciated and advised."

Safety.body:
Cycling alone is no problem, not even as a woman. Laos is a very safe country.

Laos is the most bombed country in the world (during the Vietnam War), many of the explosives did not detonate, almost the whole country was bombed, but the area around Phonsavan (plain of jars) was the worst affected. Never put your foot (or your bike or tent) in a place where someone has not clearly been before you.
Safety.body_traffic:
The road from Vientiane to Luang Prabang is safe. Not all roads in Laos are always completely safe. It is wise to inform yourself of the current situation. In general, the road conditions are poor, with the exception of some main connections.

There is little traffic, a small number of passenger cars, a little truck traffic and a relatively large number of tourist buses and pick-ups. In and around the major cities, especially Vientiane, it is very busy with motorized traffic.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Camping is very unusual. It is possible to spend the night in Buddhist temples.
Sleeping.body_hostels: You will regularly find simple guesthouses in the villages along the main roads. Pay attention! Some guesthouses are also brothels. In a number of touristic places that are often visited by backpackers you will often find a wider choice of guesthouses. In 2013 you pay about 80,000 kip (= about 8 $) for a double room in tourist areas. In the lesser known places you can find cheaper accommodation.

Transport.body_boat: From Thailand you can reach Laos on the Mekong River. You can board in Chiang Khong, Nakhon Phanom or Thakhek, among others.
Transport.body_bus: The bicycle can be transported without problems on top of a local bus without paying extra for it.
Transport.body_train: From Thailand you can take the train to Nong Khai. From there you can cycle across the Friendship Bridge to Vientiane.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Laos. If you come from one of the neighboring countries, you can get the visa at the border crossing.

You can easily have your visa extended, costs are approximately US $ 2.50 per day (price level 2015) + a fixed amount for the application (also approximately US $ 2.50). This can be done at the provincial police office in Luang Prabang (location). There is always a night between application and delivery.


Visa policy of Laos
  Laos
  Visa-free (30 days)
  Visa-free (15 days) or eVisa (30 days)
  Visa-free (14 days) or eVisa (30 days)
  Visa on arrival (30 days) or eVisa
  Visa required in advance
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: While traveling in Latvia please keep in mind - a lot of interesting marked bicycle trails are not paved. I prefer traveling here with my mountain bike because of wider tires and shock absorbers for gravel roads. When wet it might be hard to ride non-paved rods with narrow tires. The best and most precise maps for Latvia you can find at http://balticmaps.eu . They also have a free iPhone application ( http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/baltic-maps/id437264448 ) and Android phones application.

Corona.body:
You can find all the latest Covid-19 statistics, including breakdowns by geographical location and age, at this official website.

A summary in English of the latest Covid-19 situation including restrictions in place and rules on public assembly is available  at this special government website.

Use of nose and mouth coverings is compulsory in all public places indoors, including workplaces, and there are restrictions on what goods can be bought from stores. Physical distancing and frequent hand washing and sanitary cleaning habits are encouraged.

The current state of emergency runs until April 6 and the current "quiet period" restrictions regarding Covid-19 have been extended until then. However, some changes might follow depending on the epidemiological situation.
The dedicated Hotline for Covid-19 related injuries (24 hours, 7 days a week) is 8345. The number for medical emergencies is 113.

All arrivals to the country (including returnees) need to fill in an electronic declaration prior to coming to Latvia. It is available at the website covidpass.lv.
Until February 25, entry to Latvia in only allowed for the reasons listed here.
Since January 15 arrivals have needed to show a negative Covid-19 test for a maximum 72 hours before arrival or proof of vaccination or recovery from coronavirus.

FoodDrink.body:
Markets
In Riga you will find the largest market in the Baltic, perhaps in all of Eastern Europe. In 5 large halls you can find just about everything that can be called food: dairy products, meat, fish, vegetables and fruit, bakery products, etc. The offer is really overwhelming.

Supermarkets
Shops have a wider range than those in Lithuania and are more easily recognizable on the outside.

Drinkable water
The tap water is not drinkable: chemical contamination is hardly filtered out of the water. Bottled water is available at the somewhat larger filling stations of Western brands.

People.body: The people seem to be a bit distant at first. But if you approach them and ask something, they will be more than happy to help you. In the countryside, people are also curious about this strange cyclist, because tourists usually linger in the coastal region and the cities. There you will also be able to enjoy the authentic life as it has been for decades.

Safety.body: In Riga you have to be careful with your bike and not just leave it somewhere. With us (Rob & Mel, 2009), the bicycle was even stolen from the hostel hallway, while it was locked to the heater. We were lucky that the police found the bikes the same night. After several city rides in a police van, we then parked our bicycles in a guarded car shed. No problem in the rest of the country !!

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are a number of quite basic campsites scattered around Latvia, normally with a picnic table, a fireplace and, if you’re lucky, a long-drop toilet but no running water. There are normally rubbish bins, but open to wild animals and often full, so it is best if you take all your rubbish with you. The Latvian website ‘MamaDaba’ (Mother Nature) has a map showing the location of and information about these sites. Camping is allowed, but the campfire may be lit only in places intended for it, there is usually a firewood already prepared.
Sleeping.body_hostels: You will find hotels in all possible price ranges. Budget hotels are scarce and very sober.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Across the country, wild camping is allowed, although not on private land (unless with permission) or in protected reserves. 

With 531 km of coastline, one of the nicest places to sleep in Latvia is in the forest bordering the Baltic sea. This is possible in many guesthouses, but it is also allowed to pitch your tent near the sea, only not in the dunes. (However a hammock is not taking any space on the ground:) ) There is nothing better than waking up to the sound of the sea and going for a swim in the morning light. 

Please, whenever camping in nature, take everything away with you and of course do not camp in any restricted or protected areas.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body:
The country is very varied. The different types of climates and landscapes alternate quickly. Sometimes five kilometers is enough to drive in a completely different landscape.

Clothing
In Beirut you can walk around with short sleeves, also in the Muslim part. You don't have to cover your arms in the other Christian villages and cities either. Do not provoke in the Islamic or Druze villages and towns. Headscarves are only needed in mosques.

FoodDrink.body:
Lebanon's cuisine is world famous. Mezze, a collective name for various snacks and sauces, you can eat in any restaurant, such as malttabal (a delicious smoked eggplant pasta) and hummus (mashed chickpeas with olive oil).

Main dishes are often with meat, which we know from our Turkish restaurants, such as kebab and shawarma or falafel. Lebanon has good fish restaurants along the coast and trout farms in the Bekaa valley that are also restaurant and hotel. You can also buy a lot of snacks, often bread with shawarma, falafel, hummus, or fries and tomato. Furthermore, many pizzas for sale, which is a good breakfast. Try the Lebanese pizza with thyme and poppy seeds. Bread is often round and flat and old quickly. Snacks are very cheap.

Drinkable water
Water is available in plastic bottles. In the mountains there are many springs with wonderfully pure water. People drink a lot of coffee and tea, and soft drinks, beer and wine are also available everywhere.

Health.body:
Mandatory vaccinations
If you come from a yellow fever area, yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.

Useful vaccinations for cyclists
A DTP vaccination is recommended, as is protection against Hepatitis A. Typhoid fever vaccination is recommended when traveling longer than 2 weeks.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Spring and fall are ideal. Summer is too hot and muggy, especially on the coast and in the Bekaa valley. In winter there is a lot of rain along the coast and in the mountains. In April and May it can still be very cold in the mountains.

Safety.body_traffic:
It is actually too busy for cycling along the narrow coast. Many big highways and people drive like idiots. It is allowed to cycle on the motorway, there is a wide, reasonably clean hard shoulder, which is good for cycling. It is not pleasant cycling. 10 kilometers north of Beirut you can temporarily cycle along the boulevard, then a service road follows through villages along the coast to Byblos. Watch out for taxis and buses. They often misjudge the cyclist's speed (or they don't want to see the cyclist) and cut you frequently.

The roads in the Bekaa Valley are low-traffic. From the airport, which is located south of Beirut, the first part is quiet, a few kilometers quite busy and then you can cycle to the center of Beirut via the coast.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: The people are very hospitable and you are invited when night falls and there is no hotel in the village.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: The campsite at Amchit is recommended, cheap, clean and beautiful views. A nice alternative to Byblos (accommodation is very expensive there).
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels are of reasonable to good quality almost everywhere. Prices are quite high, especially in the Middle East.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible, but almost unnecessary in such a small country.

Visa.body:
The visa policy of Lebanon differs quite a lot per nationality. 


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Completely surrounded by South Africa, it is one of the few countries that is completely above 1000 meters. The central and north-eastern mountain ranges peak a little above 3000 meters; you have to like climbing when you come here to cycle, especially if you take the gradients into account.

There is plenty of accommodation, although not cheap, but life, on the other hand, is cheaper than in South Africa. The population is very friendly and hospitable.

b89d695d-2d55-4909-ae6c-f0e7de417dcd.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

FoodDrink.body:
In the smaller towns there is not much choice, sometimes only in your guesthouse. 

Drinkable water
  • Water from the tap is better to avoid.
  • Klaas: "You can occasionally find cool water from streams along the way. Just make sure there are no livestock grazing above. This water was fine to drink, it left me with nothing."
  • January 2016, drought and the government cut off mains water in eastern Lesotho. You can buy water in the shops.

Other.body:
See an do
Note from Cycle Planet: If you want, you can add these bullet points as markers to the map, and delete this piece of text.
  • Those who do not only like to conquer the heights by bicycle, can climb the Thabana-Ntlenyana, with its 3482m the highest mountain in southern Africa. The trip of about ten hours can be organized from the Sani Lodge, with or without a guide.
  • Thaba Bosiu is the most important historical sight and is also fun to do: climb for an hour to the grave of Moshoeshoe I. The guide in the visitor center asks only 10M / pp (less than one euro). You can do the tour on your way from Maseru to TY or you can spend the night in nearby accommodation.
  • Near Leribe and ... you will find dinosaur footprints.
  • From Afriski to Butha buthe you pass the Liphofung cave. Rock paintings of the San people.
  • It is fantastic to cycle over the Sani Pass. It can be cold and bleak. The road on the Lesotho side is paved by the Chinese and is already largely made of concrete. On the South African side, the very steep road full of hairpin bends is of abysmal quality. Be especially careful when going down this road. On the pass you will find the 'highest pub in Africa', a great place for a break. You can also spend the night there, lodge and camping area. I don't get much of cycling with my luggage, it took me at least four hours, pushing the bike that is.
Nice routes
  • Ludwig: "My journey (lenth: one week): Maseru - Teya-Teyaneng (via Thaba Bosiu) - Leribe - Pitseng - Ha Lejone - Katse - Thaba-Tseka - Mantsonyane (lift back to Maseru).
  • The north-western road leads to the Sani pass and Southern Africa's highest mountain, Thabana-Ntlenyana (3482 m).
  • From south to north through Lesotho is a beautiful route. Underberg-Sani Pass. Mokhotlong- Afriski (a ski resort in May) - Butha buthe. You can then continue to Maseru or back again via Pitseng and towards Sani pass. I cycled through the Caledonspoort and Clarens to the Golden Gate Highland National Park.
Best time to cycle
Ludwig: "I cycled there for a week in August, with good weather, warm during the day (+ 20 °), cold in the evening. Also easy to do in January, around 25 degrees during the day and around 5 degrees Celsius at night.

Spare parts
Get to South Africa as soon as possible if you need spare parts. I was able to contact the MTB rental company of the Malealea Lodge. He had a new and appropriate derailleur pad for me.

People.body: The population is very friendly and hospitable. "Security" Lesotho has a reputation for being safe. The language is Sesotho, many people speak good English, here and there someone speaks some South African. 'Hospitality'

Safety.body_traffic: The asphalt roads are in very good condition, the gravel roads a little less (see existing cycle routes). There is little cycling in Lesotho; therefore little consideration is given to cycling. Especially in Maseru you have to watch out for traffic that cuts you off, etc. In other places it is less busy. 'Presence of (separate) cycle paths'

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: If you cannot find accommodation, you can try to visit the village chief.
Sleeping.body_hostels: You will find lodges in almost every town.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: You can also camp in the wild. Often you can find a place 'out of sight', but when you are discovered, people often find it a bit strange but also fun.

Visa.body:
A few nationalities can enter Lesotho without a visa for a short stay of 14 days. Quite a lot of countries need to apply for the e-visa. For countries who are visa exempt, you can get a free entry stamp at the border.


Visa policy of Lesotho
  Lesotho
  Visa exempt for 90 days
  Visa exempt for 14 days
  eVisa

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: This country isn’t particularly known for its best cycling routes. In fact, cycling in Liberia can be quite though and demotivating. As one of the poorest countries, don’t expect good facilities and food. The many rain makes most of the roads nearly inaccessible. But hey, if you like real raw adventure, this might be the place to be. And maybe you find some inner truths about yourself, since that’s what though places do.

-MGMc2iFp65kTB3mTrXU.description: Quite straightforward visa application. Fill in the form and bring a passport photo. It takes 1 or 2 days to pick up the visa.

Onroad: Rice with fish (±200 LRD) 
Local food: Rice, bushmeat, fish
Local drink: Palm wine

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Most cities have accommodation. Room with fan should be around LRD 1.000, with AC a bit more. Expect bucket showers.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

-MGKTcaPlR4Ve7PnQK7Y.title: Wet feet in West Africa's Jungle

Visa.body:
A visa is required for most nationalities (grey).

Source: Wikipedia.

People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.
