FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
Spark plugs with gas are readily available at do-it-yourself stores, such as Senukai. It is also best to look for gas tanks with screw thread in these stores, but you will not always find them.

Supermarkets
In the cities there are supermarkets where almost everything is available. In the larger villages there is usually a local shop where basic items such as bread, vegetables and fruit are available. However, the range of fresh fruit and vegetables is often very limited (apples, potatoes, onions, tomatoes and cabbage are the most common).

Restaurants
Lithuanian cuisine has many similarities with Northern European and Slavic cuisine. The base is usually potatoes. As for meat, the schnitzel and pork steak are popular.

Drinkable water
Water from wells and springs is almost always drinkable, unless the well is in disuse and the water has become polluted. It is recommended to be careful when drinking tap water. Drinking water from bottles is available everywhere.

Health.body: Vaccinations against Tick Encephalitis and Rabies (Rabies) are recommended for people who spend a lot of time in the great outdoors. This includes, for example, campers.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Summer (June-September) is best for cycling here. The daytime temperature is then 18 degrees or higher. Remember to bring warm clothes and a rain suit. You can also suffer from mosquitoes during this time of year.

People.body: The people seem to be a bit distant at first. But if you approach them and ask something, they will be more than happy to help you. Of course people in the countryside are also curious about this strange cyclist, tourists want to stay mainly in the coastal region and the cities. In the countryside you will also be able to enjoy the authentic life as it has been for decades.

Safety.body_traffic: Numbered roads, especially those with a two-digit number, can be busy. On other roads it is generally calm to quiet, although closer to the larger towns it can be busy. Overtaking cars on asphalt usually go all the way to the left and therefore leave enough space. In contrast, gravel roads are driven hard, without regard for space, dust and other inconveniences.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Campsites are often no more than a lawn with a tap from which fresh water comes out. There is still a toilet, but a shower is often unknown. The price is usually not in proportion to the offer. Some campsites have huts in which you have every comfort.

Campsites in the national parks are usually slightly better equipped, often on the banks of the rivers that run through them. At the same time, these campsites also serve as a meeting place for kayakers who want to sail down the rivers.
Sleeping.body_hostels: You will find hotels in all possible price ranges. Budget hotels are scarce and very sober.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: With the exception of the national parks, it is officially allowed to camp freely. There are many good places to be found.

Transport.body_bus:
Bus company Kautra advertises that they transport bicycles for free. Some of their buses are equipped with special racks to hang the bicycles on the back of the bus. However, if there is not much luggage in the hold, the bicycle will be transported there sooner. With other bus companies, it depends on the space and the mood of the driver whether the bicycle is allowed.

You can view all timetables at http://www.autobusubilietai.lt. Here, a bicycle symbol indicates which buses can take bicycles.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body: Luxembourg can easily be seen as an odd duck compared to its neighboring countries. It's so small that you can pass it in a single day, however, there are definetly some castles you might want to see.

FoodDrink.body: Food and drink are everywhere. At many cafes you can eat good hot food between midday and evening for not too much money.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The most suitable period is May to mid-October.

People.body: Luxembourgers have their own language, Letzeburgs, related to German. The official language is French, but you can also use German well and English is also mastered by a part of the population.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
Zimmer frei: This formula is also very popular in Luxembourg. Usually the operators of small guesthouses try to attract tourists in this way. A good alternative if you want to be more comfortable in the evening. Private individuals and farms also try to earn some extra money in this way.

Gite d'etappe: Just like in France and Wallonia, you also have them in Luxembourg. In addition, there is also a form of farm tourism that can be interesting for cyclists. A list of these different forms can be obtained from the Association pour la Tourisme Rural, 48 route de Bastogne, L-9176 Niederfeulen, tel 00352-82720.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Luxembourg has the highest camping density in the world. Usually these campsites are full of overnight campers all year round, but our own experience shows that there is always a place for individual cyclists. Be careful not to camp too close to the shore; in a short time the water can rise considerably and the terrain is easily submerged.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
The absence of individual shower cubicles is characteristic of Luxembourg youth hostels. There are showers, but mostly in the form we know from our swimming pools. Fortunately, the rural youth hostels still have that cozy atmosphere of yesteryear. Some still have old-fashioned dormitories, but usually there are also small rooms. You can always count on a decent dinner after a day of exercise. The youth hostels are within walking distance of each other and are often used by hikers.

It seems that children up to the age of eight are not welcome everywhere; so inform well in advance.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Although there are good spots to be found, it is difficult to camp wild. Close attention is paid to the leftovers of nature. In any case, make sure you get out very early in the morning, because lumberjacks are relentless when they catch you. Don't expect to get permission from private owners anytime soon to camp on their property.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body: The reason to go to Macedonia are the pristine, varied mountainous landscape and the unique Orthodox churches and monasteries, many hundreds of which are scattered across the country in the most beautiful places in nature (rock and cave churches on Lake Ohrid!) , with architecture all its own, ancient artistic frescoes, beautiful carvings, lively services, beautiful chants, and priests explaining everything in good English.

FoodDrink.body:
Macedonia has some unique dishes. Sopska salad (with lots of soft goat cheese) is delicious. Popular is Avier (with lots of soft peppers in oil), you have to love that. Selsko meso (stew of all kinds of meat) is always delicious.

Drink: Kruskovec (pear liqueur) and of course Rakija from grapes or plums (usually distilled in our own home distilleries; nevertheless of reasonable to good quality).

Macedonians are very good at ice cream (sladoled): in many flavors and very tasty. Also special: Seksi salad (upright banana with two scoops of ice cream next to it, covered with small nuts), well ...

Cooking fuel
White gasoline for gas fires is very difficult to find. Simple piercing cartridges for camping gas fires can be found everywhere.

Markets
Most food is bought in the large covered markets, where it is always fresh.

Supermarkets
Large supermarkets can be found in all cities. In the villages you can go to the village shop, always located near the bus station. In large cities you will find the large supermarkets Tinex and Vero, which are most comparable to a Lidl. In small villages you have to ask about the Cooperatia. This is the old Jugoslav name for (communist) convenience store. The word Coöperatia from a foreign mouth always breaks the ice.

Restaurants
Restaurants are almost exclusively found in the cities. Beyond that you have to look carefully. Roadside eateries (Kelapcilnica) are much cheaper and more authentic than the restaurants.

Drinkable water
Tap water is drinkable in all major cities. In some villages it is better to rely on bottled water.

Other.body:
Nice routes
The road from Struga to Debar is beautiful, through a beautiful valley and very quiet. Especially the northern part is special: beautiful views and in the remote villages there everyone waves and smiles at you cheerfully.

Best time to cycle
June to mid September, later it is often too cold. The best time is mid June (dry until late August)

Spare parts
There are bicycle repair shops and bicycle shops in all large and medium-sized cities. In Skopje is a good one near the city park (football stadium) almost next to the cafe "van Gogh" Then you can e.g. get a blow out of your wheel or have damage repaired after the flight.

People.body:
They are generally very friendly, especially in the more remote areas. People chat quickly. Most younger people speak some English. You also regularly meet people who, for example, worked in Germany for a while, and therefore speak German.

There are not really dress codes, only in churches and monasteries etc. long trousers are appreciated. In some Muslim villages bare arms and legs are not appreciated, not even on the road. There is no problem in most of the country.

Safety.body: The country is safe. There is less crime on the streets than in most Western countries. You will not be bothered anywhere. John: "We met an English (blonde!) cyclist who said she was treated very friendly everywhere and that she was often invited."
Safety.body_criminality: John: "There are warnings about ethnic tensions in areas with large Albanian minorities, but we felt very safe there. This is partly because Macedonia has adopted the EU's proposals on minority rights. (Tetovo) now has an official Macedonian university with Albanian as the language of instruction). Especially if you speak a few words of Albanian, they want to do everything for you. "
Safety.body_nature: Dogs aren't an issue here.
Safety.body_traffic:
There are no real cycle paths. However, there are many new motorways; we as cyclists benefit greatly from this, because instead of renovating the old roads, they are laying the new highways next to them. This way you can drive through a large part of the country on the old roads. This is extremely quiet (one tractor every half hour) and the roads are beautiful. The quality does vary, the asphalt is broken in some parts. You can find these routes on good maps: two main roads are indicated next to each other.

Skopje, in particular, is very busy, yet there is also more and more cycling here (and not just along the river)

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: At the monastery you can spend the night very well for next to nothing; sometimes you don't even have to pay anything and only a donation is requested.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are not many campsites. Around Lake Ohrid you will find some (avto camp or авто-камп). There is also a camping site at Lake Doirani, near the border with Greece.

Strictly speaking, wild camping is illegal, but many Macedonians often do it, especially at festivities. It is doable, because there are many places where you will never be seen. Furthermore, the average Macedonian will really have no problem with it.
Sleeping.body_hostels: The hotels are very cheap.

FoodDrink.body:
Markets and small shops can be found in the main villages. There are no supermarkets, with a few exceptions in the capital (Shoprite). On the other hand, there are many shops where you can buy enough food and drink, including baguette (very light in terms of weight, especially a lot of air).

Food and drinks are available at various places along the road. Above all, it is rice-rice-rice. Rice for breakfast, rice for lunch, rice for dinner and even boiled rice water as an accompanying drink. Sometimes also zebo meat. Few vegetables. For breakfast, the fried dough with some bananas do quite well. You can buy it fresh in most villages.

Restaurants
Restaurants (hotelys) are plentiful. But there is still a lot to learn in the field of hygiene. More variety can be found in hotels. Lots of fish and French cuisine is also known here. There are some tasty fish for sale. On the coast, the prawns are unsurpassed. The country is generally not very suitable for vegetarians. In the big cities you can go to the restaurant who run Indians.

Drinkable water
Tap water is only found in the cities and is usually chlorinated there. Sometimes it looks brown and dirty. Bottled water is available almost everywhere (approx. 0.50 euros per 1½ liter bottle).

It is recommended to bring a water filter or purification tablets. Sometimes the distances are too great, taking extra water bottles or jerry cans with you is highly recommended.

Health.body:
In addition to vaccinations against DTP, Abdominal Typhoid, Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B, Malaria prophylaxis, a rabies vaccination is recommended. In the case of bite / lick / scratch from an animal infected by rabies, you do not need to receive MARIG within 24 hours. This is a blood product that is very difficult to obtain in these types of countries. A vaccination gives you much more time to find a doctor and start treatment. Vaccination for yellow fever should also be considered.

If you sleep in hotels, you must bring a mosquito net. Of course, the white man also needs a good sunscreen. Good cap that protects your face and neck from the sun helps against heat stroke.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Madagascar has a tropical climate that is largely determined by the southeast trade. The island is quite large and therefore has several climate zones. Some areas, especially the north and the east have a very wet rainy season. The south is the driest part. Good planning, taking into account the different climate zones is necessary!

During July and  August it is winter in Madagascar. This is generally the best time to ride a bike. In the evenings it can be chilly, especially in the mountains where the temperature can drop to freezing point. Therefore, when taking your clothes with you, always take into account the chance of major differences: extreme heat, solar power, cold, drought, rain and wind.

Spare parts
In Madagascar, people cycle a lot, even in remote places or in areas with mountains. Cheap (Chinese) parts are easily available. The chance that you will find modern Shimano parts is extremely small, there are hardly any specialist tools. We have not seen 28 inch tires anywhere; 26 inch tires, on the other hand, are for sale in every village.

Wherever you cycle (and that is in many places) there are simple bicycle repairmen who are probably very good at improvising.

People.body:
The population is a mix of diverse ethnic groups, more from Malaysia and India than Africa. There are local religious regulations because of the so-called fadis. These are "taboos" usually related to the worship of the dead. There are countless of them. For example, in some areas it is forbidden to shake hands with people. However, it is assumed that the whites are not aware of all the applicable taboos, therefore any "missteps" are turned a blind eye. In fact, it is best to observe the local population and act as they do.

Frank: "The Malgache word for" white man "is" vazaha ", and I think I must have heard that horrible word at least ten million times. When the kids saw me, they all started screaming" white man ", usually of great fun, but sometimes also a few out of fear or completely in panic. The first day that is still cool: 'Look how friendly these children are here!', but the fun quickly ends and in the long run you will experience that constant shouting like nothing but a never-ending psychological torture! "

Others characterize the population slightly differently. Hans and Annemarie: "Friendly, enthusiastic and curious, especially if you are that yourself. However, they are not pushy, but rather wait until the ice is broken. There is no question of any animosity. People think it is great that world cyclists in their country can and want to travel such great distances."

Safety.body:
Madagascar is known as a safe country. But ... It is, of course, Africa. It is unwise to go down the street in cities in the dark, in villages you can handle this more relaxed. So plan well to be at your destination well before dark. 

A "strange" area is the region of the opal mines in the south of the island, including between Tulear and Ilakaka. There is a lawless "wild west" atmosphere there. Not really pleasant to stay longer than necessary.
Safety.body_criminality:
Never take a lot of money with you in your wallet, only money for that day safely store the rest. Also a good idea not to flaunt expensive electronics such as SLR cameras, watches...

Nice to put your passport in the bottom of your bags and have copies validated at the police station in Antananarivo (5 min work). Provide multiple validated copies of Visa and Passport and do not keep them in the same place. Validated copy is valid at police / banks.

Several people. both locals and tourists, warned me about Zebu robbers with guns in the south below Tulear / Fianarantsoa line. They steal cows (Zebu) from each other to prove their manhood. In the course of time they would have increased interest in stripping white tourists.
Safety.body_nature: You will not suffer from dogs, they are too dazed by the heat and insect bites. Ferry: "Alone on the way RN2 had two false dogs chasing me, otherwise never seen such relaxed dogs."
Safety.body_traffic: Outside the cities there is hardly any traffic, so the main road is fairly quiet. All other roads are extremely quiet.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: When the distances become too great, the population appears to be hospitable, although some will experience this differently than others. Villagers are usually poor and their meager houses are already full of children and other family members, so calling on hospitality will not always be easy.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites, but you can sometimes camp next to a hotel. There are not many hotels, sometimes you also have old information (map, GPS data). In case you can't find anything, people are often very helpful. In remote villages you ask "Chef de Ville" if you can camp there. In some towns where there was nothing I slept in an electricity house or in a schoolroom, for example, this came from with helpful locals.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
Please note: a hotely (restaurant) is, contrary to what the name might suggest, not a hotel. Confusing, especially because the word hotely sometimes appears as the word hotel on the facade.

Hotels are usually within cycling distance, but sometimes you will have to settle for very basic accommodation. You can always bring your bike inside and you can often store it in your room.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is not a problem, but be careful not to do so in places where there is a "taboo" on it, such as near cemeteries and the like.

Transport.body_airplane: Domestic flights (Air Madagascar) are excellent for covering large distances quickly and relatively cheaply. Check in advance which type is being flown. You cannot take your bicycle with you in the Twin Otter.
Transport.body_bus: Your bike on top of a taxibrousse (small van) is no problem at all. But with 26 people crammed into such a van is a real endurance test.
Transport.body_train: There is a beautiful train line (Fianarantsoa – Manakara). You can easily bring your bike.

Visa.body: Visa on arrival is free. Your passport must be valid for at least 6 months after returning to the Netherlands. Procedure is a bit chaotic at the airport but will be fine. Fill out the form on the plane before arrival. In overcrowded arrival hall to police office (3m x 3m), so not an office with visa on it. There, give your passport + form to the agent in front of the office as soon as he asks for it, not before. He hands it to someone in the office after tearing some off. Your passport then disappears in a big pile with 15 other people who want to enter the country. Then the first officer sternly points you to a place where you have to wait. There you wait 15 minutes. By now you wonder if you will ever see your passport again with all those people around you. But then suddenly you get your passport with visa stamps again and you are ready to go.

About.body: Twenty percent is occupied by Lake Malawi. Malawi borders Tanzania to the north, Zambia to the west and Mozambique to the south and east. The highest peak is over 3000 meters high and the lowlands are almost at sea level. These great contrasts make Malawi's landscape one of the most varied in Africa.

1ea045a7-d52c-42c8-9838-f31b1837f6bf.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

FoodDrink.body:
There is plenty of fruit on the market. There are small and cheap shops everywhere. In addition, in the larger towns there are good (super) markets and shops with Western items at Western prices. Along the way you will meet people who "offer donuts bread or fruit for sale."

Restaurants
Restaurants mainly serve chicken, fish, rice, nsima and chips.

Drinkable water
Many travelers drink the tap water, but many also get sick. You can consider bringing a water filter or disinfectants. Bottled water is widely available in 1.5 liter bottles, in addition of course the indispensable coca-cola. There is a water pump in almost every village. We filtered the water with a Katadyne water filter. Not cheap, but safe.

Health.body:
• A yellow fever vaccination is not required for a visit to Malawi when traveling directly from the Netherlands. This is mandatory when traveling through a neighboring country in the yellow fever area.
  • DTP and Hepatitis A are recommended as well as the use of anti-malaria pills.
  • The road from Lilogwe to Nkotakhota goes right through a park. That is of course very interesting, but there are a lot of tsetse flies here.

Other.body:
Nice routes and places
  • If you want to visit a "real" game park, South Luanga Park is recommended, just across the border in Zambia. You can cycle here from Chipata in a day, 135 km mostly unpaved. Make sure you arrive before dark because of stray animals (lions, elephants, hippos, etc.).
  • Janneke: Majete National Park near Blantyre is really on the rise! This is now also a full-fledged park with opportunities to see the Big5, professionally run by African Parks
  • Highlights of Ton and Henk's journey: Mua Mission, Sucoma Estate, Zomba plateau. Mvuu Camp, boat trip on Lake Malawi. Pleasant places: Balaka, Zomba, Nhkata Bay. Overall impression: good and safe cycling country with dry weather.
  • Bert's highlights: Nyika plateau, Rumpti, Nakatabay, the road from Monkeybay to Zomba and the road from Bangula to the Mozambique border.
  • Jeffrey: It's nice to dive inland for once, it's doable.
  • From lilongwe to the north (M1 or inland): no 'Give me money!' Beautiful nature: Vipha Mountains, Nyika Plateau. Nice cheap game park: Vwaza Marsh NP
Best time to cycle
  • The dry season runs from April to November with temperatures of 20-30 degrees.
  • June to August is a great time to travel in Malawi. It cools down in the evening and at night. It is advisable to bring warm clothes, a sweater and long pants. Sometimes a very strong wind blows from south to north.
  • In the rainy season from December to March it is much warmer and many roads are impassable.
  • In mid-May 2012, it was still raining every day north of Rumphi: the roads were very bad there. The rainy season seems to end later and later in recent years.

Spare parts
The locals cycle a lot and there are bicycle repair places, but it is doubtful whether they have the right equipment for Western bicycles. You regularly see counterfeit Shimano parts in markets such as brakes, derailleurs, brake and gear cables and, occasionally, a 26-inch tire. People are resourceful and helpful in an emergency.

People.body: Incredibly nice people. The main reason to go here! A striking number of people speak quite a bit of English. Many just one sentence (give me money) You won't have any communication problem. In the north they speak little / no English, but Tumbuku. Yet they always round up someone who can speak English.

Safety.body: It is advisable to pay from a small wallet on the go. The smaller and thinner your stock market, the less wealthy you are estimated. Or do as the locals do: collect as much change as possible and keep it in a plastic bag.
Safety.body_traffic:
Traffic runs fairly smoothly. Except in and around Lilongwe and Blantyre, there are not many cars. You drive on the left.

John: "I didn't think the traffic was good at all. A mirror is indispensable: cars expect you to shoot into the verge as they approach and want to overtake you. If you also have an oncoming vehicle, they will still overtake you and there is really no more room for your bike."

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Camping is often possible at hotels or other venues. There are many campsites and lodges run by whites (mostly English). They want their income in dollars, so the prices are right here. The advantage is that you can come for a while and do not eat Nsima for a night.

Jeffrey: "Pitching a tent at a village is allowed. However, always ask permission from the chief of the village first."
Sleeping.body_hostels: At eateries there are sometimes simple accommodation options, the so-called trucker stops. Especially in trading centers there are always a number of guesthouses.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping attracts a lot of attention from the locals.

Transport.body_boat: A boat sails across Lake Malawi that visits various places and islands. There are cabins with beds on board. You can bring the bike.
Transport.body_bus:
There are buses but they are not very frequent, on Sundays sometimes not at all. Bringing bicycles with you is no problem. Mini vans run regularly between the villages and towns.

Marianne: "My experience is that taking the bicycle with you on the bus is not that easy. You want to take every bus with you, but few have the facilities to do that properly. The National Bus Company has a large rack on the back of the roof where you can put your bike. Do bring a few lashing straps."

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa.

Visa policy of Malawi
  Malawi
  Visa exemption
  Visa on arrival or eVisa
  eVisa
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Stalls on the street
Eating in many food stalls is fine (no problem at all). Fruits are plentiful. There is a choice of all kinds of dishes (Chinese, Malay or Indian). In the strict Islamic region around Kota Baru, beer is only available at Chinese restaurants.

There is a lot of choice for vegetarians. On the west coast you will find (Chinese) vegetarian restaurants (restoran sayuran). In the larger towns there are restaurants with display cases where you can choose from, there are many tasty vegetable dishes. Also on the night market you will find enough vegetarian but less extensive.

Drinkable water
Tap water varies in quality, usually drinkable and safe. Drinking water is available in bottles (from half a liter to 2 liters). In many cities there are water taps where you can fill up with liters of filtered water very cheaply. This water is not cooled, but much cheaper than bottled water and you can just put your own water bottles under it.

Health.body:
Malaysia has very good health facilities.

Common Illnesses
  • Tuberculosis.  
  • The dengue mosquito is active in the cities. This mosquito is active during the day. Remedy: use Deet (on top of the sunburn).
  • Malaria is almost non-existent in Malaysia, only in the border area with Borneo (Indonesia).
Useful vaccinations for cyclists
Hepatitis A.
Hepatitis B.
Rabies (rabies)

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
On the east coast it is dry and beautiful in summer (light south wind), the same applies to the west coast in autumn and winter. The wet time on the east coast is between October and February, while that on the west coast is from September to December. At the end of January and the beginning of February there is a strong northerly wind on the east coast.

Spare parts
Bicycle shops can be found in all (medium) large cities, with very decent equipment and sometimes even really good! But also in small villages you can get a 26 "tire.

People.body: Malaysia is a very hospitable country, with a very friendly and non-intrusive population. Cyclists find them very cute. Muslims: 60%, Chinese: 30%; Hindu: 10%.

Safety.body_traffic: West Malaysia on the west coast has a fairly dense road network. The main roads are often very busy here. It is quite possible to look for smaller roads. Many small roads along irrigation canals and rivers are also paved. These are perfect cycle paths. The roads are generally paved and of good quality

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no camping facilities in Malaysia.
Sleeping.body_hostels: The hotels are between 50 and 120 km apart. Although Malaysia is a developed country, the quality of the budget hotels can be disappointing. In Thailand, for example, you get a much better hotel for the same money. Exceptions are the tourist centers.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is allowed.

Transport.body_bus: In the air-conditioned bus from Georgetown to Singapore, the bus could be taken in the luggage hold for a small extra charge
Transport.body_train: Bicycles cannot be taken on the train between Georgetown and KL/Singapore. It is possible to let the bicycle go with a separate carco train. This still has to be transhipped in KL. Very cumbersome and expensive. The bus is a better alternative. Note that if you take the bus to Singapore you get off before the border and take the road for the mopeds through the border.

About.body:
WARNING: AT THE MOMENT, YOU SHOULDN'T GO TO MALI!

Mali was a relatively safe and stable country. Currently, large parts of Mali are designated as 'danger of terrorist actions', among other things due to a number of kidnappings of Westerners. Cyclists are strongly advised not to go there. The southern part (south of the Bamako / Segou line) should still be relatively safe, but vigilance is required and inform yourself well before you decide to go.

FoodDrink.body:
In markets it is often better to find fresh food than in shops, but hitting a market is usually impossible to calculate (In many places only once or twice a week). So always stock up on provisions for a few days. Mangos, papayas, bananas and avocados are offered in villages everywhere (depending on the season). River fish can be found in the harbor town of Mopti, but not really recommended due to a lack of hygiene.

There is usually little fresh produce to be found in the shops. Beware of dust in the food along the way: it is often prepared sitting on the floor. Restaurants are often no more than a few tables in the open air with pre-prepared dishes such as cold limp chips, rice and chicken. If you are lucky you can find well-prepared green beans. In various places, meat is roasted over wood fires, oliebollen (without filling) and other pastries are baked.

Drinkable water
Drinking water comes from wells or pumps outside the cities. The latter usually deliver the best quality, if it contains a good filter, it is directly drinkable. Bottled water is available everywhere in the larger towns and cities, but is expensive. Another alternative is water that is sold in plastic bags: Printed and sealed, it contains controlled drinking water, buttoned tap or pump water and sometimes even well water. Bringing a filter is highly recommended.

Soft drinks (Cola, Fanta, Sprite) are available everywhere and sometimes also beer (including Flag and Guinness).

Health.body: Malaria is the number one enemy of the nation and occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis, etc. are available on site. Yellow fever, DTP and hepatitis A vaccinations are recommended. Healthcare leaves a lot to be desired, Mali is a poor country.

Other.body:
Nice routes
For many, a visit to Dogonland is the highlight of a trip through Mali. Cycling here requires special attention. People are very traditional and easily offended if you enter holy places without realizing it. Bringing a guide is certainly advisable but difficult if you want to cycle. You may find one that wants to ride with you. The motto is to stay on the roads without a guide. The access roads are all easy to cycle on. Bandiagara is a good base for a trip of a few days. The road towards Djiguibombo is of excellent quality. If you want to traverse a larger area and cycle along the Falaise, Sanga is a good starting point. A mountain bike is necessary, the paths between the villages contain sandy stretches.

Spare parts
There is a lot of cycling in Mali, but parts for the modern Western bicycle are not available. An exception is tires, both 26 and 28 inch are available. In the event of a breakdown, you can always get a lift.

People.body: The population is usually very friendly and exuberant. It is taken as an insult to ignore people. The official language is French, those who have been to school speak it. The second language is Bambara and is spoken by everyone in and around Bamako and often further afield. There are also dozens of other languages and dialects.

Safety.body: As mentioned before, currently it's not safe to cycle in Mali.
Safety.body_nature: It is extremely hot from April to June, until the rainy season in the south. 45 degrees in the shade is very normal and, in combination with the bone-dry wind, killer. The north is part of the Sahara and is hot until October. The best time to cycle is from December to March. The temperature is then about 20-35 degrees. It can get quite cool at night, especially in the northern parts of the country. There is almost always a north-east wind. This Harmattan wind sometimes carries so much dust from the desert that visibility is only 500 meters. The sun barely penetrates the dust and the maximum temperature is 25 instead of 35 degrees.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: If you have a chat with this or that person, staying overnight with private individuals is often an option, or ask for the 'Chef de Village' in the village.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: You can sometimes camp at hotels (including Djenné, Sévaré, Tombouctou, Douebtza and Madougou). Usually this means that you can roll out your mat on the roof of the hotel or that you can put your tent on it (if it can be set up without pegs).
Sleeping.body_hostels: In the larger towns there are hotels or the so-called campements (a room with a bed or sometimes just a mattress). Luxury hotels including in Bamako, Mopti, Sevaré and Segou.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible, not even dangerous if you do not stand in high grass (snakes) and be careful with fire. You do get a lot of attention near the villages.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body:
More desert than life, Mauritania can be a pity. But it’s also pleasing to see the transition from the Sahara in the North to a little bit of green in the South. The history of the North African country isn’t very flamboyant, with several recent coups. But for now, like other Western African countries, there is a time of peace and prosperity.

Mauritania is an Islamic country, so adjust your clothes accordingly. Cycling in short cycling shorts is usually without problems, people think it is a sport where this is allowed. When you get off the bike, put on long or 3/4 pants. For women, I would recommend slightly more cover-up clothing than just cycling shorts.

You can get the visa at the border crossing.
1 month, single entry, €55
-MGI-H2eCHExp0_YnkOW.description_first:

1 month, single entry, €55
