FoodDrink.body:
In the shops, outside Nouakchott and Nouadhibou, there is little to be found in terms of fresh. Onions are the only thing you have almost everywhere and with a little luck also potatoes. Furthermore, macaroni and cans of fish, bread and packets of biscuits and that's about it. The Mauritanians themselves mainly eat camel and goat meat.

There are some fruits and vegetables for sale on the market (always bananas). Fish in the interior is anything but fresh: it is usually transported unrefrigerated and often takes days on the road. The dates are delicious, different (darker in color and stronger in taste) than in Morocco, for example. Excellent bicycle food.

Bas (2019): "On the road I mainly ate bread with jam, as there was little to be found on the road. Bread dries out pretty quick due to the temperatures. For dinner I had Thieboudienne a few times, which is a plate with rice, vegetables and meat. Really tasty! A lot of tea is drunken here, which seems to consist out of sugar mainly."

Drinkable water
Drinking water comes from wells outside the cities. The quality is often much better than in other parts of the world. There are not an awful lot of people living there, so the soil is not very polluted and it also comes from great depth, so that it was well filtered. Be careful when drinking the water near livestock. The droppings often contain diseases that you really don't want to get. A Katadyn filter can then be a solution. Bottled water is available everywhere in the larger towns and cities.

Jeroen: "In the northern desert you will find huge PVC bags with drinking water here and there, usually at small (temporary) settlements, such as road workers. You can fill your bottles through a trunk, but make sure that you otherwise the whole bag will empty in the blink of an eye and you won't make many friends with it. Although the water looks good, I would still treat it with disinfectants. "

Health.body: In the south, Malaria occurs all year round. Yellow fever, DTP and hepatitis A vaccinations are recommended. Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed. Healthcare is at a low level. Many westerners therefore prefer to visit clinics in Dakar (Senegal) in case of emergency.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Most precipitation falls in the south, here there is a short rainy season every year. In the desert, years can pass without rain. If this does happen, there could be a major flood in one go.

It is extremely hot from April to October and especially from June to August. 45 degrees in the shade is very normal and, in combination with the bone-dry wind, killer. The best time to cycle is from December to March. The temperature is then about 20-30 degrees. At night it cools down considerably, especially in the interior.

Spare parts
In Mauritania you can hardly get parts for the modern western bicycle. Western rental companies in tourist areas (eg Atar) may be able to help in emergencies. In the event of a breakdown, you can always get a (paid) lift. marcomeijerink: we have seen little or no bicycle repair shop in Mauritania. Certainly not bicycle repairers for western bicycles

People.body:
The people are curious and friendly, but it can be difficult to get in touch with them. You can stay with locals quite often during the harsh ride. Sometimes they stop their car to have a chat with you or to make a picture with you.

The official language is Arabic. In addition, people speak, among other things, Hassaniya, a variant of Arabic. With French you can go anywhere else, those who have been to school speak it. But you often don't need words to drink a cup of tea together.

-MGI6XduUnZfluDlK2u-.description: This route starts at the border with Morocco, passes Nouakchott, and goes to the border with Diama, Senegal.
-MGI6XduUnZfluDlK2u-.title: North to South

Safety.body:
Mauritania is a relatively safe but poor country. In Nouakchott you have to look after your belongings better than in the rest of the country. You regularly come across police posts. Sometimes they ask if you are moving on to the next post or where you are going to sleep. This will be called to the next police station and you will be expected there, so if you deviate from your plan, ask someone to call them. "After an unexpected night of desert camping, I was told that they had searched for me the night before but could not find me."

The fact that the Paris - Dakar rally is no longer organized for security reasons has more to do with the rally as a target than with the security situation in general.
Safety.body_corruption: Bas (2019): "I haven't experienced any corruption. I heard stories that the border with Senegal at Rosso is very corrupt, so try to avoid this border crossing."
Safety.body_criminality:
Coups take place with some regularity. This usually has no influence on the security situation, you can cycle in Mauritania without any problems, even in the capital Nouakchott.

78-year-old French engineer Michel Germaneau was kidnapped in April 2010 by the Maghrebian branch of the Al Qaeda terror network (AQMI), he was later murdered.
Safety.body_nature:
The heat can be dangerous. During the day it can get 45 degrees celsius, and it's impossible to cycle. Try to find a shade and do as less as possible from 1pm to 4 or 5 pm. Before and after this time, it's possible to cycle. During the night would be possible as well, but the roads are not lighted and there are quite some potholes, which can be dangerous in combination with the cars and trucks still passing by.

Sandstorms do occur, so make sure you can cover at least your face.
Safety.body_traffic: Cars drive as in many African country, a little crazy, but somehow it all goes well in most cases. Trucks pass by with high speed, and in combination with the wind, this can be a little dangerous as you will lose your balance.

-MGI3PjoMfMO1PHXMGJh.description: Experience how it is to be an iron ore by hopping on one of the largest trains in the world. The train will bring you from Zouerat to Nouadhibou or otherwise. Plan wisely, because you don’t want to burned alive as the temperatures inland increase a lot.
-MGI3PjoMfMO1PHXMGJh.description_first: Experience how it is to be an iron ore by hopping on one of the largest trains in the world. The train will bring you from Zouerat to Nouadhibou or otherwise. Plan wisely, because you don’t want to burned alive as the temperatures inland increase a lot.
-MGI3PjoMfMO1PHXMGJh.title: Train hitchhike

-MGI3bdO8zH0CPkj9Z22.description: By far the largest city in the otherwise quite desolated country. It’s a nice pitstop after cycling in the Sahara, or a good place to charge before entering it.
-MGI3bdO8zH0CPkj9Z22.description_first: By far the largest city in the otherwise quite desolated country. It’s a nice pitstop after cycling in the Sahara, or a good place to charge before entering it.
-MGI3bdO8zH0CPkj9Z22.title: Nouakchott

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Spending the night with private individuals can be an option. There is a good chance that people will ask for money.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are plenty of campsites in Nouadhibou. Camping Abba and Baie du Lévrier are the best according to Lonely Planet.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
There are hotels in the larger towns and of varying quality.
. Think about 300-800 MRO for the cheapest price.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible almost everywhere. Be aware of the weather, the desert can be surprisingly cold and windy at night. Make sure you have a good storm-proof and sand-proof tent and clean the zippers regularly: due to the sand and dust, they wear out very quickly.

-MGIA-CM5I8dtwT5X2oV.title: A windy Sahara and tropical smiles

Visa.body:
Most nationailities need a visa for entering Mauritania. If you come from Morocco, you can get a visa at the border. Coming from Senegal it's likely that you can get a visa at the border as well, but we're not sure (please update if you know).


Source: Wikipedia.

Corona.body:
As for Mexico City cyclist are allowed to roll on the streets and establishments request the use of mask such as restaurants and shops in general. Cycle shops are open although some of them do not sell bikes but parts or replacements as well as repairs and bike service.
malls are not open and replacements are lacking a bit.

FoodDrink.body:
The Mexican cuisine belongs to one of the best in the world. You'll find many corn, chilli and tomato based product, combined with chicken. Horchata is a wonderfully cooling drink, made by the owners themselves. 

Markets
Where it's busy you can safely eat, for little and often very good

Supermarkets
There are supermarkets in cities.

Stalls on the street
Here too, where it's busy you can safely eat, we haven't gotten sick once in 3 months

Restaurants
There are plenty of (cheap) restaurants. The quality of the food is good. Yummy sandwiches and pastries! And of course tortillas. Vegetarian dishes are also available.

Drinkable water
Only drink bottled water. These are readily available. We always bought 20 liter bottles, there is a deposit, it is much better for the environment and actually also for your wallet, relatively much cheaper.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In December, January and February the temperature is most suitable for cycling. Virtually no precipitation. Temperature ranges from 25 to 35 degrees. In Yucatán it is 25 to 30 degrees all year round. The rainy season is from May to mid-October. It rains a lot, but often only in the afternoon. There are major floods in the mountains. The dry season is of course also the busiest season. The quietest, cheapest and dry time is from mid-October to mid-December. It is very hot in March and April. On the Altiplano it is cool in December and January (about 20 degrees), but dry. On the southeastern lowlands then drizzly, rainy weather prevails.

Spare parts
The flatter the environment, the more chance of racing bike parts (also 700mm). The standard are mountain bikes with 26 inch wheels. There are reasonable bicycle repair shops in the major cities.

People.body: Generally speaking people are polite, friendly and curious. People can be very empathetic such as the time I got myself in the night in the highway and other fellow cyclist in his car lit up the road for me for about 50km.

QuickFacts.climate: Mostly Sunny. Lowest: 10 degrees and Highest: 28 average (From February to November). December and January are colder in both morning and night. May up to August is rain time (normally)
QuickFacts.sim_card: Telcel, Movistar, At and T, Unefon, Iusacell

Safety.body:
Campeche is safe in Yucatan; in Chiapas it is certainly not safe. Wilco, however, indicates that the security situation has improved recently. The tourist info indicated that it was also safe in Chiapas.

As a woman alone it is fine to do but you do need to endure whistling and yelling. However, no obstacles. For the night it's better to of stay with local families.
Safety.body_nature: Keep in mind that it can get hot inland. So drink a lot.
Safety.body_traffic: The Mexicans drive like crazy, but that seems to bother you more as a driver than as a cyclist. The closer you get to Mexico City, the worse it gets. Cycling in the dark is suicide. You can cycle on the highway if there is no other way.

225f974c-a8d3-4460-9f8a-5de5b93a1721.description: Downtown: you can find buildings related to the arrival of the Spanish to the ancient Mexico
225f974c-a8d3-4460-9f8a-5de5b93a1721.title: Downtown

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Except in tourist places such as Yucatán, there are few official campsites. These campsites are usually geared to campers, and are therefore not attractive for cyclists. Sometimes you can be with families or in villages, always in consultation. 

There are quite a few campsites in Baja California (called "trailer park"). Sometimes there is even a patch of grass. In smaller towns along main roads you will often find restaurants with showers, geared towards truck drivers. Usually you can camp behind the restaurant. Camping is also often possible at swimming pools (balnearios)."
Sleeping.body_hostels: Only the larger or touristic places have accommodation options. There are also hotels along the main roads, albeit at irregular distances. The distance between the hotels is sometimes up to 120 km. If you camp (in villages) staying overnight is not a problem. Bike can be taken anywhere in the room.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is allowed, but not recommended. Along the road there are few possibilities for wild camping due to (jungle-like) vegetation.

Transport.body_bus: Buses are very cheap and luxurious (with air conditioning). The bike can easily be taken in the luggage hold of the local slow and express bus. It is best to board at the starting station; there is sometimes little space along the way. It is advisable to buy a ticket in advance to ensure seats on the long-distance buses. Local taxi vans (the colectivos), if equipped with a roof rack, will also take you.

Visa.body:
A few countries can enter Mexico without a visa.


  Mexico
  Countries with visa-free access to Mexico
  Electronic Visa Authorization
  Visa required for entry to Mexico
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
Most villages do have a small shop where the basic products, such as bread, drinks, spreads, pasta and beer, are available.

Restaurants
Restaurants can be found along the main roads and in the larger towns. These usually have a fairly extensive menu. For about 5 euros you can get a meal with meat, potatoes, salad and a beer. There are enough restaurants to have a hot meal every day.

Drinkable water
In some areas there are wells along the road. In general, this water is pure and suitable for drinking. The locals do that too. Mineral water is also sold in the shops. In general, that is mineral water with bubbles.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In summer it can be very hot in Moldova. Temperatures above 30 degrees Celsius are no exception. The temperatures in spring and autumn are more pleasant.

Spare parts
Moldova is a poor country, with only one real city. Parts can probably be obtained in Chisinau, but that should not be assumed. It is wise to bring spare parts yourself.

People.body:
The people are a bit distant. Especially in Transnistria, which has seceded from Moldova. The detachment is probably left over from the time of the Soviet Union. Very few tourists come to Moldova, especially the countryside. People are not used to tourists.

Tom: "Although Moldova is the poorest country in Europe, I never had the idea that people wanted to rip me off. It simply does not occur to them that they can ask twice as much for a bar of chocolate. In The people of Transnistria were a bit surly. People who work at "official" agencies, such as customs and the police, all want to make money from you and come up with all kinds of excuses to get money. Abuse of power is not shunned."

Romanian is spoken in Moldova. Because Moldova used to be part of the Soviet Union, many people also speak Russian. Mostly Russians live in Transnistria that seceded from Moldova. Only Russian is spoken there.

Not many people speak a foreign language like English or German. The people who do speak English or German generally live in Chisinau. Incidentally, it is usually the young people who speak English or German.

Safety.body:
Security is good in Moldova. 

Cyclists passing through from Chisinau to Odessa can pass through Transnistria. The distance is about 50 kilometers and is almost flat. However, it is wise to set aside a whole day for it. It is quite a test of your patience to cross the "border". The speed can be increased the more willing you are to pay. Euros and dollars are always welcome.

Wilbert Thoonen: "On the way from Chisinau to Odessa, there is also a smaller alternative route so you don't have to go through Transnistria."
In Transnistria, the "government apparatus" is corrupt from the outset.

Officials see tourists as a source of additional income. The police will quickly try to blame you for a certain crime, driving on the left unnecessarily or cycling on the road. It is normal to negotiate the amount of the fine with the police. Be firm that you have done nothing wrong (although that is sometimes difficult, because the police do not "understand") English. The longer you keep it up, the more the fine goes down. Keep in mind that Transnistria is not recognized by any country. There is therefore no embassy that can stand up for you if you end up in jail for whatever reason.
Safety.body_corruption: There are a lot of police around. These are mainly found at the major intersections and in the capital Chisinau. There also seem to be corrupt police officers looking to supplement their meager salaries. It is wise to always have (copies of) your passport with you. This is regularly requested. You can be fined if you can't show them.
Safety.body_traffic: There is little traffic on the road until about 100 kilometers before Chisinau. It is busy in Chisinau and the surrounding area. It is not too busy to not be able to cycle normally. However, care must be taken for buses. If they see customers standing by the road, they can suddenly cut you off. In rural areas, drivers generally honk when they want to overtake you. It is intended as a warning, not to push you into the verge.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are few campsites in Moldova. The quality is probably such that it is better to go wild camping.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: It is not known whether wild camping is legal. There are plenty of opportunities for wild camping in the countryside.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Moldova without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
If you like endless green, undulating hills (the steppe) with sporadic white dots (gers, the nomad tents), horses and sheep, and rough husks with white kernels (the Mongols) then you have 3 good reasons to visit Mongolia .

And if you also like to pitch your tent where and when it suits you, and you like quiet unpaved roads, undulating but not too steep, then you have two bonus reasons to make your next cycling trip in this country.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
Gasoline at the gas pump.

Markets
Container markets in the larger towns, a good source to stock up on food.

Supermarkets
In every village of significance there is a supermarket...or what passes for it. Note the sun-drenched billboards with vegetables and a bottle of coke. You will then enter a booth with a long counter. And you don't see everything you want, but is at the bottom on the other side of the counter. (onions, carrots and potatoes) It is therefore best to look carefully over it. What you do see are all the sweets that the Mongolians are so fond of. And they also sell long-life yoghurts, ideal as a spread. This is mainly because the bread is always old.

Stalls on the street
There are no real stalls on the street, but there are small shops where stocks for preparing your own jar are limited to a kind of pasta, garlic, onions with a bit of luck, a few peppers, a tube of tomato concentrate and so on.

Restaurants
In the capital there are countless eateries, outside you will often find small restaurants at the intersection of roads. Usually there are trucks parked there. The classic food consists of noodles with some vegetables and pieces of mutton, whether or not processed as soup. You should not expect culinary delights. Vegetarians will also have a hard time getting their money's worth. Buuz (meat in a dough package) and a fried larger version of Buuz is great.

"I am normally vegetarian, but I had resolved to eat meat if there really was no other option. I see no objection to meat in Mongolia. In my opinion, the animals are treated well there. It is very good in UB possible vegetarian food I have even seen a vegetarian restaurant there but many other restaurants have vegetarian food on the menu however it is more difficult outside UB The problem already arises because I can not read Cyrillic I was sorry that I It is then difficult to order food (even if you are not vegetarian) We usually looked at other people's plates and indicated what we wanted to eat. What I noticed is that most restaurants do have fries have on their menu and salad (the sweet and sour from a jar), sometimes fried egg. We also cooked a lot ourselves, then it is no problem to eat vegetarian. Also in Harhorin I found a restaurant that etarian food, Morin Jim. Was a nice restaurant too, just like a saloon."


Drinkable water
Mineral water is readily available in bottles but the distances at which you can find it are often large so you should take a supply and replenish it when you can. A water filter can be useful if ... there is water in the rivers you cross. Often cattle are trampling in the remains of water in such dense throngs that it is an unappealing alternative. Tap water is not completely reliable. One solution is to purify with micropur or chlorine drops. Where there is a ger there is also a water source not very far. The water tastes very metallic, even after filtering.

Buying bottled water is a shame - all those plastic bottles. So bring a water filter with you. Each pitch has a water house with a pump. We drank this water untreated. The people who live in a ger often know where the source of the source is. We also often drank from a stream of water that we purified with a filter. Keep in mind that some parts are very dry, so always take water with you for more than a day.

Health.body: It is recommended that you get vaccinated against rabies and tick-borne encephalitis.

Other.body:
Fun tracks
The route Bayanhongor to Tstetserleg was very tough, but very beautiful.

Best time to cycle
Because of the harsh climate, you can only travel in a 'normal' way in July and August and even then you can expect very variable weather conditions. Plenty of sun and 40° and hail and thunderstorms and barely 10°. I cycled there in August and September. In August to Dalandzadgad (south) with temperatures above 50 degrees. And in September to Tsetserleg (west) and back to Ulaan Bator with long cycling shorts and around freezing point in the night.

The wind is usually from the north or northwest. Don't worry about the prevailing wind direction because during our round we encountered it almost everywhere.

Spare parts
You may be able to find some simple parts at the large market in UB. It is best to bring your own spare.

Tips
  • Eat fresh cottage cheese with a little sugar, stir and enjoy!
  • When you get a menu in a restaurant, immediately ask what is there.....
  • Eat steaks and baked potatoes at Bert in Terelj National Park. You do have to stay in his eco (primitive) gerkamp, but that is not a punishment. You have to love his hum about Mongolians, but luckily you can also enjoy cycling with his two sons. Horseback riding with his brother-in-law is also an absolute must.
  • Ikh Nart National park: beautiful nature reserve where you can still spot ibix and argali sheep. But also snakes and vultures and other wild animals.

People.body: People rarely speak another language but are very curious and nice. People come up to you to shake your hand and take a look. Usually we were able to make clear what we meant quite easily. Despite the language barrier, we were invited a few times to a ger where we were offered food and drinks. We bought some useful things at the market in the capital (shampoo, sachets of washing powder, needles, matches, …) to distribute on these occasions but found that cigarettes, sweets and a little bit of money were more appreciated.

Safety.body: Mongolia is definitely a safe country, also the capital, but don't be reckless. Stay away from intoxicated individuals, the vodka flows freely. Don't camp too close to the road, someone could get off and accidentally run over your tent.
Safety.body_criminality:
Bernadette: "Unfortunately I cannot confirm from my own experience that it is absolutely safe. Camping close to villages and towns is not recommended because of the drunks. If you are a woman cycling and camping solo, make sure you go to a ger will be placed wherever women are. You are really safe with the average farmer."

We also recommend that you properly connect your bicycle to your tent. Several people were robbed of their bicycles at night.
Safety.body_nature:
My experience with the dogs was very good. If I came near a ger (to camp there), the dog would of course go wild, but I stood still on the spot. The boss who was alarmed would come to me and hold the dog tight. Stray dogs apparently did not belong to a ger, had nothing to defend and were therefore sluggish. Sometimes dogs can be very fierce I've heard, bring a dazer.

When around dogs, use common sense; Get off and walk quietly with your bike between you and the dog, or wait for the owner to take action. That greatly reduces the risk of a bite.

Be wary of thunderstorms: Don't stand on top of a hill and put steel bicycles far away from the tent.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Nyam, Froit, Begz are the experienced WS-hosts in UB City.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Mongolia is the biggest legal, free camping place on earth ;)
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are several budget hostels (called usually Guesthouse) in center of Ulaanbaatar and maybe in some of the towns. Tourist Gercamps usually provide a hot shower and a place to eat. However, they are quite pricey (35 to 40 USD p.p.p.n. including food).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: The optimal overnight stay in Mongolia and often the only option

Transport.body_bus: Public transport is virtually non-existent. Many trekkers try to rent a jeep with a driver together and thus share the costs. Public transport also consists of small vans and they work perfectly. Ask at the hotel where you need to go for the right direction. Everyone was very helpful to me.
Transport.body_train: I traveled back to the capital from Sainshand by train and that was no problem at all. Domestic trains have a separate baggage car. Can they learn something from this in the Netherlands? Although you have to take the time to buy a ticket. It was no problem at all with the train from Erdenet. Your bike is standing between parts of a Ger and bags of camel wool.

About.body: Do you love mountains but do you think the Alps and the Pyrenees are too busy? Then Montenegro is definitely your country! The roads are quiet, the slopes are green and at the top of the mountains it is also a great place to stay in summer.

FoodDrink.body:
The Montenegrins eat much more fish than meat, in combination with wine and olive oil. You can get good vegetable salads. Also many pizzas. In the mountains there is more meat than fish (mainly trout) on the menu. In general, the meat is a lot and very fatty. The national drink is the Rakija (gin made from white grapes).

Supermarkets
There are plenty of supermarkets and shops along the coast and major towns. Outside of that, it is wise to stock up for a day.

Restaurants
Restaurants can be found mainly in the touristic places along the coast.

Drinkable water
The tap water is perfectly drinkable. Much water comes directly from mountain springs, contains little lime and is nice and fresh.

Other.body:
Nice routes
  • The areas along the coast are beautiful. We (Paules and Ilona) went there at the beginning of July 2009. We found the coastal region very touristy. My idea is that the mass tourism has discovered Montenegro.
  • Especially the Bay of Kotor (Unesco World Heritage) is unique. There is no campsite itself in Kotor, but there is a small private campsite in the village of Stoliv, about 7 km north on the western shore of the bay.
  • The mountainous area around Lake Skadar is also a pure gem, well worth exploring.
  • Ivo: "Kotor was the highlight of my trip through Montenegro for me. For literature freaks, the bridge over the Tara is of course a bridge that you absolutely have to cycle over."
  • Minko: "Cycled through Montenegro for a week in 2010. Almost the entire route was breathtakingly beautiful. From Dubrovnik to Kotor (along the whole bay, recommended). Then from Kotor up a long climb to the Lovcen National Park to the mausoleum, views are sublime. Descend via Centinje to Rijeka Crnojevica along the Skadar lake, also very beautiful. Via Podgorica and NW Albania to Gusinje. The view from the Grbaje valley on the Prokletije mountains should also be beautiful but we had too much cloud. The route from Andreijevica via Kolasin, Zabljak, the Durmitor NP and Pluzine to Bosnia was one of the highlights of the trip.
Best time to cycle
At all times of the year you can enjoy cycling in the areas along the coast, because of the Mediterranean climate. Spring and autumn are the most pleasant. In winter it is not pleasant cycling in the mountains because of the cold and snow.

Spare parts
There is no cycling in Montenegro, not even on the flat road around the Bay of Kotor. In Podgorica there are a number of bicycle repair shops that are good.

People.body:
The people are friendly and easily approachable. Foreigners are received as guests. They like it when you talk to them. They are happy to talk about their views on the politics of their country. Many Serbs in Montenegro voted against, but you don't notice much animosity between the population groups. Partly because the detachment from Serbia took place peacefully through a referendum.

The Montenegrins themselves do not cycle at all. Cycling tourists find them something special. Minko: recumbent bicycles are quite a special appearance. In every village I was 'laughed at' by the children. As soon as I stopped somewhere, they gathered around me and the recumbent was admired. Sometimes all that attention became too much for us, especially when they would stop in the middle of the road and try to stop you for a test drive. Once I was stopped in the middle of a descent and I was violently pulled off my bike by a drunk driver.

Eric van Dijken: "Montenegro is very mountainous and therefore people are used to an isolated life. The character of the population also seemed a bit stiff to us, but not unfriendly."

Safety.body: The country is absolutely safe. Crime is much lower there than in the Western world. You can walk quietly on the street at night and there are no land mines anywhere. There are also no tensions between the population groups. The police have been instructed to let tourists have their way as much as possible.
Safety.body_nature: For what it's worth: The locals warn about bears. During the Balkan War (until 1995), many of these animals fled to the forests of Montenegro and more or less remained there ever since. It seems to happen occasionally that they can also be seen on the road.
Safety.body_traffic:
For a tunnel more or less the Montenegrins do not turn their hand around, there are very many. Most are unlit. It is therefore strongly recommended to bring a good lamp.

You can generally avoid the busy roads. Jurriaan: "I crossed the country from the south (Sukobin) to the north (Serbia) and ended up on a main road a total of 1 time where it was really busy, and that could have been avoided. There are many good roads through the interior with no tunnels, with almost no car traffic, good asphalt, and often right through the forest. It is a tough climb on these roads."

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You will come across signs along the road with Sobe, Apartment, Rooms or Zimmer on them. In smaller towns: just ask people along the way. They will then walk with you to the relevant house.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are a few campsites on the coast and inland you can pitch your tent at bungalow parks (eko katun lodges). The prices of the campsites are not in proportion to the facilities. In some locations the toilet was gross. Enclosed shower rooms are a rarity. The owner of the campsite often lives across the street or a little further on. You better go and see him before you set up your tent. This is to prevent you from being surprised by the prices they charge.

There is no camping site in Kotor. There is a small private camp site in the village of Stoliv, about 7 km north on the western shore of the bay. There are a number of campsites in Zabljak. There is a small campsite in Rozaje; in Kolasin cheap rooms.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are plenty of hotels along the coast. Hostels: in Budva, Podgorica and Kotor. In the mountains you have many Eko Katun lodges. These are bungalows that you can buy for about 10 euros pp. can rent, but often you can also pitch your tent there for 2 euros pp and use the sanitary facilities (shower/toilet).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Jurriaan: "I've camped wild twice, both times I was in plain sight but it's not much of a point there; In any case, the police won't be making a fuss anytime soon. It may be a little less convenient in terms of safety, but I felt perfectly comfortable in both places.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Montenegro without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: I do think a lot of people agree with me if I say that Morocco is a paradise for cyclers. And then I’m talking about the real Morocco, not the crowded touristic places. Come in touch with the incredible hospitable local people, who easily share their food with you. Having a huge diversity in landscapes, a cycle trip can be adjusted to any wishes. The outstanding Atlas ranges are the pearl, while the remote and dull Sahara has its charm.

-MB0XXrTDwMfkHc6mfJJ.description: There are two ferry companies that make the crossing to Morocco. One is called FRS (https://www.frs.es/en/)
-MB0XXrTDwMfkHc6mfJJ.description_first: There are two ferry companies that make the crossing to Morocco. One is called FRS (https://www.frs.es/en/)

-MB0XzYgmV3LS8whzN-4.description: Warning: Between Morocco and Mauritania is a no mans land, claimed by Polisario. Between the 2 borders, you shouldn’t go off the gravel road. The gravel road itself is no problem, as many cars and people pass it.
-MB0XzYgmV3LS8whzN-4.description_first: Warning: Between Morocco and Mauritania is a no mans land, claimed by Polisario. Between the 2 borders, you shouldn’t go off the gravel road. The gravel road itself is no problem, as many cars and people pass it.

Corona.body: IMPORTANT AWARENESS: Land border currently closed.

Health.body: Hygiene is not always taken very seriously. The risk of diarrhea is quite high if you are not careful. There are no mandatory vaccinations. Vaccinations against DTP and hepatitis A are recommended.

Other.body:
Nice routes
  • The Sous Valley is busy with cars and flat, try to avoid it.
  • The part between Ouarzazate and Tinerhir is very busy with many coaches and it is a narrow road.
  • The route from Ceuta in the far north through the Rif Mountains over Meknes, Fez and Beni-Mellal to Marrakech is easy to do; staying overnight in hotels en route is no problem.
  • Last stretch of desert run to sand dunes at Merzouga is passable but poor signage, there are many tracks here that are barely distinguishable from the main route. An alternative is to take the new asphalt road from Risani, this takes a 15 km detour.
  • The Atlas about is very beautiful. The Tizi N test is a very nice mountain pass to take with a long run-up and beautiful views
Best time to cycle
In December to February there is a chance of snow in the Central and parts of the High Atlas and it is often very cold in the mornings. It is much more moderate along the coast in winter, when temperatures can rise to 25 degrees in the south. October to mid-May is the most suitable for cycling, along the coast all year round. The rest of the year it is very hot in the interior, with often exceptions in the mountain areas.

Spare parts
Spare parts are for sale but usually not of good quality. In Casablanca it is possible to find modern (Shimano) parts after a good search. The locals also say that Agadir is possible there, but don't count on it. It is recommended to bring your own. Workshops can be found in many villages and towns.

People.body: The Moroccan people are incredibly kind, especially in remote places. They like to make new friends and they offer you food, drinks and places to sleep quite regularly. It's hard to not fall in love with the people.

-MB8_gfLXjpvfDbkWnPg.description: This route starts in Tangier, goes via Chefchaouen, Fes, towards the Middle Atlas, High Atlas, Anti Atlas and then the long, dull but interesting stretch through the Sahara.
-MB8_gfLXjpvfDbkWnPg.title: North to South

Safety.body: Morocco is generally a safe country with strong social control. In the poorer regions, and of course in the cities, pay close attention to your belongings.
Safety.body_corruption: Police officers seem to take their jobs seriously, and are not corrupt. Even the soldiers at the many soldierposts in the Sahara are not corrupt, and rather share their food with you than to ask something from you.
Safety.body_criminality:
Local market days are known to attract scum from outside, so be careful. As a tourist you stand out and a westerner is rich by definition.

The Rif Mountains are considered a poor region where the trading of hashish (locally called 'kif') is very common. Especially in Chefchaoune, many tourists come especially for the hash. As in the Netherlands, smoking is tolerated. Traders will try to get you to buy by the roadside, sometimes in an obtrusive way, but usually a simple 'non merci' is enough to get rid of them. The route to Ketama was notorious in the past. Nowadays it is quiet like the rest of the Rif where you simply don't encounter many tourists. The people are friendly and even begging children don't bother you much.
Safety.body_nature:
It can be hot in the center of the country. In the sahara, you will have the cool wind from the ocean. At the highest mountain, it can be very snowy and cold, so be prepared if you go there. Some dogs can frighten, but normally don't bite.

In the desert, be prepared for sandstorms. Think of goggles (ski goggles or something similar) and a cloth for your face and make sure you have enough water!!! Otherwise you run the risk of drying out.
Safety.body_traffic: Some through roads are too tight for all traffic, which puts you under pressure as a cyclist. Drivers following behind expect you to leave the road if necessary to make room. A rear-view mirror is highly recommended. You even see Moroccan cyclists regularly riding it, although bicycle lights and helmets are unknown.

-MB0Z4xYLGADiVHTx8N3.description: This is not one activity, but can easily be marked as an entire trip. Get lost in the beautiful mountains. There are hundreds of roads, but where ever you go you will find beauty. Tizi-n-Test was the absolute highlight, if you’re seeking for a single spot.
-MB0Z4xYLGADiVHTx8N3.description_first: This is not one activity, but can easily be marked as an entire trip. Get lost in the beautiful mountains. There are hundreds of roads, but where ever you go you will find beauty. Tizi-n-Test was the absolute highlight, if you’re seeking for a single spot.
-MB0Z4xYLGADiVHTx8N3.title: High Atlas

a4c32839-a2b3-4cdc-8ae5-0954b86b74b3.comment: This was a very epic journey

-MB0ZCF5ZIU0UD2KXlwc.description: Cycling here in the Sahara can be dull, boring, though and mind killing, but it truly is an awesome experience to cover the largest desert on earth by bicycle. There is a road along the coast which mostly has a strong wind that goes from North to South. Along the coast you can find hundreds of soldier posts, which are great spots for camping as the soldiers like some companion and even share their delicious food.
-MB0ZCF5ZIU0UD2KXlwc.description_first: Cycling in the Sahara can be dull, boring, though and mind killing, but it truly is an awesome experience to cover the largest desert on earth by bicycle. There is a road along the coast which mostly has a strong wind that goes from North to South. Along the coast you can find hundreds of soldier posts, which are great spots for camping as the soldiers like some companion and even share their delicious food.
-MB0ZCF5ZIU0UD2KXlwc.title: Sahara

-MB0ZH1cMhQmOwMKxhLN.description: There are plenty of cities drenched in culture to be found, but Marrakesh, Fes and Chefchaouen are probably one of the ones worth a visit the most.
-MB0ZH1cMhQmOwMKxhLN.description_first: There are plenty of cities drenched in culture to be found, but Marrakesh, Fes and Chefchaouen are probably one of the ones worth a visit the most.
-MB0ZH1cMhQmOwMKxhLN.title: Marrakesh

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: WS is not very common, in the big cities you can find CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are campsites in various places, but rarely within cycling distance. For safety, a wall has often been built around it and the security is in the hands of a policeman or soldier. Gerben Lovink (2006): "In South Morocco you will find more and more campsites. Although most are geared to large campers, there is always a place for your tent. Average price is 10 dirhams per person and 10 dirhams for your tent." The problem with many campsites is that the ground is rock hard and that you cannot get herring into the ground. The price has also gone up considerably, 25-50 per person with a small tent, sometimes even more.

Formal camping is a great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are cheap hotels in the cities and larger towns. The quality is not always directly proportional to the price. It is recommended to see the room in advance. Sometimes there is no shower
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Quite easy, although especially in the North there are many people everywhere, so it might be difficult to find a spot without being seen. It's easier in the desert where you often don't even need a tent. If you go on unpaved roads, it is necessary to bring a tent, the villages there are remote and have no hotel accommodation.

Transport.body_boat: There are several ferry services from Spain: Algeciras-Ceuta, Algeciras-Tanger or Almeria-Melilia.
Transport.body_bus:
There are several bus companies in Morocco that run long-distance lines with coaches. The bicycle can usually be taken in the luggage compartment or on top of the bus. Make sure it is properly positioned without a heavy load on top. The best thing you can do is go and see for yourself.

The companies CTM and Supratours told the counter that taking bicycles is allowed, but the driver determines whether the bicycle is actually included. A bus ticket has a fixed price, but for the price of the bike you have to negotiate. 40 to 50 dirhams seems normal. Paul: "I was neatly shown the number of kilos of weight with the price on it, negotiation was not an issue at CTM or Supratours."
Transport.body_train: There are trains in Morocco with the exception of the south. The bike can go with you.

-MB0f1Vo8NOy_tmDEJ_W.title: The Atlas ranges and the Sahara desert

Visa.body:
In the below overview you can see which countries need a visa for Morocco. The green countries can enter Morocco for 90 days (Singapore and Hong Kong only 30 days).

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: The landscape is not very varied. The coast is paradise, standard white beach with palm trees and not too many people. Few mountains. History and people are the most interesting. South is easier, north is more adventurous.

FoodDrink.body:
In the north, in sparsely populated areas, it can be difficult to find good food: there are always biscuits, there is always cola, but not always bread. Not even fruits and vegetables. Often there are onions, sometimes tomatoes, sometimes mangoes. In the south (from Vilankulos) a lot is available, in Maputo everything.

Restaurants
The daily fare in Mozambique is rice with chicken or rice with fish. In the richer south you can get fantastic and tasty sea creatures, fresh herbs, wine and a lot of cashew nuts, guys stand by the road with big bags. A breath of fresh air if you come from the north.

Unlike most African countries, many employees bring their own food to work, and the number of restaurants is limited. In cities you can always find something cheap, but not in the small villages. The quality is variable. In the south there are more luxurious restaurants where you can eat reasonably well for a few euros.

For vegetarians it can be difficult to find something you like.

Drinkable water
Be careful with water, filtering is necessary before drinking it
Robert and Wiesje have always filtered the water, this is also recommended by official bodies. 

In the north and center there is very little water in the dry season, we have had the biggest problems of the entire trip with this. There are few pumps in a number of areas, where people get water from holes dug themselves at the bottom of dried-up rivers. You will not die of thirst, however: Beer and cola are always there.

Health.body:
On the coast the chigoe-flea (or sandfly (which is different from sandfly) or jigger-flea) occurs. If you've walked on the paradisiacal beach for a few days, chances are that you'll be able to squeeze a nest full of sickening fly eggs from under your toenail a few days later. Not dangerous (except possible inflammation), quite dirty.

Mandatory vaccinations
  • If you come from a yellow fever area, yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis, etc. are available on site.

Other.body:
Spare parts
26” Mountain bike tires are reasonably good, not super quality, but something to be able to cycle with for a few more weeks. Fake Shimano parts such as brakes and derailleurs are sometimes available in markets. Parts are relatively expensive, eg an inner tube for 4 to 5 euros. We found stickers on the market once, for 75 euro cents each!

There are many bicycle repair shops, as the population also cycles a lot. Of course they do this with a different type of bicycle than the average bicycle traveler. The most commonly used tool is the hammer, you probably prefer to repair it yourself.

People.body:
Mozambique has a fascinating (yet bloody) recent history, a little reading gives a lot of insight. The difference between central/north and south is quite large: "North really felt like 'Africa' to us, South is much more Western due to the influence of South Africa." The transition is gradual, it is difficult to indicate exactly where that limit should lie.

The people are generally calmer than in neighboring countries, warm, friendly and interested. People usually react positively but also surprised to cyclists, sometimes they cheer. There is less enthusiasm in South Mozambique: it is assumed that you are a wealthy South African and people are less interested. The country has no religious regulations regarding clothing.

Portuguese is the official language, there are also various indigenous languages, including from the language group Makua-Lomwe, Tsonga and Sena-Nyonja.

Safety.body:
There are still landmines in the far north and near the border with Swaziland. In some parts there has been a lot of fighting, and not everything has been cleared up. In the south there are signs here and there that there could be mines, in the poorer north there are no signs, but that is probably because less is done about it. Apart from this, Mozambique is a safe country to travel through. The population appears very friendly and calm, but it is known that the disarmament is not yet completely complete.

It is true throughout the country that the police can become difficult if you cannot show your passport. So always take it with you just to be sure, even if you go for a walk
Safety.body_nature: Problems with dogs are unknown.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: It should be possible to stay overnight at private homes. Just ask according to Bert.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: In the south you can find boring, sometimes luxurious campsites along the coast. These are generally made for South Africans.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels are slightly more expensive than in Malawi and Tanzania but cheaper than in South Africa. They are not very thickly seeded.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is officially discouraged. There is a danger of landmines , (See safety). Robert and Wiesje camped wild in the north and did not explode, but later in Maputo they did see a few things in the museum of the revolution, which made them realize that they have been a bit careless here and there.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa for entering Mozambique.


Visa policy of Mozambique
  Mozambique
  Visa-free
  Visa on arrival
Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
There is plenty of food and drink available in almost all places. Quality and price of the food are fine. Vegetarians are well catered for in Burma. Vegetarian curry is recommended. The Burmese word for vegetarian would be 'thatelo', but that is not always understood.

Stalls on the street
You will see many Indian and Chinese eateries. Along the way you will regularly come across stalls where you can snack or eat something.

Restaurants
In the cities you have restaurants everywhere, from very simple to more expensive. You can often get something to eat in villages along the way.

Drinkable water
You can buy drinking water everywhere.

Health.body:
Useful vaccinations for cyclists
Hepatitis A and DTP are recommended, typhoid fever for a stay longer than two weeks and rabies specifically for cyclists.

Useful things in the travel pharmacy
Malaria prophylaxis: with the exception of Mandalay and Yangon, the whole of Myanmar is a malaria area. In addition to malaria mosquitoes, an insect repellent also serves against dengue mosquitoes.

Availability hospitals / doctors
Very limited and quality is low.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
For most areas, the best time is from November to March. In the north it can get quite cold in the evenings. April is not recommended as it gets very hot then. The rainy season is from July to September.

Spare parts
Spare parts are hardly available. Tires are only available in major cities such as Yangon and Mandalay. There are many bicycle repair shops along the road, because the population cycles a lot, but they have the sturdy Chinese steeds, without gears. The repair options for western bicycles are limited.

People.body:
The population is very hospitable, curious and helpful. Contact runs very smoothly, because they find cyclists very interesting, although people do keep their distance due to the political situation.

Appropriate clothing is generally required in temples (shoulders and knees covered). Also in the countryside do not dress too naked. Jolanda: "I was wearing cycling shorts on the bike, which was no problem because I was practicing a sport. As soon as I got off I put on a wrap skirt." Carl: "According to a Burmese I asked about it, it was not necessary to wear anything over my cycling shorts during breaks in tea houses, etc. For visits to temples and monasteries (overnight stays) a longyi is useful."

You can get by reasonably well with English. The older people speak English and the very young children also know some English words. Carl: "My experience (2014) was different: outside the areas where many foreigners come, I spoke on average 1 person per day who spoke more than a single word of English. Also hotel staff who were able to communicate prices and checkout times reasonably in English, often didn't understand questions on a different level. 'Water' is very generally understood."

People generally have a very accurate idea of ​​distances and directions and give correct answers when you ask them the way or how far it is to the next place.

Safety.body: The security is great. Perhaps the safest country in Asia. Sometimes I left a tip on the table, they came running after me, shouting "You're forgetting something".
Safety.body_nature:
It seems that most deaths worldwide from snakebites are in Myanmar. If you stay on the road, you will only see dead snakes, but be very careful when you go into the berm for a sanitary stop or something. and wild camping. Scorpions also occur.

There are many stray dogs, but they usually don't give you a glance. The rare time they come at you barking, you can keep them off by keeping your legs still and yelling loud and angry at them.
Safety.body_traffic: There is little traffic except in the big cities and the traffic that there is is friendly. But that friendliness doesn't always result in safe driving: by default, they cut corners, or just pass you when they overtake you. With Thailand as a reference, cycling is more dangerous here. And that will increase as car ownership grows rapidly in size.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Spending the night at private homes has not been a problem. Carl: "The Burmese themselves are not all aware of this yet! Almost everyone has a mobile phone these days; if a stranded foreigner is on the doorstep, someone from the Immigration Office, called the police or the army who speak a little English and will take you somewhere. That went very friendly with me and without any threat."
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: If you are stranded somewhere where there is no hotel or guesthouse nearby, ask if you can spend the night in a monastery (kyaung) or pagoda (hpaya). Sanitary facilities usually consist of a mandi basin and a simple squat toilet. In monasteries you can get a bed in a room, in pagodas it is useful if you have camping gear with you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are plenty of accommodation options, often of surprisingly good quality. In tourist resorts the price level is relatively high. The regime sometimes makes things difficult, so that a manager must first request permission from the local authorities to be able to accommodate a Western tourist. Some hotels are not authorized to accommodate non-Myanmarese.

Transport.body_bus: Bikes are strapped into the walkway or placed in the back seat. Sometimes they tie him with a string on the roof (without stretch) but luckily it went well. In the coaches of companies such as Asian Express that operate trips such as Naypyidaw-Pyay and Pyay-Yangon, a bicycle can be taken in the luggage compartment at the bottom. A protective cover or plastic bag around the saddle can be useful to prevent damage.
Transport.body_train: You can take your bike with you in the luggage compartment for little money.

About.body:
Namibia is known for its vast desert areas, where the thought of cycling in that country only occurs to a seasoned cyclist. The country confronts the cyclist with the great mutual distance between places, which the experienced cyclist cannot bridge in a day. In the south of Namibia it is not inconceivable that the next town is more than 200 kilometers away and that wild camping is necessary. Namibia experiences a prolonged heat wave in the summer, during which the sun burns brightly for hours and the cloudless sky remains a clear blue. The Namibian summer has few bearable and cool cycling days. The open desert areas offer the cyclist hardly any protection against the scorching heat, because there are no cool shadows along the roads.

Namibia offers the itinerant cyclist many impressive natural phenomena and beautiful views of unique, sometimes surreal landscapes. Rock formations and the red sand dunes reflect the color nuances during the rising and setting of the sun, changing the landscape image after a few minutes. The country is partly divided into two large desert areas, viz. Namib and Kalahari desert in resp. the west and east of the country. Despite the presence of deserts, the country has a biodiversity of flora and fauna in the Namib desert and the country can be divided into various ecosystems, which enjoy protection in the form of national parks and nature reserves.

The gravity factors that determine the cycling tours in Namibia are mainly the presence of sometimes poorly maintained gravel roads, the western headwind from the sea and the gradual kilometer-long climb to the high plateaus. In the remote areas, the high summer temperatures and the extra baggage of water (approx. 15 litres) do influence cycling performance and one should absolutely not underestimate dehydration, heat and the blazing sun. The itinerant cyclist cannot escape the high plateau in the central part of Namibia, which is not always easy to conquer with a heavily loaded bicycle. The Khomas region contains the hilly areas of the country, where the English term 'rolling hills' applies. Gradient gradient from sea level to the plateau (from Walvis Bay to Windhoek) is often false flat for more than tens of kilometers.

FoodDrink.body:
Nambia is a meat country. There is so much game, that it's often cheap to buy. A typical meal is called pap, which is some kind of porridge. It's made from cornmeal and is served with meat and vegetables. You'll quite often see a grill at any place, where people can grill their own meat. 

There are supermarkets with a huge variety of products in the larger towns. The small shops along the way have only a limited range. Fresh products are not always available. In most villages there is a small shop where you can buy rice, macaroni, canned vegetables, soft drinks and beer. The country is not densely populated, on a number of stages you only come to a village a few times or only once a day.

Drinkable water
Tap water is almost always groundwater: you can drink it straight away. In the desert it is often difficult to get drinking water, make sure you have enough with you! If you get off the main roads, you can sometimes find water at watermills that you can see in the landscape from afar. A ceramic water filter & water bags (eg from MSR) can be very useful.

A very nice way to get water, is from passing tourists. Just raise your arm and they might give you some (cold!) water. Don't be shy to ask, it gives them a good reason to talk with you as they probably can't imagine that someone cycles through Namibia.

Health.body:
• If you come from a yellow fever area, a vaccination is mandatory.
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Malaria occurs from July to October. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis, etc. are available on site.

Other.body:
Nice routes
Many cyclists think that there are no nice routes to be found in the Namib desert. Those who cycle in the Namib desert will certainly not miss the biodiversity of the area. The desert can be divided into various ecosystems. In the south of the Namib desert (Succulent Karoo) the cyclist encounters various desert plants (succulents) and wild flowers, which are only in full bloom in spring. In the arid (dry) desert areas in the north of the Namib desert, flora and fauna can be found, which can survive under extreme weather and climate conditions. The diverse ecosystems are located in various national parks and nature reserves, so that untouched nature reserves can still be found on the route from Noordoewer to Walvisbay. The presence of different ecosystems and impressive natural phenomena such as rock (de)formations and erosion make cycling in the oldest desert in the world a unique experience with many highlights (Sossusvlei, Namib Rand Nature Reserve, Namib Desert Park, Neisip Plain, Orange River).

About half of the beautiful cycling routes in the Namib desert are located on a plateau, which is not always easy to conquer with a heavily loaded bicycle. Gradients from sea level to the plateau are often false flats for more than tens of kilometers. Below is an overview of the nice cycling routes in the Namib desert:
  • Those entering Namibia from South Africa can cycle along the Orange River (Gariep) via the villages of Noordoewer and Aussenkehr to Rosh Pinah and will enjoy the great wine regions and scenic, rugged mountain landscapes along the river. The most beautiful part of the river is located in the Ai-Ais/Richtersveld National Park and is easily accessible from the Fish River Canyon.
  • The gravel road D707 is one of the beautiful routes that you can cycle in the Namib desert. The tourist route is about 50 kilometers south of the town of Helmeringhausen and leads you along the vast pale yellow desert plain (Neisip Plain). You also have a view of the mountain ranges or the red sand dunes of the Namib Desert. On this route you have several accommodation options, if you do not want to camp in the wild.
  • Nature and animal lovers cycle early in the morning in the Namib Rand Nature Reserve, which is surrounded by the Naukluft mountain range. The lucky ones will see giraffes, springbok etc. and in the future perhaps rhinoceroses, which will be placed in the area.
  • The fanatics cycle the infamous 230 kilometer long gravel road C14 from Walvis Bay to Solitaire and experience the real Namibia. In the vicinity of Kuiseb Pass and Gaub Pass, the gigantic deformations of rock layers dominate and the cyclist experiences the heaviness of the very hilly part in the Namib-Naukluft Park. The road from Kuiseb Canyon to Walvis Bay is located in an open sandy plain (Namib Desert Park), with dune formation along the road clearly visible.
National parks & nature reserves
When entering many national parks and nature reserves in Namibia, the visitor needs an admission ticket (permit). Here's an overview of where you may or may not need tickets to enter national parks and nature reserves:
  • You do not need a permit for Ai-Ais Richtersveld NP, Namib Naukluft Park (follow highway D707) and Namib Nature Rand Reserve.
  • Namib Naukluft Desert Park you need a permit if you cycle towards Homeb (research station).
  • For Sossusvlei you pay an entrance fee, and you can cycle to the famous dunes. It is 65 km by bike (about 200 to 300 h.m) on a well-paved road and the last 2 to 4 km you will have to enter by car, because it is a 4WD track.
  • In Etosha NP there are roaming wild animals such as elephants, buffalo, lions, rhinoceroses and leopards, so you are not allowed to enter the park with an open vehicle.
  • You can cycle to Skeleton Coast NP, provided you have reserved an overnight stay in Tora Bay. Due to the great distance to Tora Bay, the cyclist will probably not be allowed in the park. If you are admitted, you pay an entrance fee and you cycle on hard, sometimes sandy roads.
Best time to cycle
The high season starts from mid-December to the end of January and many South Africans book the cheapest sleeping accommodation. Early December kicks off the preseason and overnight accommodations in some cities like Rosh Pinah fill up quickly.

Wind
The wind can be a problem, some days it is stormy and it is hard. The predominant direction is west to southwest. At Walvis Bay and Luderitz you will encounter a lot of resistance from the strong westerly wind from the sea. From Rosh Pinah (+300 m) to Aus you will cycle twice to the plateau (Huib Hoch plateau, +1400 m) within a distance of 167 kilometers and you will experience a lot of hindrance from the wind from the north.

Average temperature
September is a good period for cycling as it is spring in Namibia with a temperature of around 25 degrees. It is nice and cool along the coast. Later in the year it gets hotter, often above 35 degrees. May, the start of the Namibian winter, is also a great period. The average temperature is about 25 degrees. In the evening it cools down quite a bit. The rainy season has just ended, so the country is still relatively green.

Spare parts
Outside of Windhoek or Swakopmund, there are few or no parts for randonneurs available. The situation outside these cities is better for ATBs, although there are no high-tech gear for sale.

Due to the bad roads and the fact that sometimes quite a bit of weight (water) has to be carried, good equipment is required. In any case, take a spare tire and spokes with you. The sand causes the chain and derailleurs to suffer quite a bit, so good maintenance is necessary. Also check from time to time that all bolts are still tight.

Before the start of the cycling tours in Namibia, make sure that the bicycle is well prepared for long trips on the sand and gravel roads. Placing a hard plastic ribbon inside the tire offers sufficient protection against tiny sharp thorns and sharp gravel stones. Check the tire for small cracks, which appear after thousands of kilometers of cycling. These cracks in most cases cause punctures. The cyclist will have to be wary of thin long spines of plants and shrubs along the roads.

Even in touristic places like Sesriem near the Sossusvlei you can't go for bicycle repairs. The bicycle repair shops can only be found in the major cities. The cyclist, who is on his way from South Africa to Namibia, will find a good bicycle specialist in Springbok before the Namibian border is reached after about 120 kilometers.

People.body:
Contact is no problem with the Namibians of European descent and they are hospitable. Also the native Africans are friendly and helpful, but are sometimes harder to reach as a white person, as a gap between the two remains. It's most often other tourists that you are talking to, wondering why you are on a bicycle. Sometimes they offer you (cold) drink, or you can try to ask it.

Frank: "The German tourists in particular often stopped to have a chat, could it have been because of my Ortlieb bags? I got a lot of cans of drink."

English is the official language, and many people are proficient in that language. In the larger towns, Afrikaans is the official language. Especially in places like Swakopmund you can get by quite well in German. Outside the larger towns, several different 'traditional' languages are spoken.

Safety.body: In Africa it seems that the more touristic a place or country is, the more attractive for crimes. Namibia is fairly popular for wealthier tourists, so always be careful.
Safety.body_corruption: Bas (2019): "Corruption seems not to exists in Namibia".
Safety.body_criminality: Windhoek has certain regions where crime exists and you can get robbed. When you walk on the street, try to look confident and don't bring expensive things with you. If you walk with a group, you might be fine. Outside Windhoek, you sometimes hear stories of people getting robbed during the night on campsites. In the North, local people like to drink, and sometimes you see more bars than shops. Local people getting drunk can be dangerous, so always try keep an eye on unexpected behaviour.
Safety.body_nature: The Namib desert does host wild elephants, which can be dangerous. The heat is extreme, but once you get used to it, it is doable to cycle here. Just make sure to bring enough water. Count on cycling less kilometers, as the dirt roads are all badly corrugated.
Safety.body_traffic: There are no bicycle lanes, and you often have to drive on the busy road without shoulders. This can be very dangerous and accidents do occur!

4964ac83-3451-4a14-9cc4-1aef2c7b24b0.description: Part of the Uga Terrace, the Fingerklip rock formation is quite a remarkable one, standing as a single column in the open space. There are a few more impressive rock formation here.
4964ac83-3451-4a14-9cc4-1aef2c7b24b0.title: Fingerklip rock

681dc9c7-b3a7-4e7d-ad6c-ab25ba463f21.description:
This is where the biggest dune (Big Daddy, 800 m) is located, next to Dead Vlei. This place is truly remarkable. Some dead trees stand on a dry clay surface, turned black because of their age. The earlier you come, the better the view. 

You can't camp here, as you can't even enter the road to this point by bicycle. You have to come by car. The best way is to just ask some people on the campsite you're staying at to join them. It takes about an hour to go from Sesriem to the dunes, as there is also a part that is not tarred. In total, it will take about 6 hours from departing to arriving back to Sesriem.
681dc9c7-b3a7-4e7d-ad6c-ab25ba463f21.title: Sossusvlei + Dead Vlei

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are plenty of campsites in the (quite touristy) South. Above the line Swakopmund/Windhoek it decreases, except on the coast. Then you have to cover longer distances (> 100 km) or camp wild. The facilities vary, from luxurious with a swimming pool to primitive. At various campsites it is also possible to stay overnight in cottages.

Bas: "There are plenty of campsites, and they are from a good quality, which means they can also be pricy. Sometimes I camped in the wild, even in the Namib desert, but preferably I tried to stay with locals, either in my tent next to their house. Once I camped at a police station, and another time in the garden of a cafe".
Sleeping.body_hostels: Especially in the big cities, there are youth hostels of good quality and price, which is a good way to come in touch with other tourists and to recharge from the otherwise long and dull days. Outside the big cities, you'll find ridiculously priced accomodations, which sometimes allow cyclers to camp at their property for free (sometimes in return for ordering food).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
It is not clear whether wild camping is allowed, there is nothing about this in the guides. Wild camping is definitely prohibited in the National Parks.

Mark and Mandy: "Distances are large, so sometimes wild camping. Good campsites (South Africans with huts!), lodges and guesthouses. When camping in the Namib: Take the wind into account! We had no wind :)"

Transport.body_bus: The bicycle can be taken on the bus for longer journeys, there are also buses with a trailer that can accommodate the bicycle. There are pick-up trucks that serve as public transport. In sparsely populated areas, however, it can take a while to find one and get on with it.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Namibia without a visa for 3 months. You can get an entry stamp at the border.
Source: Wikipedia

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
Gasoline is simply available from taxi drivers. Coleman fuel, etc. also available in Pokhara and Kathmandu

Stalls on the street
You can eat well, tasty and cheap on the street. Use your wits and pay attention to where others buy, talk to the sellers and try things you don't know, great fun. When eating on the street, keep a close eye on how they prepare it. That they do not dilute a sauce with cold water and then no longer heat it. 

Restaurants
The food is quite good, for sale everywhere and there are many Dhabas (roadside restaurants). Be prepared for hot (spicy) food. You can buy dahl bat everywhere: rice with lentils and vegetables. And when it's gone, you get shoveled again. Nepal is the mecca for vegetarians, at least if you like lentils.

Drinkable water
Bottled water is reasonably available. Note the sealed bottles! There is virtually nothing for sale on the Pharphing-Bhimpedi section. Tap water is only available in the major cities but is unsafe for consumption. Handy to carry pills or water filter to purify water. Milk, tea and soft drinks are readily available.

Health.body:
Common diseases
Hepatitis A and E, Typhoid, Cholera, Malaria, Filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, Water in lakes and standing water can be contaminated with Leptospira bacteria, TB, meningitis, Diphtheria, Meningococcal infection, rabies, Various STDs

Mandatory Vaccinations
Yellow fever vaccination mandatory upon arrival from an endemic area (= area where yellow fever occurs)

Recommended vaccinations 
DTP, typhoid fever, Tetanus, Hepatitis A, Malaria prophylaxis recommended for certain parts of Nepal.

Useful items in pharmacy
  • When cycling at high altitudes acetazolamide (Diamox®)
  • Loperamide against diarrhea
  • Broad spectrum antibiotics against any abdominal infectionsinfectie
Availablity hospitals/doctors
Doctors Clinics are plentiful, but for real medical care there are hospitals that are reasonably reputable. Doctors are often present at the pharmacies in the city. If he is not present, they know at the pharmacy what time he will come.

If you need a hospital or western doctor, you can contact CIWEC clinic. This one is on Lazimpat, near the English Embassy. They are also very good at identifying the cause of your diarrhea. Your treatment is often reimbursed by the insurance, but you have to pay in cash.

If you end up in a Nepalese hospital, keep in mind that you have to take care of your own food. They assume that your family will take care of you. Before you end up in a hospital, contact your insurance company (if this is possible) otherwise there is a chance that your insurance will not reimburse.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
February - April is a good time. October and November are also excellent months to be in Nepal. In the mountains it is very cold after sunset. Sleeping bag and fleece sweater are then needed. In the Chitwan Park it is hot again, clammy. 

The monsoon is from May to September and is very wet. Bad roads turn into mud puddles. In Pokhara you can go whitewater MTB. It is therefore very hot. In November and December the airy hazy are often no clear view of the mountains and no tight skies.

Spare parts
Neither parts nor quality tires are easily available. 28” tires are not to be found.

Things to see
You can hardly go to Nepal without trekking in the Himalayas. The easiest treks to organize are the Annapurna and Everest treks; you can easily do it yourself; you can still take a carrier on the way, then your money also goes directly to him and not to a (foreign) agency.

Martin: “Don't forget to take a walk. If you don't feel like the Annapurna, the Gosainkund is a very nice substitute. By bus from Kathmandu to Dunche and from there you walk back to Sundarije (few km from Kathmandu).

Marijke: “We left our bicycles at a hotel in Kathmandu (no problem). We then rented backpacks and went on a trek for two weeks. Renting equipment, backpacks, etc. is no problem. Kathmandu is full of small shops where these items are rented out. Price on the order of a few quarters a day or something, not much anyway. We did not use any guides or porters for our trek and we have absolutely no regrets. Even if you go to any tourist office in Kathmandu, they will all recommend at least one guide and a few porters, but that turns out not to be really necessary. It is virtually impossible to get lost. Free route maps are often available at the hotels at the start of the trek. Take some warm clothes with you (fleece sweater, warm sleeping bag, etc.), because it is very cold at night. During the day it is generally shorts weather. The weight of our backpacks was about 6-8 kg. A lot of extra provisions are not really necessary, because every 2 hours you will come across a tea house, where you can eat and drink”.

Nice routes
The old main road to Kathmandu via Hetauda is recommended, but it is quite a climb.

Martin: “Go via Hetauda to Daman, cycle 55 km of which 40 km climb. When you arrive in Daman you can see Mount Everest in clear weather; the view is a wonderful reward.”

Brike: "Actually, the only nice round Kathmandu-Hetauda-Chitwan-Butwal-Tansen-Pokahar-Kathmandu. It takes you (including hanging out in Chitwan and Pokhara) about 2 weeks. The East-West highway of more than 1000 km in the Terai you can cycle back and forth, but is that fun? Furthermore, there are many gravel roads into the mountains, but that is almost all a dead end after a few tens to a few hundred kms, and then you have to go back on the same road, unless you going to walk by bike on mountain paths."

People.body:
The population is friendly and hospitable, not intrusive and you can easily get in touch with them. Namaste is always a good start.

Roelof: "Nepali are friendly and helpful, but they have trouble with Western sign language. Their English is quite limited. Dress appropriately in shrines. Nobody is interested in cycling, but your bike is! It is impossible not to interact with the population to get in touch."

Safety.body:
In principle Nepal is a safe country, use your common sense and ask the people what is safe. Walking alone at night is not recommended. If you camp along the road, let people nearby know you're there and ask if it's safe.

The border area with India is considered unsafe, people are often armed here. Don't get into a discussion here, just smile kindly and go away.
Safety.body_traffic: Traffic in Nepal drives on the left. The maximum speed of traffic is low, freight traffic is limited to 40 km/h, taxi vans can be quite hectic. Freight traffic usually does not move to the side for a cyclist. Everyone honks for everything at all times.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Homestays are not popular, but they are possible but neither cheaper nor more comfortable than hotels.
Sleeping.body_hostels: You can find guesthouses or simple hotels almost everywhere. At least every 100km there is in a village along the “highways” with a lodge for less than 4 US$. Plenty of options in tourist centers. Price indication: all kinds of price ranges possible: ranging from ± 3 $ to 17.5 $ in a luxury hotel (but bargained! original price 50 dollars).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: You can camp if you can find a flat piece of land. With a little patience with the attention of the locals it is doable.

Transport.body_bus:
Almost all taxis, taxibuses and buses are equipped with carriers on the roofs. However, there is not always material available to secure the bike, I always had elastic with me. It is best to ask the taxi drivers to run the meter, this often provides you with a better deal than an agreed price.

On the buses, coaches, etc., the bicycle can also simply be placed on the roof. Make sure that you have the bike loaded last, to prevent heavy bags from ending up on it. The bus drivers often ask for a contribution for the bicycle (100-200 rps).

About.body: A great country for traveling by bicycle. It's mostly flat land, only in the far south there are hills. The highest is about 300 mtr. high. The Dutch almost invited cycling themselves. It's the most common transport.

3fc23df5-7973-4cb7-91f8-b3334daa2184.description:
Santos dealer
https://www.bike4travel.nl/
3fc23df5-7973-4cb7-91f8-b3334daa2184.title: Bike4travel

De Vakantiefietser (The Holiday Cycler) is a bikeshop specialized in tourbiking.

Website: https://www.vakantiefietser.nl
Phone: +31206164091
49f7dd23-e1ac-428e-b1f0-87367333e0de.title: De Vakantiefietser

8ab7405d-bc23-4334-95f3-f6557fcd35ae.description:
Great bicycle shop owned by Job, who is (as the company's name sais) very passionate about cycling.

-MDksBwcX971ugDoJF5s.description: There are many possible border crossings
-MDksBwcX971ugDoJF5s.description_first: There are many possible border crossings

Corona.body: The current situation is stable. Face masks are obligatory in public transport. 1,5 mtr. rule countrywide. There is no curfew anymore. Shops, restaurants and grocery stores are open.

FoodDrink.body:
Typical Dutch food is "stamppot", which is mashed potatoes with a specific vegetable (carrot, coal, spinach). At the snackbar you will find a "frikandel" or "kroket", which are the Dutch proud. As candy there is "drop" (licorice) and "stroopwafel" (cookie with caramel).

For drinks, Dutch people like to stick to beer and wine. Many different beers are being brewed in The Netherlands and if you like to taste new ones, you should visit a beer cafe that sometimes have more than a 1.000 different types of beers.

Other.body: • Map with cycling routes in Netherlands

People.body: There are more bicycles than people in the country, and bicycle lanes can be found anywhere. The Netherlands has a dense population, so you'll find small villages amd people almost everywhere.
