In general Dutch people are friendly, but sometimes they seem to be afraid to get in contact with strangers.

QuickFacts.climate: Sea climate, not very cold winters, summerdays can be hot in July and August.
QuickFacts.language: Dutch, most people speak also English.

Safety.body: The Netherlands is very safe.
Safety.body_corruption: Don't worry, you don't have to bribe anyone here.
Safety.body_criminality: Criminality is around, so make sure to always lock your bicycle.
Safety.body_nature: In the winter temperatures can drop to -10 degrees celsius, while summers can be +35 degrees celsius. There are no dangerous animals. Since a few years there are wolves around in National parks, but apparently they don't go after humans.
Safety.body_traffic: There are a lot of roads and there is a lot of traffic, but there are bicycle paths everywhere.

1655ca74-4cd3-4615-9fb6-e6e96b7e850d.description: One of the five larger islands in The NEtherlands, and definetly worth to visit when you're nearby. You can reach this place from Harlingen at the main land. From this island you can hop on another boat to Vlieland. From Vlieland you can go Texel, and then back to the main land. This saves you a difficult ride on the Aflsuitdijk (A7).
1655ca74-4cd3-4615-9fb6-e6e96b7e850d.title: Terschelling

813a161d-70ed-4967-850a-8865bf86a2f2.description: This village is best known for the many 18th-century windmills that are stately positioned next to the water.
813a161d-70ed-4967-850a-8865bf86a2f2.title: Kinderdijk

9353ac9f-f095-4d2a-887e-9526a1c198f7.description: Visit the capital of The Netherlands to dive into a piece of history of the Dutch culture. Wander around in the city, and cross one of the many canals. The Anne Frank House, Rijksmuseum and Rembrandt House Museum are the most popular museums. Don't forget tp visit the Dam and get a glimpse of the night life in the Red Light Disctrict.
9353ac9f-f095-4d2a-887e-9526a1c198f7.title: Historic city center Amsterdam

c066883b-fe77-4569-8dce-2468ce02cc41.description: Venlo has a historic city center. Nice to visit.
c066883b-fe77-4569-8dce-2468ce02cc41.title: Historic city center Venlo

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: There are plenty of Couchsurfers and Warmshowers hosts available.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: This is pretty difficult as there are many campsites around and people will redirect you to them.
Sleeping.body_hostels: The big cities offer Hostels, while hotels can be found in many different places.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wildcamping is illegal. As the country has a dense population, it can be difficult to find places where there are no people.

Transport.body_airplane: Schiphol, near Amsterdam, is the largest and most used airport, and has connections to many places. Smallers airports can be found at Rotterdam, Eindhoven and Maastricht.
Transport.body_boat: There are connections with England departing from Hoek van Holland or Ijmuiden. Between the Fryssian Islands there are also connections with boats. You can bring your bicycle on them, but need to pay extra for that.
Transport.body_bus: The bus network is quite good as well, and should be able to bring you almost any place in The Netherlands, combined with some train rides. However, you can't bring a bicycle into the bus.
Transport.body_train:
There is a very good train network that can bring you to almost any place. The tickets are a little expensive, with a maximum price of 24 euro for a single ride (depends on the distance). You can bring your bicycle, but therefore you need to buy a separate ticket online. You can also rent bicycles at every train station for about 3 euros per 24 hours. You might need a pass for this, which takes a few weeks to get.

Website: https://www.ns.nl/en

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body:
If you are looking for a country with an overwhelming nature, with little traffic on the roads, with many good places for wild camping and with local people who are friendly and helpful, New Zealand is a chosen country. Cycling in New Zealand is popular and you will encounter many other cyclists on the road. New Zealand is not called the "Pedallers Paradise" for nothing.

New Zealand has a lot to offer for nature lovers. On the North Island you have active volcanoes and geysers. Together with the Alpine mountains on the south island, there is a lot of variety in nature.

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
In the big cities you will find supermarkets with a range that is comparable to Belgium, in smaller villages there is a supperrette. Every village has a shop for the most commonly used groceries. Also try the Bin In Stores. Here you can create food such as rice, pasta, sugar, flour, raisins, etc. yourself. You pay per unit weight, and relatively much.

Given the distances between the places, it is wise to always keep something on hand. Especially on the South Island there is virtually nothing available between the places. This is especially true for gas or water filter.

In the larger cities in NZ there are many outdoor shops, even in the smaller villages there is often a general store where they have screw tanks of gas and a petrol pump. NZ outdoor shops use Dutch prices and have a comparable range. What I found out they don't have: zip-off pants. New Zealanders only trample and that is always in shorts. For cheaper tents, people are more likely to go to a sports shop.

Stalls on the street
In the South Island you will regularly come across local products (honey, vegetables,...) that are displayed at the driveway of a farm. Put some money in the jar, and you can serve yourself.

Drinkable water
Drinkable water from the pipes. New Zealanders pride themselves on the fact that a lot of water in lakes and rivers is drinkable. Drinking from surface water without purifying it first is strongly discouraged by the authorities. In large parts of New Zealand, the surface water is contaminated with the Giardia parasite. DoC sites often have untreated water.

Health.body:
Drinking from surface water without purifying it first is strongly discouraged by the authorities. In large parts of New Zealand, the surface water is contaminated with the Giardia parasite.

On the west coast of the South Island, so-called sandflies can become a real pest. They are small black flies that can sting viciously. If you are attacked by a horde, they can almost drive you crazy. This is probably why the beaches are so remarkably empty, despite their alluring appearance.

New Zealand has the highest percentage of people with skin cancer of all western countries. The ozone layer is very thin here. It is recommended to use sunscreen 30+ and cover as much skin as possible. The best solution is long shirts that are super thin and light (also in color): much cooler than bare arms actually and therefore less chance of burning.

Other.body:
Special clauses
New Zealand has a strict quarantine regime. It is prohibited to import food such as meat and meat products, honey, fruits, dairy products, etc. That can go very far: if you indicate that you have rubbed your saddle with beeswax, they will even sand it off to check. The beeswax itself is also confiscated.

At the airport it often happens that your bicycle, tent, footwear, etc. must be disinfected before you can enter the country. Make sure there is no mud on your bike, and that your tires are clean.

Best time to cycle
New Zealand's summer lasts from December to February and is the best time for cycling. In general, the weather is very changeable. The North Island is warmer (located between 35 and 40 degrees south latitude), the west coast of the South Island is notorious for the large amount of precipitation (6 meters per year in Milford Sound!). Taking bad weather into account can therefore not hurt. Daytime temperatures between 20 and 30°C.

The West Coast (aka Wet Coast) on the south coast receives 7 meters of rain annually. You will not stay dry here. The best cycling month is November: decent weather, and little holiday crowds on the roads. February is also very suitable, after the hustle and bustle of the summer holidays.

Spare parts
Spare parts (Shimano etc.) are available everywhere. There are bicycle repair shops in the larger cities. Elsewhere it has been saved. The outdoor sports paradise Queenstown also has many bicycle shops. The most common problems are loosened and lost screws (screws). Your bike vibrates hard on the many dirt roads causing all screws to come loose. A set of spare screws of all sizes certainly deserves a place in your repair kit.

Special Sightseeing
Whales, dolphins, seals, penguins, albatrosses, you can encounter them all in the wild. Local 'safaris' are often organized in places where there is a good chance of encountering these animals.

Historically and culturally, New Zealand has less to offer, New Zealand became inhabited quite late. The old Maori culture still exists here and there, with a concentration around Rotorua on the North Island. But apart from the few big cities, as far as you can judge, cultural life is not thriving during a bike ride.

For those who like challenges, New Zealand is a paradise. Bungee jumping, rafting, caving, water sports, mountaineering or you name it, you can probably try it somewhere. Queenstown is the center for challenges. Henk Klein Baltink: "I have tried rafting and I have to admit that it is just as much fun when it is promoted in all brochures and on video. But we also had a special 'raft' mate who performed all kinds of fun tricks with us as (willing The trip by van from Queenstown through the Skipper Canyon to the Shot-over River is an adventure in itself, and those who (also) like walking can also indulge themselves in New Zealand.In the Lonely Planet guide describes the most famous routes.I myself walked the 'Tangariro Crossing' on the north island.A long one-day walk, very popular in New Zealand, but definitely worth it because you walk along volcanoes with a view of 'emerald lakes ' and 'red crater'."

Tips
  • Wearing a bicycle helmet is mandatory in New Zealand.
  • Ice Cream Tip-Top is very refreshing and can be found everywhere.
  • Watch out, Kea's sometimes dare to pick up the sleeve of your bike.

People.body:
The further south you get, the more friendly people become, or so it seems. As a cyclist you are still sometimes approached, despite the fact that there are still quite a lot of cyclists around, especially on the South Island.

The Maoris, the first inhabitants of New Zealand, mainly live on the North Island.

Safety.body: In general, New Zealand is a fairly safe country. The daily street scene gives the impression of being a mix of English and American influences.
Safety.body_traffic:
As a legacy of English colonization, you drive on the left, but you get used to it after a hundred meters. However, stay alert, the automaticity that comes into effect in an emergency will still work for a few months in the right-hand drive mode.

The larger roads have a wide hard shoulder on which you can easily cycle. The smaller roads are less busy, but do not have this hard shoulder. In bad weather and on busier roads, it may be advisable to wear a fluorescent vest or to provide the necessary extra visibility. Motorists are not used to cyclists. A bicycle mirror is therefore recommended. Pay attention!

John: "Cycling in NZ in general is not very pleasant and certainly not without its dangers. Wasn't cycling there myself, but I did talk to cyclists (of course :) normally I cycle too) and everyone likes it in more or less dangerous."

d335749f-1fd7-47e3-8ecd-bcdd0c32dabf.description: Even though you can not cycle this, doing the Tongariro crossing might be one the reasons why you've come to New Zealand. This 19,4 km hike crosses the famous Mount Ngauruhoe, better known as Mount Doom from Lord of the Rings, and gives away some stunning views. In good conditions it is possible to climb the volcano, but you can also walk passed it. In wintertime you need to prepare a little better with crampons and maybe even an icehax. The hike takes about 8 hours and you can't buy anyhting on the road, so prepare well.
d335749f-1fd7-47e3-8ecd-bcdd0c32dabf.title: Tongariro crossing

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: It is also possible to stay overnight with private individuals. The people are very hospitable and like to invite you to spend the night at their home.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There is a distinction between the so-called motor camps, holidays parks and DOC sites.

The motor camps are mostly areas with mobile homes and sometimes also places for tents, and are usually visited by New Zealanders who spend a long holiday there. The facilities are often usually inferior to those of the holiday parks. Recreational areas and washing machines are often not available on motor camps, motor camps are usually older and less maintained, but also significantly cheaper.

The holiday parks are home to most foreign tourists, who are often there with a camper. These campsites also often have secluded space for tents, covered cooking facilities for hikers, but are still quite expensive.

Finally, there are the cheap nature campsites managed by the http://www.doc.govt.nz/. The DOC (Department Of Conservation) DOC manages New Zealand's national parks, forests, reserves, riverbanks, coasts and wetlands. The DOC provides 2 leaflets (North and South Island) with an overview of these nature campsites. The facilities at these campsites are usually minimal, but they are located in the most beautiful places... Usually you will find a fire pit and water. A small contribution is requested for the use and maintenance of the campsite. You can leave this money in an envelope in a special mailbox at the campsite. The DOC campsites are highly recommended, although it can get busy in high season. There is always a place for a couple of cyclists. Click here for an overview of DOC campsites (choose Parks & Recreation section, then Places to stay and finally Conservation campsites by region). 

Finally, you can also ask a landowner to pitch your tent on his piece of land. You will rarely get a negative answer, on the contrary you will often be treated to the hospitality of the local people. Some hostels also offer the possibility to camp in the (back) garden.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are many hostels ("backpackers") in New Zealand, whether or not they are affiliated with an organization. Hostels have communal facilities (kitchen, bathroom, living room). Prices per night are from NZD 18 (for a dorm room).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: You can also go wild camping. This is allowed and generally accepted, except in the national parks. Often, however, the land belongs to farmers, so you actually have to ask them for permission first. In nature reserves, camping spots are sometimes set up by the government, with only a toilet (the DoC sites, see above). Of course you don't have to pay much for this.

Transport.body_boat:
The bicycle can easily be taken on the ferry between the North Island and South Island. For the bike you pay 10 dollars extra. In principle, you can take your bike with you without a reservation. But if you book a few days in advance, you often get a discount on the crossing.

The ferry that brings and picks up walkers on the beaches of Abel Tasman NP also takes bicycles. That way you can make a nice boat trip between Totaranui and Kaiteriteri. Well in advance
Transport.body_bus: There is no government-organized bus service, but several low-cost companies take bicycles – to a limited extent – with them. On the South Island, for example, there is Atomic Shuttles, which can take two bikes per ride (for $15 per bike, regardless of distance). Competitor Intercity also takes bicycles, but only at the driver's discretion: you cannot book a place for your bicycle in advance, but must check with the driver on departure whether the bike along.
Transport.body_train:
With a youth hostel card or backpackers pass you often get a discount on public transport. This can be up to 30%. Your bicycle can be taken on the train without any problems, is the most normal thing. Rate $10, regardless of the distance.

On some routes you pay nothing for your bike, for example in the train from Pukerangi to Dunedin. 2017: Check in advance whether the train is running. Due to the earthquake of Nov.2016, the train from Picton to Christchurch is not running for the time being.

Visa.body:
Depending on your nationailty you may need to apply for a visa.

Visa requirements for New Zealand passport holders
  New Zealand
  Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement
  Visa not required / ESTA / eTA
  Visa issued upon arrival
  Electronic authorisation or online payment required / eVisa
  Both visa on arrival and eVisa available
  Visa required prior to arrival
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Nicaragua is underrated as a cycling country. It is a beautiful and quiet country for cycling. The landscape is varied: volcanoes, mountains and lowlands with two large lakes. Only the capital Managua is not particularly beautiful, and is notorious for its crime.

It is less prosperous than neighboring Costa Rica, but just as beautiful. A lot of work is being done on the construction and improvement of roads, so maps may be outdated.

FoodDrink.body:
You can eat anywhere. There are not as many food stalls as in Costa Rica. Rudy: "Dining and supplies are not a problem in most larger towns. Lots of chicken, beans, rice, tortillas etc. In most restaurants you can get a full meal for USD 8-10 pp."

Preferably buy bottled mineral water. In many places the tap water is fairly reliable and sanitisers are not immediately needed, but you are taking a risk. Drinking water is also available at roadside stalls.

Health.body:
Common Diseases
Like the surrounding countries, this is a dengue area. Nicaragua has an active rabies vaccination policy for dogs, so the risk of rabies is relatively small.

Mandatory vaccinations
Additional vaccination obligations apply from certain countries.

Useful vaccinations for cyclists
Rabies, Hepatitis A and B. Depending on the region also malaria prophylaxis.

Useful things in the travel pharmacy
Disinfectant for dubious (tap) drinking water.

Other.body:
Nice routes
Between Managua and Leon you can cut off quite a bit of the highway by looking for the old train station at La Paz Centro, and from there follow the old rail route towards Leon. Unpaved, but perfectly flat road, and also a lot shorter.

Disparate de Potter: The road between Jinotega and Matagalpa is a must. Beautiful views, with steep climbs but not too steep.

Best time to cycle
December is the dry season and therefore suitable for cycling. September is the rainy season. It is then warm, 30-35oC, and humid. Rain is very local, heavy and short. After half an hour the shower has passed and the weather is a bit cooler. You suffer more from wet dirt roads than from the rain showers themselves. The dry season from November to March is more suitable.

Spare parts
There are many workshops, but good parts are scarce. Tire and valve size can be an issue. On their trip we brought inner tubes and spokes.

People.body:
The people are friendly and welcoming, not intrusive. They also cycle a lot, but on simple bicycles. People simply take a bicycle inside, also in restaurants and even in church.

The population often only speaks Spanish. Outside the real tourist locations - Managua, Granada and Masaya - it is difficult to communicate without Spanish.

Safety.body: The fact that the Nicaraguans cycle a lot also has the advantage that the (many) dogs are used to it and do not move, you are not interesting! With exceptions of course....
Safety.body_traffic: The PanAmerican highway can be dangerous, especially where the hard shoulder is missing. The highway between Managua and Granada is no fun either. Avoid those roads if possible. Also watch out for the buses.

164d397f-df3c-46a0-8b25-1861632b6c5d.description: This is one of the prime destinations for sandboarding in all of the world. You can book tours to this volcano on the city of Leon.
164d397f-df3c-46a0-8b25-1861632b6c5d.title: Cerro Negro (Sandboarding volcano)

267f7902-951f-4adb-93db-eb4958f0ca28.description: Here you can find the fastest ferry to Ometepe Island, one of the prime destinations in Nicaragua.
267f7902-951f-4adb-93db-eb4958f0ca28.title: San Jorge (City with ferry dock)

36558633-28dd-4c86-9ddf-b01bc482c99b.description: This is a beautiful volcanic island in the middle of the biggest lake of Nicargua. Here you can find places to stay, this is one of the most visited places by backpackers in Nicaragua. You can take the ferry in the city of Granada if you are coming from the North or in San Jorge if you are coming from the South.
36558633-28dd-4c86-9ddf-b01bc482c99b.title: Ometepe (Volcanic Island)

4bfd5e35-38b8-49b6-9db9-270d7230b153.description: This is one of the prime touristic destinations in Nicargua. Beautiful city with multiple hotels and hostels. You can also find surfing services all along the city.
4bfd5e35-38b8-49b6-9db9-270d7230b153.title: San Juan del Sur (Coastal and surfing city)

a8f0bb9a-d329-4a6a-8c3f-13d1a4a81054.description: Telica is a beautiful volcano in the municipality of Leon. You can book tours to the volcano in the city of Leon.
a8f0bb9a-d329-4a6a-8c3f-13d1a4a81054.title: Telica (Volcano)

bc927778-4632-46df-a2ef-ab920431ee6d.description: One of the prime destinations passing through Nicaragua, here you can book tours to visit multiple volcanoes, you can find cheap hostels and food. Beautiful colonial city. Its also fairly close to Las Peñitas Beach where you can surf.
bc927778-4632-46df-a2ef-ab920431ee6d.title: Leon (City)

Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible, but not recommended. Possibly in a yard. Asking private individuals is also no problem. We spent one night in the living room of a hotel owner due to a full hotel.

Transport.body_bus: The "regular" bus services are a godsend if you just need quick transport. Even if you are not at an official stop, raise your hand and chances are the bus will stop. There are special helpers on the bus and in no time your bike is on the roof and you are on your way. But: full = bad luck!

Visa.body:
Quite a numerous amount of nationalities can enter Nicaragua without a visa.

  Nicaragua
  Visa-free access to Nicaragua
  Visa on arrival access to Nicaragua
  May not enter on Canada/Schengen/US visa

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
The population consists of various ethnic groups, the majority of which are Muslim, so appropriate clothing (legs covered) is recommended. The big difference with the surrounding countries is that poverty is very dire in many places. Despite this, the population can be characterized as sincere and cordial. Like many Africans in the region, people live by the day, they are traditional and used to living with severe setbacks.

The official language is French, but given that the vast majority of the population is out of school and illiterate, not everyone speaks it. The local native languages are Hausa (in the south), Zarma (in the west), Fula and Tamashek (desert nomads in the north).

FoodDrink.body:
The country is painfully poor, the food that can be found is not much culinary, unless it has to be fried grasshoppers (tastes like chips). There are plenty of restaurants in cities, the quality is usually not fantastic. Outside the cities you are on your own, taking a supply for 2-3 days is nice. For vegetarians there is rice and not much more than that.

Drinkable water
Tap water is available in the cities but also very scarce there. In Zinder it was there about 6 hours a day. The rest of the water comes from wells or pumps. Filtering is recommended in all cases.

Health.body:
• A yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs all year round. Precautions are recommended.
Availability hospitals / doctors
Healthcare is at a very low level. Pharmacies, for example, do not store their medicines refrigerated due to a lack of electricity.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Between March and June the temperature is at its highest and downright killer, especially in the north, in the desert. December to February are the best cycling months. In the desert, the temperature drops to freezing at night.

August is the month with the most rain, mainly in the south. Harmatan winds that blow before the rainy season can bring in suffocating dust and significantly impair visibility. Provide respiratory protection!

Spare parts
If you ride a Chinese bicycle, there are parts available, unfortunately these are of poor quality. Even tire patches suck, make sure you have plenty of them with you, thorns can be a problem. There are no Shimano parts, etc.

Because of the heat, it is advisable to also take a decent extra rim tape with you. (Glue comes loose, plastic becomes soft, etc.).
Do not rely on the skills of the bicycle mechanics, they are especially good at carpentry.

Nice routes
  • The route of Robert and Wiesje through the south: From Benin: Gaia, Birni N'Konni, Zinder towards Kano, Nigeria. “The landscape is a bit monotonous but it was exciting and the country has left an indelible impression.”
  • The classic heart of the country is around Agadez. This is an old trading town similar to Tomboucktou in Mali.
  • The Aïr Mountains are a spectacular area of dark volcanic rock. There are cave paintings dating as far back as 5000 BC.
  • In Tawachi, about 70 km. southwest of the city of Agadez is a huge cemetery of dinosaur remains. A start was made on uncovering some of them in 2000.

Safety.body: Niger is a politically safe country, it is one of the more stable democracies in the region. Corruption is less and less tolerated. In view of the visibly shocking poverty, you may experience it differently and guarantees cannot be given here. However, the chance that you will be approached aggressively is small.
Safety.body_nature: Dogs are normally not a problem.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Spontaneously invited to people's homes is not one of them. Not out of unwillingness, but simply because they are too poor for it.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There is a campsite in Niamey
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are hotels in the larger towns. Don't expect too much from the quality. More luxurious hotels mainly in Niamey.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible, but you will get a lot of attention near the villages.

Visa.body: If you come by land, visas for Niger are not available in the neighboring countries Mali and Burkina Faso. However, in Benin, Ivory Coast, Nigeria and Ghana. At the border would also be possible. Always provide sufficient passport photos.

FoodDrink.body:
Gasoline is available for cooking, the quality is generally poor, it still contains lead.

Markets
The fruit there is fantastic. Food is available everywhere on the street, but this is usually very boring. Moin-moin is quite tasty, which should be steamed bean flour puddings, sometimes with egg in them. In small towns there is a good chance of finding something edible at the bus station, in small villages there are almost always women sitting under the largest tree in the village square with plastic containers with spaghetti or rice. The quality of this is poor and it is bland (spaghetti or rice with just some oil). Hygiene is particularly bad ('washing dishes' is sometimes wiping with a finger...) If you cook yourself, the supplies can often be found on the street.

Restaurants
In the larger cities there are good restaurants, quite a few from the middle east. Usually it is very difficult even for meat eaters to get enough protein: often spaghetti is spaghetti and nothing else. As a vegetarian you can therefore manage, but not for a well-balanced meal. If there is sauce, it often contains meat.

Drinkable water
Tap water, insofar as it is available, is often not to be trusted, as is the water from wells. Bottled water is not available outside the major cities. The water sold in half liter bags is NOT SAFE, even though they look official! Be very careful with your water supply: pumps are not very dense.

Health.body:
It is very hot in the north: in addition to enough water, make sure you also have enough salts (ORS) in your luggage. Robert and Wiesje: “We often suffered from cramps.”

Vaccinations
  • Yellow fever vaccination is recommended and sometimes required.
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis, etc. are available on site.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The dry season is from October to May. Around March / April is the hottest period. With rain you can only cycle on major roads and that is a lot less interesting.

Spare parts
There are many small bicycle shops, with beautiful bicycle decorations: saddle pads, waving hands, pink plumes. Old-fashioned parts are everywhere, just like 28 x 1.3/8 tires of moderate quality, for more modern parts you have to rely on the bigger cities and/or luck.

There are bicycle repair shops everywhere, the hammer is his most important tool. Usually people are not familiar with the common travel bikes in Europe, make sure you know your bike well and are ready to intervene if you do hand it over to a repairer.

People.body:
The population was experienced as very nice. Because very few whites come, the interest is even greater than in the surrounding countries. Fortunately, people are usually genuinely interested.

Robert and Wiesje: "People bought us water a few times. The people were incredibly warm, but we were not easily invited to their home".
Officially, the Sharia (law of Islam) is in force in the north. Robert and Wiesje: “However, when Wiesje crossed the border with a headscarf in the north, she was almost laughed at by the customs officers.”

The official language is English, it is spoken in the larger cities, but nobody speaks it in the smaller villages. The main local languages are Hausa, Igbo and Yoruba.

Safety.body:
Safety depends on the area you are traveling through. The south and especially Lagos and the southern highway are known to be unsafe. In 2020 there have been at least a few people that cycled from West to East Nigeria, staying on the South side of the country. DO NOT go to the North, this is where Boko Haram is located.

Robert and Wiesje: “Because of the friendly locals, it seemed safe to us: we left our bicycles 'unguarded' somewhere for a short time. But... we haven't been to the south, this seems to be a completely different world. We have heard many negative stories about Lagos, so we avoided that. When we told in the Netherlands that we would be cycling through Nigeria, we received a lot of warnings that it would be really dangerous. As with 'dangerous areas', those warnings became less frequent and more nuanced the closer we got to Nigeria. After a while we only heard that 'the south' would be dangerous, when we were in Nigeria they said 'only Lagos is dangerous', when we spoke to people from Lagos who reacted surprised to our question about safety, saying that only 1 neighborhood in Lagos that is really dangerous. We are not extreme daredevils, have flown over Sudan/Congos for example, but in our opinion the route we took through Nigeria is absolutely no less safe than neighboring countries.”

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are no campsites. Formal camping should be possible when asking permission from the chief. 

Robert and Wiesje: “The few times we asked in a village, we were accommodated in a school under construction. People didn't ask us to come in quickly: hospitality was mainly on the street.”
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are many very affordable hotels or guesthouses, although they are often of poor quality. In most cities the guesthouses are generally spacious, and the bicycles can easily be placed inside.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is fine here and there, but some areas are quite densely populated. It's better to ask permission from the chief. Two Swiss guys were found wildcamping and locals started to shoot guns in the air, and used a knife to demolish the tent, as the locals thought they were bad guys. Eventually it turned out that these locals were jsut trying to protect their area, and brought the Swiss guys to the chief, were they could stay.

Visa.body:
Getting a visa for Nigeria is very difficult, but we've heard succesful stories. Please share your experience if you have been able to obtain it. You might want to contact these 2 Swiss guys. They obtained a bussiness visa in Benin with quite some hassle.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
This beautiful Scandinavian country has very much to offer for cyclists and it is famous for it's wild and unspoiled nature.

First of all it has very good and well paved roads with usually enough space for cyclists and if there isn't the drivers are behaving well. Also many dirt tracks can be cycled. 

From the capital Oslo you can cycle north to climb the Hardangervidda the biggest European plateau from which you can descend into the land of fjords which are represented amongst almost all the southwestern coast. Cycle next to the fjordwaters with huge cliffes to be seen all around you and take bridges and ferries to hop the countless islands around the coastline.

Also very popular is to cycle to the North cape, as known by many this is seen as the most northern point of Europe. On the way to it do not forget to include the Lofoten as there seem to be very scenic places that would blow away your imagination.

Really recommended to take good rain clothing because in some places it could rain more than 300 days per year.

Going out for dinner is usually very expensive in Norway.

Feel free to write your own experiences of Norway.

Corona.body:
It is not necessary to wear masks in public, shops or anything.
There are many possibilitys to disinfect.

FoodDrink.body:
There is plenty of food and drink available everywhere. The prices are a lot higher than in Belgium or the Netherlands.

Cooking fuel
Unleaded petrol and diesel are readily available. I have used camping gas with valve tanks. They are expensive but obtainable. Spiritus is called rødsprit (pronounced "reu-sprit") and I've only come across it at gas stations; sometimes it's not on the shelf and you have to ask for it. Esbit blocks are not available.

Supermarkets/shops
Supermarkets are your source of food. Stock up enough. There is a supermarket in all larger towns. If you are short, you can often still buy something at gas stations, but you will then pay the main price.

Along the coastal route there are many villages with supermarkets within a short distance of each other. Opening times vary widely, often until 8pm in larger towns and are occasionally open on Sundays as well. In small villages they may close at 5pm. The shops are often closed before 10 am. If you have left a village before that time and you do not have emergency rations, then you have to be sure that you will find a shop or eatery before 5 p.m.

Food items such as bread are also available at some campgrounds and gas stations.

Stalls on the street
No experience with it, except in the fruit harvest time. Stalls with boxes of strawberries and raspberries are then unmanned. You put the money in a bowl and take the fruit with you. Usually it comes in an open box, so eat it on the spot.

Restaurants
Restaurants abound, but eating out in Norway is very expensive.

Drinkable water
Water from rivers and streams is pure and drinkable. Water from fjords is salty!! I'm hesitant to drink water from lakes (still), but Norwegians assure me that you can just drink that.

Health.body: Mosquitoes can be very annoying sometimes. Buy a good mosquito oil, provide a "mosquito-proof" tent and always stand in the wind. Cook before the wind dies down in the evening. Jim: "During my 3-week holiday in August there was no wind and I had hardly seen any mosquitoes."

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Anyone who goes cycling in Norway should prepare for (a lot of) rain. However, once a high pressure area has settled above Scandinavia, it can also linger there for a long time and you might as well have a warm sunny summer. During the day it is warm while in the evening it cools down and it remains light indefinitely. In recent years, it appears that June is the best summer month. July and August are often very wet. Although September can sometimes still be a beautiful month, keep in mind that from mid-August the summer comes to an end and the temperatures can already drop considerably.

Every season is wet. Norway has only two kinds of rain: 1: a lot and 2: a lot. A good rain suit is a basic requirement for cycling in Norway. The weather can change quickly, by the way: heavy rain in the morning and radiant sun in the afternoon or rain in the evening and at night, followed by a bright day. You go to Norway for the views and when it rains you don't see anything. Therefore, build in your planning rainy days when you do not have to move. There also seem to be longer dry periods, but I was not allowed to experience that during two bike rides of several months each.

There are big differences in temperature and precipitation between north, west and south of Norway. In general, the weather can change quickly. In summer, the chance of rain, especially on the coast, is high.

The autumn period (September/October) is very beautiful, because of the intensive autumn colours. You are also hardly bothered by mosquitoes. The weather can then still be reasonable (sunny and reasonable temperatures), but can quickly turn to cold weather (snow).

People.body:
The people are friendly and hospitable, but will not easily approach you of their own accord. If you ask them something, they are very friendly and helpful.

Norwegian is a language related to German and Dutch. If you read a text out loud, it often makes sense. The spoken language is incomprehensible to a beginner. Don't worry, almost all Norwegians (except older people in the north) speak good English.

QuickFacts.language:
-Official Language: Norwegian
-Pretty much everyone speaks very good english

Safety.body_criminality: There is little crime, but I always lock the bike. I have never felt unsafe. There are warnings about bicycle theft in cities.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Along the way there are many huts at campsites but also at private homes. A welcome luxury on a rainy day and these are often cheaper, sometimes under Nkr200. I have come across mini huts for Nkr100..
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are plenty of campsites, but they can be pricey. For most campsites you pay Nkr 60-150 for one tent, it does not matter whether you are with 1 or 2 people. You often have to pay for a hot shower separately. Campsites in and around large cities are usually more expensive. Campsites often have a kitchen or dining area. An overview of campsites can be found at www.nafcamp.com
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels are in abundance, but they are very expensive by Western European standards. The quality is very good.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is allowed in Norway, except in nature parks. A practical problem is that quite often the ground is very swampy or very rocky and far from level.

Transport.body_boat:
It is no problem at all on a car ferry. The Hurtigrute is also quite simple. Be attentive when you arrive at the port where you get off. It is usually forgotten to open the door to the car deck (where your bicycle is). It is most convenient to leave the boat via the passenger exit and go to your bicycle via the luggage entrance.

There are also boats that cannot be used by cars (including Hurtigbåt). Taking the bike with you is usually no problem at all. Often the bicycle is outside on the deck and in case of strong waves the chain must have a squirt of oil. Salt water makes it rust quickly. A practical problem is the usually rather narrow gangways. Depending on the tide, you have to pull the bike up or down steeply. The aluminum gangways get treacherously slippery in wet weather.
Transport.body_bus:
In the far north it's no problem at all to take your bike with you. A long-distance bus usually has a cargo compartment at the back where the bicycle with luggage and all is hoisted via the hydraulic tailgate. Pay attention to the anchoring of the bicycle yourself. Some drivers are casual about that.

In buses without a cargo compartment, the bicycle must be placed at the bottom of the bus. All luggage must then be removed. I've never had any problems with the bike on the bus.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body: Cycling in Oman is wonderful, nice weather and very friendly people. When it comes to sightseeing, Oman has to rely mainly on its natural beauty: The extensive desert landscapes, Dhofar that turns into a green rolling oasis in summer during the khareef (the local monsoon), Masirah, Wadi Tiwi, Jebel Akdar and Jebel Shams are beautiful . Muscat is not super special, an afternoon in the souk and a tour to the palace are nice, but the real 'Middle East' feeling is a bit lacking.

FoodDrink.body:
Food and drink is very cheap. During Ramadan, eating and drinking in public is prohibited. However, as long as you do it inconspicuously, it's no problem.

Cooking fuel
Campinggaz is readily available in the major cities, gasoline is dirt cheap and small tanks are topped up with a big smile without any problems.

Markets
In the desert you will only find small markets where nothing is actually for sale. From Duqm you can find reasonably assorted supermarkets again. Hygiene can be called excellent compared to other Arab countries

Supermarkets
Shops are sparse, especially in the desert areas (every 100km with a little luck), but the locals are very friendly and regularly stop you for something to eat or drink. This applies to the many oil workers who find it interesting to chat with you during lunch in the canteen.

All the ingredients for a good meal are available in the shops, but pay attention to the shelf life! Bread, in particular, can be spoiled. Prices are low. You get the best food at people's homes.

Restaurants
Eating in small restaurants along the road is good if you like Indian, often basic, but fine. The choice of restaurants is limited. In many smaller places there is nothing to be found, in large cities the offer is better.

Drinkable water
Douwe en Blanche: "Almost everywhere you will find a mosque where you can tap cooled drinking water and shower water. Sometimes the drinking water facilities have filters." Tap water is usually drinkable as it comes from great depths in the desert.

Health.body:
Mandatory vaccinations
If you come from a yellow fever area, a vaccination is mandatory.

Useful vaccinations for cyclists
A DTP vaccination is recommended, as is protection against Hepatitis A. Typhoid fever vaccination is recommended when traveling longer than 2 weeks.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
December and January is a great time to visit Oman, although there are sometimes cold winds. During the day temperatures up to about 30 degrees, in the morning about 15. In the rainy season from June to September it is unpleasant to stay in the south.

Spare parts
There are many bicycle repair shops to be found in case of an emergency, but they will generally only be used to bicycles of the India model. In Muscat (Raleigh shop) and Sur there are bicycles and bicycle shops based on the western model. If you are looking for a specific spare part, it is better to look for it in Dubai (Wolfi's Bikeshop is a small paradise in that regard).

People.body:
Population consists of 50% Omani and 50% guest workers. The Omani are very friendly and helpful.

Arabic is the official language. Urdu is also widely spoken. In Muscat people speak reasonable English, in other big cities less, and outside of that hardly any.

Safety.body:
The sultanate has no Muslim extremism. In fact, it is known for religious tolerance. Women alone are almost never harassed by male Omanis.

In Dhofar (South Oman) there are still a few land mines from the civil war (1960s to early 1970s) that are off the beaten track.

Douwe en Blanche: "We camped there almost every night without any problems. People also say that there is no theft and you are safe everywhere. Only the traffic is something to watch out for, the Omani love to race"
Safety.body_traffic: It is often busy on the main roads (mainly roads in a radius of 30 km around Seeb Airport are very annoying), but on the smaller roads it is quiet. Motorways are easier to cycle on than through roads because they have a wide hard shoulder or a quiet parallel road.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: People regularly invite you to spend the night at their home.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no official campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels are often expensive and limited to large cities. Often minimum price of 20 euros per night for a simple room without breakfast (info 2006). There are more hotels outside the major cities than listed in travel guides. However, they are difficult to find and the quality seems to be moderate to poor.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: It is often difficult to find a good camping site. It is either rocky and not flat or strong in sight from a village or the road. Furthermore, free camping is not a problem, there is more than enough space in the desert, and a kilometer from the road there is no one left to find you. If that happens, you will be left alone.

Visa.body:
Quite a lot of nationalities can enter Oman without a visa.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
There are many eateries and you can eat in every hotel. The food is one-sided (chapati and dal) and often spicy. The food is greasy, very greasy. Most cyclists have stomach problems when they arrive in Quetta. Be careful with food, hygiene is not that great. In guesthouses for tourists the food is usually reasonable. Good food for vegetarians is hard to find. Cooking yourself is wise.

Drinkable water
Water is available at every village. You have to purify this water because water from a pump is not really hygienic. Tap water is also not reliable. In the cities (Quetta, Punjab, Sindh) mineral water is widely available. Soft drinks are also easy to get. There is absolutely no alcohol available. You can drink sweet tea anywhere.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Fall, winter and early spring are suitable for the lowlands in the south. Summer is suitable for the Himalayas. Martin: "It was very hot in the Baluchistan desert in mid-October. When I left Quetta in early November, it was with gloves on in the morning."

Freek and Quirien: "April-May is a good period for the KKH. It is already very hot in the sun, although it cools down considerably at night in the higher areas (to freezing point). near the pass). Please note that the pass is not open all year round: in the spring it opens on May 1 (and closes October 31, I believe)."

Spare parts
High quality parts are only available in Punjab and Sindh. There is little cycling, so bring your own parts. People are inventive with repairs.

People.body:
The people are nice, very hospitable and curious. It is almost impossible not to get in touch. However, you see few women, they are not part of everyday life. In bazaars you see them but heavily veiled. Only as a woman can you come into contact with other women. However, as a woman it is better to wear a veil and long clothes. Appropriate clothing is very important. Long pants and a long-sleeved shirt are recommended.

The population consists of Pakistanis, Afghans, Punjabi, Shina, Waghi and many more populations. • People speak Urdu, but many also know English.

Safety.body_nature: In some places some pebbles come rolling down the mountain: then it is better to wear a helmet. The road from Gilgit to Skardu is very narrow, with poor road surfaces and steep sections. The abyss is steep and deep. So be careful if you come across a truck: get off if necessary.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: People often ivite you to their homes, which is fun, cheap and safe (with the exception of tribal areas).
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Occasionally there are campsites and sometimes you can pitch your tent at a hotel.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
There are plenty of hotels everywhere, with the exception of the desert, where you will still find primitive accommodation options. Along the Karakoram Highway there is a hotel in every place, which is also cheap. They eat together there. There is a so-called “traveler” atmosphere.

Accommodations are also easy to find between Islamabad and Lahore, it is not equally clean everywhere. If there is no hotel, there are sometimes PWD government resthouses. They are often still very British and basic, but cheap. Hotels in cities are often very dirty.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: In quiet areas free camping is often dangerous, in busy areas (Punjab and Sindh) too restless.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Pakistan.

Visa policy of Pakistan
  Pakistan
  Visa-free entry; eligible for all electronic visas
  Electronic Travel Authorization for visa on arrival for tourism and business purposes; online visa application eligible
  Electronic Travel Authorization for visa on arrival for business purposes only; online visa application eligible
  Online visa application only
  Visa required in advance
Source: Wikipedia.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Changing climates in different parts of the country. In the mountains it can cool down considerably in the evening. Usually warm and around David hot.

Spare parts
Seen several bike shops, most with simple bikes. Also quite a lot of 28 inch tires.

Nice routes
  • Last Uvas - El Valle de Antón - Penonomé: Good asphalt, little traffic, beautiful surroundings, plenty of supplies.
  • Santiago - Soná - Guabito: Quiet tarred alternative to the Panamericana, with beautiful nature.
  • La Concepción - Volcán - Río Sereno: Good road to paddle to Costa Rica in peace.

Visa.body:
Quite a lot of nationalities can enter Panama without a visa.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
Partly due to the many immigrants, there is a lot of comparable food available in addition to the local food. Price approx 4$. The many stalls along the way and the large supermarkets provide enough stock and variety. The well-known "mate" herbal tea is drunk here cold (so no boiled water!)

Drink
Peter: In the chaco alto, in addition to my three water bottles, I carried another three 5-litre jerry cans with me, two of which I had put in my front bags, the third I never filled because I had a good idea where I could get some again. I always had extra water with me for 1 day. I often trusted water from the ground, I had a pump with me and micropur pills. If I could buy water, I'd rather do it.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle 
May to September is the most ideal for cycling here.

Spare parts
A lot of items are available in Asuncion. Hardware stores often sell cycling gear as well.

Nice routes
Chaco Alto - drought, heat, little food and water, bad roads, no traffic, wild animals (including puma) and virtually uninhabited. Peter chose to sleep at military posts for safety, often he could also get water here and sometimes something to eat. The soldiers were very hospitable. These distances could be done in a day:
  • Boyuibe - Choroquetaz 65km (11.00-17.30), in school.
  • Choroquetaz - Villazon 77km (8.30-17.00) in border post.
  • Villazon - Mister Long 27km (8.15-17.00) in military post.
  • Mister Long – Nueva Asunción walk 18km (10:00-15:00) in military post. After 3.15 hours of walking: estancia with food and drink (Don Pedro).
  • Nueva Asunción – La Patria 95km (8.00-19.00) camped at hotel. Here you can also buy food in a supermarket.
  • La Patria – Mariscal Estigarribia 120km (10.30-21.30) in hotel alleman.

People.body:
The people are largely hospitable and curious and contact is easily made. Appropriate clothing is required.

The language is Guaraní, but most people also speak Spanish, sometimes with some reluctance. Furthermore, German and Portuguese are sometimes spoken and some English.

Safety.body: Safety doesn't seem to be an issue, with normal caution.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: It's possible to stay at a farm (estancia) or private individual.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Free camping is possible, if you dare.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In a little town you can find (budget) hotels from 5$.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Paraguay without a visa for up to 90 days.

  Paraguay
  Countries with visa-free access to Paraguay
  Visa on arrival to Paraguay
  Visa required for entry to Paraguay
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Beautiful country with a lot of historical, cultural and natural places. Perú is divided by the Coast, the Andes mountains, and the Amazon rainforest and all are worth to be visited.
People is warm and willing to help, the food is delicious, and you will find landscapes you won´t want to stop watching.
Perú doesn´t have a cycling culture, but is visited by a lot of biking tourists.

Corona.body: The Corona is spreading very fast, now the country is in quarantine and the public health service is collapsed.

FoodDrink.body:
A typical Peruvian dish is fried guinea pig.

Restaurants
Cheap restaurants can be found in all villages and towns, often located at bus stops and markets. Restaurants often have one set menu for a few euros. This is usually good to eat and enough for a cyclist! Cheaper meals are not big, simple and one-sided.

The slightly better restaurants in the cities in the highlands are also not expensive. In the Andes region, taking food for a few days is not a luxury. Vegetarian dishes are not available as standard.

Drink
Be careful with water from the tap, this is not very reliable. Everywhere along the road you can buy drinking water in shops and restaurants. Exception: the sparsely populated desert areas. You have to bring enough water with you.

Health.body:
Even the smallest shops sell alcohol to disinfect wounds Almost every village has a botica / pharmacy / drugstore

Cycling at a high altitude means that you have to take altitude sickness into account. You better take it easy, even if you are still in such good shape. It is also better not to start your cycling tour in the highlands.

Desert areas: consume at least 5 liters pppd (incl. to prepare food). Be careful with water from the tap, this is not very reliable.

Other.body:
Nice routes
  • Peru's Great Divide by Neil and Harriet Pike. Information on their site http://www.andesbybike.com This is a really beautiful and challenging route!
  • Tour of Huaraz - Cordillera Blanca Bicycle Junkies in the Cordillera Blanca
  • Karin Troch and Marten IJzerman cycle in 2011 from the north through the Andes to the south, crossing the high mountains of the Cordillera Blanca up to 2 times
  • The surroundings of Cuzco and the road Ocongate to Urcos are beautiful.
  • The Colca Canyon is beautiful but certainly not spectacular.
Best time to cycle
The Andes: in summer (November - March). Then it is less cold than the rest of the year. The desert areas (coast): in summer (November - March). Then it is less foggy than the rest of the year. In other areas, May is a suitable month for cycling in Peru: just after the rainy season and before the high season.

Spare parts
Bicycle parts are mainly available in the cities. Also Shimano parts. The local tire size is 26 inches. The common brakes are v-brakes.

People.body:
The population is friendly and helpful, but also greedy for money (but that probably applies to every poor country). The response to cyclists is mixed. Robertjan: "Some throw stones. Others see money in you. Still others are genuinely interested. The stone throwers are relatively in the minority (this happened to me in 3 and a half months), the money seekers and the genuinely interested make up the largest group."

The most widely spoken languages are Spanish, Quéchua and Aymara. Little English is spoken outside the tourist areas.

QuickFacts.climate:
Coast: mild weather and humid. Very warm in summer, not so cold in winter.
Highlands: sunny and dry in summer, rainy and very cold in winter.
Rainforest: very rainy and very humid.
QuickFacts.currency:
Sol (PEN). 1 USD=3.6 PEN
There are 10, 20, 50, 100, 200 bills and 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5 coins.

Safety.body: Outside the big cities and main highways, it is safe ride. But you always have to be careful.
Safety.body_criminality: In general there is no big criminality, just in big cities in specific places. However, you should always be careful with your belongings.
Safety.body_nature:
Cycling at a high altitude means that you have to take altitude sickness into account. You better take it easy, even if you are still in such good shape. It is also better not to start your cycling tour in the highlands. Like everywhere in the mountains, with "heavy" rainfall, landslides very easily occur.

Desert areas: consume at least 5 liters pppd (incl. to prepare food).
Safety.body_traffic: Traffic in big cities is very hard and sometimes drivers don´t respect cyclist. Always be careful when biking in highways.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
There is a big Couchsurfing offer in big and touristic cities. Not so many Warmshowers, but it is growing. 

Private individuals are somewhat reluctant to invite. Unless they own a hotel/restaurant, and/or there is no hostel for miles around. Of course you can always ask if you can set up your tent.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Only in touristic places. Some hostel give space for camping.
Sleeping.body_hostels: the quantity and quality of hostels or hotels is according to the size and the tourism/industry in the city.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: It is not commonly forbidden, but if there is a house around, it is better to ask first.

Transport.body_airplane: There is one Internaational Airport in Lima, the capital city. You can flight directly from Europe and almost all the American Countries.
Transport.body_boat:
In the Amazon Rainforest there are cities where you only can get by boat. There are big and small boats depending on the size of the river.
You can also navigate in the Titicaca Lake.
Transport.body_bus: You can go almost anywhere in Perú by bus.
Transport.body_train: Very few destinations in the south of Perú. Just for touristic purposes.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Peru without a visa.



Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: The Philippines is a revelation! An ideal cycling country, good roads, nice and quiet, hospitable, incredibly nice people, safe, cheap, beautiful beaches, good food, etc.

FoodDrink.body:
Filipinos love fast food, all possible variants are available. In local restaurants there are a row of pans that you can choose from. For simple meals you will not spend more than €3. 

There are many fish dishes available. Also with raw fish, but that is probably not very wise to eat. Vegetarians have a little less choice, but there is plenty. Lots of fruits too. Or buy yourself a fish at the market and someone will put it on the BBQ for you, they smoke everywhere.

Drinkable water
Drinking tap water is not recommended. Good enough to brush your teeth. Mineral water is for sale everywhere. Water costs €0.50 to €1 per litre. Filtering is of course also an option. Along the way you can regularly buy cooled soft drinks in shops, restaurants and gas stations. This costs about €0.30 for a bottle, cans cost double.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In winter it is dry here and there is little natural violence. April: Fairly warm, 35-40 degrees but almost no rain. The rainy season starts in mid-May. December, January and February for the northern islands, December is still rainy season in the south. The country has a tropical climate with a dry and rainy season. On Samar , Leyte and Mindanao there can always be a shower.

Spare parts
Peter (2006): "In the bigger cities there are good bike shops with all modern parts such as Shimano, the most common tire size is 26 inches." Peter has also seen many small workshops with welding equipment along the way.

Nice routes
Peter cycled the following route in 2006: Angeles, Manila, Lucena, Naga, Legazpi on Luzon, Samar the west coast, the west coast from Leyte to Maasin, from there a ferry to Mindanao, Bohol, Cebu, Negros, Panay and back to Mindoro via Mindoro. Manila. He found this as a whole interesting and much more adventurous for the cyclist than, for example, Thailand.

People.body:
The people are nice, candid and hospitable. You will also meet many Filipinos in touristic places who are on holiday themselves.

Everyone who went to school speaks English because that is what is taught. English is an important trade language. As a first language people sometimes speak local languages with, for example, a beautiful name like Tagalog!

Safety.body: Peter: "I have had no unpleasant experiences or heard this from other travellers."
Safety.body_criminality: Watch out for pickpockets in Manila (Malate), otherwise it feels safe everywhere.
Safety.body_nature: There are many dogs, but they do not cause much trouble.

Sleeping.body_hostels:
count
You can always find a hotel in the larger cities. In some hotels the price is not stated per night but per hour (short stay), it is better not to take that. Distances between hotels are usually easy to cycle in a day. Price per room varies between €6 and €15.

Accommodation is easy to find in the cities (hostels and cheap hotels). Outside there is adequate accommodation but only basic and often spartan. For those who want a little more luxury, there are often pleasant resorts in places with a beautiful beach.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is not recommended. Too many people and a lot of buildings or agriculture along the roads.

About.body: To say that Poland is a gray country is a prejudice. Near the big cities there are indeed still gray areas, but in the countryside it is really quiet cycling and there is still a lot of untouched nature. You can regularly see nesting storks. The country also has more to offer in terms of culture than you might think. There are a lot of quiet roads of decent quality. It is sometimes said that you have to watch out for the trucks, but not everyone has negative experiences with that. Reason why you would cycle to this country: To meet real nature, or to get to know the taste of vodka. (Choose Zubrówka, vodka with a blade of peat grass).

Border.body: There are plenty of borders to cross. There are no problems with neighboring countries.

FoodDrink.body:
Polish cuisine is quite simple, sometimes surprising and consists of soup (always) and a meal, usually something with potatoes, vegetables and a piece of meat. Recommendations: gołąbki: dish of meat rolled in cabbage leaves, buckwheat, pierogi: ravioli, bigos: sauerkraut dish (mushrooms, sauerkraut, sausage, meat, real winter dish), nalesniki: pancakes.

Cooking fuel
We found a few very well-equipped outdoor sports specialists, but cooking fuel proved elusive. We just used gasoline. Spiritus ("denaturat") can only be found in the large supermarkets (we have not tried hardware stores), in half litres. Note: there are several types of denaturate: look on the label for 90% (or more) ethanol / ethyl alcohol.

Markets 
Can be found in almost every place, sometimes huge with literally everything for sale, sometimes just a few stalls. Open early in the morning, closing time: between 2 and 4 pm.

Supermarkets 
Can be found everywhere, even in the small villages there are mini-supermarkets, recognizable under the name sklep. These shops (sklep) are open from early in the morning until late at night, often also on Sundays. You never have to buy large packages; almost everything can be done individually. Supermarkets, but also the village shops usually have a reasonable to wide range of fruit and fresh, canned and frozen vegetables.

Stalls on the street 
In kiosks you can sometimes order a zapiekanka, a baked baguette with tomato, cheese and onion. Sometimes they offer more: typical Polish soups (Zurek), Bigos (sauerkraut dish) or other delicacies.

Restaurants 
Available in most villages, in the cities there are many eateries. In some cities there are still "bar mleczny" (literally milk (product) bars): self-service canteens with a limited menu. Traditional dishes, a legacy of the former communism.

Drinkable water 
No problem at all. Tap water is generally safe, although depending on the region, a lot of chlorine may have been added. In some cities (Wroclaw for example) Poles never drink tap water themselves: too dirty! They buy spring water, or get water from the countryside. Pump water in the very small villages is sometimes of questionable quality and sometimes tastes very much like rust. There is plenty of bottled water for sale. The water at the campsites is usually questionable, purifying or filtering is recommended. Sometimes there are 2 pumps, one for drinking water (woda do picia).

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
June-July-August are the most humid months, and even then it hardly ever rains. The chance of rain is highest in August. September is called the golden autumn and is drier. It can get a bit warmer in the south. For nature lovers, the end of May, the beginning of June is the most interesting period.

Spare parts
Cheap mountain bikes with 26" tires are often sold. But there are also other bicycles, conventional 28" tires are also easy to buy. Dutch bicycles (grandma bicycles) are a trend in large cities.

There are bicycle repair shops. Pay special attention to the inscription rowery (rower is bicycle). Usually they are shops where they sell bicycles and bicycle parts in addition to home appliance (AGD) audio, video or TVs. You can recognize a bicycle repairman by naprawy rowerów (bicycle repair). After a bit of searching and asking, you can find something you can go to in almost every provincial town.

Special sightseeing
  • Warsaw (Warszawa) is a big city, there are beautiful churches, palaces and parks. They are a bit apart, but for a cyclist that is of course no problem.
  • Krakow (Kraków) has a very picturesque and compact city center.
  • From Krakow you can take the bus to Wieliczka where there is a beautiful salt mine (with guided tour in several languages). These salt mines are on the UNESCO World Heritage List and are highly recommended.
  • Treblinka and Auschwitz (Oswiecim) and Auschwitz Birkenau (Brzezinka) are sad but well worth a visit, even the small road there.
  • Gdańsk The "old" city center is well worth a visit. In 1939, at the beginning of W.W. II, this city center has been totally destroyed. After the war it was rebuilt exactly as it was before the war. It is striking that it is not visible that all this is "new".
  • Toruń My hometown and the birthplace of Copernicus. One of the few cities in Poland that was not bombed in WWII (just like Kraków). The old town is in its entirety on the UNESCO World Heritage List. One large succession of brick Gothic. From the south bank of the river Wisła (German: Weichsel), where there is also a camping site, a magnificent view of the old town, ramparts and gates.
  • Malbork The town itself, in the north of Poland on the river Nogat, is not much. A major attraction is the largest brick castle in Europe, the Marienburg, the headquarters of the Teutonic Order (Knights of the Cross) from the early 14th century to the mid-15th century. There is a campsite in Malbork.
  • Wroclaw City in Silesia on the river Odra: many monuments, churches, beautiful Rynek (market) with Ratusz (town hall). Interesting is Panorama Raclawicka. There are several campsites in Wroclaw.
  • Primeval forest Bialowieza Around Bialowieza, close to the border with Belarus is the largest remnant of the primeval forest that once covered central Europe. Half of the forest (as large as the province of Utrecht) is located in Belarus and is not easily accessible. Bialowieza is located in Podlasie, 20 km east of Hajnówka.
Fun tracks
  • Warsaw -> Kazimierz Dolny -> Sandomierz -> Krasniow -> Krakow -> Miedzybrodzie Bialskie.
  • From just outside Warsaw you can follow the Vistula River to Kraków. Start in Warszawa on the east side of the Vistula. The first 15 km is largely a cycle path. Then you drive along a main but not too busy road. Sometimes you drive right next to the rivers, sometimes you drive a few km from them. It is a relatively easy course without difficult slopes. There is a hotel boat in Kazimierz Dolny where you can enjoy the tranquility and sunset.
  • The Bialowieski and Biebrzanski National Parks are well worth a visit: moose, bison, the last virgin forest in Europe. Best time is late April to early summer: lots of birds, few mosquitoes.

People.body:
The local population is generally friendly, especially in the cities, in the villages they are a bit shy. If you speak a word of Polish, the people appear to be very hospitable.

In the cities the knowledge of English is not a problem, in the smaller villages it is more difficult to find someone who speaks some English, often the local youth knows a little bit of English. You sometimes come across German or French speakers. If it's to find a place to sleep or something to eat or drink, sign language is always an option too. A language guide is useful. People often react very positively when you try to speak Polish!

Safety.body: Poland is a safe country for tourists. Crimnality is at a level similar to that in other countries of the European Union.
Safety.body_traffic:
Avoid the major through roads (red roads on the map). The drivers are quite courteous. In terms of crowds, it is certainly not that bad since we mostly cycled on secondary roads.

More and more Poles have a car. Because there are not that many highways, most traffic is handled on the N-roads. These are therefore quite busy. Driving is quite fast on these roads. On roads with a lane for slow traffic, left overtaking maneuvers are often performed.

Near the larger towns, the drivers can be quite brutal and aggressive. It helps to be clearly visible and to make yourself wider than you are, so that you can swerve if necessary. On the smaller roads the traffic is less busy and it is quieter cycling.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Poles love camping, but camping sites are scarce outside the tourist zones. Sandra: "Our experience in Western Poland was that most of the campsites indicated on the (very up-to-date) map did NOT exist. There is no camping tradition in this area."

Farm camping sites are especially recommended. Look out for "AGROKEMPING", "AGROCAMPING" or "AGROTURYSTYKA". The latter is often room rental from the farmer, sometimes with the option of camping. They are not expensive and often have nice places. There are also often nice people to be found there. For example, in and around the Biebrzanski National Park, http://www.biebrza.org.pl, Poland's largest national park, there are several small camping areas. Website unfortunately only in Polish, click on the homepage on "Baza Noclegowa", Pole Namiotowe.

Larger campsites are often noisy and dirty and less geared to cyclists. Outside the holiday season it is quiet. In bad weather it can happen that a campsite is closed because no visitors are expected.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In the big cities you can find hostels for €5,- and are also good.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Poland is also great for wild camping, although it is officially banned. There are many forests and fallow farmlands. If you ask you can stand on a farmer's land, we don't think this would cause a problem.

Bas: "Once I camped on a farmland without permission, and was scared away in the morning by an angry farmer, so make sure to ask".

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body: Portugal is a great destination for cyclists. Enjoy some of the beautiful and historical cities, or find yourself between the beautiful landscapes. The food is amazing, the climate can be good depending on the time and place you visit.

FoodDrink.body:
Portugal has great pastries to offer ("pastel de nata" are a must). Also the Bacalhau is a popular dish.

Supermarkets
In the larger villages there are supermarkets that are comparable to those in the Netherlands. The supermarkets are often open until the evening and on Sundays. Small villages often have a small shop with a necessary supply. There are not many gas stations, so for drinks and snacks you will have to cycle to a village.

Restaurants
Eating out is cheap in Portugal. In every village there is a restaurant with a cheap daily menu. Portions are always large and a glass of wine is often included. Often villages are completely extinct, but the restaurant turns out to be full.

Usually at the start of the meal - unsolicited - a plate is placed with smaller dishes. This is not free, if you taste it it will be on your account. You can ask for it to be removed from your table without any problem.

Not the easiest country for vegetarian, but its slowly improving, especially in major cities.

Drinkable water
Many villages have pumps or a well. This water is good to drink. The water from the wells along the mountain roads is also good. Bottled drinking water is available in many places.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Algarve: Spring is most suitable for Algarve and the surrounding interior. In summer it is unbearably hot.
Central and Northern Portugal: The best weather is in May-June and September with temperatures between 25 and 30 degrees. In the dry part of the interior it cools down considerably at night. In August it is usually warm but a sleeping bag is needed at night, sometimes rain and getting warmer towards the south until hot on some days. In the mountains it is also doable in summer.

Special sightseeing
The Rota Vicentina is a hiking trail and opened in 2013 in the southwest of Portugal. (Alentejo) This route follows the jagged cliff coast from Santiago do Cacem to Sagres in the south. (rotavicentina.com). The route is also indicated as a mountain bike trail. It is very nice to plan a hike of about 10 days (including cycling from Lisbon). Count on solid mountain biking, especially with a pack! Best time: April-May.

People.body: Very friendly people who are willing to help. If you're cycling through rural areas people are likely to wave at you. In the north people are friendlier, but also more modest than elsewhere. The Portuguese themselves are also aware of this distinction. It would have to do with the harsh winter climate in the north. As a woman, more southerly, you are approached more often than you would like.

Safety.body: Portugal is a safe country, especially in the east where only simple people live and everyone in the villages knows each other. Greed seems completely alien to these people.
Safety.body_criminality: The usual thinking of being more careful in some cities or touristy areas at night, but overall quite safe.
Safety.body_nature: Nothing really to worry about.
Safety.body_traffic:
Car drivers are still not very use to see cyclists on the road, but it's overall safe. Central and Northern Portugal: The roads are quiet inland. In (near) the cities, the main roads are especially busy. Motorists are not used to cyclists and oncoming traffic in particular can overtake recklessly.

Algarve: The main roads are busy and often highway-like. A number of through roads are prohibited for cyclists. The coastal road between Faro and Albufeira is more like a highway and, despite a wide hard shoulder, is unpleasant for cycling. In the conservatories outside the tourist area you are sometimes alone on the road for hours. You can avoid busy roads on the Ecovia de Algarve.

2160b5a1-576e-4957-b4fd-030c46069406.description: After a huge explosion, more than 1000 people died in the 18th century. The bones of the victims are now decorated on the walls of this chapel. It sounds scarier than it acctually is. Opening times vary, but I was lucky to meet the owner of the chapel who let me in while it was actually closed. There is no entrance fee, only a tip will be appreciated.
2160b5a1-576e-4957-b4fd-030c46069406.title: Capela dos Ossos de Campo Maior

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Lisbon and Porto have large couchsurfing communities. This is much less in the interior.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
In the tourist areas you can cycle from campsite to campsite. During the holidays these are busy, but there is always room. The ground is quite hard, a tent hammer is recommended. Campsites are often far apart outside the tourist areas.

Wild camping is possible in non-touristy areas. The population also thinks this is normal and will not report you to the local authorities.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In Portugal, many places have a guest house. The further from the tourist destinations, the cheaper they become.

Transport.body_bus: In the Algarve it is not possible to take a bicycle on the bus. Only in express buses from Algarve (Lagos) to Lisbon (bicycle in bag or box in 2015) or Porto or back. In northern Portugal you can always take a bus, they will not let you down.
Transport.body_train: Not all trains are allowed to accommodate cyclists. Sometimes you have to take the first or last train to get on by bike.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

As Puerto Rico is an unincorporated territory of the U.S.A., the same visa rules apply to Puerto Rico.

  The United States and its territories
  Visa-free countries
  Visa Waiver Program countries
  Visa required for entry to the United States

Source: Wikipedia.

Most nationalities need to apply for the visa waiver program, while some other nationalities need to apply for the evisa.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Romania has a lot to offer cyclists. There are mountains (Carpathians), hills (Transylvania) and plains (Danube basin). The Carpathians are densely forested, even bears and wolves still live there. Transylvania is a hilly landscape without steep slopes. The coast of the Black Sea seems to be beautiful and varied. Cycling in the countryside means pedaling from village to village, often with wooden houses with trees and geese. Many traditional costumes are still worn in the countryside on public holidays and Sundays. Some cities have drab large flats and industrial areas. However, there are also some beautiful cities such as Sighisoara.

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
In the larger villages there is usually a shop. Only in the mountains it can happen that you can't find a shop for one or two days.

Stalls on the street
