In somewhat larger towns you will find small shops with savory treats, such as covrigi (savory pretzels) and filled pancakes.

Restaurants
There are cheap restaurants, but the quality is often mediocre. There are almost never restaurants in the (small) villages. If you ask about a restaurant you will sometimes be offered a meal. Sometimes you can also eat in a hotel without having to sleep there. Some cafes also offer sausages (mici) with bread. A typical drink that is always and everywhere offered is ţuica (pronounced tsoeika), a plum gin.

Drinkable water
Tap water is drinkable almost everywhere, but it is good to inquire on site. Bottled water is available in many shops. There is not always water without carbon dioxide. In the mountains, water is not a problem. There are many springs and you can drink from streams.

There are drinking water wells in many villages (2011). I was only ill once, when there was no drinking cup hanging by the well. For the rest it went fine, without filter or pills in it.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In summer it can be quite hot. Especially in the south and near the Black Sea. It is cooler in the mountain areas, but it also rains more there. This is often accompanied by thunderstorms. In the spring it is nice cycling weather. Even when the sun shines, it doesn't get too hot. However, the higher mountain passes, for example Pasul Urdele (2141 meters), are not open due to snow.

Spare parts
26 inch tires are available and if you look carefully, also 28 inch. Availability of other parts is a problem. Some bike shops also sell Shimano products, but not always the latest series. There are bicycle repair shops, but a large set for self-help, with a spare tire is not a bad idea.

People.body:
The people are very nice, interested and hospitable. They don't understand that you don't have a car. Making contacts is quite easy, the people are generally helpful and interested. Some invite you to their home.

When you want to thank people by giving them some money, sometimes you have to push. Romanians sometimes don't take your payment, even if they are very poor. Keep pushing. Only after two or three offers will people accept it. Otherwise, just put the money on the table.

In churches and monasteries you have to be properly dressed.
There are quite a lot of beggars and other penniless people whose poverty is dire. Many people are also drinking. These people can be pushy at times.

Romanians hardly speak foreign languages. If they do, it is often Italian or French. However, more and more young people speak English or German, especially in the cities.

Safety.body: Romania is a safe country to cycle at.
Safety.body_traffic:
It is not recommended to cycle the Transfagarasan at the weekend as this road is very popular among Romanian tourists and it is one big stream of cars.

Main roads are not recommended due to the unreliable behavior of motorists. Compared to a few years ago, there has been an increase in traffic, especially on the main roads to Hungary. There are not many highways, which means that a lot of (heavy) transport travels on provincial roads. Where horse and carriage used to have plenty of space, they and you as a cyclist are pushed off the road. They don't take much into account, you just have to step aside. Great risks are often taken during overtaking maneuvers. Coming straight at you on the left lane is quite normal. A mirror is recommended.

However, side roads are still quiet, but their quality is sometimes deplorable. You will also encounter other traffic on very small roads / cart tracks about once every half hour. If not: GO BACK! Either you end up in a meadow, or the road has been washed away or you sink up to your armpits in the soggy clay a little further on.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are few campsites in Romania. You will find them mainly in border cities, Bucharest and the Black Sea. Incidentally, the number of campsites on the Black Sea is falling rapidly: they are making way for expensive resorts.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Rustic House, Turnu Magurele just off Eurovelo 6.  3 rooms for rent in annex of private house, secure bike store, mechanical help of needed and very hospitable hosts.  Traditional meals available.  WiFi, laundry.  Can book through AirBnb.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: You allowed to camp in the wild, but it is (as everywhere) advisable to take the necessary precautions (put your tent out of sight, do not light a fire). In certain parts of the country it is difficult to find a good camping spot due to ribbon development. Setting up your tent on a meadow (hayland) is not appreciated by the locals. Wild campers are strictly monitored on the Black Sea.

Transport.body_bus: Many coaches drive between the larger cities that also visit small villages, it was no problem for us to take the bicycles with us at the bottom of the luggage hold.
Transport.body_train: There are different types of trains: 'Personal', which run very slow and stop at every molehill, and 'Accelerat' which are faster. You buy train tickets for each train you take. The ticket also shows the train number and (usually) your seat. So if you have to change trains, you have two (or more) tickets.

Visa.body:
Romania is not yet part of the Schengen area, but are members of EU. However, they have a visa policy that is based on the Schengen policy.

Schengen Area visa lists.
  Schengen Area
  Other EU member states outside the Schengen Area but bound by the same visa policy and legally obliged to join the Area when they meet the criteria, and special territories of Schengen member states (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Member of the EU with independent visa policy (freedom of movement in the Schengen Area)
  Visa-free access to the Schengen states for short stays, usually 90 days in any 180-day period (EU 2018/1806 Annex II)
  Visa required to enter the Schengen states, and to transit some Schengen states in some circumstances (EU 2018/1806 Annex I)
  Visa required to transit any Schengen state (EC 810/2009 Annex IV)
  Travel documents not accepted
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Welcome to mother Russia. Perhaps this is not the most popular cycling destination at first sight, but let us give you some encouraging feedback that would convince you to go for it.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
You can of course cook your own food on your gas burner, the famous Gazprom will help you with gas. If you like it, it can even be used on wood, especially in Siberia it is widely available.

Markets
There are stalls everywhere, sometimes they only sell bread, sometimes only fruit. Sometimes they are also newsagents for newspapers and magazines.

Supermarkets
Grocery stores can be found in almost every village, note the word продукты (produkty). Also on Sunday. Sometimes shops are open 24 hours. Prices can be much higher in modern supermarkets than in small village shops.

Restaurants
Restaurants often have good food and excellent service. Note the word столовая (stolovaja): self-service restaurants with good and cheap food.

Along the main roads there are constantly roadside restaurants - note the word кафе (read: kaffè) - where you can eat well for a very pleasant price.

Drinkable water
In villages you will often find village taps and wells with drinking water. The quality is sometimes good, sometimes not so. In the cities, the water often contains chlorine. Sometimes it has a musty smell and tastes like rusted pipes. It is recommended that water is always bought as bottled water from the store.

Health.body: It may be wise to take preventive vaccinations against FSME. FSME is a nasty virus infection that is transmitted by ticks, just like Lyme disease. For more information, see www.saag.nl/nederland/teken.htm and www.zecken.de

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In southern Russia you can already cycle from the end of April, in northern Russia you still have to count on night frost and wet snow during that period. From mid-June to mid-September, almost all of Russia can be cycled, with the exception of the North Caucasus, where it is too hot.

Spare parts
Russians are happy to help you if you have technical problems. Heavier tools can be borrowed from the local population, they are used to being resourceful and helping each other. That is also expected of you as a cyclist.

Nice routes
  • Karelia. North of St Petersburg. An easily accessible area with beautiful nature and many lakes. The Baltic Star St. Petersburg club has a route around Lake Ladoga on its website, as does a route from Petrozavodsk to St. Petersburg. Usually around cat. 3.
  • Golden ring. This is a historic route that has been completely trodden down. Lots of culture and lots of amenities. The Golden Ring runs around Moscow with cities like Vladimir and Suzdal.
  • Black Sea coast. In the spring and autumn a nice area to travel, with good tourist facilities.
  • Altai Mountains. A rugged mountain area half a day trains south of Novosibirsk. Fantastic scenery, very empty and an experience in itself. From category 4 to expedition level."
Tips
There is a 9 hour time difference between Moscow and Chukotka (in the far east). The zones are quite erratic and often a zone changes by two hours. At stations and airports everything is indicated in Moscow time, both the schedules and the clocks run on Moscow time. Moscow is two hours ahead of our time.

People.body: The population is very friendly and helpful. Some cyclists experience the Russians as open, others find them reluctant at first. It can happen that a police patrol stops you out of sheer curiosity.

Safety.body:
There are the wildest stories about traveling in Russia: "it is unsafe, there is a lot of crime, police and customs make life difficult for tourists." That's all terribly exaggerated. After the chaotic 1990s, the security situation has greatly improved. The chance that you as a cyclist will end up in a dangerous situation is very small. Cyclists are not a target for the big criminals.

Make sure your papers are in order. Formally, you must have your visa registered within a few days of entry. Once you are registered for the period of your visa, you are free to go wherever you want. However, there are still 'forbidden cities' in the Urals, among others, but you will notice that automatically. The police may ask you to identify yourself. You have to show your passport to the question 'Dokjument'.

Jan (2012): I cycled alone. I never felt unsafe for a moment. The most unsafe was (in retrospect) probably the road. I cycled on the main road from Riga to Moscow. There are still quite a few trucks on the road. They go well around you and I did not see that there were drunk drivers. But of course there only has to be one that. . . .
Safety.body_traffic:
Drunk drivers are probably the biggest problem for cyclists. Many Russians drive under the influence of some vodkas. Making a phone call while driving is also quite normal: one hand on the steering wheel, the other on the mobile phone. Truck drivers are not used to cyclists, they often just pass you by.

Biking in the big cities is no fun, as drivers, especially those in large western cars, drive quite aggressively. Outside the cities, cyclists are taken into account. On bad parts with many potholes in the road, the driver tries to find the best part so that it often ends up on your side of the road. Russian drivers also perform crazy antics to overtake on busy narrow roads. In addition, it can happen that cars at great speeds come straight at you.

91b1abbc-32f9-498d-9ba3-6e4aa0b913e0.description:
If you take a trip to the Bajkal lake (Biggest fresh water body on earth) take the 2 min ferry to Olchon island where you can explore shaman rituals, see random cows in the morning, witness incredible silence and even see seals if you are lucky.
In the end of may, the lake which is frozen solid most of the year will melt and sometimes break the silence of the tundra with the sound of shattering glass

The island has had electricity since 2015
91b1abbc-32f9-498d-9ba3-6e4aa0b913e0.title: Olchon Island

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Private rooms are becoming increasingly popular for stays in Moscow, St. Petersburg and tourist spots, often surprisingly cheap.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: In Russia there are hardly any campsites, along the Black Sea coast there are a few.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels are not only in the larger cities, but also in small towns where there are trade activities, for example. Cheap hotels are usually basic; sometimes you can use a kitchen and you can put the bikes inside.

Transport.body_airplane: Each airport has its own regulations, which can also change regularly. Bicycles must fall within 20 kg, which also includes hand luggage. But it can also be easy that bicycles have to be paid separately anyway, especially if they do not meet certain dimensions. Paying extra is almost inevitable in many cases, but never immediately agree with the first offer.
Transport.body_bus: As a rule, you can take a bicycle with you on the bus, as long as there is space and it concerns at most one or two bicycles.
Transport.body_train:
A short distance away you take the local train, or the 'elektretsjke'. You can always take your bike there. Russians are solution-oriented, so even in a full train it usually works. Sometimes you have to pay a small extra for luggage on the train.

In the long-distance trains, such as the Trans-Siberian express, it is also possible. There is always a strict conductor at the entrance who says 'nelzja' (not allowed, impossible). I don't understand anything, I keep looking friendly, turn my steering wheel a quarter turn and take the pedals off. Then I throw in a bag. Always succeeded. (This also applies to Belarus and Ukraine). It is best to buy a 3rd class ticket (Platzkart). If it concerns one bicycle, you can hide it above the beds on the luggage shelf (there is always a Russian who helps to lift). Two bikes have always worked for me. You can place them in the informal smoking area, at the very back of the carriage, if necessary. with the front wheel up, with a lock on a rod (Hans Metz).

Visa.body:
The visa policy of Russia differs quite a lot per nationality.


  Russia and Crimea[note 1]
  Freedom of movement
  Visa waiver countries and territories
  Electronic visa

About.body: As pearls sticking out of the ocean, this group of islands does guarantee adventure, no matter what. The steamy mountains look over the forgotten boulevards and slowly decays the stately Portuguese settlements.

-MGOaZ684nKREChuexjr.title: Exploring the natural wonder São Tomé

Border.body: As there are no physical borders because this country is an island, you can only reach it by airplane. From Ghana, Accra there is good flight connection with TAPair. From Gabon there is a flight connection with ASKY Airline. Both airlines took my bicycle, but it wasn't all very clear.

FoodDrink.body:
Onroad: Corn (10 STN)
Local food: Fish
Local drink: Local beer

-MGO_hydGjE8cmNj7TSZ.description: This route goes from Sao Tome to the South via the East side of the island. Unfortunately it is not (yet) possible to go around the island.
-MGO_hydGjE8cmNj7TSZ.title: East side

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities. I almost got attacked during my first night, when I walked on the street of Sao Tome in the dark.

-MGOZkXk8vpleOom_LCp.description: The capital and biggest city of the largest island is also called Sao Tome. Here you find the main history of the country, crowded markets, “leve leve” daily life and delicious fish plates. Visit the chocolate shop Claudio Corallo for the unique bitterless chocolate.
-MGOZkXk8vpleOom_LCp.description_first: The capital and biggest city of the largest island is also called Sao Tome. Here you find the main history of the country, crowded markets, “leve leve” daily life and delicious fish plates. Visit the chocolate shop Claudio Corallo for the unique bitterless chocolate.
-MGOZkXk8vpleOom_LCp.title: Sao Tome

-MGOZuHdYoTOEF7Z4zJW.description: You can only visit this island by airplane from Sao Tome. It appears to be even wilder than the Sao Tome.
-MGOZuHdYoTOEF7Z4zJW.description_first: You can only visit this island by airplane from Sao Tome. It appears to be even wilder than the Sao Tome.
-MGOZuHdYoTOEF7Z4zJW.title: Principe

-MGO_2qnom571S4knaDM.description: A small island on the equator, which you can walk around in about 2 hours, along the stunning coast and some golden beaches. If you go to this island from Sao Tome, you will pass Pesqueira Waterfall and Pico Cao Grande.
-MGO_2qnom571S4knaDM.description_first: A small island on the equator, which you can walk around in about 2 hours, along the stunning coast and some golden beaches. If you go to this island from Sao Tome, you will pass Pesqueira Waterfall and Pico Cao Grande.
-MGO_2qnom571S4knaDM.title: Ilheu das Rolas

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only Sao Tome offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are some places where you can camp at, like hotels.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are hotels around the island, but they are very expensive. Some hotels might offer campgrounds.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: The country is very hilly, but there are some spots where you might pitch your tent. The beaches look attractive to camp at as well, but locals advices me not to do it because of robbers.

-MGOaAgvY0a_H79H7gFp.title: Cycling the natural wonder Sao Tome

Most nationalities need a visa or evisa to enter Saudi Arabia.

About.body: Senegal is a wonderful country to cycle in. If not for their delicious food, it’s for the beautiful landscapes and the mighty baobab trees. You might want to consider bringing earplugs, because the many times the kids scream “tubab, tubab” to you makes you want to cycle in the remote Sahara.

-MGJHFkB-QLWBfJQw41Z.title: Charity, mangoes and Fanta in North Senegal

-MGJH_16BBey-KV0tK19.title: Learning the language of the rain season

-MGJ9SR5dfYyNTbrpv0o.description: Easy place to obtain the visa.
-MGJ9SR5dfYyNTbrpv0o.description_first: Easy place to obtain the visa.

-MGJ9ruZgdF2oXPCkhE3.description: There is not so much information available about this embassy.
-MGJ9ruZgdF2oXPCkhE3.description_first: There is not so much information available about this embassy.

FoodDrink.body:
Senegalese cuisine is called the best in West Africa and has some tasty dishes. 'Poulet yassa' (chicken in onion-lemon sauce) and 'riz yollof' (rice with meat-tomato sauce) can be found in almost every restaurant and without exception in every eatery. The disadvantage here is that if you don't cook yourself, it can come out of your nose at some point.

In the morning, breakfast usually consists of Nescafe and a piece of baguette with your choice of butter or (Calvé) mayonnaise. You can mainly find fresh vegetables on the market. Onions are the second most popular food after rice and are consumed in such quantities that people cannot fully provide them themselves. Available in almost every shop, just like cheese from 'la vache qui rit'.

Drinking water comes from wells outside the cities. The quality is often unreliable, especially when there are livestock around, the droppings often contain diseases that you really don't want to contract. The locals will almost always claim that it is perfectly drinkable. The fact that people usually don't get very old has nothing to do with that? It is therefore highly recommended to bring a Katadyn filter. Bottled water is available everywhere in the larger towns and cities, but it is expensive. Water is also sold chilled in plastic bags. Only buy the printed and sealed ones, only this is reliable drinking water.

Soft drinks: Cola, Fanta and Sprite are (chilled) available everywhere in the shops, sometimes also beer. Cafes with seats and terraces are rare outside the cities.

Tea is the popular drink, it is imported from China and prepared in the same way as in Morocco and other West African countries: boiled and with a lot of sugar, served in three rounds. Tea as we know it is also there and is called 'the Lipton'. Coffee is almost without exception Nescafe.

Health.body:
• Malaria is public enemy number one, especially in the rainy season! Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis, etc. are available on site.
  • Vaccinations against yellow fever, DTP and hepatitis A are recommended.
  • It is recommended to bring sterile needles as well as prophylaxis against malaria.
  • Many Westerners prefer to visit clinics in Dakar in case of emergency.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
September to March, during the dry season is the best time to go. In April it gets quite hot (about 40 degrees). The rainy season in the south (Casamance) is significantly longer than in the north. Between the rain showers: very hot and high humidity. Sandstorms (harmatan) can occur in January and February.

Spare parts
In Senegal you can hardly get parts for the modern western bike. So take enough spare material with you. In case of extreme emergency you can go to Bomtey Sport, Rue Petavin (in the center of Dakar) in Dakar. This is possibly the only bike dealer with western parts in all of West Africa. However, cycling there is no fun due to the busy and dirty traffic.

What you find at the local bike shops is mainly Chinese and India's stuff, not really suitable for your holiday bike with the exception of maybe an inner tube and some stickers.

People.body:
In the cities (Dakar!) and tourist areas the people are sometimes very pushy. It is considered quite normal that you pay for things for them. Depending on your resilience, begging for pens (Bic) and money can drive you to despair. Being blunt and arrogant is sometimes a requirement. The traces of colonization and well-meaning white tourists who regularly stuff the poor black people have contributed to this mentality.

In the province outside the tourist areas (coast), on the other hand, people are very hospitable and friendly, especially in the Casamance. Here it has been restless for years (rebel uprising) so tourists have avoided it.

The official language is French, those who have been to school speak it. Next to this, Wolof is the second semi-official language. Furthermore, many other languages are spoken which differ per region

-MGJDARRHNYXHMs88CMu.description: From Mauritania, through The Gambia, towards Guinea-Bissau. This route doesn't pass Dakar.
-MGJDARRHNYXHMs88CMu.title: North to South

Safety.body:
Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.

Without exception, you can cycle without any problems in the whole of Senegal, nowadays also in the Casamance (south). (For the current situation, please consult the travel advice for Senegal at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.)

Dakar is known as a dangerous city, it has the highest crime rate in West Africa after Lagos (Nigeria). However, if you don't behave too flashy, a stay is usually not a problem in terms of safety.

-MGJEsh13Wk43zBeaC9J.description: Visit Dakar to take one last Western styled breath if you’re heading towards South of Africa, or celebrate reaching this place if you’re on your way North. This city offers almost everything a normal tourist is looking for. Don’t forget to visit the island Goree.
-MGJEsh13Wk43zBeaC9J.description_first: Visit Dakar to take one last Western styled breath if you’re heading towards South of Africa, or celebrate reaching this place if you’re on your way North. This city offers almost everything a normal tourist is looking for. Don’t forget to visit the island Goree.
-MGJEsh13Wk43zBeaC9J.title: Dakar

-MGJFMgguWGyCvi4vcdV.description: The African Stonehenge, only smaller stones, but much more locations. It’s the largest concentration of stone circles in the world. In Senegal, the main sites are in Sine Ngayène (location) and Wanar (location).
-MGJFMgguWGyCvi4vcdV.description_first: The African Stonehenge, only smaller stones, but much more locations. It’s the largest concentration of stone circles in the world. In Senegal, the main sites are in Sine Ngayène (https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=19/13.69546/-15.53557) and Wanar (https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=18/13.7685837/-15.5181782).
-MGJFMgguWGyCvi4vcdV.title: Senegambia stone circles

-MGJFlHHEPZCwlItUlqQ.description: Wander around in the French styled appendix, which you can only reach by a bridge. The colonial houses make you feel like you traveled back in time.
-MGJFlHHEPZCwlItUlqQ.description_first: Wander around in the French styled appendix, which you can only reach by a bridge. The colonial houses make you feel like you traveled back in time.
-MGJFlHHEPZCwlItUlqQ.title: Saint-Louis

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Staying overnight with private individuals can be an option. Ask in the village for the 'chef du Village' (the village elder) or have a chat with this and that person, the chance that they will find something for you is quite high.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are just a few campsites. Formal camping is a great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Some places have accomodation, but it’s expensive. Think about 10.000 CFA for the cheapest price.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible, and not dangerous, despite the fact that the population usually thinks otherwise. If you don't look for a quiet place, you will get a lot of attention. Make sure you have a well-ventilated tent: the sun burns the earth's surface quite warm during the day, so it can remain very hot in your tent at night while it is cool outside.

-MGJIM-F-uulYHM3p9dS.title: A windy Sahara and tropical smiles

Visa.body:
Some nationalities (dark green) can enter Senegal visa free for 90 days. The other nationalities need to apply for a visa. Citizens that can visit Senegal without visa will receive an entry stamp at the border.


Source: Wikipedia.

Health.body:
Supermarkets and shops can be found everywhere in Serbia.
Due to the departure of many young people to the big cities, there is no longer a shop in every village, or it is only open to a limited extent, so don't wait until the next village to do your shopping. You have the best chance of a shop in villages that are at a crossroads of roads.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Serbia has a continental climate with cold harsh winters and dry hot summers. Best cycling seasons are spring, summer and autumn.

Spare parts
In Belgrade there are good bicycle shops with mainly ATB bicycles and parts.

People.body:
The people are friendly and interested, like to chat with you and want to know what you think of their country. Even politically sensitive topics such as the recent Balkan war can be discussed. Many would prefer to see the old situation again when it was still possible to live peacefully with the Croats and (Islamic) Bosnians.

There are no real dress codes, only in churches and monasteries, for example, long pants are appreciated.

The national language is Serbian. In addition, English is mainly spoken by young people. Some elderly people speak German. They used to work as guest workers in Germany.

Safety.body: Serbia is safe in itself, even if you cycle alone. It is not known whether this also applies to Kosovo.
Safety.body_traffic: Since Serbia is mainly a country of farmers, people are used to slow moving traffic (tractors and horse and carriage). Also, especially in the flat parts of the country, the population also cycles to get to the land. It is only busier around the large and larger cities, but cyclists are well taken into account. The greatest danger lies in the condition of the road surface, especially the manhole covers that are not flush with the rest of the asphalt. I therefore advise against cycling at night.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Serbia has few official campsites. Many campsites have closed down or are hosting refugees. It is not known whether wild camping is legal, but it is doable.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Prices of hotels and pensions range from 20 to 40 euros if you search a bit. However, most state hotels are in many cases in poor condition and date from the 1970s and have hardly changed with the times since then. It is often difficult, especially outside the tourist areas. The Serbian tourist office has a guide to all hotels in the country.

Transport.body_boat: If you follow the Donauradweg towards Veliko Gradiste you will have to take the ferry over the Danube to Ram, which sails 3-5 times a day, depending on the season, and not always on time. You could be lucky or unlucky because of this. In Stara Palanka, however, you can easily relax by having lunch in one of the restaurants on the water. In March 2017, the crossing cost 300 dinars (about €2.40).

Visa.body:
Serbia is not part of the Schengen area. Some nationalities can enter Serbia without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: The contrast here is huge. The places that have tarmac, do have incredibly good roads, sometimes even with 4 lanes and a shoulder for cyclers. But there are plenty of areas without tarmac roads. This is all due to the Chinese, who build good roads to improve the trading network and to dig up valuable minerals. Sierra Leone itself has a wild history with coups and civil wars, but now seems quiet and building towards a future.

-MGMYye6BhJ26I42r82Z.description: In some cases you can obtain your visa here in one day, if you come early. Bring two passport pictures, copy of your passport. You might be asked for a hotel reservation. You might have to pay at a bank, which is quite far away from the embassy.

FoodDrink.body:
Onroad: Egg with bread (±7.000 SLL) 
Local food: Rice, bushmeat, fish
Local drink: Palm wine

-MGMb0zedhnNR_xOyBPe.description: This route goes from the Guinea border to Freetown, and eventually to Liberia, following an amazing jungle road that has hosted an old railway road.
-MGMb0zedhnNR_xOyBPe.title: From Guinea border to Liberia border

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.

-MGMZzZmiDfrscPOnMR8.description: Yes, Freetown was actually the town of free men during the slavery. It’s a lively city, with stunning beaches and a few incredible peaks which are visible from all places around. The warm water and the soft waves make is an excellent place to rest your legs.
-MGMZzZmiDfrscPOnMR8.description_first: Yes, Freetown was actually the town of free men during the slavery. It’s a lively city, with stunning beaches and a few incredible peaks which are visible from all places around. The warm water and the soft waves make is an excellent place to rest your legs.
-MGMZzZmiDfrscPOnMR8.title: Freetown

-MGM_Chszfo-pujs2xYu.description_first: If your pockets allow it, you can try to find pygmy hippo during the night at this place.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Not very common, only big cities offer CS hosts.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Some places have accomodation, but it’s expensive, the cheapest is around SLL 100.000.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

-MGMaA3Mmma9L4zWNNhX.title: Wet feet in West Africa's Jungle

Visa.body:
A visa is required for most nationalities. It seems possible to apply online and will cost $100. 

Source: Wikipedia.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In Singapore it is 30 degrees all year round and it rains regularly, especially in the afternoon.

Spare parts
Everything is available and everything can be made by a few specialists.

People.body:
The population can appear distant and arrogant, very different from the surrounding countries. John: "However, this is not always the case, certainly in the case of a common interest (cycling) Singaporeans turn out to be very friendly people. Detachment also stems from shyness and 'looking out of the tree'. This can happen. as arrogant."

Almost everyone speaks excellent English. Only elderly Singaporeans of Chinese descent are not always able to speak English. In addition, the 'foreign workers' often do not speak the English language.

Sleeping.body_hostels: Singapore has a huge range of luxury, expensive hotels. Finding a cheaper hotel is more difficult. In many places, apartments in condominiums are used as affordable hotel rooms.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities (blue countries in the below map) can enter Sint Maarten without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

Corona.body: When you enter Slovakia, you need to go in quarantaine for 10 days. However, they don't seem to check this everywhere, and if you enter the country on a small road, you might get through it without problems.

FoodDrink.body:
Dumplings are a local speciality, as in more neighbouring countries. 

Supermarkets
Supermarkets can be found in the larger towns. The shops are not always sufficiently stocked outside the larger towns. Coop supermarkets can be found in almost all smaller villages. All basic products are present here.

Restaurants
The food in restaurants is cheap, but the choice is often limited.

Drinkable water
Tap water seems to be reliable.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
In the mountains it can rain a lot in summer, however, it's probably the best time to cycle in Slovakia.

Spare parts
In the cities of Bratislava and Kosice there are bicycle shops where the latest parts are sold. In smaller places, the offer is less.

People.body: Making contact with the population is quite easy. The people are very friendly. They speak Slovak. Some speak German and the young people usually speak some English.

Safety.body: Slovakia is a safe country to cycle at.
Safety.body_nature: Bears and wolves do live in the woods of Slovakia.
Safety.body_traffic: The small roads are wonderfully quiet and great for cycling. Also the major roads are not too busy.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are a few campsites around, which usually cost around €10 or less.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Only the big cities have hostels, for average prices (min €10).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is legal. There seem to be bears and wolves in the nature, but apparently it has been more than a 100 years since they attacked a person.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body: Slovenia is a beautiful, strongly hilly to mountainous country. Most roads are quiet to very quiet, some through roads are busy.

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
There is a supermarket in almost all villages, except for the really small mountain villages. Small villages often have a small supermarket, and in larger towns and cities there are also several larger supermarkets. In the mountains often drives a kind of SRV car. The Mercator is by far the most common, especially in the smaller villages. In the cities you will also find a lot of Spar, and Lidl.

On Monday-Saturday most supermarkets are open all day (until 8pm) and on Sunday many are open in the morning (2013). The latter applies in the cities to the supermarkets outside the center on business parks, etc. Those in the center are actually closed.

Restaurants
There are plenty in the cities, in the villages there are sometimes none, but in almost every hamlet you can find a pizzeria or 'gostilna'. Campsites often also have a restaurant with a limited menu.

Restaurants are very cheap. Often it is traditional cuisine, or pizza. You have pizza for 5-9,-. The quality is good: good service, good food and low price. In most restaurants you can get vegetarian dishes.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The weather varies greatly, from very nice to downright bad. It is quite hot on the coast in summer. In the mountains, on the other hand, it is a lot cooler. Average over the whole country about 23 degrees in summer. In the evenings, as is normal in an Alpine country, there can often be thunderstorms in the mountains.

Spare parts
The local tire size is 26 inches. Bicycle shops can be found in Ljubliana. The tourist office knows the addresses. You will hardly find any in the villages. In the larger towns and on the larger campsites you have a bicycle rental, so there are undoubtedly repair options there too. A map is available at the tourist information with mountain bike routes, and this also lists the various bicycle repair shops in the various places.

Existing routes
  • Cycling is still relatively unknown in Slovenia. There is mainly a lot of mountain biking and racing. At the moment people are busy building bicycle routes. The current cycling routes are very short or mainly aimed at mountain bikers. In the guide of the Central Europe route, some of the existing cycling routes in Slovenia are linked. More information at: http://www.cyclingeurope.nl/
  • From Čabar (Croatia), on the border with Slovenia, you can drive 60 km along the border river (Kulpa). Quiet & beautiful!
  • From Dravograd, the Drau Cycle Path runs along the Drau/Drava via Maribor towards Ptuj on a quiet road.
  • From Tarvisio in Italy via Kranjska Gora to Mojstrana there is a brand new cycle path along the north side of the Julian Alps

People.body: The locals are generally friendly. Knowledge of English and German is not a problem in most of the country. The alphabet is the same as with us, place names on the map are easy to read.

Safety.body: Slovenia is a safe country to cycle in.
Safety.body_nature: Bears occur in some areas. Be well informed. Dogs rarely bother you. They are usually kept as pets. Gypsy villages are an exception.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are plenty of campsites in Slovenia, except far south and east. There is a map with all of them on it. It is very busy on the coast. Many campsites close after mid-September or early October, especially inland.

Bert: "Camping is no longer so cheap in Slovenia. A rate is charged per person and it does not matter whether you come with a bicycle and a small tent or with a car with a whopping caravan: you pay the same, so as a cyclist you are always out more unfavorably!

If you had to ask if you can stand on a farmer's land, we don't think this would cause a problem.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are many cheap youth hostels and guest houses. The country is also very geared to motorcyclists.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is not allowed and it can be dangerous here and there because of bears.

Transport.body_train: The bicycle can be taken on the train. There are not always special areas for the bicycles, but that in itself is not a problem. Some older trains have a special area for luggage/bicycles. Boarding can be difficult on those trains, because the entry is high. The staff will then help with tackling the bicycle in the loading area. The newer trains have a lower floor and the bicycle is similar to the Dutch trains in a section with folding seats intended for prams/wheelchairs/bicycles. Reservations must be made for the eurocity trains.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.
We haven't been able to find information about getting a visa for Somalia. However, the current situation in Somalia is too unstable and traveling to this country should be avoided.

About.body:
Cycling is popular with South Africans. Especially in the Western Cape you will meet racing cyclists on weekends, and you will also hear stories about countless mountain bike races. You can indeed reach spectacular destinations and the road there is not too busy. With good maps you can avoid the major roads and you will also find many gravel roads, mostly in very good condition. In addition, there are also many bike shops with decent equipment.

There is sufficient accommodation within a day distance (in the Western Cape and the garden route), so it is not necessary to bring a tent. Of course, this will make your trip more expensive, because B&Bs or hotels are not cheap. Restaurants also quickly cost half or 2/3 of European prices, although there are alternatives here such as take-aways and hot food in the supermarket.

FoodDrink.body:
The food is generally fine, as with us. There is plenty for sale everywhere, especially in and around the larger cities.

Marc: "Braai (barbecue) is traditional among the Afrikaners. A famous African meal is 'potjiekos', a stew."

Markets
You won't find many food stalls in the Western Cape

Supermarkets
Many towns have a supermarket (Checkers, Spar, Seven-Eleven, ...). In larger supermarkets you will find an extensive section with hot food (meat, fish, chicken, pasta, potato preparations, ...). This is next to the take-aways one of the cheapest options.

Stalls on the street
You can often find take-aways in the towns; the offer often consists of samoosas, fish & chips, pizza, ...

Restaurants
In the Western Cape you will find very good restaurants, depending on the region, with a wide range of fish, meat (steak), game, ... In a good restaurant you quickly pay 100 to 200 R pp for a good meal with wine.

Drinkable water
Tap water is drinkable. It can sometimes be sulphurous.

Health.body:
Common diseases
Malaria occurs from October to May. Especially in Kwazulu-Natal and in the Kruger Park. In the Western Cape you don't have to worry about malaria in winter (Jul-Aug).

Mandatory vaccinations
If you come from a yellow fever area, yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.

Recomended vaccinations
A DTP vaccination is recommended

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The seasons are opposite to the north in the southern hemisphere.
  • Spring, early summer: great cycling weather.
  • In October/November it is not very warm, about 22 degrees, a lot of wind and sometimes rain. It also depends on where you cycle in South Africa.
  • Jan-March temperatures up to 40 degrees, little rain. In mid-March it gets chilly at night on the south coast. Also depends on where you cycle, on the coast it is fine, far inland it is indeed 40 degrees.
  • Despite what the books say, winter (July-August) is a very good season for cycling for the Western Cape. It is nice and warm during the day, often +20°, ideal cycling weather in places where the mercury rises high in the summer. I was also told that the garden route gets more rain in the summer.
Spare parts
In the Western Cape, racing bicycles and MTBs are very popular. There are therefore many good and modern bicycle shops with an extensive stock of parts. Both 26" tires and 28" tires are available (albeit in a more limited choice).

Existing routes
  • The coastal tourist route in the Cape Town area is the Chapman's Peak Drive from Noordhoek to Hout Bay. The follow-up route along the coast to Cape Town is just as beautiful for its stunning views of Table Mountain and rock formations (Twelve Apostles). Information on this route can be found at www.chapmanspeakdrive.co.za; In winter, that route is often closed because of boulders on the road.
  • You can cycle from Cape Town on the Beachroad (west side of the peninsula) to the Cape of Good Hope. You can rent a lodge in the Table mountain Park. Then via the east side back to Muisenberg. Via Stellenbosch - Franschhoek-Robertson to Montagu, here you can pick up the N62
  • Route 62, so named after the well-known American Route 66, is also promoted as a tourist route; you will find small and friendly towns with good accommodation. It is a quiet route from Montagu to Oudtshoorn, although it runs along the Klein- and Groot-Swartberge it is fairly flat. With this route you can connect Cape Town with the Garden route.
Special sightseeing
If you are in Cape Town and enjoy hiking, you should definitely climb Table Mountain. You can get a free ticket at the tourist office: "Safe hiking on Table Mountain". There are several tracks leading up, the Skeleton Gorge (starts from Kirstenbosch Gardens) one of the most beautiful for me. Table Mountain is also intersected at the top by all kinds of hiking trails, so you can go down from another side. You can also combine a walk with the cable car (about 80R one way).

Tips
  • The tourist services in the Western Cape are generally very helpful; they often have good information about accommodation and also reserve your sleeping place for free. With a map and itinerary, they can even help you plan the route if they have accommodation for the entire area.
  • If you're going to Lesotho, it's a good idea to stock up on ZA Rand before crossing the border. The Rand has the same value as the Maluti and is also accepted everywhere in Lesotho, while the reverse is not the case. The same principle counts for Namibia.

People.body:
The population, both white and colored, is very hospitable. People react very openly and surprised to cyclists and think it's great what you do.

South Africa has eleven official languages: Afrikaans, English, Ndebele, Pedi, Sotho, Swazi, Tsonga, Tswana, Venda, Xosha, and Zulu. Other African languages are also spoken. Whites and coloreds speak English and sometimes also Afrikaans, which is very similar to Dutch. Tip for learning Afrikaans: buy a South African newspaper a few times.

Safety.body:
Cycling through townships is always a risk. The fact that people here are often poor is reinforced by the past of apartheid. You can avoid townships by taking a taxi or bus and starting your tour in a smaller town.

There is also a warning against taking trains. If you take a train for a longer distance, you should preferably take first class. Keep your valuable luggage with you on sleeper trains and also watch out for shoes or sandals when you take them off.
Safety.body_criminality: Criminality does occur in South Africa!
Safety.body_traffic:
You drive on the left. Traffic is minimal and calm with the exception of the main roads. Pay attention to the overtaking actions of passing cars and freight traffic. A brightly colored bag or shirt and rear-view mirror is not a luxury. Trucks can be 22 meters long. Despite the wide roads, vehicles often occupy part of the hard shoulder so that the vehicles behind have space to perform their overtaking action.

Traffic is getting busier. Most motorists do want to drive around a bend if possible. If not, they will quietly race right past you at 120 km/h. There's really no point in taking the gas back.

d8e14706-9539-45a3-9201-128acbd50f12.description: Cape Agulhas, Africa's most southern tip.
d8e14706-9539-45a3-9201-128acbd50f12.title: Cape Agulhas

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: The average distance between campsites is at least 70 - 80 km. You can also regularly camp in the garden of backpacker hotels.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are many backpackers hotels in all the larger cities. There are many accommodation options in the Western Cape. In addition to the backpackers, you will find a wide range of hotels and B&B. Accommodation is not cheap, you don't pay that much for a dorm (a bed in a shared dormitory) in a backpacker (100-150R), but an individual room quickly costs almost as much in a backpacker as in a B&B.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible and allowed, but is often difficult because there are fences along every road to keep the wild/livestock away.

Transport.body_bus:
Bicycle transport by bus is no problem, not even on the regular buses. Mention that you have a bicycle with you. You can also use the Baz bus, the "back-packers" bus. See www.bazbus.com.

I took a bus from Bloemfontein to Cape Town; some airlines didn't want to take the bike, Greyhound did. This probably depends on the availability of a trailer for the bicycle or the crowds. The bicycle was taken along for free on that ride.
Transport.body_train: The train is pleasant to travel, but as a rule of thumb takes twice as long as a bus ride in ZA. From Port Elisabeth to Bloemfontein it took me 12 hours. I took a third class because there was no first class available and it is very cheap. See the safety notes.

Visa.body:
Quite a lot of nationalities don't need to apply for a visa beforehand and can visit South Africa 30 or 90 days visa free. You'll get an entry and exit stamp when passing the border.

Visa policy of South Africa
  South Africa
  Visa-free access to South Africa for 90 days
  Visa-free access to South Africa for 30 days
  Visa required for ordinary passports; Visa-free access for diplomatic, official and service passports
  Visa required for entry to South Africa for all passports

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
The national "dish" of Korea is kimchi and is served with every meal. Actually, kimchi is not so much a dish, but a preservation method. The standard version is with cabbage, but there are several other variants. Wilco: "In the beginning I had to get used to it, but after a few days of getting used to it, it is fine to eat."

The 'standard' dish is bimbimbap. This is a meal with rice, various vegetables, an egg, sometimes meat and a hot sauce. If you manage to make it clear that you want to eat, but it's not clear what they offer/you want, this is usually the dish you get.

Another well-known (and controversial) dish is bosintang (dog soup). Koreans often like to promote this as very healthy. It is available in a limited number of restaurants. If you ask about it, you are remarkably often sent to a restaurant outside the center.

Wilco: "In the countryside I found the kitchen a bit boring, sometimes eating bimbimbap for days in a row, but this also has to do with communication."

Supermarkets
In every village or city you will find a 7-eleven, in the larger cities a Lotte Mart and/or E-mart (mega supermarkets)

Restaurants
There is a wide range of dining options. Cheap restaurants mainly serve noodle and rice dishes and soups for only a few euros.

BBQ/Grill restaurants are slightly more expensive. The meal here mainly consists of meat that you have to prepare yourself and eaten folded in leafy vegetables. These restaurants sometimes want to be difficult when you are alone. Occasionally you will even be refused when you are alone.

Fish is mainly eaten raw and dried. You also regularly get a bowl with dozens of small dried fish as a side dish. In various temples you can eat for free during certain times. You are expected to eat everything you scoop up and wash your belongings yourself.

Western food is mainly limited to the cities and consists mostly of pizza and hamburger chains. Especially in the cheap restaurants they have vegetarian meals. The temple meals are vegetarian by default.

Drinkable water
There are water sources in hotels and restaurants where you can safely tap water. You can also fill your bottles here. Koreans also do this regularly.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Spring and autumn are the best time to travel to Korea. Winter can be very cold, summer is hot and humid.

Frank: "We cycled from early September to mid-October. During this period we had two rainy days and temperatures of 18 to 37 degrees."

Spare parts
Koreans use modern Western/Japanese bicycles, especially mountain bikes. Parts are probably available. In every city we found 1 or more bicycle shops that are generally well equipped with modern parts.

People.body:
The people are friendly, especially in the countryside and in national parks. In the big cities people are more distant, probably because they see more westerners there and the rat race is in full swing and people have less time. People are not really surprised at world cyclists, although they do express admiration for cyclists.

Korean is the only official language. In principle, all young people speak some English. Children are taught English from primary school. In practice, however, the knowledge of English is often very disappointing. It is practical to learn the Korean script (Hangul). This is relatively easy and is very useful in cheap restaurants and sometimes also for finding the way and places of interest.

Safety.body:
South Korea is a safe country to cycle at. Towards the North Korean border, the security measures can seem intimidating if you are not used to that.

Iteawon is known as a nightlife area where American soldiers often want to make 'mess'. However, steps have been taken to curb this.
Safety.body_criminality: South Korea is very safe in terms of crime.
Safety.body_traffic: It can be busy around the larger cities, the roads are intimidatingly wide, but we never felt unsafe for a single moment, not even in Seoul. Cyclists are considered to be fully-fledged road users, so if they want to overtake you, they do so via the left side of the road. If they want to overtake you but can't swerve all the way to the left, they will horn, turn on the hazard lights and overtake.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Campsites appear to be around.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Accommodation is available in almost every town of any size, often at reasonable prices. If you don't know Korean, accommodation as such is usually not recognizable. Many accommodation is recognizable by a circle with steam rising from it (three winding lines). However, this symbol is (originally) also used for bathhouses.

5f328978-6317-4e60-8391-04ad119213ae.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter South Sudan.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Northern Spain is a wonderful place for cycle touring. Green Spain as it's known has all you want. Fantastic beaches and little coves abrupt the Atlantic ocean and make perfect stop overs.
Asturias and Galacia are green and differ from the South of Spain as the weather is cooler but still warm. The Picos de Europa mountain range is very close to the coast and has fantastic scenery and camping sites.
Average camping costs between €7 to €15 a night in July...

FoodDrink.body:
Fantastic food.. Tapas is a must as well as the local cuisine Even in the smallest village you'll find a small bar/coffee shop where you can by "tortilla de patatas".

Cooking fuel
Everything is readily available, except benzene and Coleman Fuel.
Last summer (2010) in the north of Spain could not find any replacement gas bottles from CampingGaz with a click closure, out of poverty but switched to injection bottles again.

Vegetarians
The vegetarian is a bit spoiled, but there are dishes to be found. For small amounts of vegetables and pasta you can go to the small mercados. In the large supermarkets you can have fresh and sometimes frozen vegetables weighed, but the vegetables are often prepackaged in larger quantities.

Supermarkets
There are more and more supermarkets, often on the edge of the core. Every village has a shop for the necessary foodstuffs.
Make sure you do your shopping on time. Between 2 and 5-7 pm it is siesta and all shops are closed. During that time you can enjoy all kinds of small snacks (tapas) in bars/cafes/restaurants.

Restaurants
Eating out is cheap but can be quite one-sided. During the siesta and in the evening from 21.00 or even 22.00 is eaten. If you can't wait until then, you can often enjoy the delicious tapas. You can also order a hot snack in cafes at noon.

Drinkable water
You can drink tap water almost everywhere, but in many cities, villages and sometimes also on campsites the water often tastes bad because it contains chlorine. Water in fountains in the mountains and in town squares usually tastes good. If this is not drinking water, it is stated: "agua no potable". In late summer, many springs can be dried up because of the drought. Bottled water is widely available in shops, bars or gas stations.Campsites sometimes have 2 systems: drinking water and shower water.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Spring and Autumn: This is the best time for cycling. In September (and sometimes even October) the temperature is still around 25 to 30 degrees. In the spring it is greener and many are in bloom. In the fall you see beautiful fall colors. In the mountains, temperatures can be cool, especially at night.

Spare parts
In major cities, all quality bicycle parts are available. In the smaller places only the cheaper ones but enough to keep cycling. Most towns and larger villages have one or more bicycle repair shops. The addresses are listed in Luc Oteman's guide. There are many 26 inch tires available. On the island of Mallorca you will find many bike rental companies that rent out racing bikes, ATBs and hybrid bikes (prices range from 25 euros per week for a beach bike to about 90 euros per week for a racing bike).

People.body: I find the Spanish people friendly but not as much other countries I've cycled in.

QuickFacts.climate:
Cool and cold on winter..
Summer months from June to August are warm

Safety.body:
Spain is very safe for cycle touring.
Most car drivers are considerate and usually wait for a safe time to overtake but in cities its very different where everyone is in a rush...
Safety.body_traffic: The experiences with Spanish motorists are positive. On smaller roads, driving is usually fairly quiet. In general, people overtake well and often people wait behind you if necessary.

1ff857d9-7737-45c7-946d-59369ad8a02e.description: A nice beach with a cliff backdrop, more of a morning beach as it gets good morning sunshine. In the afternoon the sun sets behind the cliffs so beach will be in shadow, in winter it´s quite early, but summer quite late. Worth a visit either way.
1ff857d9-7737-45c7-946d-59369ad8a02e.title: Beach - Horcas Coloradas

3e492ff5-e15c-484d-b511-b3b2322e70d2.description:
Check out the city centre, well worth a day´s visit. 
There is the old town - la Viaja looking over Melilla, then the Modernist city centre with amazing examples of modernist architecture which was mostly built by a student of Gaudi´s - Enrique Nieto y Nieto.
3e492ff5-e15c-484d-b511-b3b2322e70d2.title: City centre

7a862069-bd10-4005-b00e-20873e8c334a.description:
Long stretch of beaches along the Paseo Maritimo which has a bicycle lane. 
Very shallow and calm water as it in a harbour. Lots of cafes and shops along paseo maritimo. 
It´s where all the cities residents come walk, run, cycle, have an ice cream and relax. In the summer it is perfect for night swimming.
7a862069-bd10-4005-b00e-20873e8c334a.title: Beaches

dcb1a336-87d4-4b40-a3cb-2999ef563b2b.description: Cycle to this UNESCO world herritage to see the beautiful city. It's the final destination of the popular pilgrim route.
dcb1a336-87d4-4b40-a3cb-2999ef563b2b.title: Santiago de Compostela

f3423102-b986-4133-acde-4835ab117acf.description:
I nice park in Melilla - if you love palm trees, there iss a beautiful, exotic palm tree grove in the NE corner of the park. 
From the open space by the pond you can see Mount Gurugu in Morocco. 
Nice for sunsets.
f3423102-b986-4133-acde-4835ab117acf.title: Beautiful Park

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Addressing residents of a small town without a hotel can't hurt either. The Spaniard sometimes has a room or apartment left. Moreover, they always know a place for the tent.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Plenty of camp sites but many do tend to close over winter. There are many more open in the south and winter rates are far cheaper.

Except on the coast, the distances between the campsites are large. In Andalusia, most campsites are located on the coast and in attractive mountain areas. Campsites are quite comfortable and almost all have a swimming pool. The ground is always very hard, special (rock) pegs are needed. Camping Cortijo near Cazorla is one of the few campsites with green grass and soft soil. This one is therefore highly recommended.
Sleeping.body_hostels: If you are following the pilgrimage routes and bought the pilgrimage pass (~5€) you are allowed to sleep in the pilgrimage hostels  for one night (costs: donation or 5-10€). Very simple but nice accommodations (usually with a kitchen). Cycling pilgrims should arrive after 5pm and everyone has to leave before 9am.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Wild camping is possible in many places, especially at the many reservoirs. In the heat and drought of summer and autumn you have to take into account that rivers and sources have dried up, the water in reservoirs is then very low. Keep in mind that many forests in Spain are privately owned. At small villages in the deep interior you can also simply ask for a camping spot.

Vesna: "I never had any problems wild camping in the countryside but there are signs at times saying no camping. I arrived late and left the camp early before anyone arrived."

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

FoodDrink.body:
Stalls everywhere (including delicious coconuts, very good for thirst!), many restaurants of almost always good quality. The snacks in the pastry shops are very tasty: roti, sandwiches filled with vegetables, egg or meat. Sri Lankan food is hot! Lots of choice for vegetarians.

Josë (2016) We found the choice for vegetarians in most places to be very limited, rice & curry, fried rice, fried noodles, kottu or chop sue. If you can find vegetarian restaurants, there is plenty of diversity, see www.happycow.net.

Drinkable water
Drinking water only in bottles! Available almost everywhere, but not on every street corner. Also use for brushing teeth!

Tips
  • Drinking Thambili (yellow coconut) at a roadside stall. Delicious for the thirsty cyclist.
  • Along the road: colored juices with fruits.
  • Ask for freshly squeezed juice. Just be careful with lime, which is almost always diluted, perhaps also with tap water.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Except in the higher areas, it is always warm in Sri Lanka. The mountainous region in the center divides Sri Lanka into a predominantly hot and dry southeast and a warm and humid southwest.

January: the temperature is pleasant and it is dry. From April it gets very hot. In July it is dry in the east and south. In the (south) west there is the monsoon with short heavy showers. It is then humid and warm. From mid-September to mid-October: there is still just the end of the monsoon. There are only a few showers left, very suitable for cycling. From November to March, the northeast has a somewhat weaker monsoon season.

Spare parts
There are many (moped) bicycle makers. The local population cycles a lot. There are tires for sale, other specific parts should be brought with you. Metal workshops or car workshops are present in almost every larger village: useful if your porters are broken.

The parts you need to take with you depend on the type of bike you have. Therefore, assume that there are no suitable parts for sale.

Tips
There are many lakes and (irrigation) canals where you can swim. There seem to be crocodiles (we didn't see them). Locals also wash and wash clothes in the canals. If you go swimming there, the crocodile risk is not that great (I think).

People.body:
Very helpful, very friendly but also very curious. You are constantly being called out on the bike. Get off and you're in touch. 

There are also less positive experiences. There are many scammers: they want money for every service. Lots of service in the hotels. In non-touristy towns there are quite a few stone throwers.

User experiences
Max has mainly positive experiences. The further you go into the non-touristy interior, the friendlier you are. People are curious, without being intrusive. Where there are tourists, there are parasites who want to get their share. Sometimes that's irritating, especially when you're tired. Ignore is the motto.

Dick: The people are very hospitable and friendly, one of the charms of this island! Contacts are easy to make and especially in the somewhat sparsely populated areas, they all want attention when you pass by. If you continuously respond to this, you will be waving all day long. They also want to know how much everything costs, and whether they can buy it from you.

Habits
Rather not walk around in shorts, it is allowed, but a small adjustment to their culture is very much appreciated as a gesture, zip-off pants (pipes off while cycling, on at a stop) is a good solution. No bare torso (men) or undershirts (women) but just a T-shirt.

No hats/helmets in temples, no bare legs (I had a wrap skirt with me, very handy), shoes off! Keeping your socks on to protect your feet from sharp stones and overheated stones is allowed. Never turn your ass to a Buddha statue, that's a gross insult.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
There are many guest houses and hotels within regular distance. They are reasonably cheap, but not always clean and comfortable. The distances between the hotels vary from 40 to 80 km.

Many private individuals rent out rooms in the form of an Inn or guesthouse. Eateries are sometimes called "Hotel", but you can't stay there overnight. So don't ask for a hotel, but for a guesthouse.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Free camping is not possible.

About.body: Because of the news and coverage you may not immediately have a positive feeling about this country. Against all odds, Sudan is a fantastic country for cycling! The people are very nice and hospitable, the roads are good and the Sudanese cuisine exceeds all expectations when you eat at people's homes. Isa-Youri definitely recommend it and found the desert of Sudan beautiful.

FoodDrink.body:
The food is very tasty in Sudan. Simple but very pure and tasty. Along the way you can always get foul (brown beans with onion and herbs). You wouldn't think so, but with 47 degrees it's really nice. You get bread with it and sometimes an egg. Because you are often near the Nile, we also regularly ate fish. When you eat at people's homes, it is very tasty and varied. They conjure up the tastiest dishes on the table. In poorer people it is often beans or khorasa (a kind of pancake). When people have a little more to spend, you also get meat, fish and some vegetables (not much). Fruit and vegetables are only available in the cities, so bring enough if you like it. Fruit is mainly; orange and grapefruit. You can get coffee and tea everywhere and it is very tasteful (they put ginger in it).

Drinkable water
You cannot drink the water in Sudan. You can easily get water along the way, but take a water filter or steripen with you. In some places the water is better than others (it comes from the Nile and sometimes there is a lot of mud and sand in it). As soon as you see good water, immediately stock up and top up everything. Another solution is to ask cars on the road.

If you do a bit of 'water planning', that's no problem. Together we always had 13 liters with us and that was more than enough (meant for drinking and cooking). We washed dishes with sand and ourselves with baby wipes.

In the cities you can buy bottled water. In small villages sometimes yes and sometimes not, depending on the stock. A steripen / water filter is therefore really necessary!

For the water on the west side of the nile just above Khartoum see the detail information at: http://www.ithaka.im/worldbiking/route-sudan-wadi-halfa-dongola-karima-bayuda-barra-khartoum

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Sudan is actually always warm and hot in the summer. The best period is therefore from November to February. However, we cycled the route in September / October and that was doable with some adjustments. Cycling from 06.00 – 11.00 and from 16.00 – 19.00. In that period, count on temperatures from 36 to 48 degrees. The peak (melting point!) was in the Bayuda desert where the mercury rose once to 54 degrees.

Spare parts
It's better not to count on finding suitabel spare parts here.

Nice routes
Isa-Youri: "We have cycled the following route with great pleasure; Wadi Halfa – Dongola – Al Goled – Al Dabbah – Karima – Ad Damar – Shendi – Khartoum – Wad Madani – Gondar. Because shade and water are essential, we have kept an extensive route with distances, water and shadow spots. For the detailed description, see http://www.ithaka.im/worldbiking/route-sudan-wadi-halfa-dongola-karima-bayuda-barra-khartoum.

People.body:
The people of Sudan are absolutely the beating heart of the country. The people are warm and very welcoming. You are welcome everywhere and at all times they will offer you a bed where an extensive meal is not missing. When you are a guest they will do everything they can to make you feel comfortable without being intrusive. For the Sudanese it is 'their duty' to take care of you and you notice that on all sides. The people are honest and calm which is very nice to travel.

Sudan is an Islamic country with Sharia law. In practice you hardly notice this. A few times we have experienced that as a woman you have to eat with the women, very nice! It is striking that the women simply work and participate in daily life. In Egypt this was much less and the women were mainly at home.

Because it is strictly Islamic, we recommend that you adjust your clothing. Isa has cycled with a skirt over her leggings and always with long sleeves. Shorts and tight cycling shorts are also very inappropriate for men. Alcohol is prohibited and not available in the country. When you eat with people, don't use your left hand (!) They use it for other purposes.

Safety.body_traffic: Isa-Youri (2015) We have experienced traffic in Sudan as very safe. The people give you space and they go all the way around you.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You can always sleep at people's houses! When it was very hot or we wanted some water for a shower, we knocked on the door of the most beautiful house. The people give you a warm welcome in their home and then they are happy to share the meal with you. Without exception, this was possible every time we asked for it. Very special to experience!
Sleeping.body_hostels: The hotels we encountered along the way were very simple and dirty. We often camped and slept at people's homes.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: More than enough space in the desert. It was even possible to often camp behind a small hill so that you are not visible to any traffic. The times when there was nothing but plain it felt completely safe to be visible to the occasional traffic that comes by. There are no campsites in Sudan.

About.body: Bike touring is not done. You harvest admiration; If you are going inland and are unfamiliar with the situation, you should consider traveling with a guide. The distances are long, the area is virtually uninhabited and it is easy to get lost because there are no current road maps available. In concession areas, roads are built for gold mining, bauxite mining and forestry that cannot be found on the maps.

FoodDrink.body:
The Surinamese cuisine is very varied due to the many population groups. The food is not spectacular but reasonable to good. In the city and the villages there are many eateries where you can eat cheaply. The food is in general reliable. 

Typical food: BB+R (Brown beans with rice), fried rice, rice with chicken and roti. Vegetarian food is available. Suriname has many small supermarkets where all basic items are available. If you go into the bush you will need to take enough provisions and drinks with you. Be careful with tap water. Mineral water, soft drinks, juices and beer are readily available. There are many fruit juices for sale, but they are often very chemical. Unfortunately, fruit outside the markets is hard to come by.

Agnes: "The Javanese dinners have the reputation of being the most hygienic. That is why we ate a lot of noodles and fried rice, always with chicken. There are also many Chinese eateries, with noodles and fried rice, but less. The Creole cuisine is harder to find: we have only seen 2 restaurants in Paramaribo."

Health.body:
With the exception of the coast, malaria is common in Suriname.

Hazards
  • Burns: Avoid excessive exposure to sunlight.
  • Dehydration: Usually the result of altered dietary habits. Easy to treat with drinking ORS solution or a salted broth.
  • Insect bites: Avoid with long pants and long sleeves, use mosquito net. Mosquito repellent with DEET for unprotected parts. My Surinamese guide advised not to smear anything; when DEET is exhausted it would attract additional mosquitoes, which indeed seemed to be the case (b).
  • Ticks: Easy to remove with tick tweezers.
  • Dengue: See under Insect Bites.
  • Animals: Snakes in particular are a point of interest in the interior. Bring a good flashlight, because it gets dark early. Agnes: "We were also advised to sprinkle insecticide around the tent, which would not only stop insects but also snakes. We tried it, but had dosed a little too much, because we almost had to do it ourselves due to stinging eyes clear the field."

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The dry periods are from mid-August to November and from February to April. But also in the dry season there can be a heavy shower that is usually short-lived. In the rest of the year it is hot and humid, with a lot of rain. With a few showers, the roads turn into mud puddles. The daytime temperatures fluctuate around 32 degrees all year round. At night it does not get colder than about 22 degrees.

Spare parts
There are bicycle repair shops in Paramaribo and Nickerie. Take all critical parts with you. Both 26 and 28 inch tires are available, but only in the larger towns.

Nice routes
  • Paramaribo, Domburg, Paranam, Kraka, Berg en Dal, Afobaka. The route of 105 km. has been asphalted since November 2009. Outside Paramaribo it is a quiet route. There are sleeping accommodations in the recreation resorts of White Beach, Overbridge and Berg en Dal and in Brokopondo there is a state guest house.
  • Paramaribo, Carolina, Java, Moengo (3 days, approx. 210 km). Wonderful tour through savannah and jungle. In fact, it is not easy to do without a guide because there is no bridge over the Commewijne River in Java and the roads are unclear in the concession area between Java and Moengo.
Special sightseeing
Paramaribo
The colonial wooden houses in the center.
Peter and Paul Church (currently being renovated)
the recently renovated Palmentuin
Fort Zelandia

Surroundings Paramaribo
Ferry to Meerzorg
Plantation Pepperpot
Fort New Amsterdam
Plantation Mariënburg (with ruins of sugar factory)

People.body: The Surinamese are nice, carefree, not very industrious, full of humor and self-mockery. People are not particularly welcoming or helpful. You are greeted with 'Fawaka?' (how are you) to which you reply that you are fine. For a meeting you meet somewhere in the city. If you are invited to your home, it is a great honour. Then dress neatly. Take off your shoes on arrival and always eat some of the food on offer.

Safety.body:
Watch your stuff and try not to stand out too much. Do not walk alone on the street at night. Do not leave valuables unattended. If you are cycling the East-West Connection, it is preferable not to go alone. 

East Suriname is suffering from tensions related to the activities of illegal Brazilian gold miners. 

Hank: "We felt safe everywhere, although people themselves don't think so. Most houses are also equipped with anti-burglary grilles."
Safety.body_nature: Dogs don't bother you, because they are very slow.
Safety.body_traffic: The main roads around and in Paramaribo have heavy traffic. Here you sometimes have bike paths, but they are not maintained. In Suriname people drive on the left and they are not used to cyclists. This requires extra attention from the cyclist. Wearing a bicycle helmet is not mandatory, but highly recommended.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You can go fairly easily to private individuals. Just ask.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are no campsites as you'll find in most Western countries. You will find more and more recreational areas along the described routes: you can camp there and there are toilets and showers. You can often just rent a hammock and sometimes a sheet bag and hang it up under a shelter. You share the shelter with others. Sometimes you can even rent a house. The manager is often willing to serve a breakfast or hot meal.

There is no camping gas.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels, guesthouses and guest houses are available in many places such as Paramaribo, Groningen, Totness, Wageningen, Nickerie, Apura, Blanche Marie, Zanderij, Lelydorp, Brokopondo, 6 km east of Tamanredjo, Mungo, Albina. There are also houses or huts for rent in many recreational areas (near rivers and creeks).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is possible in Suriname. Try to get a spot with someone in the yard. In the jungle you will come across open bivouac sites along the roads where you can place your tent or stretch a tarpaulin over a frame of branches. There is always a creek nearby where you can find water. It is a pity that the waste is not taken or incinerated.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Suriname without a visa for up to 90 days.

Visa policy map of Suriname
  Suriname
  Short term visa exemption
  E-Tourist Card
  E-Visa
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Sweden is a very large country where it is pleasant to cycle. The south is flatter and less sparsely populated than the center and north. There are also more roads in the south. The coastal regions are also usually busier than the rest of the country. It is important to choose the right roads for a bike ride. Major thoroughfares with their rushing freight traffic can be annoying. Other roads are excellent.

Many holiday cyclists in Sweden are on their way to the North Cape or on the way back. Many try to drive through Sweden as quickly as possible and then opt for the A45, A4 or other busy roads. Unfortunately, they often do not get a positive impression of Sweden because of this. That is unfortunate and unfair.

Sweden consists for the most part of lakes and coniferous forest and is hilly and flat. Many cyclists are very pleased with the tranquility. In the south a lot of land has been cultivated and you mainly cycle between rolling fields, but if you go more to the north the country becomes desolate. Sweden is a large country, cycling from north to south takes about three weeks.

Northern Sweden is rough, unspoilt and sparsely populated. This area covers almost half of Sweden. You will find extensive forests, inaccessible wetlands, mountains, fjords and islands. So you can cycle for days without meeting anyone. So plan your purchases well.

Central Sweden is a low plain with some hill areas and large lakes. The southern part has a rolling landscape, is most visited by tourists and is therefore busier than the northern regions.

FoodDrink.body:
Supermarkets
Only shops (supermarkets) in the somewhat larger cities. But almost everything is available here. Many of these supermarkets are open from 7am to 9pm, sometimes longer and even on Saturdays and Sundays. Some "big" villages have a small local shop. The choice and opening times are more limited here.

Keep in mind that there may be several tens of kilometers between two shopping cities/villages. Especially in the sparsely populated areas (70 km is no exception to the next shop). Alcoholic drinks above 3% are available in special stores.

Restaurants
