Eating out is very expensive. If you cook for yourself, it's okay. Pizzerias can be found in many small villages. Don't skip the small conditories: the coffee and pastries are excellent.

A tip from Arjan Giling: "In many restaurants, inns and hotels, lunches are served from 11.30 am to 2.30 pm, for 5.5 - 8 euros you can have excellent food with salad, drink and main meal, coffee at the end. okay with you."

John: "In large cities it is often difficult to get into a cafe during the evening as a -23 year old. This is still possible in the student area, but in many larger cafes this is not possible. Especially on Thursdays there is often an outside bouncer who is inexorable."

Drinkable water
The tap water is of the best quality. In the far north you can also drink from streams.

Health.body: In the summer there are many midges (the annoying little flies). Mosquitoes are mainly found in the north of Sweden. If you travel through the woods in the summer, make sure you have mosquito repellent with you. However, do not expect miracles from using those remedies. The best remedy against the mosquitoes is to choose the right season, i.e. early spring, autumn, or if you like cold, winter. A cap with a mosquito net is very comfortable.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The best cycling time is from early June to mid-September. Sweden has a continental climate with harsh winters and beautiful summers. It is a lot drier and warmer than neighboring Norway. In the south, the influence of the ocean is noticeable and it rains more often here. It hardly ever rains for days on end. It can cool down quite a bit at night.

People.body:
Swedes are fairly self-contained, but if you make contact they are hospitable and helpful. They are sporty. Cyclists are treated with respect.

Communication is fine in English with half a word of Swedish. Sometimes you can also use German.

Safety.body: Sweden is a safe country. Cycling alone is not a problem. Just pay close attention to your bicycle, because bicycle theft does occur!
Safety.body_traffic:
There is little traffic on the road, with the exception of the major roads. Cars take good care of cyclists. If you follow the signposted cycling routes, you usually ride on nice and quiet roads.

Many regional roads have been converted in "2+1 roads" where there is a wire barrier separating alternating stretches of 1-lane and 2-lane sides. Cycling in a 1-lane stretch is very dangerous: lorries cannot leave cyclists almost any margin when they are driving at 90 km/h. Google maps does not give this information, ask the locals.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are excellent campsites where you can camp as well as rent a small wooden bungalow (trekker hut type). The campsites usually have good facilities: laundry room, cooking area, drying or ironing facilities. You don't pay per person but per place. Keep in mind that you will soon lose about 12 euros per night. Many campsites are affiliated with a camping organization. If you want to use these campsites you must have a pass. This can be purchased for about 10 euros at any affiliated campsite. An overview of camping sites can be found at www.camping.se .

Camping gas is not available.
Sleeping.body_hostels: The youth hostels are not age-related. There are about 200 of these inns in Sweden. They are open from May to mid-September. In summer it is advisable to discuss. It is often possible to get meals.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is allowed because of everyone's rights. This means that you can camp anywhere as long as you stay out of sight of the owner of the estate. If you do that near houses, then discuss it.

Transport.body_boat: Bicycles can always be taken on the domestic ferries. Usually it will cost you nothing or a few euros. A very nice trip by old steamboat from the historic town of Marietstad to the center of Stockhom. Of course you can bring bicycles. Google steamship Mariefred.
Transport.body_bus:
It is not possible to take a bicycle on long-distance routes of Swebus and Eurolines, but FlixBus takes bicycles.

From Karslborg you can take the Skövdebus to Skövde and to Askersund. From Askersund you can take your bike on the back of the bus to Örebro. From Eskilstuna you can go to Mariefred and Stockholm by bike on the back of the bus.
Transport.body_train:
It is possible to cover large sections by trains of most local railroad companies. Often the cost is the price of a children's ticket.

On the national carrier of Sweden SJ, one cannot take bicycles. Instead, the bicycle can be transported separately. This can sometimes take up to three days. The bicycle is stored at the final destination and therefore does not have to be picked up immediately. Bicycle transport is only possible to and from the major stations and costs about 30 euros, regardless of the distance.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

About.body: Most people think that you have to be a 'mountain goat' to cycle in Switzerland. Nothing could be further from the truth: you can cycle perfectly flat or even downhill for several days. Of course you can also opt for one or more panoramic Alpine cols. It is a matter of choosing the right region and route.

FoodDrink.body:
Some tasty speciality are cheese fondue, nut cake, raclette, rösti (you can also buy prepackaged in the supermarket to enjoy at your tent).

Cooking fuel
Campinggaz is often for sale in garden stores.
Outdoor sports stores also carry screw valve cans for other brands.

Supermarkets
Many villages do have a shop where food is for sale. The offer is often the same as in the Netherlands. However, the prices are much higher. The large supermarkets offer a wide range of organic products

Drinkable water
Drinkable water everywhere, and more: almost every village square has its public drinking water point, often in the form of a hollowed-out tree trunk in which potable water flows continuously.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The weather is not too different from this in Flanders, unless you get to a higher altitude. So you can cycle in Switzerland all year round. Until May and from the end of September you can still find snow above about 1500m and it is not certain that all passes are open ... Be sure to inquire in the spring whether the passes are open.

Spare parts
Many Swiss drive with 26" tires, but you will certainly find a 28" as well. Marten: "In the German-speaking part there is a lot of cycling and MTBing. Especially in the larger cities there are excellent bicycle repair shops (often near a station). The Italian part was always more race-bike oriented."

Nice routes
As part of a project called "Veloland Schweiz", 9 national routes (map) have been mapped out and signposted flawlessly. In addition to these national routes, there are also dozens of local routes.

These routes are signposted in two directions. You can cycle the Rhone and Rhine Route both upstream or downstream. What is striking is that the routes remain neatly within the national borders. As a result, you miss connections between the routes in the South and all the way in the East, the right bank of the Rhine (abroad!) is actually much more pleasant to cycle than the left bank. The Rhone route is not exactly the most beautiful: the more you go to the west, the wider the valley becomes, with the highway, the train, the high-voltage line and a lot of industry to the left and right of the cycle path.

People.body:
The people are friendly and often greet you. She is also very helpful in some cases.

4 languages are spoken in Switzerland: German (64%,), French (20%,), Italian (8%,) and Rhetoric (1%,). German predominates, so almost everyone speaks German. English is also spoken by many people.

Safety.body_traffic:
It is busy on the main roads. In the mountains there are few roads other than main roads, but the Veloland Schweiz routes know where possible to find nice alternatives. Count on unpaved and/or extra climbing.

On the roads of the popular cycling routes, such as around Lake Constance, there is a lot of bicycle traffic in high season.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: The campsites in Switzerland are of excellent quality. Yet they remain quite affordable, although the price sometimes varies from reasonable to expensive. You pay a lot, especially along the lakes.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Of course there are plenty of hotels, guest houses, bed & breakfast establishments. There are plenty of cheap hotels. The folder of the Swiss Tourist Board can be useful for this.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is not allowed in Switzerland.

Transport.body_boat: Crossing on one of the lakes such as Vierwaldstätter See or the Brienzer See is possible by bike.
Transport.body_bus: Many regular buses (called "PostAuto" in Switzerland) have about 5 bicycle hooks on the back. Bringing a bike seems to be no problem.
Transport.body_train:
Bicycles can be taken on almost all trains, including on the many private mountain railways (see http://mct.sbb.ch/mct/velo ). You can often 'avoid' a tough climb by taking the train for a while, because a railway (with tunnel) runs parallel to a pass. And if there is no parallel railway track, you will see a striking number of mailboxes (with bicycle racks) passing by.

Most Intercity and Interregions consist of a locomotive with a long train of carriages. Almost every wagon has places for the bicycle (between 2 and 5 hooks on the ceiling per wagon), so that there is always enough space for the bicycle in the train. The slow trains generally have folding seats against which you have to place the bicycle. Bicycles do not need to be reserved in Switzerland, except on the ICN (intercity-neigezug). This reservation costs 5 euros per bike. Please note: many cross-border connections, such as ICEs (to Germany) do not take bicycles.

This is not really cheap! Often there is no counter and you have to try to buy the right ticket at a machine, also for your bicycle. You therefore do not always see whether the train does take bicycles, such as international trains, etc. But a little assertiveness will also solve this. The official info can be found here.

Visa.body: People from EU, Canada, Japan and USA don't need a visa. All other people need a Schengen visa to visit this country. You can find more information here https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/tourist-schengen-visa/. The visa is valid for 90 days, and allows you to travel through all Schengen countries.

FoodDrink.body:
In Taiwan, Chinese and Japanese cuisines are well represented. You can recognize Japanese eateries especially if you have yakitori (grilled chicken products), marinated meat products, soy sauce or seaweed on the menu. Chinese-oriented eateries are recognizable if you can order grilled duck, soup with lots of vegetables and meat or noodles with spicy herb sauce.

John: "I have no idea whether there are also vegetarian dishes, but given that blood-filled pig intestines, chicken butts, muggi-chai and a multitude of other things come together in an overfull kitchen, there will probably also be a vegetarian plate somewhere. must be."

Cooking fuel
Coleman screw gas cans can only be found in the larger cities in the better outdoor shops. Alcohol (95%) is available at the drugstore for a Trangia stove.

Markets
The night markets in the major Taiwanese cities are a fusion of Japanese, Chinese and local food cuisines. At these eateries, you can ease the long agony of the live crabs lying on the ice cubes by pointing them out and having them served as a delicious dinner dish. A visit to one of the night markets is a must for any traveler. Keelung has the largest coziest night market in Taiwan.

Supermarkets
The small villages in the mountains have few shops, but there is always a town to be found somewhere.

Stalls on the street
There are many fine, inexpensive roadside eateries and night markets.

Drinkable water
According to Eelco, the tap water is drinkable, but the Taiwanese themselves sometimes think differently.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The best time is October/November. The typhoons are usually behind us by then, the temperature is a bit lower but still not so cold that it is no longer pleasant to cycle in the mountains. From June to September it's typhoon season, so it's a bit risky to plan your bike ride that way. In addition, it is very hot.

In April - May it can also rain for weeks in a row. The end of December to February is wonderful in the south of Taiwan, but the north and in the mountains can be very cold. March is also a perfect month for cycling, just before the rainy season and temperatures can reach the late 20s.

Spare parts
Taiwan is the country where many modern bicycles are made, including the parts. So almost everything can be found.

Nice routes
  • North of the capital Taipei, numerous interesting geological phenomena, historical sites and the colorfully decorated temples are just a stone's throw from the highway 2. Outcrops of geological formations are clearly visible all along the north, northeast and east coasts.
  • The coastal routes (motorways 2 and 11) have many lookouts and short hiking trails, giving visitors ample opportunities to enjoy Taiwan's pristine coastal areas.
  • Whoever follows coastal route 11 from Hualien to Taitung will encounter the tunnels along the east coast; an alternative is to follow national highway 9 (east rift valley), where you will find many fertile and green areas of Taiwan. The valley is known for its special butterflies, rural life and honey production.
  • Taroko Kloof is an absolute must as a trip from Hualien. Until Tianxiang, the route is passable for cyclists and contains many lookouts and walking routes (trails), then the steep part to Guanyuan follows.
  • North of Hualien are the impressive sheer cliffs, Chingshuei Cliffs, along National Highway 9. Taiwanese consider this stretch of highway one of the masterpieces of their country.
Tips
  • Taiwan has no cultural or religious regulations regarding your clothing on the bike.
  • During Chinese New Year, everyone goes on vacation and the whole country is stuck in traffic (and cheering).
  • Every police station has a bicycle service, which includes: free cold/hot drinking water, toilets, air for tires and tools.
  • Watch your language during emotional outbursts. What in the Western world can be regarded as "normal" English spoken language, can be experienced as offensive in Taiwan. Police report cases of this kind and apologies will follow. If the victim does not accept an apology, a lawsuit may follow!

Safety.body_nature:
Eelco had a wonderful time driving around alone. Even the barking dogs that showed up next to my tent turned out to have very neat manners in the end. So safe. Even safer is to bring a "dazzer" for stubborn dogs that keep running after you.

Taiwan is nice and warm and beautiful, but if you go high in the mountains it suddenly gets very cold. So bring a nice warm sweater in that case.
Safety.body_traffic:
The Taiwanese population makes massive use of scooters and mopeds. At busy intersections and T-junctions, you as a cyclist can be hindered by scooters and mopeds. Do not deviate from your line, because scooters and mopeds can unexpectedly pass you at high speed. Most intersections and T-junctions have separate areas for cyclists, mopeds and scooters and you can stand in front as a cyclist. Do this too, because you will be visible to turning traffic. Many Taiwanese do not indicate a turn when they are in a turning lane.

Please note: some motorists use the separate lanes for cyclists, mopeds and scooters to carry out their overtaking actions.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Most campsites are open all year round and have good facilities.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Youth hostels in Taiwan are five-star hotels at a bargain price. Definitely recommend. Cheap hotels can also be found with a bit of searching.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is not a problem, occasionally even in city parks.

Transport.body_train:
Officially, the bicycle must be in a bicycle cover. If you don't have one, you can consider purchasing one on site (approx. 40 euros). It is cheaper to send the bike in advance for a few euros or to send it back by night train. We experienced the latter on the east coast, but on the west coast we were able to ride the bicycle with our luggage in wagon 13 (the bicycle wagon) of the express train. It just depends on which station master is on duty, a stiff bureaucratic (East Coast) or a very friendly helpful (West Coast).

If there is no separate train set for bicycles, the best chance of getting the bicycle on the regional or express train is by traveling during off-peak hours and packing the bicycle. Railway workers want to keep the aisles in trainsets clear!

About.body: If there were 7 biketouring world wonders, Tajikistan would host one of them: The Pamir Highway. For this spectacular route, many bike tourists find their way to Tajikistan.

0ad6ce42-405a-42c6-80db-9e9608848aff.description:
There is another evisa website available. We don't have experience with one of these websites, so please update this information if you have recent experience.

The visa has to be used within 90 days. According to Caravanistan, you also need a GBAO permit to apply fot he visa.

FoodDrink.body:
Typical dishes are Plov or Osh in Tajik (rice meal with fried strands of carrot, chickpeas and chunks of meat). In the south people eat Kurtob or Shakarob (yogurt meal with pieces of fried bread and various vegetables). And then there's Shashlik... Everywhere on the street you will find barbecue stands. Shorpa is a kind of soup based on mutton fat, with meat, carrot and potato. Samsa are puff pastry triangles filled with onions and mutton or (if you're lucky) onions and chickpeas.

Bread is fantastic. Baked in a tandoor, it is thick and nutritious and not bland. At the bazaar you can buy the base of nougat in a cut PET bottle. Delicious as a sandwich spread.

Plenty of cheap restaurants but the quality is often hard to find. In every village you will find a chajchana, where you can eat and drink tea.There are small shops everywhere that sell everything. Make sure you buy enough when you move into the Pamirs.

Maarten: "If you have a bit of a firm stomach, you will survive.  Tajikistan is one of the most vegetarian-unfriendly countries: Meat is really in EVERYTHING!! I have also been served a lot of, in my view, disgusting food such as boiled sheep skin or entrails. Shipovnik (non-alcoholic drink made from berries, tastes a bit like Roosvicee) is a nice drink. And then of course there's vodka... Be warned! They can be ruthless drinkers..."

Drinkable water
ALWAYS filter water because in Tajikistan you can get all diseases. The water is of poor quality, except in the mountain areas. In Dushanbe the brown comes out of the tap. The water in the mountains is reliable. Only high in the mountains are no more streams.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The best cycling season is from March to May and from September to November. Then you have nice mild warm weather. However, early spring or late autumn can be very cold in the mountains (especially Pamir). At night it is cold, during the day around 20 to 25°C. In other seasons it is sweltering hot (40+ in summer) or quite cold (around 5 degrees in winter).

Wilbert: "The weather in September was lovely for cycling. But at the end of September it was suddenly very cold on the Pamir Highway. The last few days the temperature did not rise above freezing. It was still nice in the sun, but the wind picked up the mountain passes was freezing cold."

Spare parts
In cities you can find bicycle parts dealers on the market. Do not expect super parts, but tires, pedals, simple brakes, everything of dubious Chinese / Russian quality.

Nice routes
  • Eelco: "I only drove from Samarkand to Dushanbe (via Pejikent and a few excursions to beautiful mountain lakes; definitely recommended!!). The only drawback is that it can sometimes get really hot in the valleys. Anzob pass to Dushanbe is a torture, very bad road, your smallest gear is actually just too little, narrow, mud everywhere and often half eaten away by thawing glaciers on or next to the road. meters or something), nice oxygen too short, etc, I think you get the idea.Not that it doesn't get any less beautiful there, but it does make me think about the Pamirs, which are at their highest up to 4800 meters to reach..."
  • Marco: "Cycling through the Pamir Mountains is a wonderful experience. You cycle at a great height. Both the landscape and the people are breathtaking. The Pamir Highway is a popular route. You will also find more cyclists there. The Pamir Highway is paved for large parts and in reasonable condition. As soon as you leave the road, the paths are of poor quality.
Tips
Because you are often invited, it is advisable to bring small gifts.

People.body:
The local people are tremendously hospitable. It appears easy to knock on people's doors to find shelter or food. At first, they wait and see who you are.. It is no problem to walk quietly through a town. But if you want to have contact, that's how it is.

For men there are not so many clothing restrictions (maybe only in the really remote regions where it is better not to wear shorts). Women should dress conservatively outside of Khujand and Dushanbe. Islam is not widely practiced in Tajikistan. During Ramadan you can eat well everywhere during the day. Women can move around markets well without being harassed by men. There is a nice relaxed atmosphere in markets. Around Dushanbe especially the warzab gorge is extremely rich. It is a stark contrast to the rest of the country.

Safety.body:
Tajikistan is easily accessible and no traveler mentions a problem. Especially at the Afghan border it is advisable to be a little more careful with camping because of smugglers and Russian patrols.

In 2018, four bike touritst got killed by militants from IS, and two more got injured. This, however, seems a single event that has been taken very seriously by the authorities in order to prevent something like this happening again.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
In villages you are easily invited to stay the night. 

Wilbert: "On the route from Samarkant via the Anzob pass and Dushanbe to Chorog there was a restaurant every 10 to 40 km. Usually in a kind of garden/orchard. I was always allowed to pitch my tent there. On the Pamir Highway I was always invited inside when I asked if I could set up the tent near a house."
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels vary enormously in quality and price range. The old Soviet hotels are often of very poor quality and a bit on the expensive side.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Wild camping is allowed, but inquire with the local population. Often people advise against it (wild animals, robbery). They will offer you a place in their house. In the mountains you can always find a suitable spot near a river. Be careful when staying overnight at a high altitude, it can get quite cold and windy at night.

John: "Be careful when camping on the Afghan border. The Russian (!) military prefers not to, although it is not officially banned. I was directed to the compound with quite a show of force."

Transport.body_bus: Transporting your bike on the bus is (just like in many third world countries) no problem as long as you don't have any problems with the bike being transported between other loads. In the Pamirs, the buses consist of small minibuses.

Visa.body:
The visa policy of Tajikistan differs quite a lot for different nationalities. Most countries (yellow) can apply for the evisa. In addition to the visa, you must obtain a GBAO permit if you want to enter the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region, which can be obtained in Dushanbe and Khorogh.

Source: Wikipedia.

7f9a8f5d-80d0-4df4-b735-1cc650b1de50.description: We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

FoodDrink.body:
There are plenty of food stalls and simple restaurants along the road. The food (rice with beans and spinach and chicken or fish) is not always reliable. Once you've seen the meat on the market, you don't need it anymore. It is fine for vegetarians.

Supplies on the road mainly go to markets, which are really everywhere and there is enough available, but not so much choice (rice, potato, vegetables). Lots of eggs and peanuts. In the cities there are shops with sometimes jars of peanut butter and often pasta, which are expensive. In Mwanza, for example, there is a supermarket, in Dar a real western one.

White bread (mkate, skonzi) and donut-like things (andazi, keki) are widely available, and often some Indian snacks as well. In the southeast of the country there is even brown bread, bumunda.

Drinks
Drinking water is available in bottles. It is difficult to find good water outside the big cities, there is no tap water. It is recommended to bring a water filter. Look carefully at the map or ask how far the next village is.

Nienke: "I usually had 3 liters of water in my bag when I left. There was no tap water in the mountains. Drinking and filling I did at rivers and in villages. I did not drink tap water in the larger towns, but water from the lake did. Opinions are divided on whether that is healthy. I haven't had any trouble."

Health.body: Vaccinations against yellow fever, DTP and hepatitis A are recommended. A Cholera statement is also required. Malaria occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis, etc. are available on site.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The most pleasant period is from June to September. It is then nice and dry and cool (around 30 degrees). During November-February it is hottest in Tanzania.

Tanzania has two rainy seasons: from March to May and, to a lesser extent, from November to January. Especially from March to May, roads on the south coast can be impassable.

Susanne: "We cycled there during the rainy season. It doesn't really rain much, sometimes a shower (possibly with thunder), so not wet all day, and sometimes drizzly days. The roads can be flooded (south of Tabora, no most roads are passable, but your parts wear out faster due to the combination of sand and water. On the coast it was sweltering hot and stuffy, the rest of the country was fine after some getting used to. In the mountains it gets cold ( very cold (sweater + jacket) at Makete)."

Spare parts
Parts for the modern western bike are not available, only bad Chinese stuff. You have to bring all parts that could wear out (gears, chain, brake pads, etc.). The most commonly used tire size is 28 inches (so available, but poor quality).

There are bicycle repair shops (fundi za baisekeli) with tools and inventiveness. In Dar El Salaam there is Samir (Google on Bicycle Doctors, Ruhinda Street) bicycledocters.weebly.com. Samir is very communicative and willing to arrange spare goods from outside. They are doing a good job.

Nice routes
  • Wilbert: "From Lunga Lunga to Pangani there is a good dirt road, then in the rainy season impassable to Bogamogo, to Dar again good. From Dar to Malauri is asphalt, largely newly laid."
  • Nienke: "The dirt roads are very attractive for cyclists. Little or no car traffic and mostly hard sand or pulverized gravel. The Kitulo plateau in the south was very cool, narrow paths through afro-montane grassland. The country as a whole is very nice and beautiful, the towns are very lively, Tanzania is fun! Better first time Africa than Malawi!"
  • Beautiful tropical route along the coast, then alternating savannas, landscapes with the Mikumi National Park (a lot of game and according to Tanzanians too dangerous to cycle).
  • Theo: "Now that you're there: don't forget to go to Zanzibar: you can cycle there for a day or four on many unpaved roads through tropical forest and spend the night on bounty-like beaches."

People.body:
Just like elsewhere in Africa you have quick contact with people, people have no idea how to keep a distance. They are usually very friendly and hospitable, but in the more touristy areas it often happens that people are greedy for money and overcharge.

Children can be loud and intrusive. If you sit down somewhere in a village, they will immediately gather around you. Appropriate clothing is not necessary. Men usually don't give a shit about women, but they think a cycling woman is just retarded. Especially when you are alone you stand out and all the beauty is overlooked. But in a friendly way! Giggles, laughter, comments and kisses.

The official language is Swahili. It's a language that you can master pretty quickly (if you don't know, just use the English word with an i after it) and then you have really nice contact.

Safety.body_criminality: Nienke: "If I left my bike alone for a while, I didn't have to worry that it would be stolen, because when I returned, twenty people were on their knees around it to admire it. In larger places I put it inside someone's house. . In cities I took it into the hotel room!"

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are hardly any campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: It is not necessary to bring a tent, there are lodges or guest houses in most villages. These are very basic but are fine (spacious rooms, where necessary with a fan and where the bicycles fit). Outside the tourist areas these are very cheap. Please bring your own padlock for the door.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is sometimes difficult because there are people almost everywhere.

Transport.body_bus: Buses stop if you ask and on most roads there are many, you can take a bike and it doesn't cost much.
Transport.body_train: You can take the bike with you, but it has to be put in the freight car and you have to arrange that it goes with you at the same time, otherwise you can sit and wait for it. If you send the bike forward, it will be treated nicely and will be ready for you at the station. You pay per kilo, not much.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa for entering Tanzania.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Thailand, the land of the smile. A beautiful paradise with lots of food, drinks and tourists.

FoodDrink.body:
Thailand is known for arguably the most spicy cuisine in the world. However, there are also very neutral dishes. Every village has a cheap food stall, noodle shop or restaurant. At many places like this, the menu is limited to a single dish. For the big eater, the portions are sometimes very small. Then you just take two in a row.

The "Night Market" is a great place for a good meal. Here and there you will find a vegetarian restaurant. In most eateries you can make something without meat or fish, the Chinese offer the best chance.

Fruit is widely available. You can get bread more and more in modern supermarkets and all kinds of sandwiches in the coffee shops a la Starbucks that are sprouting everywhere like mushrooms. Brown and white bread is sold in every 7/11 store.

In modern supermarkets, more and more food is available that you know from your home country. If you can't miss that, you can make your move here. The widely available and very cheap packs of noodle soup are easy to prepare and serve well for breakfast or lunch.

Drinkable water
Tap water is sometimes drinkable, but not really recommended. Filtering is recommended. The Thais drink rainwater, Roelof has done so without any problems. There are water tap devices in more and more cities where you can fill up with filtered water for a few bath liters. This water is not cooled, but much cheaper than bottled water and you can just put your own bottles under it.

You can buy drinking water in handy plastic bottles of about a liter that fit right in your water bottle cage.

Supermarkets
In the larger places there is often a 7-eleven, the smaller places are often shops at home with a more limited range

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Roughly speaking, Thailand has three seasons.
  • The best cycling season is from mid-October to the end of February. There is little rainfall and it is relatively cool, the coolest in the northern part of the country. Daytime temperatures of 30 degrees remain very common. This is the season of beautiful blue skies.
  • From the end of February to mid-May it is relatively dry, but it can be very hot. Temperatures of 35 degrees are then very normal.
  • The rainy season is from late May to mid-October. It is a bit cooler, the sun shines less. The rain usually falls in the late afternoon.
Spare parts
28 inch inner tubes are hard to come by. But a 27 inch Chinese inner tube also fits. Medium-sized cities often have a simple bicycle repair shop with a basic supply of parts.

Nice routes
An absolute must is the Mae Hong Son loop. The whole region is beautiful. Spectacular is the road from Chiang Mai to Mae Hong Son via Pai, but difficult for cycling, many large and steep slopes. Waterfalls and hot springs along the way. From Pai you can make beautiful trips to the Nam Nang Park. From Mae Hong Son you can take trips to the mountain villages to the north or to Mae Surin Park further south with wild sunflowers blooming in November. If you drive from Khun Yuam to Mae Chang, you have to take into account a very tough 75 km through a very deserted area with virtually no options to get food and drink. Doi Inthanon Park: Thailand's highest peak is located here, 2565 m. An asphalt road goes to the top, last 10 km an average increase of 10%.

People.body:
The population is very cordial, but you are rarely invited home. In villages you are welcomed by hordes of children. Cyclists are almost always welcomed. Along the way you will be loudly cheered from common pick-ups.

Roelof: “As a cyclist it is impossible not to come into contact with Thai. A cyclist is by definition disturbed but is treated in a friendly manner. As long as the shoulders are covered and the pants are clearly not underpants, it's fine."

Ivo: “The population is very hospitable. Actually, this was the most relaxed country in Southeast Asia. People are interested and eager to have a chat, but they are also not pushy if you don't feel like talking.”

The Thai language is difficult but the Thais react enthusiastically when you speak a few words in their language. Many people speak some English. In the most unexpected places there is someone who speaks English or a student who wants to practice it.

Safety.body: Thailand is a safe country. Attacks are sometimes committed in the southernmost three provinces. Also in the northwest corner of the country there are tensions around some population groups. This is not aimed at foreigners, but still. English-language Thai newspapers and media report this and there is also a warning on the Foreign Affairs website.

aa9ff8d0-595d-4794-afac-977aa749f8b6.description: A large Bhudist temple with a goldn Buddha. The place is free of entrance.
aa9ff8d0-595d-4794-afac-977aa749f8b6.title: Shrine to Siddhartha

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Men in particular can sleep without difficulty and for free in the omnipresent temples, there are no facilities there. Homestays require polite Thai behavior which is often strange for a Westener.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
You can camp at most national parks. Tents can often be rented there as well. 

Ton: “Camping in Thailand is going well. I mainly let my route be determined by the National Parks that are everywhere. There I was allowed to pitch my tent and often I just slept under the roof of the restaurant. I was also regularly given a place in an information center. The beach is also ideal for free nights. I myself also have good memories of overnight stays with people.”

John: "Police in the north of Thailand often have a nice fenced grassland. We were always allowed to camp here for free. In the toilet you will find a water pistol with which you can take a shower!"
Sleeping.body_hostels:
Hotels and guesthouses can be obtained from a travel guide. Every city with 10,000 or more inhabitants has a small hotel. The price ranges from roughly 100 to 300 Baht (2 to 6 euros) for guesthouses. The bottom-end hotels are a fraction more expensive. The hotels are on average around 70 km from each other (sometimes 136 km). For about € 15,- you even have a room with air conditioning, bathroom and sometimes a swimming pool. Women traveling alone can safely spend the night in the so-called whore hotels (indicated by number).

In addition to the cities, hotels and/or guesthouses can also be found in places where (important) roads converge. The food is fine. In Thailand, don't let the name "resort" put you off. It sounds expensive and luxurious, but that is not always the case. A resort often rents out simple cabins.

Bangkok: Recommended: Granny Bike Bed. A small hostel (10 beds) above a bicycle repair shop. The bicycle mechanic and his wife run this. Very friendly people and a good place to sleep. 250 baht. https://www.facebook.com/grannybikebed
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is sometimes difficult due to overcrowding. You are generally not harassed. You do attract a lot of attention, wherever you camp.

Transport.body_airplane: Thailand has an extensive domestic network of air connections. The bicycle can be taken on a domestic flight without any problems. Packing is sometimes not necessary. Thai Airways: http://www.thaiair.com.
Transport.body_bus:
Bicycles can be taken on the bus. Note: do not pay too much. The bicycle can also be taken in so-called songthaews (covered pick-up with benches) for shorter distances.

Aircon bus: bike goes at the bottom of the luggage, usually for free. The luggage compartment must be large enough. My experience is that the bicycle often does not fit or very difficult to fit.

Non aircon bus: either in the bus, or on the roof. Costs: for yourself 1x and the bike 1/2x
Transport.body_train: Bicycles can be taken on the train, cheap and no problem. Check in at the baggage counter one hour in advance. The disadvantage is that not all trains have a baggage car, sometimes transport by bus (or just cycling) is easier.

About.body: A small, but long country. Pass through it in one day, or explore the inner depths more inland. The country offers an interesting history of their Voodoo religion. The people are very friendly, but also very poor. You can expect some begging.

e2fcd9f8-8ca2-4292-9211-bc32e4591789.description: Obtain your visa at this border crossing with very friendly officials. Bring one photo.

FoodDrink.body:
Togolese cuisine is one of the best in West Africa and restaurants are very cheap. On the road you'll find a lot of small bars where they serve bread with egg or delicious spaghetti. The local food is Fufu and Akume. Palm wine is the local drink, which has a very strong taste.

It is recommended to bring a water filter.

Health.body:
• A yellow fever vaccination is mandatory for all travelers.
  • DTP and hepatitis A are recommended.
  • Precautions are recommended.
  • Sometimes a cholera certificate is required.
  • Malaria occurs all year round. Protective equipment DEET, prophylaxis, etc. are available on site.
  • Healthcare is at a low level.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The rainy season lasts from May to October with a break in the south from mid-July to mid-September. The hottest period is from mid-February to mid-April. The dry season is the best for cycling, when the roads are at their best. The only disadvantage is that the harmatan (desert wind) often creates a lot of dust in the air.

Spare parts
Parts for modern western bicycles, with the exception of tires, are virtually impossible to obtain.

People.body:
Togo, which is one of the smaller countries in Africa, is home to about 40 ethnic groups! The people are usually very friendly.

The official language is French, in addition, various local languages are spoken such as Ewe, Mina and Kabyé

-MGMuxFsuDoApFc-qzW7.description: This route starts at the border with Ghana and goes north to the Koutammakou area close to the border with Benin.
-MGMuxFsuDoApFc-qzW7.title: West to East

Safety.body: Generally safe to cycle, be cautious in big cities.
Safety.body_traffic: The roads and the traffic are similar to other Afircan countries. Mostly there is a shoulder on which you can cycle.

-MGMuCwPEa7Sim7aLs9i.description: Next to the stately mountains, a village with traditional tata houses – small mud castels – is still doing business the old way.
-MGMuCwPEa7Sim7aLs9i.description_first: Next to the stately mountains, a village with traditional tata houses – small mud castels – is still doing business the old way.
-MGMuCwPEa7Sim7aLs9i.title: Koutammakou

-MGMuKwsmkuHOTUk50c6.description: Explore the vibrant coastline by visiting Cotonou, Coco Beach or Lac Togo.
-MGMuKwsmkuHOTUk50c6.description_first: Explore the vibrant coastline by visiting Cotonou, Coco Beach or Lac Togo.
-MGMuKwsmkuHOTUk50c6.title: Coastline

-MGMuSnCJm-9IP9dpps5.description: Find refreshment under the rumbling waterfall near Kpalime.
-MGMuSnCJm-9IP9dpps5.description_first: Find refreshment under the rumbling waterfall near Kpalime.
-MGMuSnCJm-9IP9dpps5.title: Waterfall

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You can stay with locals quite easily, they are always helpful and sometimes even give their own bed to you. Saying that you can sleep in your own tent is not a problem.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: A great way of meeting locals and sleeping in your own comfortable bed. Ask anyone in a village and they will search a spot for you.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are hotels in many places. These are very variable in quality. In many cases, the bicycle can be taken with you in the room or stored separately. The first option is always preferable. The price of an overnight stay depends on your requirements and varies. Staying overnight in hostels: quality differs: with / without electricity, running water, water at all, proper toilet, shower, etc.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Possible, but there are lots of people everywhere, so consider asking permission first.

-MGMw7ZQWqrK0SwJDiT_.title: A confiscated drone and experiencing voodoo

Visa.body:
A few African nationalities and for some reason Romanians can enter Togo without a visa. Other nationalities can get a visa on arrival. You can get a 7-day visa at some border crossings. An extension of 21 days can be obtained in Lome or Kara.


Source: Wikipedia.

Some nationalities can enter Trinidad and Tobago without a visa.


Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Food
You can eat in many small restaurants: generally fine and cheap, lots of couscous. Large quantities of French bread are consumed with every meal. Harissa is the almost standard seasoning: a mixture of red peppers, tomatoes, cumin, coriander and garlic that can be quite pungent. Meat can be questionable, but hygiene is at a higher level than in many other African countries.

Almost all villages have something like a shop. Often they sell very little, but always a snack or sardines. They sell bread and the like in almost every village.

Drink
Tap water is usually regarded as reliable, but it is recommended to ask beforehand. A water tower in the landscape almost always indicates a transport pipeline running kilometers long underneath. On the basis of this it is possible to estimate where the water comes from.

Bottled water can be bought almost everywhere but not in the desert. Restaurants or cafes store drinking water there in earthen pitchers that are often of excellent quality. It is obtained from locally known sources. It is recommended to bring extra water.

Cafes and restaurants often sell freshly squeezed orange juice and, of course, the ineradicable coca-cola. The local soda brand is Boga, available in the cola-like Cidre or Limon (Sprite/7-up)

Health.body:
The standard Hepatitis A and DTP injections are recommended for a cycling trip, but this is not mandatory. If you come from a yellow fever area, a vaccination is mandatory. You can also take immodium with you, especially recommended if you have sensitive intestines. Sanne: "Despite the fact that I didn't eat meat, I still had problems with my intestines."

Hygiene is usually not taken very seriously. Tip: When you order something to drink, ask for a straw, often the glasses are rinsed in a bucket of water instead of washed off.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Spring and autumn are suitable. In winter it can be found a bit on the cool side with about 15 degrees. March (20-24 degrees) is perfect for cycling, little wind, no rain, also a very cheap period. In winter, the south is also very suitable for cycling, there is a chance of a shower of rain, but that usually won't be much. Take into account sandstorms, make sure you have a good stormproof and sandproof tent! Prevailing wind directions differ depending on the time of year.

Spare parts
Bicycle shops are available in the larger towns. Parts are also available, but unfortunately these are mostly made in China or Taiwan. You will rarely find the better quality (Shimano) parts. There may be something to be found in the capital Tunis. The tire size used is mainly 26 inches with the French-style 27 inches next to it.

People.body:
Tunisia is part of the so-called Maghreb countries, alongside Morocco and Algeria. The population is of mixed Berber Arab descent and predominantly Muslim. There is hardly any segregation between these population groups, as still exists in Morocco, in Tunisia. Tourists like to bring the rich Berber culture of the past to the attention.

Many tourists come to Tunisia, especially on the coast. The 'Zone touristiques' as they are locally called are usually well outside the villages. It is a series of hotels, cafes, restaurants and secluded private beaches. In the interior you will mainly be confronted with groups of tourists who make organized hikes by land rover.

The cities are fairly westernized due to tourism and the west-oriented course of the government. Outside of that, it is often families who manage to maintain traditions.

People can be very pushy at times especially in tourist markets. For example, Matmata is notorious for the many touts who are eager to be your guide. They force you to visit the cave dwellings and the 'Starwars' film set. In addition, there are groups of students who can sometimes make it difficult for you as a cyclist. Begging for pens and Dinars is a regular occurrence. With drink on his men are often pushy towards women. In the interior people are generally extremely friendly and much less obtrusive than in other Arab countries.

In tourist cities on the coast, any clothing is possible, outside tight cycling clothing is viewed with disapproval, and dressing is desirable.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: It can happen that you are spontaneously invited to people. Decide for yourself whether you will accept it, usually people are very friendly and sincere.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are only a few campsites. 

Sanne has been on a campsite in Tozeur, and this was well arranged, there were even places in the shade. It can happen that a room is cheaper than a camping spot.

Tip: Camp under the palm trees at Ksar Halouf. Not free but great fun if you travel out of season.
Sleeping.body_hostels: These are a maximum of 140 km apart and are usually not expensive. The prices almost always include breakfast. The bicycle can usually be left in the room. Keep in mind that only the larger towns have a hotel.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping can be tricky, but it is possible. In the mountains the ground is quite rocky, so you don't have a good surface to sleep on. In the south the landscape is very open, everyone sees you. Where you don't suspect houses, they may be. People walk miles across the country from the road on their way home. Further south, the amount of buildings become less and less and there are plenty of opportunities.

Transport.body_bus: Taking the bike on the bus is possible and cheap. With several bicycles, it can sometimes require some more arrangements. In some cases, extortionate prices are charged and it is your own decision to pay or continue cycling. You can also take your bike on the roof in the regional taxi buses, the so-called louages. Very affordable, and often faster than the bus.
Transport.body_train: It is not a problem to bring a bicycle, it goes in the luggage compartment. It does take a while before the correct stamps (proof of payment) are affixed to the bicycles. The price is about half of a character ticket.

About.body: According to Alee Denham from CyclingAbout.com, and 150 other bike tourers, Turkey is the number 1 country to cycle at. See also this article with video. It's the all in one destination in which you can see an interesting change in culture, awesome landscapes and gorgeous villages. The Ottomon Empire has created a rich cultural history for the country.

d7bdf73e-5713-42cc-a056-037b87be3f28.description: Not all nationalities can make use of the e-visa. If you try to apply online, and fill in your country, you can see if it works for you. You can also check out this Wikipedia page.

FoodDrink.body:
Every town has a restaurant. Turkish cuisine is good and varied. Much use is made of olive oil, garlic, tomatoes and goat cheese. Fresh bread is consumed with every meal. The "lokantasi" are simple restaurants, cheap and reasonably good. You can make your own choice from display cases. Be careful, because food has often been in it for a whole day. Sometimes you can take a look in the kitchen and say what you want to eat, they are very resourceful. If you get the chance, you should try the homemade creamy yogurt.

Supermarkets
Small villages can sometimes have an astonishingly large supermarket; larger villages where you do expect a supermarket, sometimes do not have it. In the supermarkets you can always get macaroni, meat, milk, cheese, bread, vegetables, cola, etc.
Vegetarian can be found and may even be recommended when it is not too hygienic.

Water
Tap water is usually reliable but tastes less. You can top up with cold water at petrol pumps. Bottled water is widely available. Please note, especially in eateries, that the original cap is on the bottle. People sometimes want to fill old bottles with unreliable tap water. * Where there are mountains there are springs. You can find them in the most diverse places along the side of the road. Locals are proud of it and cherished. In most cases the water is drinkable and often a cup hangs next to it.
A refreshing non-alcoholic drink is ayran, a mixture of yogurt, water and salt mixed in a special way and very tasty, is often offered as a welcome drink in people's homes.

Health.body:
• A DTP vaccination is recommended, as is protection against Hepatitis A.
  • Malaria occurs from May to October.
  • The wild dogs sometimes are infected with rabies.
  • In Turkey it is possible to get Congo (?) Disease through a tick bite.

Other.body:
Communication 
  • Internet cafes are widely available everywhere. Many hotels also have wifi.
  • Wifi networks are almost all secured, but at petrol stations or cafes, for example, it is often possible to request the password.
  • You can make mobile calls almost everywhere, except in the remote mountain areas. 3G also works very well in many places.
When to cycle?
  • Late spring and early fall are the best times for cycling: it's warm but not too hot, mostly dry and you have a lot of sun. In the mountain areas it can be quite chilly at night.
  • In the summer it is very hot. In the area around the Black Sea it is a bit cooler and more humid than in the center and south.
  • Early in the spring and late in the autumn it is especially cold at night. It rains more often. Especially high in the mountains it is cold and it can snow. It is still pleasant on the coast.
Spare parts
  • Finding parts is difficult. If there are any parts it is less quality. Turkish people are very helpful and you will certainly be taken and dropped off at the first bicycle repair shop. It then does not have the appropriate parts. You have to be self-sufficient in that respect, also in terms of tools. There are also many moped repair workshops where people are very resourceful and can repair your bike. In Istanbul there are good bicycle repairers with an almost Dutch range (slightly outdated parts are more difficult to obtain than the very latest). Everything is much cheaper, especially wages.
  • 28 "tires are also hard to get, as are inner tubes of this size. If there are any, they have thick valves.
Tips
  • Bij de Galatabrug in Istanbul zijn veel privé boten die een kortere dure tocht over de Bosporus aanbieden. Vanaf pier 3 vertrekt echter driemaaldaags een lokale boot tot aan de Zwarte Zee.
Useful links
  • https://turkeytravelplanner.com/
    The Turkey Travel Planner from Lonely planet author Tom Brosnahan.

Safety.body:
• Turkey is a safe country with enormous social control.
  • Along the way you will regularly pass “roadblocks” of the traffic police. As a cyclist you are sometimes stopped, but more for the distraction of the police than it causes problems.
  • In Turkey you can suffer from dogs, especially sheep dogs there are many. Throwing stones or water, or hitting with a bicycle pump are a few measures. The Dazzer is also effective, a device that emits high tones that startle dogs enough. Best to be used at a distance of 3 to 4 meters.
  • Cycling alone is not a problem, especially for men.
  • Bernadette about traveling alone as a woman: “I cycled in the south and southeast. As a woman alone, that usually went very well. People were very enthusiastic and I was invited to many villages and treated with great respect. But there have also been some less positive experiences. Being rude or asking for help immediately was my salvation. As long as I was in a larger group, I felt safe anyway because the social control is still great. ”
  • In the east, between Lake Van and the border town of Dogubayazit (Tendürek Gecidi pass) and between Dogubayazit and the Iranian border, there are some dirty herders with sticks and dead snakes who try to rob travelers as an extra income. Most of them are teenagers and if you have a stick with you they will leave you alone.
Safety.body_nature: Wild dogs can be a big problem for bicycle tourist!
Safety.body_traffic:
• Cycling on the highways cannot be avoided. It is not allowed everywhere.
  • In recent years, considerable investments have been made in the quality of the (main) roads in Turkey. Many roads that were dangerous early on because they were fast and busy have now become 2 x 2 lanes, often even with separate lanes. Perhaps less beautiful to cycle on, but certainly a lot safer than before!
  • The roads are reasonable to good, but the composition and quality of the asphalt are not always taken very seriously. After some time, slippery tar lanes are formed which can be dangerous in the molten state due to heavy traffic. Also watch out for slipperiness during rain.
  • Turkey is mountainous, with gradients of 8-10% here and there.
  • The smaller roads are often unpaved, sometimes bad but extremely quiet and pleasant. The road surface is rough, you bump all day long. Wider tires for comfort is recommended.
  • You can cycle on many highways, which are very quiet outside the big cities and tourist places. Not across Istanbul's Bosphorus bridges.
  • In 2015 indeed cycled a lot on highways (in central and eastern Turkey), very quiet and pleasant. It is also handy that during the Ramazan you could get food at most gas stations during the day.

1bf685e1-886f-4407-a519-9de322b12e33.description: A natural wonder with fairy chimneys and houses carved into the rocks. Every morning, hundreds of hot air balloons take over the skies. We've never been here, but seen many pictures from people wildcamping near the rock formations.
1bf685e1-886f-4407-a519-9de322b12e33.title: Cappadocia

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: • You are easily invited to private individuals. Sometimes it starts with tea and all in all you continue to eat and sleep.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: • Campsites are mainly on the coast but sometimes more expensive than a room. There are hardly any campsites outside the coastal region and they also have few facilities. They are even closed early in the season. Along the Black Sea they are often situated on the beach, a different experience. Especially in the east you have to look for a protected place. The negative experiences were mainly heard in the area around Erzurum.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
• In Istanbul, the "Yucelt" youth hostel is the cheapest accommodation option and if you don't mind muezzins very nice. There are several close together (whether or not officially under the banner of Youth-hosting international) not far from the Aya Sofia. You have a great view over the Bosphorus from the roof terraces. The bicycle can usually be taken, or taken to the room, or in a basement or similar Other hotels are also abundant from cheap to expensive.
  • Cheap hotels can be found everywhere. Every village or town with more than 20,000 people has a hotel. Inland, the distances between them are often 100 km or more. In the north and east, the hotels are not always clean. Bringing your own sheet bag is advisable. A hotel does not always have a shower, but the hammam offers a solution. There is always a safe place for the bicycle.
  • Spending the night in teachers' houses is possible, provided there is room. A list of teachers' houses (Öğretmenevi) by municipality / province can be found online (please provide website).
  • In central and eastern Turkey there are sections where the ögretmenevi are the only option. Fortunately, you can always find one within a day's distance (approx. 80 km). (you can find them via google).
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
• Wild camping is officially prohibited, but is generally tolerated. It is good to stay at lakes and rivers. There is a lot of picnic on the weekends. You can also camp with private individuals and sometimes in the garden of a hotel or at a petrol station. However, making inquiries with policy / poor or other government officials does not pose any problems; usually you are even shown a nice place.
  • Tom: "Wild camping is no problem, but don't do it in a village, otherwise you will have the whole village at your tent." Dorenda: "That can also have advantages, such as being invited by someone for breakfast in the morning."
  • If you feel unsafe (eastern Turkey) camping at a gas station is a very good option. Almost all of them have a restaurant and a shop. Noisy but safe and quite luxurious.

Transport.body_airplane:
• Several (low budget) airlines fly to Turkey. Ask for the conditions for bicycle transport. Interesting low-cost carriers include Corendon (www.corendon.com), Komfly (www.komfly.com), Air Berlin (www.airberlin.com), Transavia and Pegasus (the latter two allow you to reserve the bike online, simultaneously with booking your flight ticket).
  • The renowned airlines also fly to Turkey. Prices for a single journey are relatively affordable at [www.turkishairlines.com/ Turkish Airlines].
Transport.body_boat:
• Boat connections to Italy can be found at www.cemar.it/ferries/1_ferries.html.
  • Ferry services with Greece run between Samos and Kuşadası, Kos and Bodrum, Cesme and Chios and between Rhodes and Marmaris. There are no direct ferry connections to Athens. You always have to transfer to one of the islands.
  • Several ferry services run directly to the center of Istanbul. It's a great way to avoid Istanbul's traffic chaos. (Even from Izmir (10 pm)) Or you have to cycle through a city with 15 million inhabitants.
Transport.body_bus: Buses are often really good, with frequent stops for breaks. A bus comes to almost every town, and several buses leave daily from the larger towns to Istanbul.
Transport.body_train: Trains are not recommended. Few of them drive and if they do, they are very slow.

Visa.body:
Since 2014 it has been possible (and recommended) to buy your visa in advance via the internet. In the long term it is the intention that this is the only way to get a visa. Costs $ 20 per person, payable by Mastercard / VISA. See the official e-Visa website. Passport must be valid for at least 6 months at the time of entering Turkey.

You can buy a visa upon arrival at any border post and airport in Turkey. You buy it at the visa desk, before passport control. Costs € 15 (or 20 USD) per person, to be paid in cash with euros. It is possible to withdraw euros in front of the visa desk at both airports in Istanbul.

The visa is valid for a maximum of 90 days within a period of 180 days. You may travel in and out several times (multiple entry). Your passport or identity card must be valid for at least three months after your planned departure from Turkey. 

Source: Wikipedia

FoodDrink.body:
The Turkmen cuisine is rich and fat according to the Russian cuisine with an influence of the Middle East, so kebab and shashlik.

Supermarkets
Shops can be found everywhere in larger villages. If you go into the desert, it is smart to make sure you have a supply of food.

Stalls on the street
Restaurants can be found everywhere. Good food, but a bit too expensive in the desert. There are regular stalls along the way selling fizzy lemonade with syrup: 'gazly suv'. Dirt cheap, very sweet but good for thirst.

Drinkable water
Take enough water with you, and sometimes it is indeed (as the locals say) better to rest during the afternoon heat. Cycling here in the middle of summer is not recommended.

ALWAYS filter water, even if it comes in a bottle. A lot of water comes directly from the canal and some wells are contaminated.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Eelco: "I cycled in the spring and that was nice. Many desert areas (with the exception of the strip along the mountains in the south and the river in the north), so presumably a ditto climate. So very hot in the summer."

Marc: "We cycled through Turkmenistan in July 2007 and it was very hot, up to 50C. A siesta between 12:00 and 15:00 is then a must."

Nice routes
Eelco: "I cycled the route Ashgabat - Mary - Merv - Turkmenabat. Ashgabat is crazy, a city built by the president full of all kinds of kitsch, parks and statues just to satisfy his delusions of grandeur and self-aggrandizement. I think it's one of the biggest sights in the country. Merv was disappointing, but the gas craters north of Ashgabat could be interesting. Turkmenabat is a nice town where you can't spend your money in the wonderful bazaar."

Safety.body:
At the moment the whole of Turkmenistan is easily accessible and no traveler mentions a problem.

Eelco: "The police can sometimes be authoritarian, especially if you are not used to them yet. Most of them are shorts, and you can ignore them. Always only talk to the one with the most stars and ignore the rest. Provide a number of copies of your passport on which your personal details and your visa are visible."

d5abfaf1-a5ae-4460-9459-cc7b663a4368.description: In the middle of a huge desert, there is a burning crater with a diameter of 70 m. There are a few legends about the cause of this sight. It is truly one of the most epic and also non-touristic places I've ever seen and when you cross Turkmenistan, it's definitely wordt to visit, although the road towards this place is very long, kind of dangerous with a lot of potholes and there are no villages.
d5abfaf1-a5ae-4460-9459-cc7b663a4368.title: Darvaza gas crater

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Sometimes you get invited by locals. This is a nice way to see the local life.
Sleeping.body_hostels: The major cities have a hotel.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping is not a problem in most cases.

Visa.body:
Some Asian nationalities can enter Turkmenistan without visa. Most other nationalitites need to apply for a visa.

  Turkmenistan
  Visa-free for holders of diplomatic and service category passports
  Visa-free for holders of diplomatic passports
  Visa on arrival for holders of diplomatic passports
Source: Wikipedia.

c726f1e3-3d42-46ed-a1a6-3506d2ccf261.description:
We don't have experience with getting this visa. Please share yours if you have recent experience.

East African Tourist Visa is also available, which allows you to travel to Kenya, Rwanda and Uganda with a single visa. The visa expires if you travel outside of one these countries.

FoodDrink.body:
The food is not particularly interesting. Lots of Matoke (cooked bananas) which are particularly heavy on the stomach. It is nutritious and you can cycle well on it. For a few euros you are full.

If you cook yourself, get a petrol burner, not the cheapest to buy, but you will enjoy it for years. Camping gas burners and related products are of no use in Uganda.

Bottled drinking water is available everywhere.

Health.body:
• Yellow fever vaccination is recommended and sometimes required.
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs all year round.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
June, just after the rainy season. The humidity then still hangs in the wooded area. The temperature is manageable (about 26 degrees). In the higher areas (mountains) it is usually cooler.

The temperature is quite stable throughout the year - according to the graphs it is about 25 degrees on average every month. In Uganda, the temperature rarely drops below 15 degrees, and rarely goes above 30/35.

Spare parts
In Uganda there is quite a lot of cycling, especially on decent, classic-looking bicycles (28 inches) of Chinese manufacture (for transporting jobs, pineapples, crates, firewood, etc.). There is therefore a bicycle repair shop in every village, who often has a stock of tires, spokes, rims, etc. In Kampala, some mountain bike-style bicycles (26 inch) are also sold; You may also be able to find some parts there. Assume that western bicycle parts cannot be found.

There is also no knowledge about western bicycles. Keep in mind that if you are unable to repair and want to cycle through Uganda, you may face problems. Follow a bicycle repair course in advance with the Wereldfietser or Vakantiefetser, which is also fun.

People.body: The population is generally very hospitable, but certainly not intrusive. In the problem areas, the atmosphere will probably be different.

Safety.body:
Note from Cycle Planet: The below information might be outdated. Please confirm, adjust or delete the information when you have more recent information.

Rebel movements are active in the north of the country. They carry out attacks on the civilian population. There is an ethnic conflict in the northeast of the Karamoja and in the Katakwi district.

The border area with Congo, the mountainous west, is currently secured by the government army, including the Ruwenzori Mountains and the Bwindi National Park. An exception is the district of Nebbi.

The wildlife population has increased significantly in recent years. Especially near the NPs you can encounter wild animals (elephants, buffalo etc.).

The tsetse fly occurs in a number of areas; looking out!

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: There are many 'community-based projects' in Uganda, with or without the involvement of Western organizations. Think of schools, hospitals and orphanages, regularly supplemented with a cottage where tourists can spend the night.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Camping is almost exclusively done in the game parks.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In the large towns and wildlife parks, accommodations are geared towards Western tourists. In small towns and villages (certainly on the asphalt roads, but also along the 'dirt roads') there are small guesthouses/hotels, which are mainly used by the Ugandan population themselves. You will not find these addresses in the travel guides. A hot meal (local food) can often be arranged for you. The bicycle can usually be parked in the room or elsewhere inside.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Cooking fuel
In kiev, gas bottles with a screw valve are for sale, at least at a fishing and outdoor sports shop in the market at the petrivka metro station.

Supermarkets
In every town there is a 'magazyn' or 'produkty' where, in addition to many bottles of alcohol, cheese, bread, sausage, macaroni, biscuits, bottles of water and soft drinks are also available, also in the evenings and at weekends. Low prices. Note the expiration date. Sometimes items, even dairy, that are more than a year past their expiration date are simply sold.

Blanche : "Even in tiny villages they prepare (frozen) pasta and a salad for you. We only cooked ourselves once."

Stalls on the street
In small villages you can buy fresh products directly from the farmer. Fruit and vegetables are often offered on the side of the road. There are stalls all over the street.

Restaurants
Restaurants/cafés in villages are sometimes extensive, but sometimes they don't have much more than a drink. The offer consists of borsch (beet soup), various potato dishes, but mainly boiled or mashed potatoes, cutlets and schnitzels, and many cabbage dishes. The ukrainians love surimi (fake crab) sticks and often turn them into a tasty salad.

Vegetarians: they've never heard of that... They do have mushrooms and cheese, but you have to speak ukrainian well to explain what you want.

Tom: "We found out that food is not only available in a 'restoran' but also in a 'kafe'. In the larger towns, the cafe menus were very extensive. Ukrainians are real salad eaters, some menus had three pages of salads alone. By salad, however, they mean everything, including cold pasta and meat."

Drinkable water
Better not to drink tap water. Water in 1, 1½ or 2 liter bottles is available everywhere for little money. In the west, there are often wells along the road near houses. Many copies are neatly clean and have a shelter and a hatch to prevent pollution. In the carpathians you see here and there with signs indicated drinking water sources along the road.

Wilbert: "In many villages in the west there are still wells along the road. I drank it without any problems. But I don't know if it is reliable. In the south and in crimea I often drank tap water. Also without any problems, but I don't know if it's reliable either."

Other.body:
Best time to cycle 
Ukraine has a continental climate with warm summers and cold winters. If you have problems with these extremes, spring and autumn are pleasant periods.

Blanche : "We were there in the summer. It is then hot but certainly doable. The temperature often goes in waves, after a few warm days it rains and the weather cools down nicely. Especially in the evening the temperature drops pleasantly."

Spare parts
It is best to bring parts yourself, it is difficult to get them. In the big cities they have racing bikes and 28-inch tires. Please note that most Ukrainian tires have a different valve. A spare bicycle pump can be useful. They can repair a lot in garages.

Nice routes
The most beautiful cycling regions are the Crimea and the Carpathians. Crimea has so much to offer you that you can spend a few visits. Central Ukraine is also beautiful with its vast fields of wheat and sunflowers.

Tom: "If you like wide panoramas, Western Ukraine is recommended. At least if you are not cycling on a road with a 10-meter-wide strip of forest on both sides."

John: "The main roads in Crimea are quite busy. Take the secondary roads; they are much more beautiful in terms of nature, villages and an oasis of peace; they can be quite steep."

People.body:
In the beginning people are a bit hesitant, but as soon as they realize that you are a good person, they go wild.

Robin: "After Poland, where people are a bit stiff, this was a relief! Many people ask what you do and where you come from, but they are certainly not pushy. Very helpful, smiley (nice if you sometimes don't understand each other)."

Hans: "I met many nice and interested people. In the train I was sometimes helped with the bike while there was not really room for it."

Safety.body:
Ukraine is a safe country. Cycling alone (also as a woman) is no problem. 

Robin: "People always say that there would be so many bandits, even in the country itself, but we only found treasures."
Safety.body_nature: There are stray dogs that may bark at you to guard their territory. Never really bothered.
Safety.body_traffic: In general there is little traffic. Only the main roads between major cities are busy. Despite the bad condition of the roads, people drive fast and recklessly but around you. There are many drivers who drive with a drink. This group increases as the evening progresses. Motorists sometimes give you little space. The hard shoulder often offers you a safe haven. In urban areas, you have to be wary of bus stops. If someone stops a minibus, it can suddenly deviate from its line.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Lodging is also possible with private persons. If you spend the night here, they will usually cook for you. Then take care of small souvenirs.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: The very few campsites that exist can be found mainly on the Black Sea coast. Without a problem you can ask people if you can put up your tent in their yard or garden. After some surprise you soon get good contact and cups of tea (or vodka...).
Sleeping.body_hostels: Hotels can be found in almost every small and larger city. With daily distances of at least 70 km, this is no problem.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Free camping is possible. Many grasslands are not fenced and are grazed very extensively. Herds pass over it under the supervision of shepherds or farmers, storks search for food. In Kiev you can camp on the island in the middle of the river. During the European Championship 2012, this was used as a camping site.

Ivo: "Just leave the road and hide yourself behind some trees. Farmers won't be surprised to see you in the morning."

Transport.body_bus: You can often take your bicycle with you on the long-distance bus. You do have to pay for being overweight. City and minibuses generally do not accept bicycles. On medium distances you depend on the type of bus and the mood of the driver.
Transport.body_train: Hans: "In the long-distance trains there is an informal smoking area in the back of the car where I put the bicycle, often upright with a cable lock on a rod. Sometimes you have to pass a suspicious conductor first. I don't understand a word of Russian, I look friendly, turn the steering wheel a quarter turn, take the pedals off and throw the bags inside. I always succeeded."

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Ukraine  without a visa for up to 90 days. Some other nationalities need to obtain an e-visa or a normal visa.


Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Marco and Lisette did not find the UAE as interesting in terms of food as the countries in the area. “There are far fewer open food stalls or local small restaurants. But you certainly won't starve.'

Supermarkets
In the supermarkets, which you can find in many places in the shopping malls, you can buy everything. Even many Dutch products. The die-hards who really can't live without spaghetti with tomato sauce won't starve. It is astonishing that in a country that largely consists of desert, there is a fair amount of fruit for sale.

Restaurants
Fast food can be found in every medium and large town. From unknown local brands to the well-known chains. You will also find regular restaurants there. In the souks you can eat what the locals eat. Often that is Indian oriented but also a lot of lamb.

Drinkable water
No information yet.

Health.body:
Common Diseases
The health level is at a very high level and can be compared with Europe. Malaria occurs all year round.

Mandatory vaccinations
  • Useful vaccinations for cyclists
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended as well as protection against Hepatitis A. Typhoid fever vaccination is recommended when traveling longer than 2 weeks.
  • Useful things in the travel pharmacy

Availability hospitals / doctors
In almost every place you will find a pharmacy where many western medicines are in stock. Medicines that you only get on prescription in the Netherlands can also be obtained here without further hassle. The level of knowledge about the medicines appears to be at a high level.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Marco and Lisette: "During the day it is around 25 degrees in the desert, but at night it can get a lot colder. In the mountains the temperature is around 15 degrees during the day. not very warm in the winter and you certainly have a good sleeping bag, sweater, fleece, and so on during a hike."

Spare parts
No information yet.

Tips
  • As far as the clothing is concerned, you have to realize that you are a guest in an Islamic country, so no uncovered shoulders or knees. On the beach, however, these dress codes are less strict.
  • In almost all Carefour supermarkets you can buy outdoor sports equipment such as tents, sleeping bags, mats, flashlights, GPS receivers, etc. The quality is average but sufficient to survive in the UAE.

People.body:
The original inhabitants are Arabs, but today the majority consists of Indians who have come to work there.

Arabic is the official language. Traffic signs, signage and menus are often also written in English. Almost everyone also speaks English.

Safety.body: The security is very high. The laws are strict and crime is low.

Sleeping.body_hostels: The hotel business in the UAE is booming. But this is generally only in (tourist) cities. In other cities they are there, but much less than, for example, in the other countries of the Middle East.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter the United Arab Emirates without a visa.

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: The United Kingdom is made up of 4 different territories that originate from the countries united in the kingdom (England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland). In all countries the official language is English. Welsh is also spoken in Wales and in some other areas.

FoodDrink.body:
Almost every reasonable village has a shop and a slightly larger village has a supermarket that is usually open until 7 am. Larger supermarkets are open 7 days from 9 to 9

In Scotland, you can get typical dishes such as haggis and black and white pudding in the supermarket.

Restaurants
Pub meals are cheap, very variable in quality (be surprised!), but a guaranteed cozy atmosphere. Almost everywhere there is at least 1 vegetarian dish on the menu, even in pubs.

Drinkable water
Water is available everywhere, even in the lonely highlands. There is always a house, farm or shop to be found there.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Summer is perfect for cycling. There are, however, more tourists in some places, but also a more pleasant temperature. May and June are the best months for Scotland, when it is driest and the number of midges is smaller than in July and August.

Spare parts
Specific gear for a randonneur with 28 inch wheels is harder to find. The range is mostly limited to ATB stuff. There are plenty of bicycle shops, especially in the big cities. 

Nice routes
  • The non-profit organization Sustrans maintains a "national cycle network" (NCN) of signposted cycling routes. There are now 12,000 miles signposted. See also http://www.sustrans.org where you can order guides and maps and plan your route.
  • Of the Sustrans routes, the Coast to Coast (C2C) route in Northern England is the best known. There are different variants of the C2C process.
