As a result, you can cycle the C2C completely with a regular trekking bike, but there are also off-road sections for those who travel with a mountain bike. Whichever variant you choose: it is a beautiful route. Tradition has it that you start with your rear wheel in the Irish Sea and end with your front wheel in the North Sea! There is a place for this at both the start and the finish. A composite map of the Coast to Coast with all information in a plastic sleeve has been issued. The map also shows the alternative off-road sections.

People.body:
The population is correct, reserved, but also cordial. Etiquette is important, and saying a lot of please & thank you works wonders. However, the Scots are stiff, sometimes helpful, but often not at all.

Scots are very laid back, if you take the time with them! and always up for a chat. There is no response to cyclists. On the Isle of Sky, the people are helpful with a good dose of humor. You are greeted extensively, cars are pulled over.

Safety.body:
It's generally a safe country for cycling. 

Battle in Northern Ireland: In Northern Ireland you are regularly confronted with the consequences of 25 years of political struggle between Catholics and Protestants: checkpoints, closed streets in high-risk cities like Cookstown, graffiti in major cities on this subject, sometimes separate shops for both parties , etc. Especially around the 12th of July (Protestant holiday), the tension rises and patrols become clearly visible in the streets.
Safety.body_nature: In the west of Scotland and in Wales, be aware of midges. These are tiny, highly irritating gadflies that appear in swarms in dry and windless weather. Usually early in the morning and towards dusk. It helps to find a (camping) spot with a dry surface and to catch as much wind as possible. Anti-mosquito stuff works a bit, covering yourself better.
Safety.body_traffic:
Driving is on the left. Be alert in the cities: at traffic lights, cars are parked close to the curb so that it is difficult for cyclists to pass; left-turning cars cut off cyclists; cars entering from the left often do not give way to cyclists (if the cyclist is driving on the priority road); clearly indicate what you intend to do (hold out your hand left/right).

On small roads it is very quiet and good road surface, but the more through roads can be busy. The motorists are not very used to cyclists: They drive fast.

On small roads, most motorists continue to drive behind a cyclist until they can really safely pass them - but the devil is in the single car that does speed past you and forces you into the verge.

In rainy and foggy weather, it may be advisable to wear a reflective vest and because the weather can change very quickly, my advice is: just wear such a vest all the time. Brits often wear reflective clothing in all weather conditions. In the dark, cyclists hang themselves with several lights. Officially flashing lights are not allowed on the bicycle, but they are allowed if you wear them on your body.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: Plenty of camp sites with charges anywhere between £10 to £20 per night
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Not legal unless you ask the Land owner.

Transport.body_boat: The ferries on the west coast, including the Western Isles, Scotland are largely owned by Caledonian MacBrayne. The bicycle facilities are generally good. There is no need to pay for the bicycle. You only pay as a passenger. There are few or no catering options on the short routes, while food is also available on the longer routes (hot and cold).
Transport.body_train:
The UK has no fewer than 28 different railway companies, each with its own rules for taking bicycles on the train.

It is possible that the bicycle has to be put in a separate carriage, which is not accessible during the journey and closes 10-15 minutes before the train leaves. Keep this in mind and arrive on time. Before the car is closed, you also have to attach your bike and get back in another car.

Visa.body:
England is part of the United Kingdom and makes use of their visa policy. There are quite some nationalities that need to have a visa to enter England.

Visa policy of the United Kingdom
  United Kingdom
  Freedom of movement / Common Travel Area
  Visa-free entry for 6 months, subject to UK Visitor Rules (no UK jobs market work, no recourse to public funds)
  Electronic visa waiver countries
  Visa required for entry, and landside transit (unless holding exemption documents); visa-free airside transit
  Visa required for entry, and both landside and airside transit (unless holding exemption documents)

Source: Wikipedia.

About.body: Cycling in the USA is a dream for many,. Choose between the famous pacific coast highway 101, the Great divide mountain bike route or a coast to coast route of 5000 km. You'll find deserts, mountains, temperate rainforest, dramatic coastlines, metropolises, endless roads and agricultural fields.

FoodDrink.body:
There is plenty of food available everywhere. Fresh fruit and vegetables, however, is very difficult, especially in sparsely populated areas. Gas stations and supermarkets in sparsely populated areas or along highways usually only have convenience food in their range.

Cooking fuel
The blue camping gas is unknown. They do have butane-propane canisters. Burner fuel is called white gas/white fuel or coleman fuel.

Bottle almost empty? ask someone who is mowing the lawn for some fuel (because jerry can). with a bit of luck you can also eat or sleep there.

Paul & Yvette: "We filled up our bottles at gas stations. They are not used to it, takes into account questions. For 20-30 cents you can cook for a week."

Supermarkets
The large supermarkets have a lot to offer. Try not to get lost :)

Paul & Yvette; "If you travel for a longer period of time in the country, it is useful to ask for a free membership card at the large supermarkets, this will give you nice discounts on the final amount."

Stalls on the street
Very good and cheap. Are subject to a license and therefore subject to the Commodities Actwet.

Restaurants
Restaurants are good and cheap, but not always pleasant. The portions are usually large. The service is often very fast; the bill comes pretty fast too. However, that is not meant to get you out the door!! Americans just don't usually eat out to dine for over an hour.

Eating vegetarian food in restaurants can be tricky. Especially in neighborhoods around universities a wide variety of restaurants with food from all over the world, vegetarian is also no problem here.

TIPS. gratuities are standard in the restaurant industry. Europeans are notorious for their bad tips.

a white-collar worker earns a fixed wage of about $500 a month (well below minimum wage!!) and the rest must be earned through tips. so just tip, guideline is 15-20%. a bad service does not always have to be the servant! in this case, tip 10-15% and leave 1 cent or 5 cents on the table. 

No tipping required: starbucks, McD and other fast food chains, gas stations and their snack bars, chipotle, chickfilla, subway/quiznos and takeaway counters. 

Do give tips: everything with service such as coffee / sandwich shops, pizza hut, dennys, arbys, applebees, steak house, sushi, chinese etc.

In Alaska it is advisable to bring food for 3 to 4 days, sometimes even for more days. Gas stations and lodges have food for sale (it is expensive there though). Distances between them vary between 80 and 150 km.

Drinkable water
Tap water is usually reliable, in large cities and desert areas it is chlorinated. Bottled drinking water is also readily available in less populated areas. In Alaska you have to filter the water beforehand. And often take water with you for 1 to 2 days.

Health.body: Make sure to get a comprehensive health insurance. medical expenses are very high in the usa. If you need urgent care, do not go to the ER (emergency room) but to an urgent care center. this because of the cost!

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The weather is most pleasant in spring and autumn, especially in the south. In autumn the forest areas are very beautiful.

Tip: in May - July it is best to cycle from east to west. If you cycle from west to east, some passes in the Rocky Mountains are closed until June because they are not yet free of snow. You can find more information about this on the forum.

Spare parts
There are many bike shops: every decent town has one. Only the distance between 2 bicycle repair shops is sometimes more than 300 km! Most bike shops have 26 inches in stock. 28" is usually found in cities.

if you need parts in the middle of nowhere, you can order them online and have them delivered or forwarded by UPS. UPS and Fedex also have stores where you can have your order delivered and picked up later. consult with the shop concerned first; sometimes $5 is charged for storage, etc.

There are only a few bike shops in Alaska, especially in the larger cities. This is not a problem for most materials.

Given the great distances and the few places in the Midwest, take spare spokes, tires and cables and of course tools.

Nice routes
  • Adventure Cycling has many routes throughout the US. The great advantage of these routes is that they use quiet, safer roads. They publish maps on a bicycle-friendly scale over the entire route. See https://www.adventurecycling.org/routes-and-maps/
  • The Crest Highway (Road 2) from Hollywood through the Gabrielle Mountains is beautiful, but tough to cycle. climb up to 3000 meters altitude.

People.body:
People in the countryside quickly invite you to come and eat and/or stay overnight, especially if you are alone. In Alaska the people are very hospitable, friendly and helpful. They think cyclists are brave, sporty or crazy. They like to chat.

Bouke: "In the ten weeks that we cycled in the south, we met a lot of hospitality. We were spontaneously invited several times to come and have dinner or to stay. Not only in the countryside, but also, for example, near Washington. We soon decided gratefully accept all offers, unless they were obviously dubious in nature (which we haven't experienced!)."

Safety.body: The US is a safe country, especially outside the cities.
Safety.body_nature:
Due to bears, keep any food far from your tent. In National and state parks without a bear box you are required to bring a piece of rope to hang food in a tree. Pepper spray against bears; dogs and whatnot is legally available and often available at gunshops and outdoor stores. 

Be careful with cactus needles in Colorado: they are very sharp and your tire gets punctured fast..
Safety.body_traffic:
American cyclists (and also foreigners after a few weeks of cycling) will tell you without exception that so-called RVs (motorhomes of all shapes and sizes) are the greatest danger for cyclists. Then come trucks.

You increase your safety with a helmet, rear-view mirror, and a warning triangle on the back. A fluorescent flag on the left side of your rear bag helps to keep motorized traffic at a distance.

Bouke: "We have rarely felt unsafe in traffic. We did drive consistently with a striking orange 'road workers' vest. And of course always wear our helmet; Americans can't imagine driving without it.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
It is also possible to stay overnight at private homes. For example, in New York you can sleep at people's homes through the Servas organization.

Bouke: "If you want to get in touch with American hospitality, you should become a member of Warmshowers.org, the organization of long-distance cyclists who offer each other free accommodation and a hot shower..."

Paul: "Warmshowers.org has a very large and extensive network in America, so we regularly had a free place to sleep, shower and sometimes dinner at nice people's homes. Especially in the big cities you can stay several nights more often."

John: "Sometimes you can pitch your tent in people's gardens. Just ring the bell!"
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
Raccoons are very adept at opening the food bag or stealing your shoes. secure such items or in the vestibule. ground squirrels (chipmunks) are great at gnawing through your ortliebs if they know they have food in them. Sometimes bear vaults are present. Take advantage of this!

The biker/hiker campgrounds (6-12 dollars p.p.) in the state and national parks are almost never full and usually cheap. You regularly meet cyclists who do the same route and that is nice and cozy. Unfortunately, they are often closed until May. Sometimes there is no shower, but there is toilet and water. In the states of California, Oregon, and Washington, there are many state campgrounds with hiker-biker sites, many with showers.

Camping on state campsites (primitive) ± 10 $ per day. There is one every 60-70 km. KOA Private Campgrounds: These are more expensive, busier, and duller but have more amenities such as unlimited clean showers, WiFi, washers and dryers; and sometimes a swimming pool. a pool KOA is easily $25; without $15.

In Alaska, the campgrounds are about 80 to 150 km apart.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
There are not too expensive motels in the towns. In every motel it is very common to take your bike to the room. always ask.

John: "Hotels and motels are everywhere, especially in the ugly business areas around cities (look for the exit of a highway and you will find them in bushes, surrounded by restaurants of all chains). In the centers of small towns you will find a hotel much less often; they are often nicer but also more expensive. Hotels and motels are also much cheaper than in Europe (especially with a favorable dollar-euro exchange rate) and in our experience with almost always good beds; in any case, the gap between camping and hotel prices in the US is much smaller than in Europe."
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
In most states it is (officially) not allowed. An exception is Alaska, where it is quite possible if there is water nearby. Wild camping along the border with Mexico can be dangerous because illegal immigrants cross at night with the help of people smugglers. Inquire with the border patrol about the local security situation.

In the national parks you can wild camp along the road with an easily available 'backcountry permit'. Usually 30m off the road.

Karin: "It is allowed in all National Forest and almost all BLM land. We have used it at least 100 times."

Paul: "In some states (Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Utah) on our route there was a lot of BLM land, public land and National Forest, where you can camp wild. In bear territory it is important to make a good 'bearhang' when camping in the wild, but also for racoons. At most campsites there are special 'bearlockers' in the bear/racoon area.

Transport.body_airplane: Taking the bicycle with you differs per company. Always wise to inquire about the conditions when booking. In the so-called bushplanes within Alaska, the bicycle (without packaging) is allowed for free.
Transport.body_boat: On ferries you are the first to board and first off by bike.
Transport.body_bus:
You can take your bike on Greyhound buses. Your bicycle must be in a bicycle box, which is not always available. If available, you pay 10-20 dollars per box.

In cities, your bike goes on the rack at the front of the bus or simply on the tram or metro for free. You have to put the bike on the rack yourself, you can ask the driver for instructions, but often bystanders are willing to help.

To and from many airports there are airport shuttles (taxi vans) that can take you a long way for about $ 20 (eg Las Vegas -> St George and Flagstaff -> Phoenix).
Transport.body_train:
Bringing your bike is possible on some Amtrak routes. Make a reservation and arrange early in advance.

Your bicycle can be taken on the metro of major cities without payment.. handy because the distances are very long; the traffic is busy and the metro is cheap. Note that the word 'metro' often also means metropolis in cities.

Visa.body:
Only Canadians and citizens of a few small islands can enter the U.S.A. without a visa. A few countries can apply for the Visa Waiver Program. Other countries need to apply for a standard visa.

We've heard rumours that you can't enter the U.S.A. if you've been to Iran before. Perhaps this is only the case when the stamp of Iran is still in your passport. Please verify this information if you have experience with this situation.

  The United States and its territories
  Visa-free countries
  Visa Waiver Program countries
  Visa required for entry to the United States
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Uruguay is a great cycling country. Flat to rolling with an occasional nice climb, but relatively much wind. If you want to visit the Iguazu Falls on the Argentina-Brazil border, Uruguay is an ideal start or end point for a cycling trip through South America.

Uruguay is a rich country, but in the countryside it seems as if time has stood still for 30 years. This gives a special atmosphere and the cities in the interior are old-timer paradises, cars from 30 to 60 years old are very common.

FoodDrink.body:
What you should definitely try is the mate (herbal tea). In Uruguay you can't ignore it because everyone walks with a calabash and thermos flask under their arm.

Supermarkets
Food is readily available but not cheap. In every town/village there are one or more shops (sometimes a supermarket). Note the quite varying prices between the different products. Small supermarkets are quite expensive.

Restaurants
There are plenty of affordable restaurants. The quality is good. You often have enough choice between poor to very luxurious. The tv is always on in restaurants. There are also striking international restaurants such as pizzeria, tapas and chinese restaurants.

Just like in argentina, a lot of meat is eaten from the grill (parrilladas), you can indicate what you want, there is also organ meat in between. Milanesa is a schnitzel.

Vegetarian food is not widely available in restaurants. Usually not more like a salad and boiled vegetables with rice/chips. Try the dulce de leche (caramel-like) on your bread.

Drink
Tap water is drinkable. You will find many fresh fruit juices: the jugos.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Summer (December - March) is the best cycling period. In winter (June - September) the temperature is low (10-15 degrees) and there is a risk of prolonged rain with flooding and the associated impassability of secondary roads and bridges as a result.

Spare parts
26” is the local tire size. 28” is also available to a lesser extent. Shimano parts are available, but not everywhere, again in the larger (main) cities. 

Always bring your own inner tube and extra foldable outer tube! Before you travel in South America and therefore also Uruguay, make sure you have a steel front carrier, which you can have again if it breaks. Front carriers are almost impossible to buy in South America, unless you have one made!

Good waterproof panniers are also essential.

Nice routes
Highlights are the south coast (Colonia/Montevideo and Punta del Este) and the Termen between Paysandu and Bella Union. Furthermore, the country has few highlights, whether cultural, architectural or natural.

Christel and Robin: "We cycled north from Montevideo on the national highway 5. Via Canelones, Florida, Sarandi Grande to Durazno. From here west to Trinidad and then on the national highway 3 via Young to Paysandu (this is close to Argentina.) Then further north to Brazil via Salto and Bella Union. A total of 693 km in 11 cycling days. We did not find the route that we cycled very interesting. That is probably also due to the cold and many rain/wind."

Along the boulevard in Montevideo is a signposted bicycle route.

People.body: The population is curious, hospitable and helpful. You are usually not immediately invited for a tea, a meal or an overnight stay, only after a short introduction when the ice has been broken. If you "invite" yourself it is usually not a problem.

Safety.body:
Uruguay is a safe country. Of course, like anywhere in the world, you have to be careful around major cities. Uruguay is politically stable. Only on the border with Argentina in the west there are sometimes border problems with regard to logging and pollution of the river. However, more mutual blackmail on paper instead of action on the street.

A helmet is not required.
Safety.body_nature: Dogs are not particularly troublesome. Of course every house has a watchdog.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws:
Not all individuals are waiting for unexpected guests, especially if you don't speak the language. If you do, however, you can explain the situation much better and arranging a place to sleep is not that difficult. If you want to sleep on a low budget (read for free), you will have to regularly have a conversation with the locals, then you will often be invited.

A spot for your tent en route in the countryside is quickly arranged (a piece of grass and some water). This will be more difficult in the cities.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping:
There are many campsites on the coast. In the rest of the country, almost every city has a municipal campsite, also a field with a playground in the middle of the city/village. Good to spend the night but not very ideal for leaving your tent unattended during the day.

The Ministerio de Turismo in Montevideo has a free booklet with campsites all over Uruguay. There are also relatively many picnic spots (with parrillada) along the way where camping is allowed. (This is a better option) We were in the winter (June) when the campsites were closed, it had also rained a lot and we were not able to camp much because of flooding.

Campinggaz is reasonably available, including at hardware stores (ferreterias) in the cities.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are cheap hotels in the cities. There is always a shed or garage for your bicycle. If not, ask if they can stay in the room.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: You can camp in the wild, although many of the main roads are fenced off. Furthermore, it is a very flat country, so not always good shelter to be out of sight. We do not know whether wild camping is also allowed by the Uruguayan government. You can always ask the local football club if you can pitch your tent on the field and if you can use the shower.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Uruguay without a visa.

Visa policy of Uruguay
  Uruguay
  Visa-free (Passport and ID card entry)
  Visa-free (Passport entry)
Source: Wikipedia.

About.body:
Uzbekistan is a great country to cycle at. You'll find lots of culture in this the former Silk Route country. There are a few beautiful cities with a unique style of architecture.

In Uzbekistan you are officially obliged to register or have yourself registered for every overnight stay. If you sleep in a hotel, this will be taken care of for you. When leaving the country, all nights must be complete. There is a high fine for unregistered tours. Fortunately, the practice turns out to be smoother. Missing a number of nights will probably not be a problem. There are several stories going around. One is that you have to make sure that you spend the first three nights in a hotel. Another story is that you can miss a maximum of three consecutive nights between the registered ones.

41358b35-c510-4824-9aad-1eeed8870977.description:
It takes 2-3 days to issue the visa. The e-visa has to be used within 90 days of sending the application. It should be possible to apply for multiple entry visa as well. Please add this visa if you have experience with it.

According to Caravanistan, the official website for applying for the e-visa is this website, however they also say it's full with bugs and payments may fail. Cycle Planet redirects to another website, which looks more stable and official, however, we haven't used this website ourselves yet. Please update this information if you have recent experience with applying for the evisa.

FoodDrink.body:
Typical dishes are plov (rice meal with fried strands of carrot, chickpeas and chunks of meat). And then of course there's shashlik...

John and gudy consider uzbekistan one of the most vegetarian-unfriendly countries: "Meat is really in everything!! We have also been served a lot of what we consider disgusting foods such as vertebrae, eyes and guts."

Stalls on the street
In the autumn during the fruit harvest, fruit is for sale everywhere on the edge of the mountains and also in the mountains. As a cyclist you often receive fruit as a gift. Take a bag of rice from the bazaar and cook all those fruits and you have a delicious breakfast or lunch. A good alternative for vegetarians.

There are small shops everywhere that sell everything. You will find barbecue stands all over the street. Shorpa is a kind of soup based on mutton fat, with meat, carrot and potato. Samsa are puff pastry triangles filled with onions and mutton or (if you're lucky) onions and chickpeas.

Bread is fantastic. Baked in a tandoor, it is thick and nourishing and not bland. At the bazaar you can buy the base of nougat in a cut pet bottle. Delicious as a sandwich spread.

Restaurants
Plenty of cheap restaurants but the quality is often hard to find. In every village you will find a chajchana, where you can eat and drink tea.

John and gudy: "If you have a bit of a firm stomach, you'll survive."

Drinkable water
In populated areas you can get bottled water everywhere. The water is of poor quality, except in the mountain areas. The water in the mountains is reliable. Only high in the mountains are no more streams. In the deserts, finding reliable water is difficult. Bottled water is hardly for sale there. It is better to drink tea in a chajchana.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The best cycling season is from March to May and from September to November. Then you have nice mild warm weather. However, early spring or late autumn can be very cold in the mountains and in the desert. At night it is cold, during the day around 20 to 25°C. In other seasons it is sweltering hot (40+ in summer) or quite cold (around 5 degrees in winter).

Spare parts
In cities you can find bicycle parts dealers on the market. Do not expect super parts, but tires, pedals, simple brakes, everything of dubious Chinese / Russian quality.

In Samarkand you will find three bicycle shops in the Penjikent street (Penjikent kuchasi).

Nice routes
In the south of Uzbekistan between Samarkand and Termiz it is pleasant to cycle, both on the main roads and the narrow roads. Every village has a grocer with all the necessities of life. There are no hotels. This part of the country is quite mountainous.

Tips
  • Because you are often invited, it is advisable to bring small gifts from your country of origin (postcards or photos of your house or of your family).
  • For men there are not so many clothing restrictions (maybe only in the really remote regions where it is better not to wear shorts). Women should dress conservatively.
  • Islam is not widely practiced in Uzbekistan. During Ramadan you can eat well everywhere during the day. Women can move around markets without being harassed by men. There is a nice relaxed atmosphere in markets.

People.body:
The population is very hospitable and very curious. You are quickly invited and they all want to know what you are doing, where you are from, what your name is, etc. And they ask how much your bike costs and if they can buy it. Better not go into that.

Besides Uzbek (a Turkish related language), everyone speaks Russian, a few speak English, German or even French. All designations are in Cyrillic.

Safety.body:
Uzbekistan is a police state! Everywhere, you come across agents (Militsia) in green, especially in the capital Tashkent. Everything and everyone is being watched. On the access roads to the cities and larger towns you will find various roadblocks. Normally, little attention is paid to a cyclist and you can pass without any problems. But be careful how you behave, if you completely ignore the agents then you run the risk of being called back and having to unpack all your bags. 

Staying friendly, shaking hands and telling about your trip prevents a lot of misery. Compared to the situation seems to have improved in the past. French travelers were told that their embassy provides letters that can be useful in the event of a police check. This states that the person concerned is under the protection of the embassy and is requested to leave him/her alone.

08cb6b03-84d7-4187-9714-a955a61a8c8c.description: Meaning "The Living King", this mausoleum is an impressive building that represents the lively Silk Road times.
08cb6b03-84d7-4187-9714-a955a61a8c8c.title: Shah-i-Zinda

ae2b266d-9d36-4b11-a701-47cc935eeaad.description: A huge square with 3 impressive madrasahs (former schools).
ae2b266d-9d36-4b11-a701-47cc935eeaad.title: Registan

b4b767d7-00ff-4ac9-a08d-016d0bba488c.description: One of the most beautiful places in Uzbekistan, the historic city of Khiva. There are dozens of great looking buildings here, bordered with a city wall. You might see lots of marrying couples passing by, as they all go to this city to approve their lucky times together.
b4b767d7-00ff-4ac9-a08d-016d0bba488c.title: Khiva old city

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: In smaller places you are often invited to stay the night. It is sometimes possible to spend the night in a school, sports building, etc.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are no campsites.
Sleeping.body_hostels: There are cheap hotels, but you have to know where to find them. For foreigners, the normal hotels are very expensive.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping:
Wild camping is no problem. In the desert areas, finding water is sometimes a problem. Bring your own water bags to fill them on the go. Moreover, finding a sheltered spot is difficult. In the mountains, on the other hand, that is no problem at all.

Camping is very difficult between Bukhara and Samarkand because of the many wet cotton fields and the villages.

Transport.body_airplane: The domestic connections are provided with Russian aircraft. You can take the bike with you, but sometimes you will have to pay extra.
Transport.body_bus: Buses are always very full and you also have to wait a long time. Taking the bike with you strongly depends on the driver. Rides are very cheap. Most public transport is done with the mini Deawoo Damas vans and there is absolutely no place for a bicycle.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Uzbekistan without a visa,, others must apply fot the e-visa, see the below figure.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Food
You can eat in restaurants along the way, but they can only be found in small towns. As you get closer to the coast there are more restaurants and food and drink stalls along the side of the road. Often there is also a roadhouse at a junction of major roads. If you take the daily menu you have a good meal to cycle on. The soup of the day with some bread is also recommended, salt and moisture at the same time. Personally I have had no problems with the food and drinks.

In Llanos and Gran Sabana you occasionally have to travel a greater distance to the next eating place (max. 80 km). In any case, take food with you for 1 day.

There are plenty of small kiosks where you can buy basic things. Vegetables and meat are hard to find.

Drink
Water is not reliable. Bottles are for sale in most cities. Buy enough water and food in the large places because in some parts there are hardly any stalls on the side of the road. This is especially the case inland. And if you run out of water at 30°C, that's unpleasant.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
On the coast, the dry season is from December to April the most pleasant time. The temperatures are then the most pleasant (around 25 - 30 °C). The rainy season runs from June to October. However, you do not have to experience real rainy days (where it rained all day), although you can often expect a heavy shower.

Inland the weather is fairly constant throughout the year. Temperatures around 25°C, and usually a high chance of rain. In September and October and from January to March it is somewhat drier.

Spare parts
Skilled bicycle repair shops and good parts are available in the cities. There are almost no bicycle workshops along the way. Make sure you bring some extra stuff with you. There are many car garages along the way.

Also bring extra inner tubes! People tend to drink both beer and soda in the car and then throw the bottles on the roadside. It therefore regularly happens that you are forced to drive through glass due to the traffic situation. The local tire size is 20 and 26 inches.

Nice routes
  • Between El Amparo de Apure and Mantanal are many caimans, reptiles, birds and game in the flat grassland.
  • Los Caracas to Higuerote is a beautiful piece of tropical forest with a Caribbean atmosphere.
  • From El Dorado to Sta. Elena is a beautiful route with first 80 km of tropical forest with newly established small farmers, climb through forest to Gran Sabana, high plateau with hilly grassland in a sparsely populated area with beautiful waterfalls.

People.body:
The people are friendly but not as open as in Asia. Cyclists are viewed strangely, but not approached aggressively.

Spanish is the official language and if you speak Spanish that is very useful. English isn't spoken much.

Safety.body: Venezuela is a safe country.
Safety.body_nature:
Dogs can sometimes chase you aggressively, but it's no worse than in other South American countries.

Due to the heat, it may be wise to cycle only in the morning and at the end of the afternoon.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: You can usually go to private individuals. If you ask, you can at least camp at their house.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are only campgrounds in national parks.
Sleeping.body_hostels: Staying overnight is not a problem, but not very cheap if you travel alone. In many cases, the bicycle can be taken with you in the room or stored separately.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: Wild camping possible on the beach and with farmers in the Llanos.

Visa.body:
Some nationalities can enter Venezuela without a visa for up to 90 days.


Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
The food is generally good and reliable. In Vietnam, as a rule, noodles + rice soup with meat and vegetables are eaten in the morning, the same in the afternoon, and rice or noodles in the evening with all kinds of vegetables and meat or fish.

In the mountains it is more difficult to get food and drink than elsewhere.

Vegetarian food (an chay) is especially known in the south. These eateries are often closed early and are somewhat out of the way. Ask in hotels and they often take you there. In addition to temples, good vegetarian food is often available around lunchtime. Lots of tofu of course and in many variations. The choice is not too large in ordinary eateries, but vegetarian food is not a problem throughout Vietnam.

Supermarkets
Supermarkets are a relatively new phenomenon in Vietnam, the number of supermarkets is increasing rapidly. It is often not allowed to take a bag into a supermarket. In that case, a guarded 'wardrobe' or a number of 'lockers' is available at the entrance of the supermarket.

Stalls on the street
Since the free market economy was introduced, you can now find food stalls everywhere along the road. In the markets and in the stalls you will mainly find vegetables, fruit, meat, fish, rice, noodles, sweets and cookies. Small sandwiches and baguettes are also readily available. Not all stalls sell tasty edibles (sometimes just some old, spoiled cookies).

Restaurants
Restaurants are available in all categories and price ranges, Vietnamese cook little themselves. For less than 100,000 dong you have a nutritious meal, including a beer, soft drink or fresh fruit juice. Especially in the cities there are also restaurants with foreign cuisine, Japanese, Indian, French, Thai, etc. You will also find 'fancy' restaurants in the cities, ie with air conditioning, with corresponding price level.

Drinkable water
Tap water is unreliable. Bottles of water can be found almost everywhere, the closure must be checked, sometimes used bottles are filled clandestinely with water of dubious origin. 

Dairy products can be found in supermarkets, both fresh and pasteurized. Drinks (also cola, fanta, 7-up) are available everywhere, even the smallest stall has a few bottles of liquid. The coffee is tasty - if you like very strong and very sweet, that is - (filter on the cup).

The men like to drink a lot of beer. The large bottles of locally brewed beer taste very good. 'Homemade' rice wine is available in various flavors, delicious after a long walk, the small water bottles are filled with it.

Health.body: Malaria is common in Vietnam. However, you do not need to bring a mosquito net. They are present where necessary, often tucked away in a special cupboard above the bed!

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
Vietnam has large climate differences. Three seasons can be found in central and northern Vietnam. In October and November it is mainly rainy season in central Vietnam. The temperature varies from 20 to 35/40 degrees. Winter reigns between November and April. It is cool and even cold in the mountains, in January it can snow and freeze. Temperatures are on average around 20 degrees in Hanoi, in Sapa just above 0 degrees, but in the south the temperature can rise to 30 degrees. Precipitation amounts are low during this period.

South Vietnam has two seasons: the dry season (November to April) and the rainy season (May to October). Especially at the end of the dry season (March and April) it can be very hot (35 to 40 ˚C). In March and April there is no rain in the Mekong Delta. In the mountains around Dalat there is regular rainfall in April. The best time for cycling is October - December because of the lower rainfall and the more pleasant temperatures: 20 to 30 degrees in the mountains, although it can still rise to 40 degrees in November in the delta.

The southwest monsoon prevails between May and October. The weather is hot and humid. It also cools slightly at night. Temperatures are often between 28 and 38 degrees. During this period there is a lot of precipitation almost every day. Sometimes you have a short heavy shower, sometimes a whole day of rain or drizzle, but also two to three days in a row heavy rain.

In the deltas the weather is usually stable, sunny and hot. The power of the sun is a potential problem, south Vietnam is at 10˚ north latitude, which means that part of the year the sun is directly above you, between 11:00 and 15:00 the sun is very powerful.

Spare parts
Don't count on western parts, although they are probably available in Saigon. So bring your own spare parts and, for example, a folding tire.

There are plenty of bicycle repair shops, often small workshops under a thatched roof. The bicycle mechanics are very helpful and inventive. Finding a welder is no problem at all.

People.body:
Vietnamese are extremely nice people. Everyone reacts to every cyclist. People are friendly and have an open mentality. Outside of the touristy places, a European cyclist is sometimes the first white person a child has ever seen. People are then properly stared at. The disadvantage is that you have to pay for everything, just like the Vietnamese themselves, but the tourist is asked exorbitantly high prices. So take all the time and rest to negotiate, with a positive attitude and humor you will go a long way but remember the rule that you have to pay for everything and always agree a price in advance. We do not have this experience. Tourist areas are more expensive. Outside the tourist areas only experienced a few times that the price was too high.

Most Vietnamese are eager to forget the war and everyone is focused on the future and trying to trade. With the Doi Moi, education and health facilities have also been abandoned and parents are working hard to get their children to go to school. Birth control is taken very seriously. Older people who speak English quite well have usually had a connection with the US military. They want to talk more easily about the war and especially about re-education camps, most of them work as guides.

Outside the major cities only Vietnamese is generally spoken, in the major cities often (but not always) English and sometimes French. Especially in the north, communication is hardly possible if you don't speak Vietnamese. In the south you can get by in English or French here and there.

Safety.body:
Safety is okay, although a cyclist twice reported being pelted by stones (more like a prank).

Vietnam is very female friendly. The men let the alcohol flow freely, and as a result they behave a little more boldly. A female cyclist reported that she was not harassed by men, but by the women who found it interesting that she passed.

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: Staying in people's homes seems impossible due to, among other things, lack of space. As a rule, a permit is required to accommodate tourists, which makes staying with private individuals more difficult. In the central highlands people are very hospitable, especially the minorities, but staying overnight can cause many problems for the local population with the government.
Sleeping.body_hostels:
In any place with more than 50,000 inhabitants, you can find a reasonable to fairly good accommodation. In the villages it is simple to very primitive (with well). Prices are not fixed anywhere, they can be negotiated.

Single rooms are rare so if you are cycling solo you have to haggle extra. Not every hotel is available for tourists, there is simply no permit. Hotels are within cycling distance (maximum 100 to 150 km). Only on the route Vinh - Hue it is uncertain to find anything.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: It is impossible to wild camp in Vietnam. Next to almost every road, the land on both sides is used for agriculture. Mainly for rice cultivation and therefore quite wet. In addition, you will not be able to stand out of sight, which means that you have constant calls at night.

Transport.body_bus:
On the way you can quite easily hail a bus (during lunch break there are hardly any buses). As a tourist you can't always take the 'normal' bus. You are then dependent on tourist buses. You can always take the bike with you, as long as you pay. For that money they effortlessly put some Vietnamese off the bus (without you noticing). The price is relatively expensive, especially since they want to earn as much money as possible from you. The harder the place is to get away (rain; far from civilization) the higher the price in dollars. Take the time to negotiate for a reasonable price. First make sure you have the price clear before your bike is on the roof, they are very skilled at that.

you can also just "arrange" buses at the bus station. It is time consuming. Bicycles go in large buses (for a fee) at the bottom. With small vans on the roof or in the back (instead of 4 seats). Transportation is very slow. Normal bus runs on average 40 to 50 km per hour. Distances are long. So it takes a lot of time.
Transport.body_train:
Trains run between Saigon and Ha Noi (with several intermediate stops) and between Hanoi-Lao Cai. You can bring a bicycle for a small payment of about 20,000 dong. Due to language problems, it is not always easy to get the desired ticket, taking your bike with you helps. The bicycle cannot always be taken on the same train. Book tickets in advance! If you want to spend the night in the Victoria hotel in Sapa (pricey!) you can take the Victoria Express from Hanoi to lao Cai v.v. That means a special carriage in the regular train, more expensive but in terms of comfort etc. usually the same as the regular express.

Do inform in time, because around the rainy season it can happen that no trains run for a longer period of time due to damage to the track.

Bert: "After some insistence, our bicycles were allowed to come with us in the 4-person sleeping compartment (so you pay for 4) and no hassle with sending bicycles ahead in another train!"

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Yemen.


Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
At the market you can buy your own ingredients that a local chef will prepare for you without any problems.

The food in Zambia is not particularly interesting. Often there is a vegetable porridge with flour balls (or grain that is finely mashed). Sometimes you can get greasy fries and fried chicken.

Drinkable water
You only see bottled water in the big cities. Beware of drinking the water near livestock. The droppings often contain diseases that you really don't want to contract. Marco and Lisette always filtered the water with a Katadyn Mini Filter.

Water mainly comes from wells. The quality of the water is often much better than in other parts of the world. Not terribly many people live there, so the soil is not very polluted, so that the rainwater is reasonably filtered.

Health.body:
Beware of drinking the water near livestock. The droppings often contain diseases that you really don't want to contract. Marco and Lisette always filtered the water with a Katadyn Mini Filter.

Mandatory vaccinations
  • A DTP vaccination is recommended
  • Protection against Hepatitis A is recommended.
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs all year round.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The dry season is approximately from May to October. It is warm (maximum 35 degrees) but dry (except October-November) and so the heat is well tolerated. This time is probably the best because November is when the rainy season starts and the muddy cycling in Africa, although adventurous, is particularly tough.

Spare parts
You can't get parts for your ultramodern Western bike in Zambia. So-called 28" tires are only available in the 635mm rim size, identical to the Dutch grandpa bike. A wide variety of goods are transported with this type of bicycle, not to mention small livestock. There are no tires for 622mm rims. The quality of parts sold is poor. Most commonly used tires are intended for 559 and 571 mm rims. The last size is not known in Europe. Both used to be called 26 inch. Rims are made of steel. The tires also have the ETRTO size.

In case of breakdown you can always get a lift. But beware: in some areas it can take hours before you meet someone in a car.

People.body: The response to cyclists is good. The Zambians also cycle themselves, so you soon have a common ground. The Zambians speak reasonable to good English in the cities. English is also spoken in rural areas. Old villagers speak only the local languages. In that case, sign language helps, which works surprisingly well. Zambians are friendly and open to strangers and not pushy. Zambians are people with a lot of expressive facial expressions so you quickly understand what they mean. In 2012, almost everyone has a mobile phone, at least in the cities. It is very convenient to exchange your phone number with a taxi driver. They will even pick you up at 4.30 am to take you to the bus station, for example.

Safety.body: Marco and Lisette: “Some parts seem to be dangerous, but we didn't notice anything. Always ask the local population about the current situation because it can change quickly.”

Sleeping.body_cs_ws: It is possible to stay overnight at private homes.
Sleeping.body_formal_camping: In every small place you can find something where you can spend the night. These are often small rooms that just fit one or two beds. The bicycles can usually enter the room without any problem.
Sleeping.body_wildcamping: You can camp almost anywhere. Watch out for wild animals. The locals can tell you where it is/isn't dangerous.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa for Zambia.

Source: Wikipedia.

FoodDrink.body:
Take food and drinks with you for the journey because there are often no places to eat. Fruit is widely available.

Water is for sale in the supermarkets. The water from the tap is of good quality.

Health.body:
• If you come from a yellow fever area, yellow fever vaccination is mandatory.
  • A DTP and hepatitis A vaccination is recommended
  • Sometimes a Cholera statement is needed.
  • Malaria occurs from November to July, in the Zambezi region all year round.

Other.body:
Best time to cycle
The winter months of June, July and August are the most pleasant. Very clear, dry and sunny weather. It is sometimes very cold at night. During the day lovely weather, 25 degrees C. The wind usually blows from the east.

Spare parts
There is a bike shop in Harare: Pedal Power Cycles, Parkstreet near the Jameson Hotel. A well appointed shop with knowledgeable staff.

Special sightseeing
Interesting parks are Matopos Park, Hwange National Park, Tshabalala Sanctuary Game Reserve (which you can also cycle into), and Victoria Falls. Pleasant places are Harare, Mutare and Bulawayo.

People.body: Nice population. Not pushy. You can go anywhere with English.

Safety.body: Zimbabwe is considered a safe cycling country.

Sleeping.body_formal_camping: There are several campsites, Victoria falls has a few. You can also camp at some Backpackers Lodges.
Sleeping.body_hostels: In large places there are backpackers hostels, hotels, chalets and lodges. Usually very well cared for, sometimes with a fireplace.

Visa.body:
Most nationalities need a visa to enter Zimbabwe.

Source: Wikipedia.

data.description: Cycling here in the Sahara can be dull, boring, though and mind killing, but it truly is an awesome experience to cover the largest desert on earth by bicycle. There is a road along the coast which mostly has a strong wind that goes from North to South. Along the coast you can find hundreds of soldier posts, which are great spots for camping as the soldiers like some companion and even share their delicious food.

data.description: Budapest is the Paris of the East and has plenty of interesting sights to discover. It's even a good combination to take your bicycle with you and you can go anywhere. Even though it's busy in the center, cycling is quite doable. Visit the St. Stephen Basilica, the City Park, the parliament and the Royal house. For sunset you want to go up to the citadel on top of the hill. At 9 pm every evening there is an amazing fountain show at Margaret Island.

data.description: Experience how it is to be an iron ore by hopping on one of the largest trains in the world. The train will bring you from Zouerat to Nouadhibou or otherwise. Plan wisely, because you don’t want to burned alive as the temperatures inland increase a lot.

data.description:
It takes 4 days to get your visa here. There are a few documents required:
  • Copy of passport
  • Copy of previous visas in passport
  • 2x passport photos
  • 2 filled out copies of form given at the office
  • Explanation letter about your travel in Ghana
Be patient with the unhelpful lady. If you apply for a multi month visa, you don’t always get it as soon as you pass the border. They also ask for a Ivory Coast resident card, which you probably don’t have. Instead, you have to write an explanation letter.

Instead, write an explanation letter.

data.description:
Lake Baikal:

The biggest and deepest sweetwater lake in the world, located in the heart of Siberia, not far from the city of Irkutsk.
This absolute pearl of nature is really stunning in summer as it is in winter. For cycling it could be even better in the winter as one could cycle over the icelayers of this gigantic frozen lake.
data.title: Cycling on the ice

data.description:
Camping Mussalo is a lovely place to stay while cycling around the Turku archipelago area in the period from 14.5 until 29.8. It is a well-maintained site where cyclists are welcome to pitch their tents for a very reasonable fee. Moreover, it provides the opportunity to swim in the nearby sea, Kaitaistenrauma, after a long day of riding. But most importantly, do not forget to enjoy the dazzling sunsets over rocky terrain during the summer period.

Make sure that Camping Mussalo is open during the period of your visit and check the current COVID-19 regulations.

For more information, visit the website: Camping Mussalo, FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, and Info page.
data.title: Camping Mussalo

data.description: Full Service Immigration office.  Coming from Mexico you need an exit stamp in your passport.    Currently a negative covid test also.  It used to be free.  Perhaps still is.  Guatemala instituted an entrance fee in 2020 but it could be only at the international airport.  People have passed through this border since the fee was instituted without paying.  I personally haven't checked.  I routinely cross without bothering to get a tourist visa.

data.description:
You need to apply for an EVisa. Visa on entry is no longer issued in Kenya. 
Be sure to use the government website provided to attain your visa, there are alot of fake websites out there conning people. 

East African Tourist Visa is also available, which allows you to travel to Kenya, Rwanda and Uganda with a single visa. The visa expires if you travel outside of one these countries.

data.description:
Tippsundin leirialue is located close to the sea. This camping site can be ideal for organizing camps, camp schools or training activities. This site provides cottages for rent, outdoor toilets (huts), a kitchen, and possibilities for hiking, sauna, beach and more.

Make sure that Tippsundin leirialue is open during the period of your visit and check the current COVID-19 regulations.

You can visit Tippsundin leirialue while cycling around the Turku Archipelago since Pargas (Parainen) is part of the longer route, and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8.2021. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: Tippsundin leirialue, Archipelago Trail, and Info page
data.title: Tippsundin leirialue

14d94162-1805-49e9-8ec8-f36d78ca0568.description:
Tippsundin leirialue is located close to the sea. This camping site can be ideal for organizing camps, camp schools or training activities. This site provides cottages for rent, outdoor toilets (huts), a kitchen, and possibilities for hiking, sauna, beach and more.

Make sure that Tippsundin leirialue is open during the period of your visit and check the current COVID-19 regulations.

You can visit Tippsundin leirialue while cycling around the Turku Archipelago since Pargas (Parainen) is part of the longer route, and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8.2021. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: Tippsundin leirialue, Archipelago Trail, and Info page
14d94162-1805-49e9-8ec8-f36d78ca0568.title: Tippsundin leirialue

data.description: One of the five larger islands in The NEtherlands, and definetly worth to visit when you're nearby. You can reach this place from Harlingen at the main land. From this island you can hop on another boat to Vlieland. From Vlieland you can go Texel, and then back to the main land. This saves you a difficult ride on the Aflsuitdijk (A7).

data.description: After a huge explosion, more than 1000 people died in the 18th century. The bones of the victims are now decorated on the walls of this chapel. It sounds scarier than it acctually is. Opening times vary, but I was lucky to meet the owner of the chapel who let me in while it was actually closed. There is no entrance fee, only a tip will be appreciated.

For more information, visit the websites: Kuparivuori info, Old Town, and Visit Naantali.
3e3dbcd5-1430-4508-a825-e58348ee3f24.title: Kopparberget (Kuparivuori)

data.description:
It takes 2-3 days to issue the visa. The e-visa has to be used within 90 days of sending the application. It should be possible to apply for multiple entry visa as well. Please add this visa if you have experience with it.

According to Caravanistan, the official website for applying for the e-visa is this website, however they also say it's full with bugs and payments may fail. Cycle Planet redirects to another website, which looks more stable and official, however, we haven't used this website ourselves yet. Please update this information if you have recent experience with applying for the evisa.

data.description: Having been refused to camp at the nearby Ugab Terrace Lodge (the one top of a hill), the owner of the Vingerklip lodge saved my day. Rooms at both lodges cost about 100 USD, but the owner let me camp in the poolhouse if I would order some food, which was very delicious. You can even make use of the pool, and enjoy a stunning view. It's also the perfect place to walk to the Fingerklip rock, and take the stairs to their bar at the top of the high rock next to the lodge.
data.title: Vingerklip Lodge

data.description: Crossable with no checkpoints nor controls on either side.  I was told by several locals it was not recommended because of the difficulty of the road.  Even for cyclists.  I do know that once you get to the pavement on the Guatemala side the climb toward Tacaná is very difficult.  That's not counting the gravel road just to get to the pavement.  I've taken the next one at Bocanton near Mazapa going up the switchbacks to Veracruz.

data.description: You can only reach this border crossing by foot or bicycle. You need to get the entry/exit stamp from Guinea-Bissau in the village of Candembel. Afterwards, you have to cycle through the jungle on a nice (but bumpy) gravel road. When you'll enter Guinea, you will pass two small villages, and need to cross a river by kayak. The villagers might want to trick you saying that they are the customs, but you have to get a stamp. Only after a while, you'll pass an official border post, where you see a chain hanging over the road, and wherre they will register your name in the big book. The official is very friendly and even let me camp on the football field, where I later joined a local football match.

data.description: If you want to pass the Liberian-Cote d'Ivoire border passing Gnato, there are basically 2 options when you want to connect your route with Monrovia. You can go from Monrovia-Buchanan-Nyennfueh. From Nyennfueh you can go North towards Zwedru, or South to Greenville, and then make your way to the border at Gnato. However, the road conditions to and from Greenville are incredibly bad, and will tear down your bicycle quite a lot. Come prepared! Thick layers of mud were on top of the corrugated roads. Eventually I had to lift with a 4x4 to escape this part of the jungle and was brought to Fish Town City, where new paved roads are present.
data.title: Bad road

data.description:
Corrupt border crossing, where lots of different fees are being asked. The only tax you need to pay is for your vehicle. It's not sure if cyclists need to pay this tax also. It will take some time to refuse most of the taxes, but please don't let them win, it will only make it harder for cyclists and other tourers after you.

We did not actually use this border crossing yet, so please update the description if you do so yourself.

data.description:
Eldoret is a town located 2100m above main sea level. It is home to many world renown Kenyan athletes that train at this altitude.
Just nearby there is the Kerio Valley which is part of the famous Rift Valley located in a town called Iten, there are a few high altitude training centres there are well. 
Eldoret also has huge supermarkets, restaurants and supermarkets so it is a great place to stock up on rations and unwind.
data.title: Things to Do and See

https://www.denkort-bunker-valentin.de/englisch.html

The former submarine bunker "Valentin" is the second largest above ground bunker in Europe and the most visible legacy of three major Nazi armament projects that have transformed a predominantly agricultural region since the mid-1930s.

As early as 1935, the Wirtschaftliche Forschungsgesellschaft mbH (WIFO), a research front company run by the Economics Ministry, started construction of an underground fuel depot between Farge and Neuenkirchen. In 1938 the German Navy constructed additional fuel bunkers in the immediate vicinity. Both facilities were built in preparation for war. The existing infrastructure and labor camp were utilized for the submarine bunker “Valentin" beginning in mid 1943.

Little evidence remains today of the original fuel depot projects of the 1930s, the camps or the massive construction site. All that remains is the bunker itself, an unmistakable icon of the Nazi war machinery.
data.title: The Submarine Bunker "Valentin"

data.description:
This is where the biggest dune (Big Daddy, 800 m) is located, next to Dead Vlei. This place is truly remarkable. Some dead trees stand on a dry clay surface, turned black because of their age. The earlier you come, the better the view. 

You can't camp here, as you can't even enter the road to this point by bicycle. You have to come by car. The best way is to just ask some people on the campsite you're staying at to join them. It takes about an hour to go from Sesriem to the dunes, as there is also a part that is not tarred. In total, it will take about 6 hours from departing to arriving back to Sesriem.
data.title: Sossusvlei + Dead Vlei

data.description:
IMPORTANT AWARENESS: Land border currently closed until at least 28 February 2021, probably longer. 

Land border between Spain and Morocco.
Melilla is the Spanish autonomous city on the African coast. 
Beni Ansar is the Moroccan town which is also close to Nador, which has a ferry terminal to the Spanish peninsula. 
Melilla has an airport as does Nador, just south of the city. 

At this point in time, the border is closed and should it re-open, I (kvbcycles) will update this marker with requirements to enter/exit Morocco/Spain.

data.description:
This is a village known for it's carved out building dating from the 12th and 13th century. The isolated town of Lalibela, situated high up in the Lasta Mountains, is famous throughout the world for its incredible rock-hewn churches. At 2,630 m and perched among wild mountains, the setting is fantastic.

From the 10th to the mid-13th century it was the capital of the Zagwe Dynasty that ruled the country and it was under the direction of its most famous King, Lalibela, that the churches were carved. He gathered together the greatest craftsmen possible and some estimates think as many as 40,000 people were required to create the churches.
data.title: Lalibela

data.description: The highest mountain in Africa (5,895 m / 19,341 ft) and a popular climbing destination as it is part of the legendary "7 summits". Formed by 3 volcanoes, it stumbles 5,000 m above it's surrounding, and therfore makes it a challenging mountain to climb. There are 7 routes and it takes between 5 to 9 days to climb the mountain and come back.
data.title: Mount Kilimanjaro

data.description:
Iniö municipality's got more than 1000 small islands out of which only 10 are inhabited all year round, and the main attraction is its nature. 

Visit Iniö while cycling around the Turku Archipelago, where it is part of the longer route and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, and Info page.

data.description:
If you take a trip to the Bajkal lake (Biggest fresh water body on earth) take the 2 min ferry to Olchon island where you can explore shaman rituals, see random cows in the morning, witness incredible silence and even see seals if you are lucky.
In the end of may, the lake which is frozen solid most of the year will melt and sometimes break the silence of the tundra with the sound of shattering glass

The island has had electricity since 2015
data.title: Olchon Island

data.description:
Travelling to Kylmäpihlaja island to see the lighthouse will surely do for a fine experience. Several facilities can be found on the island, such as the lighthouse hotel, a restaurant, saunas, outdoor hot tub and more.

The hotel, restaurant, and beach cafe are open from 4 - 29.8.2021 and on weekends 3 - 5.9. and 10-12.9.2021.

Make sure to check the opening tours, COVID regulations, and waterbuses to the island before travelling. 

For more information, visit the website: Kylmäpihlaja Lighthouse and Waterbuses timetables.

data.description:
Maasai Mara National Reserve (also "Masai Mara") is one of Africa's most magnificent game reserves. Bordering Tanzania, the Mara is the northern extension of the Serengeti and forms a wildlife corridor between the two countries.

The park is famous for the Great Migration, when thousands of wildebeest, zebra, and Thomson's gazelle travel to and from the Serengeti, from July through October.
data.title: Maasai Mara National Reserve

data.description:
Aurora-mökki (Aurora cottage) is a lovely destination far up north. It is located right on the Teno riverbank and literally a stone's throw away from Norway. It is also a great place for chasing northern lights. Facilities include a sauna, an outdoor jacuzzi, a fireplace and more. Additionally, you can rent bikes and other items, do some fishing or spend time in nature.

You could also try to ask if you could pitch a tent for a smaller fee somewhere around if you do not want to book the cottage.

For more information, visit the website: Aurora-mökki
data.title: Alma Arktika (Aurora-mökki)

data.description:
Själö is a tiny island known for its history (used to be a leper hospital and a mental asylum), as well as nature and church. At the moment, the island hosts the Archipelago Research Institute, which is a part of the University of Turku. 

You can visit Själö while cycling around the Turku Archipelago, where it is part of the longer route and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, Cycling around the Archipelago, Själö info, and Info page.

data.description: Fast and easy border crossing.

The Grand Canyon is actually a National Park. With it's 446 km length, maximum depth of 1,857 m and colorful landscapes this place is one of the 7 natural wonders in the world. It's the second largest canyon in the world, after the Kali Gandeki Gorge in Nepal.
data.title: Grand Canyon

With it's 446 km length, maximum depth of 1,857 m and colorful landscapes this place is one of the 7 natural wonders in the world. It's the second largest canyon in the world, after the Kali Gandeki Gorge in Nepal.
acb46a4c-5f30-4dc9-84a2-f5481248f486.title: Grand Canyon

data.description:
Kamchatka:

A land of volcanoes and bears in an extreme climate on this Russian far-east peninsula reaching out towards Japan with only the Kuril Islands in between.
It could be the most remote adventure destination for a cyclist not being scared of wild bears. Although these bears are less agressive compared to their cousin bears in Alaska as they have natural bait in abundance.
data.title: Cycling between bears and volcanoes

data.description:
The campsite is normally open from May until September. Cyclists are welcome, and camping is possible with (tent, caravan, RVs), or you can rent a cabin or a cottage and use the facilities (showers, kitchen area). Solliden Camping's got a summer cafe and a lot of activities to choose from.

Make sure that Solliden Camping is open during the period of your visit and check the current COVID-19 regulations.

You can visit Solliden Camping while cycling around the Turku Archipelago since Pargas (Parainen) is part of the longer route, and the route is open 14.5 - 29.8. For some ferries to take you from one island to another, you will need a ticket. Always check the ferries' timetable before departure.

For more information, visit the websites: Solliden Camping, FinFerries, Archipelago Trail, Cycling around the Archipelago, and Info page.
data.title: Solliden Camping

data.description: Full Service Immigration office.  Coming from Guatemala you need an exit stamp in your passport.  And also recently a slip of paper from the Mexico SAT office on the border showing you crossed there.  This latter is by policy and not always true.  I personally haven't encountered it but that's because I'm a Mexican citizen.  But border officials have told me it is now required.  Currently a negative covid test also.  Fee for a 180 tourist visa last I checked is about 25 dollars US.

data.description: Even though you can not cycle this, doing the Tongariro crossing might be one the reasons why you've come to New Zealand. This 19,4 km hike crosses the famous Mount Ngauruhoe, better known as Mount Doom from Lord of the Rings, and gives away some stunning views. In good conditions it is possible to climb the volcano, but you can also walk passed it. In wintertime you need to prepare a little better with crampons and maybe even an icehax. The hike takes about 8 hours and you can't buy anyhting on the road, so prepare well.
data.title: Tongariro crossing

data.description: Getting the e-visa is by far the easiest option, however, you might need to fake some documents. If they approve your application, they email the document in less than 24 hours. On the website they ask for a few documents to upload. One of the documents is a return ticket, but as a cycler you might not be able to provide it. You can create a fake ticket on http://returnflights.net/, and for me (Bas Idsinga) this worked. Also, you need a letter of invitation, but you might not have it either. People in the West African WhatsApp group can help you with this. You pay the visa at the border, bring 120 USD in cash. Extensions can be obtained in Luanda, Benguela and Lubango. 1 month extension costs around 12.000 Kwanza (20 USD).

If they approve your application, they email the document in less than 24 hours. On the website they ask for a few documents to upload. One of the documents is a return ticket, but as a cycler you might not be able to provide it. You can create a fake ticket on http://returnflights.net/, and for me (Bas Idsinga) this worked. Also, you need a letter of invitation, but you might not have it either. People in the West African WhatsApp group can help you with this. You pay the visa at the border, bring 120 USD in cash. Extensions can be obtained in Luanda, Benguela and Lubango. 1 month extension costs around 12.000 Kwanza (20 USD).

data.description: Allright campsite to stay for 2 night while visiting Sossusvlei. You can leave your tent unguarded here. The swimming pool in the middle is rather cold. We asked our Australian neighbours who had a car, if we could come with them to Sossuvlei, as you can't cycle on the tarred road. We only had to pay our own entrance fee, and so we had everything settled. The road to and from Sesriem is incredibly difficult, be prepared!

data.description:
It is necessary to have a travel visa for Kazakhstan unless you are from a country which is visa-exempt.

Citizens from a number of countries can enter Kazakhstan visa-free for up to 30 days including the US, Canada, all EU countries, Brazil, and Argentina. People from eight neighboring countries (Russia, Ukraine, Georgia, Armenia, Belarus, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, and Mongolia) can enter for up to 90 days without a visa.

data.description: After entering Portugal it was getting late and the hills made it difficult to find a good spot. data.description: Busy border. Crossed here to Angola with my evisa for Angola, paid 120 USD at the border, was all fine. I had to make many copies of several documents including the passport visa by myself, so went to the small village after the border in Angola and came back. A guy sticked with me the whole process, who wanted to change money for bad rate (10.000 cfa for 7.4000 kwanza). Instead I changed money at the sim card shop (10.000 cfa for 9.000 kwanza, higer than rate shown on Google!), which is located on in the busy street on Angola side, one of the last shops on the left side with a sign of Unitel.

f43f5c19-fca4-4811-a967-2881bddb9aa9.description: Busy border. Crossed here to Angola with my evisa for Angola, paid 120 USD at the border, was all fine.
